webTitle: Charity commission plans expansion

fields.headline: Inspector calls
fields.standfirst: Charity commission plans expansion
fields.trailText: Charity commission plans expansion
fields.body:
The inspector is calling with ever greater frequency in the public services, and the voluntary sector will soon be no exception. Fuelled by the prospect of a substantial but long overdue funding boost - worth 40% over two years - the charity commission is planning to double its programme of visits and increase the number of its inquiries by up to a quarter.

The commission, often the butt of criticism that its procedures are antiquated and ponderous, also intends a "serious upgrade" of its computer systems and will set up a unit to produce analyses of cross-cutting themes and issues within the sector.

"It's good news for the organisation," says John Stoker, chief charity commissioner for the past 16 months. "When you have got the opportunity to do more, you step into a different kind of mode."

Expansion of the commission's work has been made possible by a successful bid for increased resources under the government's comprehensive spending review. The extra funding will start to kick in from April 2002, by which time the commission's £21.3m annual budget will have been held broadly level in cash terms for six years. The budget will rise £4.2m in 2002-03 and a further £4.9m the year after.

At present, the commission carries out some 300 visits a year, mainly to larger charities. The plan is to increase this to 600, overhauling the approach so that they are more structured, more demanding and more useful as early warning of developing trends and issues. In Stoker's words, the aim is to "increase significantly their impact as a regulatory tool".

With 185,000 registered charities in England and Wales, 600 visits may still seem small beer. But as more than 90% of all charity assets are held by the bigger 3,000 charities, the crude mathematics might come down to one visit every five years.

The number of regulatory inquiries, meanwhile, is scheduled to grow by 50 from its current level of 200-250 a year. Stoker acknowledges "a demand out there for visible presence of the commission as regulator", and says that "a sharp edge" must be a good thing.

But does this expansion of inquiries not imply that some charities are currently escaping investigation? "We are looking at maybe between 1,500 and 1,800 cases a year, evaluating them," says Stoker. "I suppose it might mean there would be one or two marginal decisions in there that we might take the other way."

The underlying idea of the changes is to develop further the commission's knowledge of the charity scene, enabling it to initiate more inquiries from its own monitoring. At present, only about 30% arise in this way. Another aim is to provide the material for thematic reviews, very much along the lines taken by the audit commission.

Stoker expects these reviews to deal with issues such as charities' experiences, good and bad, of having commercial subsidiaries, or governance issues such as assessment of trustees and even (within commission rules) of their payment. "We could get into some really quite lively areas," he says, "but probably we would want to pilot the arrangement on things that are not going to bring the pillars of the temple crashing down to start with."

By late 2002, the commission expects to have expanded its current staff of 550 by up to 20%. Expertise will be brought in where necessary, not least to help establish the reviews unit. Recruitment is likely to start next year.

For Stoker, the developments represent a vote of confidence by the government in the commission's dual role of regulator and adviser. "The government sees the voluntary sector as a partner," he says. "There is a lot of interest in public confidence in the sector and in building up professional capabilities and in ensuring value for money."

webTitle: Quick-fire Palermo is fatal for Real

fields.headline: Quick-fire Palermo is fatal for Real
fields.standfirst: Palermo 3, 6 | Roberto Carlos 12
fields.trailText: Boca Juniors became the first South American club to win the Intercontinental Cup for six years when they defeated European Champions Real Madrid 2-1 yesterday.
fields.body:
Boca Juniors became the first South American club to win the Intercontinental Cup for six years when they beat the European champions 2-1 at Tokyo's National stadium yesterday.

Argentina's Boca raced into a 2-0 lead after only six minutes with striker Martin Palermo scoring both goals.

Roberto Carlos scored after 12 minutes to put Real Madrid back in contention and set up a fiercely competitive game played on a freezing, windswept night in front of more than 50,000 fans. Nearly 3,000 had made the trip from South America.

Real had the ball in the net twice in the second half, but saw both efforts disallowed for offside as Boca withstood a series of attacks to win the Europe-South America challenge for the first time since 1977.

Palermo said he was as surprised as anyone at scoring twice in the first six minutes. "To be honest, no one prepares for that, it was a complete surprise, especially against a team like Real Madrid," he said.

"You cannot start a football match like that against a team as good as Boca and realistically expect to win it," Real's coach Vicente Del Bosque said. "For us the tragedy of the first few minutes proved to be fatal.

"This victory is not only for Boca but for the people of Argentina," said Boca's coach Carlos Bianchi who also led Velez Sarsfield to South America's last win in the tournament in 1994. "We were able to prove tonight that Argentine football is the best in the world." South America has now won the cup 21 times to Europe's 18. Thousands celebrated in central Buenos Aires after a game which started at 7am Argentine time.

Boca Juniors : Cordoba, Bermudez, Traverso, Ibarra, Matellan, Basualdo, Serna, Riquelme, Battaglia (Burdisso, 90min), Delgado (Barros Schelotto, 88), Palermo.

Real Madrid : Casillas, Hierro, Roberto Carlos, Karanka, McManaman (Savio, 67), Figo, Makelele (Morientes, 77), Helguera, Guti, Geremi, Raul.

Referee : OJ Ruiz Acosta (Colombia).

webTitle: Taylor is back in the England hot seat

fields.headline: Taylor is back in the England hot seat
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor has been reappointed England caretaker coach for the friendly against Spain in February after receiving assurances that he will have the final say on team selection and tactics.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor has been reappointed England caretaker coach for the friendly against Spain in February. Taylor, who will again be assisted by Manchester United's Steve McClaren, has been assured he will have the final say on team selection and tactics.

He will, however, consult Sven-Goran Eriksson, having already flown out to Italy for talks yesterday with the England coach-elect.

Taylor welcomed the news that he would take charge for the Villa Park meeting on February 28. The Football Association confirmed that he would "once again be given full control of team selection" for the match following the 1-0 defeat by Italy in Turin two weeks ago.

"I'm delighted to continue in the role of caretaker manager for the Spain game," said Taylor. "To manage your country is such an honour and Turin was a great experience.

"Having met Sven, there is no doubt in my mind that we can look forward to enjoying a good working rapport. Sven and I will be speaking again in the new year about the Spain game."

Taylor needs to give Eriksson some input as the FA is still attempting to secure the Swede's part-time release for World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March.

The Leicester City manager added: "It was very pleasing to meet Sven in Rome. It was the first opportunity that I have had to talk with him and I'm happy to say that we enjoyed very good, positive discussions in which we shared a lot of ideas.

"Obviously with our club commitments, we have had limited opportunities to get together but it was ideal to meet early this week as Leicester are not playing until the weekend."

webTitle: England women beat Ukraine

fields.headline: Yankey helps England's cause
fields.standfirst: S Smith 63, Yankey 79
fields.trailText: The England women's team last night qualified for the European Championship finals for the first time since 1995 with an emphatic and polished performance.
fields.body:
The England women's team last night qualified for the European Championship finals for the first time since 1995 with an emphatic and polished performance, which was not accurately reflected by the scoreline. Just as in the first leg it took two second-half strikes for Hope Powell's side to underline their superiority.

Tranmere's Sue Smith and second-half substitute Rachel Yankey, who profited from Kelly Smith's scintillating wing play, finally cut an out-classed Ukraine side adrift in front of a 7,102 crowd - a record for a women's international in this country.

England initially set about their task with a briskness that suggested the voluble crowd would be richly rewarded for their attendance. An immediate free kick that curled just wide set the tone for an opening period, which was spent increasingly in Ukraine territory - only the expertise of Veronika Shulga standing between England and a handsome advantage at the interval.

Once Pauline Cope had dealt with a rare Ukrainian threat by touching over Galyina Ivanova's far post header England took total command, their patient, composed football pulling the opposition out of position and creating space for both the wide players and midfield runners.

Shulga did well again in keeping out three attempts from Marieanne Spacey in addition to getting a glove to a well-struck Kelly Smith attempt. The same player also fired just wide, while Sue Smith faced with a gaping net shot over.

Clearly England will have to work on their finishing skills before next summer's European Championship in Germany. Shulga was offered respite at the start of the second half as shooting opportunities were frittered away.

It was with some irony that England celebrated their breakthrough because it came from an intended cross by Sue Smith that Shulga completely misjudged and allowed to cross over the line. The emergence of the highly-rated Rachel Yankey shortly after brought more confusion to the visitors' defence. Her pace combined with Kelly Smith's intelligent play subsequently brought England the second goal they had always threatened and certainly deserved.

England (4-4-2): Cope (Charlton); Murphy (University of Florida), Marley (Everton), Chapman (Fulham), Unitt (Everton); K Smith (Seton Hall University, USA), Easton (Doncaster), Proctor (Charlton), S Smith (Tranmere); Spacey, Banks (Arsenal).

Ukraine (1-4-3-2): Shulga; Mazurenko; Anvurschenko, Myshchenko, Chorna, Karpenkova; Ivanova, Dyatel, Verez, Oubova; Frischko, Zinchenko.

Referee: S Rinaldi (Italy)

webTitle: Collymore banned for stamping

fields.headline: Collymore banned for stamping
fields.trailText: Bradford were left picking up the pieces after Stan Collymore received a three-match ban for a stamping incident committed when he was still a Leicester player.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore stole the disciplinary thunder from Arsenal yesterday when the striker now sometimes appearing for Bradford City was banned by the Football Association for three matches for stamping on Paul Gascoigne.

Collymore's indiscretion was committed while still a Leicester player but it is beleaguered Bradford and their new manager Jim Jefferies who will lose the maverick's services over the Christmas holiday.

The Premiership's basement club have seen little first-team action from Collymore after gambling on his tempestuous talents last month. Low fitness and more recently wisdom tooth problems have limited his appearances. Now they will be without the 29-year-old when his struggling colleagues meet Chelsea, Sunderland and Liverpool next month.

Collymore was charged by the FA after appearing to stamp on Gascoigne, as well as using his elbow, in their clash during Leicester's game with Everton at Filbert Street on September 24.

The incident was missed by the referee Alan Wiley but it was scrutinised by the FA's video advisory panel, which recommended disciplinary action.

Collymore, who moved to Valley Parade on a free transfer shortly after the incident, attended the personal hearing in London but left afterwards via a back door without comment.

Meanwhile Arsenal's Patrick Vieira fears further disciplinary action after the FA confirmed that its video panel will review two incidents involving the French midfielder in Sunday's turbulent televised defeat at Leeds. A decision whether to charge him will be made in the next few days or early next week.

Vieira, who was banned for five games after being shown red cards in Arsenal's first two games of the season, appeared to kick Olivier Dacourt deliberately and earlier looked to have a head-to-head confrontation with Eirik Bakke.

But neither club will face action over post-match rows in the tunnel, remonstrations by some Arsenal players with the referee Dermot Gallagher or the running feud between the home manager David O'Leary and Robert Pires.

Gallagher has not mentioned the tunnel incidents in his report and there have been no official complaints about the O'Leary-Pires row.

Terry Venables will meet Middlesbrough's chairman Steve Gibson today to deliver his answer to the Teesside club's plea to the former England coach for help.

It is believed that major problems may arise over the length of contract being offered and the exact role Venables would play.

Venables said last night: "The first people I will talk to are Middlesbrough." He would not comment about Bryan Robson's position and his reported willingness to step down as manager.

Robbie Keane has reacted to mounting speculation that he is about to make a cut-price return to England by insisting that he wants to fight for his place at Internazionale.

Reggina have offered the £13m forward a loan move when the transfer window opens in January, and Leeds have been linked with a £10m transfer.

"There is no way I want to leave Italy, especially after such a short time," said Keane. "I knew when I came here that with competition like Ronaldo and Vieri ... I would have to be patient and wait for games.'

Rigobert Song has completed his move from Liverpool to West Ham in a deal worth around £3m with the Cameroon defender being valued at £2m and the teenage Finnish striker Daniel Sjolund, who is due to move the other way, rated at £1m.

Norwich have signed Manchester United's Scotland Under-21 forward Alex Notman for £250,000.

webTitle: No native coaches then lots come along at once

fields.headline: No native coaches then lots come along at once
fields.trailText: Now that Eriksson has been appointed, the FA should back away and stop trying to appease critics by trying to involve every household name in the game.
fields.body:
There was a satirical guide written a generation ago entitled All You Need To Know About Europe, which usefully informed us that Germans wear tall spikes on top of their hats and that the French are short, blue-vested, garlic-smelling folk who carry their own onions when cycling abroad.

The typical Italian was represented as "a cowardly baritone who consumes mountains of carbohydrates every month and drives about in a car which is slightly smaller than he is, looking for a divorce. He is governed by a stable, conservative government called the Mafia."

Readers of the Sun or Daily Mail might have missed the satire. They still would. Yesterday's Mail, with reference to Sven-Goran Eriksson, talked of "the wretched situation in which a foreigner decides the national team". Alf Garnett, it seems, is alive and well.

Then, following its failed and miserable campaign to have the totally inappropriate Terry Venables resurrected in the England job, it concluded that Tel Boy might come back to haunt the Football Association by joining Middlesbrough and making a Tees for two with Bryan Robson. The FA, now knowing that Venables will never work for it again, has probably never slept more soundly.

In fact, at the risk of upsetting the xenophobes, the biggest worry about the current England set-up is that there are too many homegrown coaches getting in the way.

What will they all do, the Peter Taylors and Steve McClarens? Eriksson, meanwhile, will be bringing his own right-hand man from Lazio, Tord Grip.

Then there are the so-called elite coaches like Brian Kidd and Nigel Spackman, Nigel Pearson and Stuart Pearce and Clive Allen. Charlton's respected manager Alan Curbishley will also be having talks with the FA in the near future. There are certainly enough cooks here to spoil the broth, or the Swedish meatballs, perhaps. In fact this looks more like a smorgasbord.

Eriksson has enough to busy his mind at Lazio. But when he looks up he must be concerned about the number of appointments that are being made before he has even placed his feet under the polished desk at FA headquarters. He might also be curious to know about the qualifications of those people making the appointments.

Club management has changed enormously since the days when one man would run the entire club, taking charge of not only the playing side but the administration too. Some would even drive the team bus and clean out the toilets.

Today there are layers of management, clubs within clubs, with chief executives and paid directors, and others managing the reserves, the youth side, the A team and the academy. In many ways this mirrors the way things are done on the continent and should not be deplored.

The job of the England manager which, essentially, is to choose the side and what tactics to adopt, is the same as it ever was. But while he may not be personally involved in the coaching of, say, the Under-21s, he should have a say in who is and how the job should be done.

Having taken, with some courage, the decision to appoint a foreign coach, the FA should resist the temptation to appease those who condemn it by trying to involve almost every household name in the game.

There is simply not room for them all. It is a bit like that Monty Python sketch in which "there are simply too many Alan Whickers".

Management is not done by committee, not in international football anyway. For better or worse Eriksson is the man and the FA should back away quietly, as one might from a lighted firework, and watch what happens. It might end in tears; it should not end in tiers.

Meanwhile, if Eriksson is unaware of the hostile reception his appointment provoked in some quarters, he is in for a terrible shock when he finally arrives at Lancaster Gate. His experience in Italy will not have been wasted.

Xenophobia, like senile dementia, does not improve over the years. Eriksson can win popularity only by lifting a major trophy, something only one England manager has managed.

If it all does go wrong, Eriksson will not be short of shoulders to cry on - too many by the look of it.

What will they all do, the Peter Taylors and Steve McClarens? Eriksson, meanwhile, will be bringing his own right-hand man from Lazio, Tord Grip. Then there are the so-called elite coaches like Brian Kidd and Nigel Spackman, Nigel Pearson and Stuart Pearce and Clive Allen. Charlton's respected manager Alan Curbishley will also be having talks with the FA in the near future. There are certainly enough cooks here to spoil the broth, or the Swedish meatballs, perhaps. In fact this looks more like a smorgasbord. Eriksson has enough to busy his mind at Lazio. But when he looks up he must be concerned about the number of appointments that are being made before he has even placed his feet under the polished desk at FA headquarters. He might also be curious to know about the qualifications of those people making the appointments. Club management has changed enormously since the days when one man would run the entire club, taking charge of not only the playing side but the administration too. Some would even drive the team bus and clean out the toilets. Today there are layers of management, clubs within clubs, with chief executives and paid directors, and others managing the reserves, the youth side, the A team and the academy. In many ways this mirrors the way things are done on the continent and should not be deplored. The job of the England manager which, essentially, is to choose the side and what tactics to adopt, is the same as it ever was. But while he may not be personally involved in the coaching of, say, the Under-21s, he should have a say in who is and how the job should be done. Having taken, with some courage, the decision to appoint a foreign coach, the FA should resist the temptation to appease those who condemn it by trying to involve almost every household name in the game. There is simply not room for them all. It is a bit like that Monty Python sketch in which "there are simply too many Alan Whickers". Management is not done by committee, not in international football anyway. For better or worse Eriksson is the man and the FA should back away quietly, as one might from a lighted firework, and watch what happens. It might end in tears; it should not end in tiers. Meanwhile, if Eriksson is unaware of the hostile reception his appointment provoked in some quarters, he is in for a terrible shock when he finally arrives at Lancaster Gate. His experience in Italy will not have been wasted. Xenophobia, like senile dementia, does not improve over the years. Eriksson can win popularity only by lifting a major trophy, something only one England manager has managed. If it all does go wrong, Eriksson will not be short of shoulders to cry on - too many by the look of it.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Tories retreat on asylum detentions

fields.headline: Tories retreat on asylum detentions
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is revising its hard line policy of locking up all asylum applicants in special detention centres after Home Office officials costed the programme at over £2bn in capital costs and £1bn in annual running costs.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is revising its hard line policy of locking up all asylum applicants in special detention centres after Home Office officials costed the programme at over £2bn in capital costs and £1bn in annual running costs.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday strongly disputed the costings, but said: "Nobody in their sane mind would think that if you elect a Conservative government on May 3, we will lock up 30,000 asylum seekers on May 4. It will take time, possibly the whole parliament."

She said a Conservative government would detain in the first instance only asylum seekers from approved "safe' countries. On the basis of the October asylum figures this means she would be trying to lock up in the first instance less than a third of Britain's applicants for asylum.

In April, at the height of the political furore over asylum policy, the Conservative leader William Hague promised: "The Conservative government will detain all new applicants for asylum, whether port applicants or in-country applicants, in reception centres until their cases have been determined." He conceded there "will be a cost in providing the centres", but claimed there would be an overall cut in the then estimated £600m cost of the asylum system. Miss Widdecombe said she had told the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, that her policy wouldroduce savings over a four- year parliament.

Home Office officials, however, have told the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, that the capital costs of a single detention centre with 500 places is £40m. To house 25,000 asylum seekers for six months would require 50 detention centres at a total capital cost of £2bn.

The Home Office have estimated that the running costs of such establishments would be £15m per centre, amounting to £750m in extra revenue costs. There would additional administrative and escort costs taking the total figure to £1bn. These estimates are based on the cost of the government's own Oakington detention centre. The government currently has 900 places in detention centres and wants to increase this to 2,500 places.

Mr Straw yesterday described the Conservative policy reiterated by Miss Widdecombe at the time of her ill fated conference policy speech as "simply inoperable". In her party conference speech, Miss Widdecombe, who also called for zero tolerance on drugs, said: "Our asylum system will be completely overhauled and we will automatically house all new applicants in secure reception centres... If the message goes out to those who simply seek to play our system that in future they will be detained, dealt with speedily and removed, they will cease to come and we will be able to process the genuine applicant more quickly."

Miss Widdecombe rejected figures prepared by the Commons library that the capital costs for just 8,000 asylum seekers might be as high as £1.8bn. She said yesterday such figures wrongly assumed all the detention centres would be newly built, rather than converted existing buildings. Ministers claim suitable buildings are simply not available, but she said her experience as prisons ministers proved to her that sites could be found..

She added the costings also did not take into account a far faster processing of applications. She also claimed her tough new policy would also have a swift deterrent effect. She asserted there was a 40% drop in applications after the Conservative government in 1996 hardened asylum policy by removing welfare benefit.

webTitle: From: Chris Callard (29 Nov)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Chris Callard
fields.trailText: When you get to Australia don't get one of the coach tours, instead answer one the ads for a shared lift or get together with friends and buy a car/van, you see so much more of the country.
fields.body: When you get to Australia don't get one of the coach tours, instead answer one the ads for a shared lift or get together with friends and buy a car/van, you see so much more of the country and end up with much more interesting adventures. I spent two years travelling round Asia and Australia and I think sitting in the outback at night cooking food over a fire next to our van was one of the most memorable things I've ever done, but you don't want to take much notice of me or the others who email you anyway, you'll get far better advice from all the interesting people you meet! Good luck and look forward to reading what you're up to.

webTitle: From: Rickard (29 Nov)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Rickard
fields.trailText: Sam, I saw your article and thought that bloke's me (just a tad younger and not as good lookin'!) I'm Richard and I'm preparing my own year's travel around Asia, which' ll probably last a year and a bit. Totally relate to the notion of losing your soul...
fields.body:
Sam, I saw your article and thought, that bloke's me (just a tad younger and not as good lookin'!) I'm Richard and I'm preparing my own year's travel around Asia, which' ll probably last a year and a bit. Totally relate to the notion of losing your soul... (I'm a 33-year-old journalist in London). For me, filing across Tower Bridge every morning with the rest of the flock seems completely redundant. After seven years as Mr Career, time to chuck the mobile, don the sarong and see what's happening beyond the M25! So I've resigned, sold my flat am preparing my goodbyes to friends and family and planning to arrive somewhere in India by the end of February! To be honest, the scent of liberty is driving me insane... then I saw your journey with Guardian and thought "good on yer mate!"

So in the true spirit of 30-something brotherliness, here's to your trip (and don't let the pressures of deadlines dominate your journey) ... I'll drop you a line when I arrive to see if there are any tips you can pass onto me! Good luck

webTitle: From: Rosy Elliott (29 Nov)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Rosy Elliott
fields.trailText: Uluru and Alice Springs are great places. While you are in The Alice, a really good place to visit is the Strehlow Centre, lots of interesting cultural information and art, but not widely advertised.
fields.body: Hi Milly - I feel I know you already as I work with Sue Stubbings, your fellow netjetter. We are really going to miss her over the next six months and I am so jealous of all three of you. Uluru and Alice Springs are great places. While you are in The Alice, a really good place to visit is the Strehlow Centre, lots of interesting cultural information and art but, when I was there, not widely advertised. Take some time if you can to spend a night in the outback - camping under the stars is the most fantastic experience. Cairns is a great party town with some really good markets (good place for your international wardrobe!). If you haven't tried scuba diving before, it's worth a go, but there are so many barrier reef operators - choose carefully. It can look like Dunkirk at about 5pm with all the Reef trips making their way back into port. The Daintree Rainforest is a must, I had the most wonderful day up there and wished I could have stayed for longer. The beaches in Cairns are pretty non-existent, mostly mud flats, but go just a few miles further north to places like Palm Cove and you are in a tropical paradise. Have the most fantastic time - I am sure you will.

webTitle: Regeneration policies are not working

fields.headline: Regeneration policies are not working
fields.trailText: Government regeneration policies have yet to produce any significant signs of improvement on rundown housing estates, according to a report released today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. Simon Parker
fields.body:
Government regeneration policies have yet to produce any significant signs of improvement on rundown housing estates, according to a report released today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

The report warned that, although fresh resources for improving estates are beginning to come on line, ministers face a race against time if they are to prevent already depressed communities decaying further.

If improvements in housing investment and the quality and availability of public services are not forthcoming, the report said, families could start leaving troubled estates, compounding the problems faced by those involved in regeneration efforts.

Author David Page said: "This study found that resources were not getting through to provide the scale and quality of services required to tackle social exclusion. The government's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal is a move in the right direction, but there is clearly still a long way to go."

Mr Page's report is based on the results of discussion groups with residents and frontline workers in three low-income neighbourhoods.

Estate residents were critical of the lack of engagement between communities and service providers, and said they felt decisions were imposed on them by managers with little understanding of their situation.

This, said the report, has contributed to a breakdown of trust between residents and providers which, combined with cutbacks in service funding, has created a "vicious cycle of disaffection."

It highlighted anti-social behaviour by young people, including crime, vandalism and drugs, as the single biggest issue for estate residents. The report identified an "estate culture" in which anti-social behaviour is tolerated and low personal achievement accepted as the norm.

It found a serious lack of support for vulnerable children and families, saying they face conditions under which families with better resources would find it difficult to thrive. These can include unemployment and unstable family backgrounds.

Mr Page blamed these problems on cuts imposed over the last 20 years forcing local authorities to focus their housing resources on the most vulnerable, creating estates full of socially excluded families. Twenty years ago, nine out of 10 families moving into social housing were headed by someone in full-time employment. Today, that figure is just one in four.

webTitle: Catfish and Mandala by Andrew X Pham

fields.headline: Catfish and Mandala by Andrew X Pham
fields.standfirst: Exile-Pilgrim
fields.trailText: The first thing I notice about Tyle is that he can squat on his haunches Third World-style, indefinitely. He is a giant, an anachronistic Thor in rasta drag, bare-chested, barefoot, desert-baked golden. A month of wandering the Mexican wasteland has tumbled me into his lone camp warded by cacti. Rising from the makeshift pavilion staked against the camper top of his pickup, he moves to meet me with an idle power I envy. I see the wind has carved leathery lines into his legend-hewn face of fjords and right angles.
fields.body:
The first thing I notice about Tyle is that he can squat on his haunches Third World-style, indefinitely. He is a giant, an anachronistic Thor in rasta drag, bare-chested, barefoot, desert-baked golden. A month of wandering the Mexican wasteland has tumbled me into his lone camp warded by cacti. Rising from the makeshift pavilion staked against the camper top of his pickup, he moves to meet me with an idle power I envy. I see the wind has carved leathery lines into his legend-hewn face of fjords and right angles.

In a dry, earthen voice, he asks me, "Looking for the hot spring?"

"Yeah, Agua Caliente. Am I even close?"

"Sure. This is the place. Up the way a couple hundred yards."

"Amazing! I found it!"

He smiles, suddenly very charismatic, and shakes his head of long matty blond hair. "How you got here on that bike is amazing."

I had been pedaling and pushing through the forlorn land, roaming the foreign coast on disused roads and dirt tracks. When I was hungry or thirsty, I stopped at ranches and farms and begged the owners for water from their wells and tried to buy tortillas, eggs, goat cheese, and fruit. Every place gave me nourishment; men and women plucked grapefruits and tangerines from their family gardens, bagged food from their pantries, and accepted not one peso in return. Why, I asked them. Senor, they explained in the patient tone reserved for those convalescing, you are riding a bicycle, so you are poor. You are in the desert going nowhere, so you are crazy. Taking money from a poor and crazy man brings bad luck. All the extras, they confided, were because I wasn't a gringo. A crew of Mexican ranchers said they liked me because I was a bueno hermano-good brother-a Vietnamito, and my little Vietnam had golpea big America back in '75. But I'm American, Vietnamese American, I shouted at them. They grinned - Si, si, Senor - and grilled me a slab of beef.

Tyle says, "So, where are you from?"

"Bay Area, California."

"No. Where are you from? Originally."

I have always hated this question and resent him for asking. I hide my distaste because it is un-American. Perhaps I will lie. I often do when someone corners me. Sometimes, my prepared invention slips out before I realize it: I'm Japanese-Korean-Chinese-mixed-race Asian. No, sir, can't speak any language but good old American English.

This time, I turn the question: "Where do you think?"

"Korea."

Something about him makes me dance around the truth. I chuckle, painfully aware that "I'm an American" carries little weight with him. It no doubt resonates truer in his voice.

The blond giant holds me with his green eyes, making me feel small, crooked. So I reply, "We nips all look alike."

But it isn't enough. He looks the question at me again, and, by a darkness on his face, I know I owe him.

"I'm from Vietnam."

A flinch in the corner of his eye. He grunts, a sound deep from his diaphragm. Verdict passed. He turns his back to me and heaves into the cactus forest.

I stand, a trespasser in his camp, hearing echoes-Chink, gook, Jap, Charlie, GO HOME, SLANT-EYES! - words that, I believe, must have razored my sister Chi down dark alleys, hounded her in the cold after she had fled home, a sixteen-year-old runaway, an illegal alien without her green card. What vicious clicking sounds did they make in her Vietnamese ears, wholly new to English? And, within their boundaries, which America did she find?

A man once revealed something which disturbed me too much to be discounted. He said, "Your sister died because she became too American."

Later in the night, from the thick of the brush, Tyle ghosts into the orange light of my campfire. He nods at me and folds himself cross-legged before the popping flames, uncorks a fresh tequila bottle, takes a swig, and hands it to me. We sit on the ground far apart enough that with outstretched arms we still have to lean to relay the bottle.

I grip the warm sand between my toes and loll the tart tequila on my tongue. A bottom-heavy moon teeters on the treetops. Stars balm the night. We seem content in our unspoken truce.

When the bottle is half empty, Tyle begins to talk. At first, he talks about the soothing solitude of the Mexican desert. Life is simple here, food cheap, liquor plentiful. He earns most of his money from selling his handicrafts - bracelets, woven bands, beads, leather trinkets to tourists. When times are tough, there are always a few Mexicans who will hire him for English lessons or translations. And the border isn't too far if he needs to work up a large chunk of cash. Between the mundane details, his real life comes out obliquely. Tyle has a wife and two boys. He has been away from them nine years. I am the first Vietnamese he has seen since he fled to Mexico seven years ago.

When four fingers of tequila slosh at the bottom of the bottle, he asks me, "Have you been back to Vietnam?"

"No. But someday I'll go back . . . to visit."

Many Vietnamese Americans "have been back." For some of us, by returning as tourists we prove to ourselves that we are no longer Vietnamese but Vietnamese Americans. We return, with our hearts in our throats, to taunt the Communist regime, to show through our material success that we, the once pitiful exiles, are now the victors. No longer the poverty-stricken refugees clinging to fishing boats, spilling out of cargo planes onto American soil, a mess of open-mouthed terror, wide-eyed awe, hungry and howling for salvation. Time has veiled the days when America fished us out of the ocean like drowning cockroaches and fed us and clothed us-we, the onus of their tragedy. We return and, in our personal silence, we gloat at our conquerors, who now seem like obnoxious monkeys cheating over baubles, our baggage, which mean little to us. Mostly, we return because we are lost.

Tyle says, "I was in Nam." I have guessed as much. Not knowing what to say, I nod. Vets - acquaintances and strangers - have said variations of this to me since I was a kid and didn't know what or where Nam was. The contraction was lost on a boy struggling to learn English. But the note, the way these men said it, told me it was important, someplace I ought to know. With the years, this statement took on new meanings, each flavored by the tone of the speaker. There was bitterness, and there was bewilderment. There was loss and rage and every shade of emotion in between. I heard declarations, accusations, boasts, demands, obliga-tions, challenges, and curses in the four words: I was in Nam. No matter how they said it, an ache welled up in me until an urge to make some sort of reparation slicked my palms with sweat. Some gesture of conciliation. Remorse. A word of apology.

He must have seen me wince for he says it again, more gently.

At that, I do something I've never done before. I bow to him like a respected colleague. It is a bow of acknowledgment, a bow of humility, the only way I can tell him I know of his loss, his sufferings.

Looking into the fire, he says softly, "Forgive me. Forgive me for what I have done to your people."

The night buckles around me.

"What, Tyle?"

"I'm sorry, man. I'm really sorry," he whispers.

The blond giant begins to cry, a tired, sobless weeping, tears falling away untouched. My mouth forms the words, but I cannot utter them. No. No, Tyle. How can I forgive you? What have you done to my people? But who are my people? I don't know them. Are you my people? How can you be my people? All my life, I've looked at you sideways, won-dering if you were wondering if my brothers had killed your brothers in the war that made no sense except for the one act of sowing me here - my gain - in your bed, this strange rich-poor, generous-cruel land. I move through your world, a careful visitor, respectful and mindful, hoping for but not believing in the day when I become native. I am the rootless one, yet still the beneficiary of all of your and all of their sufferings. Then why, of us two, am I the savior, and you the sinner?

"Please forgive me."

I deny him with my silence.

His Viking face mashes up, twisting like a child's just before the first bawl. It doesn't come. Instead words cascade out, disjointed sentences, sputtering incoherence that at the initial rush sound like a drunk's ravings. Nameless faces. Places. Killings. He bleeds it out, airs it into the flames, pours it on me. And all I can do is gasp Oh, God at him over and over, knowing I will carry his secrets all my days.

He asks my pardon yet again, his open hand outstretched to me. This time the quiet turns and I give him the absolution that is not mine to give. And, in my fraudulence, I know I have embarked on something greater than myself.

"When you go to Vietnam," he says, stating it as a fact, "tell them about me. Tell them about my life, the way I'm living. Tell them about the family I've lost. Tell them I'm sorry."

I give Tyle the most honored gift, the singular gift we Vietnamese give best, the gift into which one can cast all one's sorrow like trash into an abyss, only sometimes the abyss lies inside the giver. I give him silence.

I chuckle, painfully aware that "I'm an American" carries little weight with him. It no doubt resonates truer in his voice. The blond giant holds me with his green eyes, making me feel small, crooked. So I reply, "We nips all look alike." But it isn't enough. He looks the question at me again, and, by a darkness on his face, I know I owe him. "I'm from Vietnam." A flinch in the corner of his eye. He grunts, a sound deep from his diaphragm. Verdict passed. He turns his back to me and heaves into the cactus forest. I stand, a trespasser in his camp, hearing echoes-Chink, gook, Jap, Charlie, GO HOME, SLANT-EYES! - words that, I believe, must have razored my sister Chi down dark alleys, hounded her in the cold after she had fled home, a sixteen-year-old runaway, an illegal alien without her green card. What vicious clicking sounds did they make in her Vietnamese ears, wholly new to English? And, within their boundaries, which America did she find? A man once revealed something which disturbed me too much to be discounted. He said, "Your sister died because she became too American." Later in the night, from the thick of the brush, Tyle ghosts into the orange light of my campfire. He nods at me and folds himself cross-legged before the popping flames, uncorks a fresh tequila bottle, takes a swig, and hands it to me. We sit on the ground far apart enough that with outstretched arms we still have to lean to relay the bottle. I grip the warm sand between my toes and loll the tart tequila on my tongue. A bottom-heavy moon teeters on the treetops. Stars balm the night. We seem content in our unspoken truce. When the bottle is half empty, Tyle begins to talk. At first, he talks about the soothing solitude of the Mexican desert. Life is simple here, food cheap, liquor plentiful. He earns most of his money from selling his handicrafts - bracelets, woven bands, beads, leather trinkets to tourists. When times are tough, there are always a few Mexicans who will hire him for English lessons or translations. And the border isn't too far if he needs to work up a large chunk of cash. Between the mundane details, his real life comes out obliquely. Tyle has a wife and two boys. He has been away from them nine years. I am the first Vietnamese he has seen since he fled to Mexico seven years ago. When four fingers of tequila slosh at the bottom of the bottle, he asks me, "Have you been back to Vietnam?" "No. But someday I'll go back . . . to visit." Many Vietnamese Americans "have been back." For some of us, by returning as tourists we prove to ourselves that we are no longer Vietnamese but Vietnamese Americans. We return, with our hearts in our throats, to taunt the Communist regime, to show through our material success that we, the once pitiful exiles, are now the victors. No longer the poverty-stricken refugees clinging to fishing boats, spilling out of cargo planes onto American soil, a mess of open-mouthed terror, wide-eyed awe, hungry and howling for salvation. Time has veiled the days when America fished us out of the ocean like drowning cockroaches and fed us and clothed us-we, the onus of their tragedy. We return and, in our personal silence, we gloat at our conquerors, who now seem like obnoxious monkeys cheating over baubles, our baggage, which mean little to us. Mostly, we return because we are lost. Tyle says, "I was in Nam." I have guessed as much. Not knowing what to say, I nod. Vets - acquaintances and strangers - have said variations of this to me since I was a kid and didn't know what or where Nam was. The contraction was lost on a boy struggling to learn English. But the note, the way these men said it, told me it was important, someplace I ought to know. With the years, this statement took on new meanings, each flavored by the tone of the speaker. There was bitterness, and there was bewilderment. There was loss and rage and every shade of emotion in between. I heard declarations, accusations, boasts, demands, obliga-tions, challenges, and curses in the four words: I was in Nam. No matter how they said it, an ache welled up in me until an urge to make some sort of reparation slicked my palms with sweat. Some gesture of conciliation. Remorse. A word of apology. He must have seen me wince for he says it again, more gently. At that, I do something I've never done before. I bow to him like a respected colleague. It is a bow of acknowledgment, a bow of humility, the only way I can tell him I know of his loss, his sufferings. Looking into the fire, he says softly, "Forgive me. Forgive me for what I have done to your people." The night buckles around me. "What, Tyle?" "I'm sorry, man. I'm really sorry," he whispers. The blond giant begins to cry, a tired, sobless weeping, tears falling away untouched. My mouth forms the words, but I cannot utter them. No. No, Tyle. How can I forgive you? What have you done to my people? But who are my people? I don't know them. Are you my people? How can you be my people? All my life, I've looked at you sideways, won-dering if you were wondering if my brothers had killed your brothers in the war that made no sense except for the one act of sowing me here - my gain - in your bed, this strange rich-poor, generous-cruel land. I move through your world, a careful visitor, respectful and mindful, hoping for but not believing in the day when I become native. I am the rootless one, yet still the beneficiary of all of your and all of their sufferings. Then why, of us two, am I the savior, and you the sinner? "Please forgive me." I deny him with my silence. His Viking face mashes up, twisting like a child's just before the first bawl. It doesn't come. Instead words cascade out, disjointed sentences, sputtering incoherence that at the initial rush sound like a drunk's ravings. Nameless faces. Places. Killings. He bleeds it out, airs it into the flames, pours it on me. And all I can do is gasp Oh, God at him over and over, knowing I will carry his secrets all my days. He asks my pardon yet again, his open hand outstretched to me. This time the quiet turns and I give him the absolution that is not mine to give. And, in my fraudulence, I know I have embarked on something greater than myself. "When you go to Vietnam," he says, stating it as a fact, "tell them about me. Tell them about my life, the way I'm living. Tell them about the family I've lost. Tell them I'm sorry." I give Tyle the most honored gift, the singular gift we Vietnamese give best, the gift into which one can cast all one's sorrow like trash into an abyss, only sometimes the abyss lies inside the giver. I give him silence.

webTitle: Ian McEwan on Malcolm Bradbury

fields.headline: The great listener
fields.standfirst:
In 1970 the young Ian McEwan arrived in Norwich to study literature with Malcolm Bradbury. A year later he left as a writer. Here he describes how the sociable don changed his life

Obituary
Andrew Motion and Kazuo Ishiguro pay tribute
David Lodge: he was my literary twin
fields.trailText: In 1970 the young Ian McEwan arrived in Norwich to study literature with Malcolm Bradbury. A year later he left as a writer. Here he describes how the sociable don changed his life.
fields.body:
Like Howard Kirk, the academic Machiavel of The History Man, Malcolm liked a good party. Just as that novel is structured round social gatherings, so were the literary conferences over which Malcolm brilliantly presided. A Cambridge college, a German monastery set in a desert of potato fields, a disintegrating Polish palace, were some of the settings for the best intellectual revels of the 80s and 90s.

Music, dancing and sex were not conspicuous ingredients. The business was talking and drinking - complementary human pleasures in which Malcolm took serious delight. After the last conference session of the afternoon, people would begin to gather in the bar and the circles formed. Limitless wine, writers far from home with nowhere else to go, nothing else to do: a delicious freedom was in the air, and the anticipation of a long journey into the night across unknown territory.

Naturally, for such a social creature, the seminar was Malcolm's element. I remember the first I attended, in October 1970. I had arrived at the University of East Anglia to do the MA in literature. The other outsider was Jon Cook from Cambridge, who is now dean of studies at UEA. Malcolm was in his late 30s then, and with his piled-up hair, narrow knitted tie and lopsided grin there was something of the miscreant teddy boy about him. In his hesitant, lilting voice - so hard to place, that accent - he set out for us the course of study ahead - 19th-century comparative literature, the modern American novel, literary theory - and then led us into a general discussion about the novel.

It was a brilliant session. Within minutes, it seemed, he had communicated a sense of adventure - the vitality of the novel as a form, its deep seriousness, its variety, the pleasures as well as the instruction in life it conveyed, its rich past and unguessable future. The general discussion began - a more formal version of the partying years ahead of us.

Malcolm was always a good listener. He emboldened his students to feel clever. He could make the most reticent of them feel like Oscar Wilde. It was part of Malcolm's automatic generosity to laugh easily at other people's jokes. Who can forget that delighted, whinnying giggle?

I would have denied it at the time, but I was keen to impress him. I think we were all intellectual show-offs that day. I remember parading my reading of Ortega y Gasset. Jon Cook appeared to be the world expert on Hegel. How tolerant Malcolm must have been. But he knew what he was about. We came away exhilarated, and determined to start on the huge reading list he had given us.

There was no dedicated creative writing course at UEA in 1970. However, along with the academic work, one was permitted to submit fiction at the end of the year in place of a long essay. This was a startling innovation in those days. Three weeks after our first seminar, I gave Malcolm an essay on the American novelist, John Barth, and a carbon copy of my first short story, Conversation With a Cupboardman. We met in a pub to discuss the story. He was mostly interested in getting me to describe what I was trying to do. I didn't really know. The story seemed to have written itself.

"I like it," he said at last, unemphatically. "It's publishable. But let's not think about that now. What are you going to write next?"

"Another short story. It's about a boy anxious to lose his virginity who makes love to his younger sister."

"Can I have it by the end of the month?"

I handed in essays to Malcolm on Borges, Mailer, and on theories of representation, and I continued to give him stories, some of which were collected up later into my first book. It was not his style to interfere in the style, structure or content of what I did. But he knew how to motivate.

Fiction, as I was seeing it through his eyes, was the highest calling. I continued to fulfil the academic requirements, but I only cared about the stories. Malcolm was my reading public. I wrote in the certainty that I would receive a close reading - and this was an extraordinary privilege.

His reading list alone was changing my life. It was the Americans, above all, that he wanted us to read. The ambition, the social range, the expressive freedom of American writing made English fiction seem poky and grey. To find bold and violent colours became my imperative. Echoes of Roth and Burroughs crept into my stories. The struggle with influence, Malcolm told me once in the pub, is part of the pleasure of finding your own way.

In the years that followed we met from time to time in whatever monastery or palace the British Council had rented for conferences. There, Malcolm's tentative, judicious style granted a licence to younger writers. He was fair, so we could be savage in our judgments. As a critic, he lacked cruelty almost to a fault. He was an instinctive celebrator, rather than destroyer, of reputations. However late it got, Malcolm would be one of the last to get to bed. What he relished was a conversation with a direction, a beat. Gossip was fine too.

Another bottle is opened. A certain writer, someone says, no longer does interviews. Only press conferences. Publicity hunger versus reclusiveness bring us to Pynchon, until the fatwa in 1989, the world's most hunted writer. Inflated, whimsical, a world view stifled by paranoia, someone says. Malcolm hears this out, then defends; inflated, only to a certain cast of English mind - to some novelists paranoia is not a disabling mental condition, but the motor of ingenious plot making.

By way of Melville, through Kafka, we arrive at an eminent novelist. The consensus around the table is that her sentences are no good - cliche-heavy, unrhythmic, no surprises. Therefore, she is no bloody good at all. Malcolm champions her: it's true up to a point about the sentences, but there's a certain kind of writing that gives pleasure through its design, its architecture. In the geometry of these moral schemes there's a beauty that no individual sentence can yield.

Can a good novel be written badly? We've been around this a number of times before. And who are today's best sentence makers? Malcolm makes the case for Martin Amis, together with some exquisite examples he has by heart. Two weeks before, Martin has given Malcolm a finely executed pistol-whipping in the Observer for his novel, Rates of Exchange. The critic remains scrupulously detached from the workaday resentments of the novelist.

Since his death, there is one encounter with Malcolm that haunts me. In the dazed hour immediately after winning the Booker Prize in 1998, I was surrounded by excited voices, and pulled from press conference to interviews, and from crowded rooms to answer questions in television trucks and radio cars. At some point I lost the Booker publicity people, or they lost me, and I stepped through a door by mistake into an empty hall. I went through another door, and found myself in a long straight ill-lit corridor.

Coming towards me, from some distance away, were Malcolm and his wife Elizabeth. We approached each other as in dream, and I remember thinking, half seriously, that this was what it might be like to be dead. In the warmth of his embrace was concentrated all the generosity of this gifted teacher and writer. His artful reticence and his passion for literature transformed my life.

webTitle: David Lodge on Malcolm Bradbury

fields.headline: He was my literary twin
fields.standfirst:
David Lodge, Bradbury's colleague and contemporary at the University of Birmingham, mourns the loss of a prolific and versatile man of letters

Obituary
Andrew Motion and Kazuo Ishiguro pay tribute
Ian McEwan: the great listener
fields.trailText: David Lodge, Bradbury's colleague and contemporary at the University of Birmingham, mourns the loss of a prolific and versatile man of letters.
fields.body:
Malcolm Bradbury was my oldest and closest friend in the literary world. Our careers were so closely entwined, especially in the early years, that I feel as if some vital support has been cut away by his death which can never be replaced. We first met as young lecturers appointed to the English department of the University of Birmingham, I in 1960, he a year later. Bliss was it to be alive in that dawn of expansion in higher educa tion! We were both grammar-school scholarship boys from lower-middle-class backgrounds, non-Oxbridge, teaching modern English and American literature to eager students of similar social origins.

We had both published our first novels, though his (Eating People is Wrong) had caused more of a stir. He was also already well established as a humorist and literary critic. His confident professionalism and readiness to turn his hand to any literary task impressed me and inspired emulation. It was typical of his exceptional generosity of spirit that he actively encouraged me to work the vein of comedy that was his own forte, and in due course introduced me to his agent and his publisher. In 1963 he initiated a collaboration between the two of us and a gifted Birmingham under graduate, Jim Duckett (who died young) to write a Beyond the Fringe-type revue for the Birmingham Rep. I have happy memories of hilarious script-writing sessions, with Jim and me pacing up and down, while Malcolm pounded out and improved our lines on an upright typewriter. I'm not sure that writing was ever such fun again.

A single university department could hardly contain two satirical campus novelists indefinitely, and in the event it was Malcolm who moved, to the fresh fields and pastures new of the University of East Anglia, where he built a distinguished career as both professor of American studies and director of the phenomenally successful MA in creative writing. (I doubt if any such course in the world has seen a higher proportion of its graduates get their work published.)

Inevitably, we saw much less of each other, and regretted that, but it never affected the essential bond between us. We became in a way literary twins - sometimes farcically confused, always with a quick, intuitive sense of each other's thoughts and feelings.

As Bakhtin observed, all writers glance aside at their peers as they write, and it is Malcolm whom I most often evoke as imagined reader, to test the quality of the work. His masterpiece was The History Man, followed closely in my estimation by Rates of Exchange, but all his fiction will go on being read and relished for its witty and acute observation of contemporary life and thoughtful, sometimes dark insights into the plight of the liberal humanist in the modern and postmodern world.

Malcolm also produced an extraordinary range and quantity of writings in almost every other possible form; literary history and criticism, essays, parodies, travelogues, television and film scripts, stage plays, poems, anthologies and reviews. (He must have written over a thousand book reviews, and I never saw one that was malicious or destructive.)

Though he shared the high modernist belief in the importance of art and artistic experiment, he also enjoyed writing for a large popular audience on occasion, and took justifiable pride in having mastered the techniques appropriate to different media. In his last novel, To the Hermitage, he deftly spliced together a wry Shandean self-portrait with a vivid historical evocation of Diderot, whose encylopaedic intellectual energy he admired and whose disappointments stirred his sympathies. The last, elegiac section of that book is charged with deep personal feeling which now seems doubly poignant.

While producing this immense body of work Malcolm also did a great many other things in the fields of culture and education. Even after his retirement from UEA he lectured at home and abroad and attended conferences and sat on committees and awarded prizes. He found it difficult to say no to any invitation that concerned literature, or to stay away for long from the typewriter or computer keyboard. Those who loved him wished he would not tax himself so remorselessly, and wish so even more at his untimely death. But it was useless to protest. Writing was his life.

webTitle: Human Rights Act may aid charity's fight

fields.headline: Human Rights Act may aid charity's fight
fields.standfirst: Child Poverty Action Group plans to use new legislation to challenge benefit decisions
fields.trailText: Charities should see the Human Rights Act 1998 as an opportunity to improve attitudes and behaviour towards people that they help and work with, says the Charity Commission. The Child Poverty Action Group has taken this message to heart. For the charity's legal officer, Stuart Wright, the act is a chance to challenge benefit decisions.
fields.body:
Charities should see the Human Rights Act 1998 as an opportunity to improve attitudes and behaviour towards people that they help and work with, says the Charity Commission. The Child Poverty Action Group has taken this message to heart. For the charity's legal officer, Stuart Wright, the act is a chance to challenge benefit decisions.

At first glance, the act has little to do with people's entitlement to benefits. "Benefits are to do with social and economic rights, whereas the rights enshrined in the convention are civil and political rights," said Mr Wright.

Nonetheless, Mr Wright said there is scope for testing benefit rules, particularly under Article 6, the right to a fair trial, which is a measure that is likely to affect complaints hearings, tribunals and appeals on benefit decisions.

The European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg has said a fair trial is one where both parties are on a level playing field, Mr Wright explained. In the UK, legal aid is not available for every stage of benefit appeals. Instead, claimants have to rely upon the panel's expertise and the support of agencies such as the citizens' advice bureaux. Using the Human Rights Act, it could be argued that without legal aid citizens who cannot effectively represent themselves at tribunals (due to the complexity of the case or problems with literacy) aren't getting the fair hearing they're entitled to, said Mr Wright.

Before receiving some benefits, claimants are asked to undergo a medical examination. Sema, the company that provides the service, was criticised for the quality of some of the medical reports in a recent Department of Social Security select committee report.

With this in mind, Mr Wright said it could be argued that in some cases claimants are not getting a fair hearing when the medical evidence accompany their claims comes from a government service rather than an independent source.

For now, CPAG, like many organisations, is on the lookout for test cases in the hope that it can use the Human Rights Act to get a better deal for vulnerable people at the heart of its campaigns.

The UK ratified the treaty in 1951 but, unlike many other countries, has failed to incorporate it into domestic law until now. Experts say implementation in the UK will not lead to a legal meltdown in spite of scaremongering to the contrary. Countries that have incorporated the Convention have found it a help not a hindrance to good management, said John Wadham, of human rights charity Liberty.

To aid smooth implementation of the act, ministers set up the Human Rights Unit. In January last year the government also launched a taskforce of leading civil liberties campaigners to help create a culture of "rights and responsibilities".

Nonetheless, Mr Wright said there is scope for testing benefit rules, particularly under Article 6, the right to a fair trial, which is a measure that is likely to affect complaints hearings, tribunals and appeals on benefit decisions. The European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg has said a fair trial is one where both parties are on a level playing field, Mr Wright explained. In the UK, legal aid is not available for every stage of benefit appeals. Instead, claimants have to rely upon the panel's expertise and the support of agencies such as the citizens' advice bureaux. Using the Human Rights Act, it could be argued that without legal aid citizens who cannot effectively represent themselves at tribunals (due to the complexity of the case or problems with literacy) aren't getting the fair hearing they're entitled to, said Mr Wright. Before receiving some benefits, claimants are asked to undergo a medical examination. Sema, the company that provides the service, was criticised for the quality of some of the medical reports in a recent Department of Social Security select committee report. With this in mind, Mr Wright said it could be argued that in some cases claimants are not getting a fair hearing when the medical evidence accompany their claims comes from a government service rather than an independent source. For now, CPAG, like many organisations, is on the lookout for test cases in the hope that it can use the Human Rights Act to get a better deal for vulnerable people at the heart of its campaigns. The UK ratified the treaty in 1951 but, unlike many other countries, has failed to incorporate it into domestic law until now. Experts say implementation in the UK will not lead to a legal meltdown in spite of scaremongering to the contrary. Countries that have incorporated the Convention have found it a help not a hindrance to good management, said John Wadham, of human rights charity Liberty. To aid smooth implementation of the act, ministers set up the Human Rights Unit. In January last year the government also launched a taskforce of leading civil liberties campaigners to help create a culture of "rights and responsibilities".

webTitle: Blunkett to force student drop out rates down

fields.headline: Blunkett to force student drop out rates down
fields.trailText: English universities are to be forced to reduce high student drop out rates, the government has announced.
fields.body:
English universities are to be forced to reduce high student drop out rates, the government has announced.

Education secretary, David Blunkett, has instructed funding council officials to put pressure on institutions with higher than expected numbers of students bailing out of degree courses.

"Widening access to higher education must not lead to an increase in the number of people who fail to complete their courses," says Blunkett in his annual funding letter to English academic institutions. "I therefore expect to see the Council bear down on the rate of 'drop out'."

Blunkett adds: "The evidence shows there are unacceptable variations in the rate of 'drop out' which appear to be linked more to the culture and workings of the institution than to the background or nature of the students recruited.

"It is therefore time for much more substantial work to be done on identifying best practice and bringing pressure to bear on those institutions whose performance falls significantly below their benchmark."

The education secretary says that he wants the Higher Education Funding Council for England to produce a report on "a programme of work and action plan developed in conjunction with institutions within the next few months".

The letter confirms that unit funding for students will rise by 0.4% in real terms in 2001-02, and increase with inflation for the next two years. Total public funding for higher education will fall though as contributions from student fees increase.

Blunkett highlights widening participation in higher education as the main priority for universities "to help the sector work towards social inclusion both nationally and in the local community".

Total publicly planned funding for higher education in 2001-02 will be over £5.8 billion, according to the Department for Education and Employment.

As in previous years, Blunkett says that he does not expect institutions to charge additional fees above the regulated fee level ('top-up' fees).

In return for £330m over three years to improve academic salaries, Blunkett says he will be looking for evidence of improvements in human resource development and staff management in univeresities. "I am determined that equal opportunities for higher education staff must improve," says the letter. "I look forward to hearing of rapid progress towards greater equality of opportunity for all groups of staff."

Within the total of 45,000 extra student places planned for next year, there will be an extra 12,500 full-time students, of which 2,000 will be first degree, 1,500 will be post-graduate and 9,000 will be for other qualifications.

There will also be an extra 32,500 part-time places, of which 4,500 will be first degree, 4,500 will be post-graduate and 23,500 will be for other qualifications. Over the two years 2002-03 and 2003-04, planned expansion will equate to a further 28,500 full time equivalent places.

fields.body:
Places are still available for 24-hour rehearsals for the Research Assessment Exercise being held over the next two months. The RAE rehearsals are being provided by the Missendon centre, which organises seminars for senior academics.

The subjects, or units of assessment, covered are: history/history of art (7/8Dec); sociology (14/15 Dec); social policy, admin, social work (11/12 Jan); nursing/ studies allied to medicine (18/19 Jan); Earth and environmental sciences (25/26 Jan).

The rehearsals will be held at the Missenden Centre, Gt Missenden, Bucks. RAE manager, John Rogers, will be available at the final session of each to answer questions. They have been organised by the centrre's director, John Wakeford.

For more information go to www.missendencentre.co.uk

webTitle: Woodhead laments boys' writing scores

fields.headline: Woodhead laments boys' writing scores
fields.trailText: Continued weaknesses in the teaching of writing have blemished the "triumph" of the government's literacy and numeracy hours, the outgoing chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Continued weaknesses in the teaching of writing have blemished the "triumph" of the government's literacy and numeracy hours, the outgoing chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, said yesterday.

Two days before bowing out as head of Ofsted, the schools standards watchdog for England, Mr Woodhead hit an upbeat note, praising an 18% improvement in national test scores in maths and English since 1996.

"Given that this is my last press conference I'm delighted to be able to report on two initiatives that have transformed the face of English primary education," he said.

But the chief inspector said the continued underperformance in writing, particularly among boys whose test scores remain below 50% achieving the required standard - level four at key stage two - was the most worrying issue highlighted by two Ofsted reports.

Writing scores for both boys and girls aged 11 improved by just 1% on the year. Some 63% of girls and 48% of boys achieved level four, the required standard. Reading scores at the same level at 11 improved by four points to 86% among girls, and five points to 80% among boys.

"While it remains possible to say, as our report does, that over half of boys leave primary school without attaining the expected level of skills in writing, the government cannot be satisfied that the national literacy strategy has yet done its job," Mr Woodhead said.

But he said he was optimistic the methods were in place to improve writing results, and praised teachers, inspectors, and Tory and Labour ministers for introducing and then expanding the strategies, saying they were "a triumph of pragmatism over party conflict".

Just 250 schools had a planned approach to literacy in 1997, compared with 19,000 now. David Blunkett, the education secretary, announced 38 new beacon schools which will receive £35,000 a year for training in teaching writing.

Mr Woodhead said the government was within striking distance of its 2002 targets for literacy and numeracy scores for 11-year-olds. The scores in English at level four are currently five points short of the 80% target, and three points behind for maths.

But Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said that test scores were rising faster before Labour got in - and before the literacy and numeracy hours had gone nationwide. "While standards are rising, if the Conservative government had remained in power David Blunkett would have already met his targets," she said. "The only reason there are problems with writing is that the literacy hour is too prescriptive and doesn't give enough time to writing."

The teaching unions showed rare levels of agreement with Mr Woodhead. "Primary schools have moved mountains in terms of literacy and numeracy standards," said David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, who echoed Ofsted's concern about writing standards.

Keith Lloyd, head of Ofsted's primary division, said: "I think it's true to say that old habits die hard. Many primary teachers didn't have a background of teaching writing. Too often they would give children an interesting topic to write about and give them the time, but didn't do any direct teaching."

webTitle: Welsh schools may swap 'best and worst' leagues for added value lists

fields.headline: Welsh schools may swap 'best and worst' leagues for added value lists
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Welsh education minister yesterday signalled a shake-up of the secondary school league tables in Wales to provide parents with better information about the their children's achievements.
fields.body:
The Welsh education minister yesterday signalled a shake-up of the secondary school league tables in Wales to provide parents with better information about the their children's achievements.

Speaking on the eve of the publication today of the annual secondary performance tables, Jane Davidson, assembly minister for education and lifelong learning, said she would launch a consultation in the new year to establish an alternative means of assessment to the present one, which used only raw data based on exam results. She said she had an "open mind" about it, although headteachers were hoping that "value added" measures to reflect the schools' input to improving performance would be considered.

Value added measures would bring the tables into line with their English counterparts. The government wants the measures to be a feature of all league tables across all age groups, by 2004.

"It is almost 10 years since the first performance tables were published," said Ms Davidson yesterday. "We need to reflect on whether they are the most effective and distinctive means of putting this information in the public domain, not least because they measure performance in terms of external exam results, and do not recognise year-on-year improvement in schools."

Ms Davidson said she was concerned about the way the media focused only on the best and worst performing schools, and wanted parents to get more information to help with choosing schools. In Wales, the results of primary assessments and tests are listed by local education authority rather than by school, in what is recognised as a less divisive system.

The data published today shows further improvements by children in Wales, with 49% of pupils achieving the equivalent of at least five GCSEs at grades A*-C, compared with 48% last year - a figure edging towards the target of 54% by 2002. Of those entered for the equivalent of two or more A-levels, a greater proportion were achieving grades A-C and more gaining pass marks.

In Wales, the state school system is genuinely more comprehensive than in England. There are no grammar schools, and no city technology colleges or specialist schools operating partial selection.

The comprehensive school with the highest proportion of pupils getting five or more good GCSEs (86%) was Cowbridge comprehensive in the Vale of Glamorgan. Its headteacher, Joan Cowell, said: "I welcome the fact that Jane Davidson is listening to headteachers and that she's recognised the need for change. Our score of 86%, while good, actually fails to reflect the colossal improvement the school has made in value added terms."
