webTitle: How to become a chief executive in 17 simple steps

fields.headline: How to become a chief executive in 17 simple steps
fields.standfirst: Top headhunter Hamish Davidson recruited Max Caller as managing director of the London borough of Hackney and David Henshaw as chief executive of Liverpool city council. Here, he lays out his step-by-step guide to following in their footsteps
fields.trailText: Top headhunter Hamish Davidson recruited Max Caller as managing director of the London borough of Hackney and David Henshaw as chief executive of Liverpool city council. Here, he lays out his step-by-step guide to following in their footsteps
fields.body:
1. Academic qualifications help, but do not overrate them. You can buy into the British Institute of Management or the Royal Society of Arts, so making too much of these can become negative. An MBA is worth acquiring, not least because it shows that you are committed to progress and learning. Do not get hung up on not having a degree. The Improvement and Development Agency's top manager programme, and Civil Service College are even better. But sometimes, your authority won't invest in you

2. Invest in yourself. What investment is your career worth if you are ambitious? A lot, presumably. In which case, do something about it - do not wait till it is too late. But achievements matter more...

3. Accreditation helps - Chartermark, Investors In People, beacon council status, and so on. Notch them up. None of this public sector inverted snobbery here. All these awards are there to be won. But again, achievements matter more

4. Highlight your achievements rather than your job descriptions. Recognise the context and environment of your achievements - who and what has contributed to this success. Titles and responsibilities are all very well - but what did you actually do? How did your interventions make a difference, and where did you add value? The downside is that getting this right is partly about understanding the recruitment system, and people know this

5. Inspection results help - district audit management letter, best value inspections, social services inspectorate joint review, Ofsted, and so on. Get the ratings and quote them as independent evidence of your achievements. But being a chief executive is not just about running services well

6. Get some corporate stretch. Run a cross-council group, lead on an area of corporate policy, not as a departmental representative, but as a member of the corporate management team. We know in some councils, with some chief executives, that levels of insecurity and lack of imagination run so high that this is difficult. But it is so crucial that you should force your way in. Try leading an area committee, or getting involved in an area regeneration initiative. Get close to the action as a corporate, not just as a departmental player. But you can still get stuck in the closed limited box of your own authority

7. Get out and see what other people are up to in corporate leadership. Never fall for the idea that somehow your council is already at the leading edge and the reason this is not recognised is because you do not prostitute yourselves in the press and with national politicians, and that in any case you have nothing to learn from elsewhere. Rubbish. Visit your opposite numbers in as many councils as you can. Find out how they are leading and motivating. Open your mind. Remember, only the mediocre are always at their best. But you can do all this and still screw up that promotion

8. Don't be a sour-faced cynic. Too many officers in local government act like tired, cynical, sour creatures of the night. Enthusiasm, energy and a smile count for a lot

9. Find a mentor - or several - inside or outside local government. People you can trust to tell you the truth, who will listen to your woes and your deepest fears and give you honest feedback, as well as help you bounce ideas around in a risk-free environment. But you'll need more than this

10. Find a hero. Always try to work for someone, or be close to someone who truly inspires and motivates you - someone who is inspirational and who has a habit of breaking the mould. With luck, you'll pick up much of their style. But you need even more than this

11. Build a network of contacts - not just in local government but outside as well. Do favours for people, make friends, be approachable, be helpful. Visibility is critical if you are ever to be recommended for jobs by those who are asked for ideas by headhunters and others. But you don't have to wait for the headhunters to come to you

12. Get close to the headhunters and if they call you, always respond to their calls (local government officers are truly appalling about returning calls) and always try to be helpful. Many chief executive jobs, and most of the really big ones, are now advertised through search and selection firms. There are not that many key players, so ring them up, try and get close to them and ask for advice. Go see them if you can and discuss your readiness for a chief executive position. Apart from anything else you will learn and they will be flattered. If they do not impress you (which is quite possible) don't let it show - they are still gatekeepers after all. But then comes the sell

13. Be serious about that first chief executive application. If it says ring up for more information or an informal discussion, then do. But do not just ring and say: 'Can you tell me more about the job, please?' Ring and offer to tell them a bit about yourself and your background and then ask if this is the kind of thing they are looking for, and maybe they will give more context about the job. Address the job spec paragraph by paragraph in your application. Bring yourself to life so powerfully that they will have to longlist you. By the quality of your application, effectively dare them not to longlist you. Prepare and research before the first and second interview. But don't expect to succeed first time

14. Keep going. Don't let it get you down. It is quite rightly a question of you finding the right fit for the right job. Keep taking it seriously and those around you will give you support throughout the process. Things could change, of course, and you may need to re-think your strategy

15. Focus on your personal goals, but revisit those goals annually, via a career and life health check. Take time out to make sure that you are still comfortable with the track that you are on, and if you are not, then do something about it, before something is done to you. But you must keep learning

16. Always take and respond to feedback, whether from your line manager, mentor, or from selection processes you have failed. You need advice as to how others see you. But keep questioning whether a chief executive's job is the one you really want

17. Do not get driven by the process. I have seen too many good and happy directors promoted to chief executive only to encounter disaster and a parting of the ways after a few years. It is a lonely job and requires resilience and a feel for how to intervene across large and diverse organisations. Don't do it because it's there. Do it because you have proved to yourself and to others that you can

 Hamish Davidson is a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, and head of its executive search and selection practice in the UK

webTitle: 'Free market' in GPs looms

fields.headline: 'Free market' in GPs looms
fields.trailText: Exclusive: The government is in danger of creating an "open market" for GPs in which health authorities compete with each other to offer the most lucrative financial inducements to family doctors to work in their area, an NHS regulator has warned. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
The government is in danger of creating an "open market" for GPs in which health authorities compete with each other to offer the most lucrative financial inducements to family doctors to work in their area, an NHS regulator has warned.

The medical practices committee (MPC) said proposals in the NHS plan to abolish national controls on the distribution of GPs at a time when there is a shortage of medical manpower could also lead to a return to pre-NHS regional inequalities in access to family doctors.

The warning, which comes from a statutory body sponsored by the Department of Health (DoH), will embarrass ministers, who have made much of their promises to remove markets from the health service and abolish so-called "post code lottery" disparities in access to care.

The NHS plan proposes to scrap the MPC, and replace it with a financial formula which will effectively devolve to scores of individual health authorities (HAs) cash and responsibility for ensuring each part of England and Wales has sufficient GPs. But the MPC - which regulates GP distribution by preventing authorities in "over-doctored" areas such as the shire counties from hiring doctors at the expense of other parts of the NHS - said this will lead to "inter-region" battles for family doctor services.

"If decisions on the GP workforce are to be made solely according to a financial allocation formula, an open market will be created for a new short-supply commodity: GPs," says an MPC report. "While it is right and proper that HAs will wish to maximise primary care provision within their boundaries, those that are able to attract additional GPs to their under-doctored areas (perhaps with the bait of attractive financial packages) may do so to the detriment of other areas.

"Without a considerable increase in the finite number of whole time equivalent GPs available, one HA's gain has to be another's loss." It adds: "Without the continued active and effective presence of a central GP distribution management body, the considerable ground gained over the last half century could easily be rapidly lost."

Ro Day, chairman of the MPC, said ministers "had not thought through" the policy. "We are not saying that you have to retain the MPC. We are saying that the MPC has mechanisms that have ensured equity of GP distribution and reduced patient list sizes."

The British Medical Association (BMA) said it had concerns about the implications of the proposed abolition. A spokesman said: "We thought that the MPC system worked really well and we are concerned about what will replace it."

A DoH spokesman defended its plans for abolition: "The MPC has only been a partial success. We don't feel the distribution of GPs is that successful in terms of fairness."

Although the MPC has no powers to compel GPs to work in certain areas, ministers are believed to be unhappy that under the existing system deprived areas such as Sunderland, Barnsley and East London have suffered persistent shortages of family doctors. But Ms Day said the removal of central controls could see HAs in the "leafy suburbs" enticing GPs away from more deprived areas. "HAs will be able to say to GPs 'Wouldn't you rather work in, say, north Devon where you can play lots of golf and go yachting?' As a HA chair my remit is to improve care on my patch. If improving care means increasing numbers of GPs I would not give a damn about what is happening in Sunderland."

It has emerged that the MPC was not consulted on its own abolition before the publication of the NHS plan in July. "I was phoned up and told we were to be abolished a few hours before the prime minister unveiled the NHS plan in the House of Commons," said Ms Day. The MPC argues that deregulating GP distribution will exacerbate predicted family doctor workforce problems caused by the imminent retirement of a generation of Asian GPs who arrived in the UK in the 1950s and 1960s, and the increasing numbers of doctors - both male and female - who are choosing to work part-time.

It claims that HAs have neither the financial resources nor the personnel to carry out the work currently done centrally. "Uncoordinated local efforts in this area will inevitably lead to disparity between HA assessment decisions and consequent inequalities in access to primary care."

The MPC says over the past 50 years it has transformed the pattern of GP coverage in the UK. Central controls have reduced the average number of patients per family doctor from 2,500 to under 2,000, and patient list sizes have continued to fall over the last 10 years even though there has been no increase in the number of GPs.

webTitle: Government secures partial air traffic privatisation

fields.headline: Government secures partial air traffic privatisation
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government secured a victory in the Lords today for its compromise deal for the partial privatisation of the air traffic control system (Nats).
fields.body:
The government secured a victory in the Lords today for its compromise deal for the partial privatisation of the air traffic control system (Nats).

Although the government had already secured a 97-vote victory in the Commons last night, the amendment was bounced back to the Lords for the final showdown this afternoon.

The victory for the compromise deal comes after the Liberal Democrats last night joined Tory MPs in denouncing the last-minute concession to delay the Nats sale for three months as "spin and nothing more than that".

On Monday peers, backed by three Labour rebels, voted for the sell-off to be delayed until after the general election, which is widely expected to be at the start of May.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, swiftly offered a concession which would see the transport bill - with its crucial plans to revive the railways and introduce congestion charging in cities - become law by the end of this week but the Nats sale delayed for three months.

Labour's Gwyneth Dunwoody, the chairman of the Commons transport select committee, last night warned that the government was "made up of ordinary people who make mistakes and the partial privatisation of Nats is a mistake."

Sources close to the bid have revealed that one of the main bidding companies is proposing to replace 70% of the engineering staff with contract staff, it emerged today.

The facilities management and support services company, Serco, is planning to sub-contract much of its engineering maintenance work, in much the same way as Railtrack. This could affect almost 1,000 of Nats engineering staff, who are strongly opposed to the move on safety grounds, as well as because of the threat to their jobs.

Senior Nats staff have already threatened to resign if the bid goes ahead. They say that Serco is the least suited to the job, although it is known that it is one favoured by the government.

Iain Findlay, national officer of the air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said: "This would lead to a total collapse of the Nats safety system because there would be no control over the quality of work being done by sub-contractors. It would be a repetition of what has happened at Railtrack."

webTitle: Bookham leads hi-tech drop

fields.headline: Bookham leads hi-tech drop
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The meltdown in technology stocks returned yesterday led by former high-flyer Bookham Technology, which saw its share price sink back to April's flotation price. And, as with just about every other downward lurch in hi-tech prices this year, the Nasdaq composite was behind it.
fields.body:
The meltdown in technology stocks returned yesterday led by former high-flyer Bookham Technology, which saw its share price sink back to April's flotation price. And, as with just about every other downward lurch in hi-tech prices this year, the Nasdaq composite was behind it.

Not that the Nasdaq collapsed or anything like that. In fact, by the time London traders headed home the hi-tech benchmark was off just 81 points. The problem was, and indeed is, that the Nasdaq seems incapable of staging a rally. And this matters.

Put simply, Nasdaq is the driver of world stock markets and if it cannot break back above 3,000 points the odds of a cold and hard landing for the global economy will increase, fears of which increased yesterday after weak economic data from the US. This - as Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's market strategist, recently pointed out - is because the Nasdaq drives the American mood and therefore US consumer spending and IT expenditures that have been the muscle of the global economic boom.

At the moment omens for a Nasdaq recovery are not good. Hopes were raised on Monday when the market opened sharply higher on the back of a 5% gain on Friday. But by the time London traders arrived at their desk yesterday morning they were disturbed to discover that a late sell-off - fuelled by concerns that a slowdown in the US economy would bite into earnings growth - had dragged the index down. All of which sent leading shares lower from the outset and from which they never recovered.

At the close the FTSE 100 was down 124.9 points at 6,249.8 as investors decided to sell anything with a fancy market rating.

The hi-tech FTSE Techmark 100 lost 144.3 points, or 5.15%, to 2,657.68 - its lowest close of the year.

Nonetheless, dealers, by nature an optimistic bunch, took comfort from the fact that market turnover was weak, indicating that it was more of a markdown than a sell-off.

A markdown or not, Bookham Technology was the biggest blue chip faller. Its shares, fell 140p to £10 - exactly the price Goldman Sachs brought them to the market at back in April. At its peak in July the shares were changing hands at more than £54 each.

Meanwhile, internet security group Baltimore slipped 33p to 341p, unsettled by talk that Merrill Lynch, one of its two brokers, had resumed coverage in lacklustre fashion. Although rating the stock a "buy", Merrill is said to have cut its target price to 800p from £11.50, apparently to reflect weakness in comparable companies.

Computer services group Sema continued its slide, losing a further 10% of its value, or 37p to 329p, as shareholders reacted angrily to news that a director had sold stock ahead of interim results.

CMG was off 57p at 900p, and Logica, off 124p to £14.82, fared little better.

It was just as bleak in the telecoms sector. BT dipped 37.5p to 622.5p, Vodafone eased 13.5p to 242.5p and Colt Telecom fell 165p to £13.85.

The session's worst performers were healthcare group SSL International, down 334.5p to 407.5p after disappointing interim figures, and Torotrak, down 215p to 127.5p after Toyota cut its ties with the group.

On the upside, defensive issues, were in favour as investors looked for safe havens. Grocer Sainsbury moved up 15.25p to 401.5p, after Deutsche Bank advised clients to switch from Tesco, up 1p to 267p. Boots rose 17p to 631p and Dixons closed the session 6p higher at 245p.

Lower down the ladder, dealers were puzzled by events at restaurant firm Belgo. Its shares added 0.25p to 3.5p after it said it would be buying the 19.8% stake held by US group Avado Brands for £5.8m, or 2.85p a share. Belgo plans to cancel the shares which should give an artificial boost to earnings.

webTitle: Explained: who holds the reins of power in Europe?

fields.headline: Who holds the reins of power in Europe?
fields.standfirst:
The European commission proposes to tidy up its affairs by drafting a new single document incorporating the main treaties which bind together the Union. The Eurosceptics smell a constitutional rat. Derek Brown, Guardian correspondent in Brussels from 1983 to 86, explains
Special report: EU integration
fields.trailText:
The European commission proposes to tidy up its affairs by drafting a new 
single document incorporating the main treaties which bind together the 
Union. The Eurosceptics smell a constitutional rat. Derek Brown, Guardian 
correspondent in Brussels from 1983 to 86, explains
fields.body:
What does the commission want to do?
It wants to distil the complex treaties which set up the union into a single document which is understandable to EU citizens. The new text would incorporate the agreements which set up the old Common Market in the 1950s - principally the Treaty of Rome - with subsequent major advances such as the 1993 Treaty of Maastricht.

Why now?
Like so much European policy, the notion of a streamlined basic statement of aims has been around for years, only nobody noticed. The present proposal was formally tabled by commission president Romano Prodi in November 1999. Officials have been working for most of this year on whittling down 700 articles, in four separate treaties, to just 100 articles in one comprehensive and comprehensible document.

So why is it suddenly controversial?
It isn't. The national governments which wield the lion's share of power in Europe have all welcomed the commission's initiative. They know that if the first draft is unacceptable, they can veto it.

And the Eurosceptics?
They have suddenly wakened from their doze of patriotism, to discover another wicked plot by Brussels to establish a superstate. Tory Euro-MP Daniel Hannan, who is in the oxymoronic position of being a Eurosceptic MEP, says that the new document will be a constitution, "the supreme defining feature of statehood". Shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude believes that the new treaty will extend the powers of the union.

Will it?
No. It will merely restate the existing treaty arrangements, in understandable language. According to foreign office minister Keith Vaz, it will "define the limits" of Europe. European commissioner Chris Patton concedes that the new document could be called a constitutional framework, but says it will simply spell out what can be done at national level, and what can be done at EU level.

So where does power lie in Europe?
Where it always has, in the national capitals. The European commission is often portrayed, by its malign or ignorant critics, as an alternative government, intent on whittling away national sovereignty. In fact, it is empowered only to administer EU legislation, and to come up with policy initiatives. In all important respects, power rests with the Council of Ministers, which represents the governments of the 15 member states, and a much under-reported body called Coreper.

Come again?
Coreper is the French acronym for the Council of Permanent Representatives, the conclave of ambassadors and their minions which does the diplomatic spadework for ministerial meetings.

What of the European parliament?
It's an intensely agreeable forum for handsomely paid elected representatives who can posture and preen to their hearts' content, without having any real responsibility. Occasionally MEPs can get ratty, as when they dismissed the entire commission last year. But when the old commissioners duly reappointed themselves, the parliament had little option but to go back to lunch.

webTitle: Gore believes White House within his grasp

fields.headline: Gore believes White House within his grasp
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Vice-President Al Gore believes he has a 50-50 chance of taking the White House through legal action.
fields.body:
Vice-President Al Gore believes he has a 50-50 chance of taking the White House through legal action.

The Democratic candidate for the presidency says he will win Florida if a court orders the count of 10,000 disputed votes in Miami-Dade County.

In a television interview designed to boost public support for his battle, Mr Gore accused rival George W Bush, who won Florida by 537 votes, of fearing a state-wide recount.

"I don't think we're having an election about the election. I think we are having a test about our democratic principles. Will we count all the votes or not?" he said.

"I think they believe if there was a hand count of the entire state, our margin of victory would be even larger."

But some of Mr Gore's closest associates say the vice-president is worried that time will run out before his arguments are heard in court.

He says the election will be settled by mid-December. In the event that he loses in the courts, Mr Gore has vowed to rally behind Mr Bush.

"The first thing I would do is turn my attention to trying to help Governor Bush unify the country [] and make sure there was no question about the legitimacy of his win," he said.

"I don't think that is going to happen. But even in that situation the country has a great need for unity and to minimize the feeling of rancor and bitterness."

Democrat campaign chairman William Daley said Mr Gore was not lamenting the future.

"I've not heard him once, in all the conversations in the last three weeks, talk about what if this doesn't happen, or 'What do I do?' or any sort of tone of forlornness or trying to figure out what's next in life."

fields.trailText: CHELSEA: DI MALE IN PEGGIO
fields.body:
CHELSEA: DI MALE IN PEGGIO

"Can things get any worse at fashionable west London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea?" a slightly naive Fiver asked Dennis Wise last night. Alas, his blunt response told us only one thing - those Italian lessons haven't started yet. But today, inevitably, things did get worse. Much worse. Chelsea began the morning by confirming what most tabloids had already "exclusively" revealed - that Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix had been fired by Claudio Ranieri, supposedly for creating divisions in the camp and hindering team spirit. But predictably it wasn't long before Ken Bates's arch-enforcer - okay, Chelsea managing director - Colin Hutchinson popped up with an altogether rosier explanation.

"The situation is relatively simple but also sad," said a surprisingly tender Hutch, holding back a tear. "Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix left us yesterday." Then, after dabbing at his bloodshot eye with a black handkerchief, he continued: "I think it was inevitable and in fact people at the training ground have said to me in hindsight that it should have been done from day one." And that wasn't the end of The Hutch's histrionics. "Whatever some people might think, we try to be a caring club and we, as well as Claudio, wanted them to be integrated as part of the new set-up," he insisted, before the grief (or is that the guilt?) finally overcame him and he collapsed into the arms of reporters.

"I can't wait to leave Chelsea," he told calciomercato.com. "I am in a situation where I can't wait any longer to go back." Panucci then went on to deny a report in Tuttosport about him having talks with Lazio's directors. "Unfortunately, it's not true," he dolefully admitted. "I hope they come though, I want to go back to Italy." To which the Fiver says: "It's all very well you venting your spleen, Christian, but can't you see there's a queue?"

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

KARPIN ON

Tired of not having enough Romanians in your team? Wish that you could field a side entirely composed of Turks? Don't see why the Italians can breeze in and out while the Slovenes have to fill in forms in quadruplicate? Well, help is at hand, courtesy of the Spanish legal system. Only months after doing their best to give that Pinochet what for, the Spanish courts have ruled that Valeri Karpin, a Russian international who plays for Celta Vigo and has a fantastic flick haircut, is now a fully paid-up member of the EU. Which means he can play for Celta every week, and also that we could have another Bosman on our hands.

The ruling currently only affects Karpin himself, but the 30-year-old said today: "The will be good for the league but bad for Spanish players", adding, "I took this decision because it benefited me, but I never thought I'd be a pioneer."

No win, not much fee, that's our motto.

"I am in favour of a Great British football team, we might start winning some games." Home secretary Jack Straw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

The Fiver was pretty gutted when the Hoxton University of Applied Chi refused us the chance to take a BA in Beckham studies. Terry Venables is close to deciding whether to take over at Middlesbrough. "I have other contracts to sort out and I am sorting them out, and it should come to a close very quickly," he admitted today.

Galatasaray striker Mario Jardel has ruled out a move to the Premiership. "To go to England would be difficult because it could take some time for me to adapt to life in another country," he claimed. "Besides, the number of games they play in the Premiership is enormous."

Bayern Munich chief chef Alfons Schuhbeck has responded angrily to his club's ban on serving beef to players because of the BSE crisis. "Planes crash occasionally as well, but we still use them," he observed.

ITV: The David Beckham story (8pm) Each week David reads from a favourite book. This week it's the story of the three bears who get lost and stuff. It gets a bit boring at the end, but the pictures are good.

Carlton/Central/HTV Sport (11.40pm) Highly specific highlights of highly important Worthington Cup ties. In fact if two people on your road don't want to see the Birmingham game, the local broadcaster is obliged to put on a re-run of Kavanagh QC instead.

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word with Jimmy Hill (6.30pm) Could equally be just a guttural rattling in the throat.

fields.headline: Q&A guide: the medical practices committee
fields.trailText:
What is the medical practices committee (MPC)?
The MPC manages the distribution of GPs across England and Wales, attempting to ensure that family doctors are evenly and fairly spread across England and Wales. It was set up in 1946 to tackle wide variations in access to GPs, who had tended to congregate in wealthier areas (where they could earn a good living) rather than deprived areas (where health needs were arguably more acute).
fields.body:
What is the medical practices committee (MPC)?
The MPC manages the distribution of GPs across England and Wales, attempting to ensure that family doctors are evenly and fairly spread across England and Wales. It was set up in 1946 to tackle wide variations in access to GPs, who had tended to congregate in wealthier areas (where they could earn a good living) rather than deprived areas (where health needs were arguably more acute).

Has it succeeded?
On its own terms, it probably has. Using its powers to refuse applications from doctors who wish to practice in "over-doctored" areas, it has gradually widened the spread of GP coverage. By 1986 there were no longer any areas of England and Wales classified as having "insufficient doctors" or average list sizes (numbers of patients per GP) of more than 2,500. The decline in list sizes is partly due to an increase in practicing GPs; but the national average list size has continued to fall during the past 10 years, even though the number of full-time GPs has remained fairly constant.

So why do ministers want to abolish the MPC?
The government feels that the MPC has been only a "partial success". It is concerned that while national figures may look good in theory, in practice there are still areas of the country that are hopelessly "under-doctored" - mainly deprived Labour heartlands such as inner-city Sunderland, East London and former mining communities around Barnsley.

Is it fair to blame the MPC?
It is certainly a convenient scapegoat. But the MPC has never had powers to appoint GPs or force them to work in certain areas. It can determine areas where additional doctors are needed, and prevent doctors from setting up in those areas where they are not needed. It argues that it has regularly approved applications from under-doctored areas to appoint more GPs. So it can't be blamed if a health authority, at a time when GPs are scarce, fails to attract any takers for the job.

What will replace the MPC?
According to the NHS plan, the MPC will be superceded by "a single resource allocation formula covering all NHS spending including general medical services non-cash limited expenditure". This effectively means each health authority will be given responsibility for working out how many GPs it needs and where, as well as the cash to attract extra family doctors if it decides it has a shortage. This will be monitored nationally by the Medical Education Standards Board.

Will this work?
Technically, it will allow health authorities with shortages of doctors the freedom to be imaginative in the ways they attract GPs - mainly by offering them handsome financial and "'quality of life" inducements. But GPs cannot be compelled to work anywhere, and there is no guarantee that authorities in more salubrious areas - the shire counties for example - will not use their freedoms to attract the increasingly dwindling GP workforce to come and work in their area.

How does the MPC decide how many GPs an area should have?
It looks at patient list sizes, and analyzes the many factors in a given locality which influence GP workload - namely deprivation, numbers of temporary residents, numbers of elderly patients, levels of out-of-hours work and numbers of drug abusers. In this way it said it is able to assess the relative need for GPs between health authorities.

Can't health authorities do this for themselves
The MPC said authority resources are already stretched, and lack the financial resources and expertise to do proper assessments of their needs. It said this will lead to fragmentation, disparities between health authority assessments, inequalities in access to primary care, and "inter and intra-HA battles" to attract scarce GPs - an "open market" in family doctors.

Didn't Labour promise to abolish markets and competition from the health service?
Yes. It also promised to replace the chaotic free-for-all of the Tories internal NHS market with more a structured, planned approach to providing care. A "one nation" NHS in fact. "It's ironic," said MPC chairman Ro Day, "Ministers don't seem to have thought this one through."

At the end of all this will the likes of Barnsley have more GPs and smaller list sizes?
It is difficult to say. The shortage of GPs is likely to get worse before it gets better, making it a seller's market. Unless Barnsley can provide prospective GPs with the sort of wallet-bulging inducements that will persuade them to give up their ambition to work in a cosy practice next to a golf club in Surrey or a marina in Hampshire, Barnsley could be out of luck, with or without the MPC.

webTitle: Rallying round the flag

fields.headline: Rallying round the flag
fields.standfirst:
Tribute to wartime valour of black and Asian servicemen
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence yesterday highlighted the crucial role played by black and Asian military heroes fighting for British imperial and strategic interests in an exercise designed to promote greater racial equality and encourage   more young people from the ethnic minorities to join the armed forces.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence yesterday highlighted the crucial role played by black and Asian military heroes fighting for British imperial and strategic interests in an exercise designed to promote greater racial equality and encourage more young people from the ethnic minorities to join the armed forces.

A photographic exhibition, We Were There, points to nearly 1.5m Indians enlisted in the first world war fighting in Turkey, Palestine, Mesopotamia (now Iraq), Africa, and in the trenches of the western front. Twelve were awarded the Victoria Cross. An Indian fighter pilot, Indra Lal "Laddie" Roy, was posthumously awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross in 1918.

The British army also recruited 180,000 Africans, while over 15,000 men joined the British West In dies Regiment. In the second world war, Indian and African soldiers fought in the western desert and Italy. Large numbers of soldiers, sailors and airmen from the Indian sub-continent, Africa, and the south-west Pacific fought in campaigns against the Japanese.

Seventy pilots and air crew from the empire who joined the RAF were awarded medals or mentioned in despatches.

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, told MPs last month that 2.2% of the forces' intake between April and September came from ethnic minority com munities though the target is 4%. However, the last comparable figure was 1.8%.

The exhibition can be seen at the Ministry of Defence in London until tomorrow, and then tours the country, including visits to Birmingham, Manchester and Leicester.

webTitle: Anger at acquittals on death of Asian man

fields.headline: Anger at acquittals on death of Asian man
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The parents of an Asian man who died violently branded the Scottish criminal justice system "institutionally racist" yesterday after watching two men charged with their son's killing walk free from court.
fields.body:
The parents of an Asian man who died violently branded the Scottish criminal justice system "institutionally racist" yesterday after watching two men charged with their son's killing walk free from court.

Andrew Coulter and David Montgomery were acquitted at Glasgow high court of murdering Surjit Singh Chhokar in Lanarkshire in November 1998.

The case has been described as the Scottish equivalent of the Stephen Lawrence case by campaigners, who yesterday said the country's police, prosecutors and courts had failed to learn the lessons of the Macpherson report.

After the verdicts Scotland's lord advocate, Colin Boyd, announced two inquiries into the case. Mr Boyd also referred to errors in liaison with the family and said the "ethnic background of the Chhokar family contributed to that."

Last year a judge criticised the crown after another man was tried and acquitted of Mr Chhokar's murder.

Yesterday Coulter, 19, and Montgomery, 23, were cleared of stabbing Mr Chhokar, but Coulter was convicted of assaulting the victim, who worked as a waiter, with a piece of metal-lined wood.

Coulter was sentenced to 15 months for that assault and stealing from Mr Chhokar, which will be added to a five year sentence he received in January for killing another man.

The prosecution told the judge, Lord Bonomy, that Coulter instigated a break-in at Mr Chhokar's house and the theft of a £100 giro cheque. When Mr Chhokar found out, he threatened to tell the police and Coulter had gone to see him on the night of the murder.

As the verdicts were read, the victim's parents, Darsham and Gurdav, bowed their heads, with the proceedings being punctuated by cries of "shame".

Both defendants named Coulter's uncle, Ronnie Coulter, in a special defence of incrimination. Ronnie Coulter, 32, alone stood trial last year for Mr Chhokar's murder and was acquitted. The trial judge, Lord McCluskey, said it was "extraordinary" that Montgomery, from Motherwell, and Andrew Coulter, from Wishaw, were not in the dock with Ronnie Coulter.

The jury in the later trial heard that Andrew Coulter arranged to meet Mr Chhokar after stealing from his flat. Drunk, he bragged he would gouge Mr Chhokar's eyes out, knee-cap him and throw him over a bridge.

He went to the meeting with Montgomery and Ronnie Coulter and pounced on Mr Chhokar as he returned to his girlfriend's house at 11.30pm.

Liz Bryce told the court that from a window she saw her partner waving up to her. She turned to open the door for him, heard a scream, and ran back to the window where she saw the three men manhandling Mr Chhokar across the street. She ran out and saw Ronnie Coulter swinging something into Mr Chhokar. The three men ran away when she shouted.

After the verdict, Aamar Anwar, spokesman for the Chhokar family, said: "The Chhokar family don't believe they would have been treated this way if they had been white. The real verdict is one of institutional racism."

The family say that police had dismissed any racial motive for the attack within hours of the murder. Police are also alleged to have failed to provide interpreters for the family, whose first language is not English, for the first trial.

Yesterday Coulter, 19, and Montgomery, 23, were cleared of stabbing Mr Chhokar, but Coulter was convicted of assaulting the victim, who worked as a waiter, with a piece of metal-lined wood. Coulter was sentenced to 15 months for that assault and stealing from Mr Chhokar, which will be added to a five year sentence he received in January for killing another man. The prosecution told the judge, Lord Bonomy, that Coulter instigated a break-in at Mr Chhokar's house and the theft of a £100 giro cheque. When Mr Chhokar found out, he threatened to tell the police and Coulter had gone to see him on the night of the murder. As the verdicts were read, the victim's parents, Darsham and Gurdav, bowed their heads, with the proceedings being punctuated by cries of "shame". Both defendants named Coulter's uncle, Ronnie Coulter, in a special defence of incrimination. Ronnie Coulter, 32, alone stood trial last year for Mr Chhokar's murder and was acquitted. The trial judge, Lord McCluskey, said it was "extraordinary" that Montgomery, from Motherwell, and Andrew Coulter, from Wishaw, were not in the dock with Ronnie Coulter. The jury in the later trial heard that Andrew Coulter arranged to meet Mr Chhokar after stealing from his flat. Drunk, he bragged he would gouge Mr Chhokar's eyes out, knee-cap him and throw him over a bridge. He went to the meeting with Montgomery and Ronnie Coulter and pounced on Mr Chhokar as he returned to his girlfriend's house at 11.30pm. Liz Bryce told the court that from a window she saw her partner waving up to her. She turned to open the door for him, heard a scream, and ran back to the window where she saw the three men manhandling Mr Chhokar across the street. She ran out and saw Ronnie Coulter swinging something into Mr Chhokar. The three men ran away when she shouted. After the verdict, Aamar Anwar, spokesman for the Chhokar family, said: "The Chhokar family don't believe they would have been treated this way if they had been white. The real verdict is one of institutional racism." The family say that police had dismissed any racial motive for the attack within hours of the murder. Police are also alleged to have failed to provide interpreters for the family, whose first language is not English, for the first trial.

webTitle: Analysis: Election call is beleaguered Barak's last hope

fields.headline: Election call is beleaguered Barak's last hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak's decision to seek a fresh mandate in national elections is not so much a brave gamble as a last desperate throw of the dice.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak's decision to seek a fresh mandate in national elections is not so much a brave gamble as a last desperate throw of the dice.

The decision was forced on him by a truculent parliament (knesset) where the ruling centre-left coalition had lost both its majority and the confidence of the resurgent right.

The stage is now set not for one bruising contest, but two. The general election will decide the immediate fate of the battered Oslo peace process. But even before that, there will be a battle royal for the leadership of the main rightwing bloc, Likud.

The present leader is the old war hero and bete noire of the Palestinians, Ariel Sharon. It was his visit to the Islamic Haram al-Sharif site in Jerusalem which sparked the savage violence of the past two months.

Sharon has a strong sense of his own destiny to lead the nation. But so too has the man he replaced as leader, former prime minister Binyamin "Bibi" Netanyahu.

Netanyahu has made an astonishing political recovery since he was thrashed at the polls by Barak a year and a half ago and written off by most observers. He has emerged from electoral humiliation, and a corruption scandal, as the most popular leader in the land.

Opinion polls suggest that while Sharon might struggle in a contest with Barak, Netanyahu would stroll back to power.

In Israel's peculiarly convoluted election system, the prime minister is directly chosen by the voters. It is thus perfectly possible - as Barak has found to his cost - for a highly popular prime minister to find himself without a majority in the knesset.

After two months of bloodshed and mayhem, Israel is poised to lurch back to the right. Thirty Israelis have been killed - a toll far more important in that polarised land than the 250-odd Palestinian dead - and public opinion is inflamed.

Likud leaders are promising a military solution and a new tough approach to negotiations with Yasser Arafat's Palestinian national authority. Sharon has never concealed his loathing for territorial concessions, particularly in Jerusalem, and strongly supports the continuing Jewish colonisation of the occupied West Bank.

Barak, on the other hand, has gone further than any Israeli leader towards achieving a final settlement with Arafat. At Camp David this summer, the two leaders came tantalisingly close to agreement on Israel's borders with a future Palestinian state; on the right of Palestinian refugees to return; and on the issue of Jewish settlements.

But the negotiation broke down over the most emotional issue of all: Jerusalem. Barak offered a degree of shared sovereignty in the eastern half of the city, captured from Jordan in the six-day war of 1967. He even offered to cede control of the Haram al-Sharif complex, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, and the site of their most revered site, the Western or Wailing Wall.

That was not enough for Arafat, who has yearned all his life to install a Palestinian government in Jerusalem. Most Israelis believe that the recent violence is entirely down to Arafat's pique at being denied his ambition. Some commentators now think that the Palestinian leader may try again to snatch the great prize - and at the same time come to the aid of the beleaguered Barak - by negotiating a new deal on Jerusalem before the Israeli elections.

That would allow Barak to resurrect his claim to be the man who finally brought peace to the region. It would also restore Arafat's authority, which has been badly undermined by Islamists and other militants.

However, even though the Israeli system allows for four or five months to pass before the election, time is perilously short.

webTitle: Sharon offers Barak coalition talks

fields.headline: Sharon offers Barak coalition talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The hard-line Israeli opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, said today that he was still open to holding coalition talks with the prime minister, Ehud Barak, following yesterday's overwhelming parliament vote to hold elections two years ahead of schedule.
fields.body:
The hard-line Israeli opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, said today that he was still open to holding coalition talks with the prime minister, Ehud Barak, following yesterday's overwhelming parliament vote to hold elections two years ahead of schedule.

Mr Sharon said he would talk about a coalition at Mr Barak's invitation, but the prospect of this appears slight as the prime minister rejected the broad idea yesterday.

But today Mr Sharon said he would still consider joining the government if he was given veto powers over Mr Barak's peace efforts - something the prime minister has said he is unwilling to do.

Mr Barak agreed yesterday to hold an early vote in a surprise move to take the initiative from the more hawkish opposition.

However, amid the political manoeuvres, Israeli-Palestinian violence persisted. An Israeli motorist was critically wounded in a West Bank shooting ambush today. And in the Gaza Strip, Israeli soldiers fired on Palestinians trying to cut through a border fence. The army said there were fatalities, but that it did not know how many.

But Nabil Shaath, a Palestinian negotiator, said he was still hopeful a peace accord can be reached before the Israeli elections and despite two months of violence that have killed more than 280 people, most of them Palestinians.

In recent days there has been a lull in violence, attributed to the holy month of Ramadan, when Muslims fast from dawn to dusk, and to cool, rainy weather.

Representatives of Mr Barak's One Israel alignment and the opposition Likud party, which Mr Sharon leads, met briefly today to try to agree on a date for elections.

Mr Sharon said elections should be held as quickly as possible and "even before Passover," the Jewish holiday that begins April 7.

One Israel did not propose an election date, but planned to do so on Monday, according to a party spokesman, Gilad Haymann.

Reaching a peace agreement with the Palestinians in the next few months is widely seen as Mr Barak's only chance to get re-elected.

The Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, suggested that elections could serve as a referendum on a peace deal. He said: "If we reach an agreement - we are facing general elections - the people will judge it," he said on Israel army radio. "They can decide that they don't want it."

Polls have indicated that without an agreement in hand, Mr Barak would be narrowly defeated by Mr Sharon and trounced by the former prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.

Mr Netanyahu has not formally announced his political plans, though he has been increasingly active in recent weeks, giving speeches and TV interviews. Mr Sharon said he was sought to become the Likud candidate for prime minister

webTitle: Comment: Wolfgang Tillmans' win is neither particularly surprising nor controversial

fields.headline: An omnivorous eye, taking pleasure
fields.trailText: That Wolfgang Tillmans has won this year's Turner prize is neither particularly surprising nor controversial. The competition was only ever between him and Glenn Brown.
fields.body:
That Wolfgang Tillmans has won this year's Turner prize is neither particularly surprising nor controversial. The competition was only ever between him and Glenn Brown.

Whether Tomoko Takahashi, whose free-form installations can be beguiling, witty and at times overwhelming,was ready for a show like the Turner - as much a media event as it is an exhibition - is doubtful. One might ask, too, whether her agglomerations of junk and rubbish were circumscribed by the display conditions - the inevitable qualms about health and safety regulations - available at Tate Britain. But hers was a disappointing installation.

Michael Raedecker's paintings never struck me as being in the running, and it was inevitable that one would compare his subtly lit, muted canvases, with their peculiar surfaces - with wormlike excrescences of paint and mad patches of sewing - with the suave sheen and high production values of Glenn Brown's work.

The small controversy over Brown's borrowings from other artists and book illustrators was something of a spoiler - Horror! Copyist accused of copying! - and neither new in Brown's work nor a case of Brown plagiarising other people's efforts. His is an art about appropriation. It is concerned with other people's images and styles. His work is a commentary on originality. But one would never mistake a Glenn Brown Frank Auerbach, with its perfect flat surface, its trompe l'oeil effects, for a genuine Auerbach, with its lumps, revisions, toil and sweat.

The quibble is: is Wolfgang Tillmans an artist, or a photographer who has strayed from fashion into art? Phooey, and who cares, I say. Tillmans's images in the Turner prize - an arrangement of more than 60 photographs, hung as a deceptively casual arrangement of unframed images, is in my view the best exhibition he has held (and there have been some clunkers). Tillmans's Turner show comprises an almost complete lexicon of his preoccupations, from close-ups of bodies to city panoramas, from homoerotic snaps of his friends to the stuff in Tupperware in the fridge, Concorde flying, a bee, the moon. It shows him as an omnivorous eye, taking pleasure in almost everything he looks at, and eroticising everything his camera sees. His work is full of life, and works best when seen in the full.

But I will remember this Turner prize for the xenophobia that has come out of the woodwork: surely, it has been said, this prize is for British artists. All the artists here work in Britain. We don't just export the YBA generation. The cultural life of Britain is immeasurably strengthened by those from abroad who have chosen to work here. We need different voices, different attitudes, different ways of looking at the world. Who needs another not-so-young British artist to win the Turner prize? No one, least of all themselves.

webTitle: Losing its Punch?

fields.headline: Losing its Punch?
fields.trailText: 4.45pm:Punch magazine has lost almost all of its star columnists following the departure of editor James Steen, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Mohammed Al Fayed's Punch magazine has lost virtually all its star columnists.

Former City Slickers Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, George Best, Jono Coleman, gossip columnist Chris Hutchings, Debbie Barham and John McVicar have all left the magazine following the departure of editor James Steen a fortnight ago.

Many columnists are believed to have resigned in anticipation of the planned overhaul, orchestrated by former News of the World editor Phil Hall, who is advising Mr Al Fayed.

Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell, who are embroiled in a DTI investigation over the Mirror share-tipping scandal, are believed to have left believing their sacking to be imminent.

Meanwhile, former deputy editor Richard Brass has become acting editor, believed to be on a temporary basis.

Mr Hall denied reports that he was masterminding the magazine's editorial strategy.

He said: "Richard is the editor and it's up to him what he does with his staff."

Mr Hall added that Mohammed Fayed had believed drastic action was needed to stem Punch's losses.

The new regime will bring in new columnists, including political writer Ed Pearce and former Daily Mirror deputy editor Bill Hagerty.

webTitle: Court threats to planning system

fields.headline: Court threats to planning system
fields.trailText: Four test cases which go to the high court today threaten to throw Britain's planning system into disarray as an unforeseen consequence of the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
Four test cases which go to the high court today threaten to throw Britain's planning system into disarray as an unforeseen consequence of the Human Rights Act.

The cases will challenge the basis of the post-war planning structure under which decisions are ultimately taken by the environment secretary.

Lawyers are arguing that the system under which decisions are made by the executive breaches the right to a fair hearing by an independent tribunal in article 6 of the European convention on human rights. The convention was incorporated into UK law last month. The Scottish courts have already ruled that the planning system breaches the human rights convention, in a judgment last July. The convention rights have applied to the Scottish executive since 1999, under the Scotland Act.

One of the four English cases challenges the right of John Prescott, the environment secretary, to determine an appeal against a refusal of planning permission for a warehouse development at an airfield at Alconbury, Cambridgeshire, which belongs to the Ministry of Defence.

The case has been brought by the Nene Valley residents' association, which opposes the application by a company jointly owned by the British Airports Authority and a US warehousing company.

In the Scottish case, the judge, Lord McFadyen, ruled that the Scottish executive had breached the human rights convention in calling in for its own determination, at the request of Historic Scotland, a planning application by Edinburgh developers, County Properties, to demolish two listed houses in Glasgow.

The Nene Valley residents have a stronger case than County Properties, because the MoD owns the airfield and stands to gain financially from its development. "We say we can't get a fair decision because the government has a vested interest in seeing planning permission granted," said David Barney, the residents' solicitor.

The hearing, expected to last at least four days, will involve 21 barristers and could go to the House of Lords on appeal. The second case involves the compulsory purchase of land for a highway scheme and the third and fourth are cases where the environment secretary has called in planning applications for his own decision.

"If the argument succeeds, they will have to change the system," said a lawyer in one of the cases. "No longer will you have inquiries done by the secretary of state."

Mr Barney said: "The department of the environment has had two years since the passing of the Human Rights Act to look at this, take appropriate advice and do something about it. They've sat on their hands."

webTitle: Lloyds treads softly in Spain

fields.headline: Lloyds treads softly in Spain
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB's online bank evolvebank.com is to begin advertising for customers in Spain today, later than initially expected.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB's online bank evolvebank.com is to begin advertising for customers in Spain today, later than initially expected.

The bank has taken a "phased" approach to launch after witnessing the problems suffered by other internet banks. It is launching to the Spanish public after conducting a "controlled" launch with 100 people over the past two months and after discussions with regulators in Spain and the UK.

The separately branded on-line bank is to adopt a similarly "phased" introduction in the UK.

Jayne Almond, managing director of European internet banking for Lloyds TSB, said yesterday that evolvebank's ambitions to expand across Europe were being thwarted in Germany by high cash machine charges - as much as € 4, more than £2.

Evolvebank does not intend to charge customers in Spain for withdrawing cash and argued yesterday that the cost imposed in Germany made the economics of launching there very difficult.

To register for an evolvebank account customers must be resident in Spain, where the bank is offering a 5% interest rate on savings.

The bank has set up a call centre in Scotland with 25 Spanish-speaking operators to help customers.

Italy is likely to be the next market for launch after Spain and Britain.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The downfall of Ehud Barak's battered minority government comes as little surprise to Israel and its neighbours. There is inevitably much interest in what will happen in the four or five months which, in the convoluted Israeli system, will precede the next election.
fields.body:
The downfall of Ehud Barak's battered minority government comes as little surprise to Israel and its neighbours. There is inevitably much interest in what will happen in the four or five months which, in the convoluted Israeli system, will precede the next election.

The Jerusalem Post is scathing about Barak's record in office, but is in no doubt about who ultimately is to blame for the crisis: "Prime minister Ehud Barak, in his speech to the knesset plenum last night, was wrong to place the blame on the opposition for the house's decision to go to the polls under the sound of gunfire in Gilo and terrorist bombs in Hadera and the Gaza Strip.

"The person most responsible for yesterday's vote to dissolve the knesset and hold early elections was not present when the vote took place and nor is he likely to appreciate the underlying democratic principles behind it. In Yasser Arafat's Palestinian authority, the notion of the nation's leader paying the political price for a failed policy is simply unheard of. Challenges to Arafat's rule are few and far between, and his numerous internal security forces make sure that it stays that way."

In a thoughtful analysis for the the liberal daily Ha'aretz, Yoel Marcus writes that many Knesset members believe Barak is committing political suicide. But he believes that the prime minister may yet have a slender hope of retaining power - by reviving the peace process: "He's counting on having won some time. Now he'll have four or five months to reach an agreement with the PA [Palestinian authority], and his goal is to turn the early elections into a referendum on such an agreement with the Palestinians.

"The intifada convulsed Israel's public and now Barak is counting on public desire in favour of reaching an agreement. At first glance, it would appear Arafat has no interest in bringing Likud to power. But logic as seen through Jewish eyes doesn't always apply to him.

"In 1996, he toppled his partner in the quest for the brave peace, Shimon Peres. Now Arafat will have to decide whether he wants an agreement with Barak, or deal with a rightwing government in Israel."

In the United Arab Emirates, the Khaleej Times reports a rising crescendo of Islamic calls for an international force to protect the Palestinians: "Senior officials representing the world's Muslims asked the United Nations security council on Monday to send UN troops to protect Palestinian civilians from Israeli forces.

"But Israel - which can count on the United States to block any hostile proposal in the council - reiterated its opposition to any international presence in the Palestinian territories. A five-man delegation from the Organisation of the Islamic Conference conferred in private with the 15 council members for two hours on a day when the death toll in the region rose to 290."

The latest press roundup issued by the Palestinian ministry of information contains little talk of peace. In its own commentary, the ministry has some unwelcome advice for the Israeli prime minister: "If Barak does not move immediately, re-engage the Palestinian leadership, take strong and decisive decisions with regard to Jewish settlements, ending the occupation, accepting and respecting the world community views, he will not just find himself in the dustbin of history, he might be planting dangerous seeds that will grow to negatively and permanently damage Israel and the Jewish people.

"The Palestinians answered with their determination to have strategic peace with Israel based on UN internationally legitimacy resolutions. Israel is asked to reciprocate now, not tomorrow. Barak must take the brave decisions and to make history, this is his last opportunity. Grab it."

The Jordan Times welcomes the belated trilateral summit of Jordanian, Egyptian and Palestinian leaders to hammer out a common stance to present to Israel and its patron, the United States: "The intifada has now entered its third month, the amount of atrocities perpetrated by Israeli troops has reached untold heights, and bodies of Palestinian children and youths have been piling up before our eyes day after day.

"As if this was not enough, Israeli premier Ehud Barak on Tuesday said he was ready to resign, paving the way for Israel to hold early elections. This unexpected twist crushed hopes that the already agonising Oslo peace process could be somehow kept alive."

Audio report
29 November: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem (3mins 05)

webTitle: Building a library for your child

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child
fields.body:
Book of the month
The Other Side of Truth by Beverley Naidoo
(Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)
Anyone who regularly reads new children's fiction could be forgiven for thinking that nobody publishes books for the over-eights any more unless they feature wizards and magic à la Harry Potter. Do publishers doubt that children are interested in the real world? Are we creating generations who see fiction only as escapism? So it's good to see a book that deals with the here and now and an issue that has been much in the news: asylum seekers.

Naidoo's powerful, gripping novel that would be perfect for the over-10s, is set in the wake of the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa in Nigeria. Sade and Femi, the children of an outspoken Nigerian journalist, find their lives in danger after their father criticises the government. The family decides to flee Nigeria for Britain. But Britain doesn't turn out to be the safe haven that they had envisaged.

This is a tough, realistic, sharply written book that gives a window on a world that is far removed from most British children's lives. With luck, it will make them swell with indignation and a determination to fight for justice.

Ages 0-3
Who Am I? by Aurelie Lanchais and Alain Crozon
(Milet, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)
Q: "I make a milk that is milky and white and helps you sleep tight. Who am I?"
A: A cow.
Q: "My tears look sad, but my teeth are happy to be snappy. Who am I?"
A: A crocodile.

If you thought the lift-and-flap book has already done everything possible, this brilliantly original series of brightly-coloured books will change your mind. The concept is simplicity itself: a riddle-like question, a visual clue and a bright picture answer with a line of text. But the execution is totally engaging. Everything about this series is well thought-out. Check out the other three books: What Am I?; I Have Wheels, What Am I? and I Can Fly, What Am I?

Go Away, Big Green Monster by Ed Emberley
(Walker, £7.99; CultureShop price £3.99)
There is tons of giggly, gurning fun to be had with this peephole book that allows its young readers to confront their worst fears by creating a gaily-coloured monster face and then banishing it again by turning the pages so that each feature gradually disappears. It puts the child firmly in control, making fun of the monster and having the power to banish it. You can even put your fingers inside the monster's mouth and tickle its teeth.

Clean, bright graphics ensure that this ingeniously simple book is very user-friendly. It would work well in different ways for different kinds of children, but is likely to cause fits of giggles in even the most anxiety-ridden toddler.

Ages 4-7
Crispin: the Pig Who Had It All by Ted Dewan
(Doubleday, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)
Crispin is a pig who has everything money can buy. Every Christmas is a riot of hi-tech toys that end up broken by New Year's Day. Then one Christmas, Santa leaves him an enormous box with a message: "In this box, you will find the only thing you do not have. It's the very best thing in the whole wide world." The box is completely empty. Crispin is sad, but it's not long before he discovers that Santa is right.

This is a gorgeous, non-preachy morality tale for kids who have everything. Dewan's story may be obvious to adults, but it has enough twists to keep children delighted, and the illustrations are lovely too.

The Last Polar Bears by Harry Horse
(Viking, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)
A new picture book that serves as a good introduction to that singular dog Roo, who accompanies Grandfather on his mad journeys around the world. Picture books still play a bigger role than parents sometimes realise at this age, and children who enjoy the screwy humour of this will happily graduate to Horse's more text-heavy Puffin editions that follow Roo and Grandfather's exploits.

This story has Roo and Grandfather deciding that the zoo provides no life for a bear; so they set off ito the North Pole to find out how Polar bears really live. It is a mad-cap, ice cream-fuelled adventure told with a quirky, off-beat humour. It's "anything is possible" approach to life is charming, wonderfully infectious and a bit of a fillip in these conformist times.

Ages 8-11
The Rope and Other Stories by Philippa Pearce
(Puffin, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)
They don't write them like this any more. Philippa Pearce, author of Tom's Midnight Garden, confirms herself as a national treasure with this collection of stories, some new and some written more than 20 years ago. Some are slightly old-fashioned, but the writing is always understated yet exquisite, and no writer captures the dreamy intensity of childhood better.

Even the most streetwise, hi-tech youngster will fall for the quiet charm of these tales, recognising themselves in the fears of Mike who, in the title story, feels obliged to prove himself on the swing rope over the river, or enjoying the insights into the odd minds of grown-ups in stories such as "Nutmeg".

Shadow of the Minotaur by Alan Gibbons
(Dolphin, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99
Phoenix's dad is a computer geek who has moved his unwilling family to a new town to do a job as a creator of computer games for a mysterious company. Phoenix is having a bad time at his new school, things are tense at home, so he takes solace in a new game based on Greek myths that his dad is involved in making.

But as Phoenix and his dad soon discover, someone has been tinkering with the software. You can't play it, it plays you: virtual reality becomes terrifyingly real as Phoenix is transformed into Theseus who must fight the Minotaur.

Girls will find this unputdownable, but if you've got a boy who is a reluctant reader then this is guaranteed to make him change his mind. Gibbons is a teacher and knows how to hook a child's interest.

Ages 12+
In Flame by Gaye Hicyilmaz
(Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)
The past comes back to haunt 14-year-old Helen when, seven years after the death of her beloved brother Tom, her family move to the Pembroke coast where they used to spend their summer holidays. But instead of a new start, Helen finds herself drawn into a web of tangled relationships. Her younger brother seems constantly frightened, her mother is obsessed with a young man called Christian and Helen feels attracted towards him herself. Then there is Christian's sister, who has recollections of Tom that are highly unsettling.

Hicyilmaz's immensely satisfying novel scores in every way. The writing is delicate and pointed, the plotting exciting and the characters psychologically convincing.

Where Were You, Robert? by Hans Magnus Enzensberger
(Hamish Hamilton, £14.99; CultureShop price £11.99)
It is a question that almost every parent with a dreamy teenager with distant eyes has asked their offspring at one time or another. But, in the case of Robert, it is a pertinent question because when he looks into a picture or a recreation of the past, he falls through time and history. Robert knows firsthand what it is like to talk to his own grandmother when she was a little girl or discover the secrets of a 17th-century painter's studio. Terribly useful for all those school projects, you imagine.

This is a spellbinding, cleverly constructed book, in which the past is brought vividly to life. Part of the adventure is in discovering how Robert will get himself back to his own time.

 Call CultureShop on 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a UK cheque payable to The Guardian CultureShop to: Off the Shelf Offer, CultureShop Freepost, LON3590, London, W3 6BR. Please add 99p UK p&p per order.

webTitle: Parents: Oh Mum, please!

fields.headline: Oh Mum, please!
fields.standfirst: Being forced to dance on daytime TV is just one of the unspeakable embarrassments  Polly Hudson  has endured for the sake of her mother's career. But revenge can be sweet...
fields.trailText: Being forced to dance on daytime TV is just one of the unspeakable embarrassments Polly Hudson has endured for the sake of her mother's career. But revenge can be sweet..
fields.body:
I am scared to open a newspaper today. You see, my mother's new book is about to be published and she's written a piece for a national newspaper. In it, she tells how she discovered, at the age of 24, that the man she thought was her father, was not. She asked whether I minded her printing such a personal story. I didn't. After all, it's not about me - for once. The problem is that then the paper asked for a photograph of my mum, dad and I, which she knows I would hate. She promises she didn't send one. Now I can't bear to look: you see, it wouldn't be the first time my mother has embarrassed me in print. It's happened throughout my life - even before I was born.

My mum, Val Hudson, used to write a column for the Sun in which she told readers of the trouble she was having conceiving me: "I'm The Girl The Stork Forgot!" screamed the headline. Her readers sent in bizarre baby-making tips by the sackful. Cue the column: "There are 101 ways to make a baby and I've tried them all!" Imagine your mum having sex in 101 different ways.

Months later, when the stork finally did visit, my mum celebrated by allowing the Sun to print my first scan picture, and Pebble Mill At One to follow her pregnancy. During this warts-and-all series, a geneticist produced a photograph of what I might look like: a baby with the face of a werewolf, my dad's long arms and mum's short legs. "Her knuckles will scrape the ground... is it too late for an abortion?" Val joked.

In the end, Val had a glamorous labour: she wore enormous false eyelashes (testing them for a magazine under strenuous conditions). They lasted well and didn't even need replacing for the photoshoot in her hospital room the next day.

Fast-forward 13 years: mum was the producer of a BBC afternoon magazine programme called Bazaar. She needed a teenager to appear on a segment about customising old T-shirts to save money and asked me to do it. "It'll be fun," she promised. Naively, I believed her.

It was only when I discovered that my partner in (fashion) crime was Andi Peters that I realised it definitely wasn't going to be fun. But nothing could have prepared me for the horror of what was to come. I thought we'd finished filming when the director asked me put the T-shirt on for a few close-ups. I stood wearing the purple, beaded monstrosity Andi and I had created while everyone stared at me. I was in my most awkward, sulky phase of adolescence: all bad hair (gel, mousse and spray) and spots.

Then it happened. Madonna's Vogue blared out, the cameras started rolling and the director pointed at me and said: "OK, dance!" It was possibly the most hideous moment of my life.

Then mum moved into writing novels, using my dad's surname of Corbett. They were sensational, glitzy stories. When I saw that the tagline for her third book, Double Trouble, was "Mother and daughter compete for fame, money and men!", I knew I was in trouble. "Darling, you'll have to help me promote the book, a few magazines are doing stories." I reluctantly agreed to do one piece.

Cosmopolitan sent a car to drive me to a gym. I had my hair and make-up done, and then the art director announced what she wanted us to do. We were going to be photographed in a boxing ring. Wearing boxing gloves. Pretending to hit each other. How I restrained myself from knocking my mother out remains a mystery.

A few weeks later mum rang me, breathless with excitement. We had been asked to go on Esther Rantzen's talk show. I was adamant in my refusal but mum still managed to persuade me. She offered £100. I was young, I needed the money. Mum had promised that they were going to put me in the audience and only ask me one question. She promised.

I should have known. Mum had said to arrive fresh-faced at the studio as my make-up would be done there. So I came straight from work but got caught in early-evening traffic and arrived nearly an hour late. As I walked into the building, the producer grabbed me and screamed: "Thank God you're here at last!" She whisked me along maze-like corridors, through the make-up room ("No time to stop, sadly"), into the studio and on to the stage. The whole show was about us. I sat down, confused, barefaced, with wild hair and a wilder expression in my eyes as the floor manager said, "5, 4, 3, 2, 1 and go!", and Emma Forbes (Esther was ill) started the show.

"You die for this," I whispered to mum without moving my lips.

"I swear I didn't know until we got here," she lied through her teeth.

That was three years ago and I can laugh about it now. Just about.

This may seem like a cruel story of child exploitation to further a career, but I now realise it isn't. When you're a writer, you are inspired by the people closest to you. That's not to say I haven't been angry with my mum over the years - we've had some blazing rows about all this and we'll probably have another one when I finally pluck up the courage to open the paper. But revenge is sweet: hope you enjoyed reading this, mum!

 Relative Strangers, co-authored by Val Hudson, is published by Headline at £5.99
