Months later, when the stork finally did visit, my mum celebrated by allowing the Sun to print my first scan picture, and Pebble Mill At One to follow her pregnancy. During this warts-and-all series, a geneticist produced a photograph of what I might look like: a baby with the face of a werewolf, my dad's long arms and mum's short legs. "Her knuckles will scrape the ground... is it too late for an abortion?" Val joked. In the end, Val had a glamorous labour: she wore enormous false eyelashes (testing them for a magazine under strenuous conditions). They lasted well and didn't even need replacing for the photoshoot in her hospital room the next day. Fast-forward 13 years: mum was the producer of a BBC afternoon magazine programme called Bazaar. She needed a teenager to appear on a segment about customising old T-shirts to save money and asked me to do it. "It'll be fun," she promised. Naively, I believed her. It was only when I discovered that my partner in (fashion) crime was Andi Peters that I realised it definitely wasn't going to be fun. But nothing could have prepared me for the horror of what was to come. I thought we'd finished filming when the director asked me put the T-shirt on for a few close-ups. I stood wearing the purple, beaded monstrosity Andi and I had created while everyone stared at me. I was in my most awkward, sulky phase of adolescence: all bad hair (gel, mousse and spray) and spots. Then it happened. Madonna's Vogue blared out, the cameras started rolling and the director pointed at me and said: "OK, dance!" It was possibly the most hideous moment of my life. Then mum moved into writing novels, using my dad's surname of Corbett. They were sensational, glitzy stories. When I saw that the tagline for her third book, Double Trouble, was "Mother and daughter compete for fame, money and men!", I knew I was in trouble. "Darling, you'll have to help me promote the book, a few magazines are doing stories." I reluctantly agreed to do one piece. Cosmopolitan sent a car to drive me to a gym. I had my hair and make-up done, and then the art director announced what she wanted us to do. We were going to be photographed in a boxing ring. Wearing boxing gloves. Pretending to hit each other. How I restrained myself from knocking my mother out remains a mystery. A few weeks later mum rang me, breathless with excitement. We had been asked to go on Esther Rantzen's talk show. I was adamant in my refusal but mum still managed to persuade me. She offered £100. I was young, I needed the money. Mum had promised that they were going to put me in the audience and only ask me one question. She promised. I should have known. Mum had said to arrive fresh-faced at the studio as my make-up would be done there. So I came straight from work but got caught in early-evening traffic and arrived nearly an hour late. As I walked into the building, the producer grabbed me and screamed: "Thank God you're here at last!" She whisked me along maze-like corridors, through the make-up room ("No time to stop, sadly"), into the studio and on to the stage. The whole show was about us. I sat down, confused, barefaced, with wild hair and a wilder expression in my eyes as the floor manager said, "5, 4, 3, 2, 1 and go!", and Emma Forbes (Esther was ill) started the show. "You die for this," I whispered to mum without moving my lips. "I swear I didn't know until we got here," she lied through her teeth. That was three years ago and I can laugh about it now. Just about. This may seem like a cruel story of child exploitation to further a career, but I now realise it isn't. When you're a writer, you are inspired by the people closest to you. That's not to say I haven't been angry with my mum over the years - we've had some blazing rows about all this and we'll probably have another one when I finally pluck up the courage to open the paper. But revenge is sweet: hope you enjoyed reading this, mum!  Relative Strangers, co-authored by Val Hudson, is published by Headline at £5.99

webTitle: Parents: My children and other animals

fields.headline: My children and other animals
fields.standfirst: A study shows kids prefer pets to parents. The feeling is mutual, says  Nicholas Lezard
fields.trailText: A study shows kids prefer pets to parents. The feeling is mutual, says Nicholas Lezard.
fields.body:
The latest survey from the Department of the Bleeding Obvious to land on our desk comes from the psychology department of the University of Warwick. (They always come from the psychology department of the University of Warwick, and we salute their tireless research, which has enlivened many a slow news day.) This time, it has been determined that seven-year-olds are very attached to their pets. The report, as summarised in the Daily Telegraph, says this: "Youngsters asked to nominate who they would turn to in a series of challenging situations always placed their pets in the top 10. They often conferred 'most special relationship' status on their pets along with parents, grandparents, siblings, aunts and uncles, teachers, best friends, and nannies or childminders."

And this: "The report, Child Representations of Pets in their Social Networks, said children showed great pragmatism about pets' limited abilities, but found comfort in sharing their problems with them."

Well, as usual, two or three thoughts occur to one after reading that. The first is that it is hard to imagine a child constructing a top 10 of anything without, at some point, having to put a pet in there. Thanks to classroom overcrowding, they may know plenty of people - rather more than you do, in fact (for parenthood has the effect of closing off your social life almost as efficiently as death); but their classmates, they work out, are not necessarily those who are going to help them in an emergency. They will usually have got them into the emergency situation in the first place.

They will also, by the age of seven, have acquired some rudimentary understanding of the difference between the real and the imaginary. (I love that phrase "great pragmatism about pets' limited abilities". How pragmatic would my generation have been, raised on Lassie reruns, Flipper and Skippy, where rescuing children from abandoned mineshafts was the kind of job that animals took on with almost contemptuous ease?) Otherwise Pokémon characters would have occupied all 10 slots. (One would like, in passing, to thank the creators of Pokémon for alerting children to the existence of the acute accent in a way that millions of French lessons across the land have failed to do.)

So the idea that children like their animals is hardly news. As the psychologists noted - astutely as ever - dogs and cats do not rebuke children for their sins of commission or omission (unless it is the child's turn to crack open the Pedigree Chum or Whiskas).

But it seems as though the psychologists at Warwick have missed a trick or two, for the unconditional companionship that pets offer extends to the adult world as well. A few cunningly-worded questions could have produced a survey with the rather more shocking news that parents prefer their pets to their own children. A monstrous suggestion, you say, but those of you with experience of The Three-Year-Old Boy, the most exasperating life-form on the planet, may begin to see my point. The family cat, for instance, does not do the following:

1. Ask you, immediately after a minutely supervised bowel movement, which usually occurs in the middle of lunch, why it has a hole in its bottom.

2. Make a fuss if you go away and leave little more than a big bowl of cat food for sustenance.

3. Confidently inform you, after a routine clash of wills, that you are "a bum-bum head".

4. Insist on pouring its own milk into its Golden Nuggets of a morning, even though milk-pouring is by no means whatsoever on its list of mastered skills.

5. Howl the place down if you you go out for the evening, for what feels like the first social engagement you have had since the Callaghan administration.

6. Turn a simple walk to the shops into an hour-long trek calling for native bearers, an inexhaustible reserve of patience, and a child psychologist or two from the University of Warwick.

Perhaps, then, it would be best if the team from Warwick left off their researches into the relative attractions of human beings and pets for the time being. We don't hold up that well.

webTitle: Parents: The panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: The government is to issue health warnings on cellphones. With a million children under 15 already owning a mobile, should parents restrict their use?
fields.trailText: The Question: The government is to issue health warnings on cellphones. With a million children under 15 already owning a mobile, should parents restrict their use?
fields.body:
Mike Caldwell
Communications director for Vodaphone
My three children have had mobiles since they were 16. The reason I didn't let them have them before was nothing to do with concerns about their health, but about what is appropriate for children of a certain age. I don't think children should have a TV in their bedrooms until they are at least 18. As far as the safety aspect goes, I think it's more important that I know where my girls, aged 20 and 21 are, and that we can contact each other. As a company we don't target children at all. I emphasise moderation to my children - particularly as I'm paying their bills.

Tapio Hedman
Vice-president of communications for Nokia
Parents should decide on this with their children. Families keeping in touch by phone is more and more important in today's busy world but I limit the amount of time my children watch TV and it's the same with phones. My 10-year-old son has had a phone since the beginning of this year, but my eight-year-old daughter does not have one. He has a monthly allowance and has to budget for calls out of that, so that he learns to be responsible. It is for that reason that his calls are limited. There is no scientific evidence that mobiles damage your health.

Deborah Mattinson
Mother of three
I'm not a big fan of mobile phones because I don't think it's good to be constantly bombarded with communication - for either children or adults. I have one myself, but leave it mostly switched off and don't give the number out. The health issues are unresolved and this lack of evidence is more worrying for children. I asked my 10-year-old daughter what she thought, and she said children shouldn't have them until they are 20 because of the risks. I think there are advantages for teenagers if they are going out and about clubbing. Beyond that, I'm not in favour.

Michael Clark
Spokesman for the National Radiological Protection Board
The best advice is from the independent inquiry by Sir William Stewart, which said use of mobiles by children for non-essential calls should be discouraged, but left it to parents to choose. The advice is not based on an observed risk but on the possibility of one. I have older children with mobiles and possible risks from them are the last thing I worry about. When they were younger I was more concerned about bullying and drugs. In any case, children seem to prefer to text-message each other these days, which means they are not holding phones to their heads.

webTitle: Parents: In my father's footsteps

fields.headline: In my father's footsteps
fields.standfirst: William Straw has become a student activist -  just as his dad, Jack, once did. Andrew  Martin, a chip off the old block himself, asks  why children so often inherit their parents'  politics
fields.trailText: William Straw has become a student activist - just as his dad, Jack, once did. Andrew Martin, a chip off the old block himself, asks why children so often inherit their parents' politics.
fields.body:
George W Bush is differentiated from his ex-president dad by one measly letter of the alphabet. As for his rival, it may have been a while since he was known as Al Gore Junior, but there's no escaping that he is the son of Al Gore Senior, former senator. Both are spoken of in terms of their fathers, the questions being: is George W trying to avenge the defeat of his father at the hands of Clinton in 1992? Is Al Gore trying to avenge the loss of his father's senate seat in 1970? Such speculations find an echo in this country, where the influence on Peter Mandelson of his grandfather Herbert Morrison (Labour's postwar deputy leader) has long preoccupied commentators.

It is odd that these dynastic issues should be so prominent in our democratic era. But there again, three of the Beatles have produced children who went on to be rock musicians. We might charitably say that factors here include inherited talent and familiarity with a milieu, but the point is, in a celebrity-powered world, a big name is a brand it must be hard not to exploit.

Could we, then, be returning to those aristocrat-dominated days of early parliamentary democracy, a period made maddeningly hard to study by the need to distinguish one damned Pitt, Fox or Russell from another? Some reinforcement for this idea comes with the news that Jack Straw's son, William, now an Oxford undergraduate, has moved from inadvertently embarrassing the government (three years ago he was cautioned for trying to sell cannabis) to doing so intentionally, by taking part in a march against tuition fees. Straw senior may disapprove, but he surely cannot do so without a rueful half-smile - after all, he himself was a student firebrand of the 60s.

My own experience is that Labour politics is, like varicose veins, easily passed from father to son. There was a compliment my father would bestow - "He's a good socialist" - and I would automatically approve of anyone so described. By contrast, whenever anyone appeared on TV whom he considered a patrician twit - Willie Whitelaw, for example - he'd say: "Do you know what that man would be if he hadn't had all the advantages life has to offer?" To which I, the other half of the long-established double act, would reply: "A milkman, Dad? Delivering coal...?"

In my mid-teens, I did veer briefly towards communism, corresponding with a man from Leeds who urged me, on letters written with blunt pencils, to set up a revolutionary cell in York. I bought a cloth badge emblazoned with the hammer and sickle, and was crudely sowing it on to my greatcoat when my father intervened on the grounds that I was going over the top with my leftwingery.

That happened 20 years ago, and it was the only political disagreement I'd had with my father until last year when I was slagging off the dome. I'd expected my dad to be with me on this, but when I'd finished he was icily silent. "It's easy to knock," he said, and I understood that he was more of a Blair loyalist than I'd realised. It was a painful moment.

John Cryer, Labour MP, had similar early experiences. He is "off-message" as the Blairites say of incorrigible lefties, and his late father, Bob, also a Labour backbencher, would have been off-message, too, if there'd been a message to be on in Labour's more anarchic days of the 70s and 80s. I asked John if, with that sort of background, there was any chance of him not growing up a Labour supporter.

"Er... no," he said. "There was no indoctrination; I just sort of knew that when the miners went on strike in 1972 that this was a pompous, overblown government trying to give ordinary working people a good kicking."

But the Conservative deputy chairman, David Prior - son of the former Conservative cabinet minister Jim Prior - thinks Labour loyalties are more likely to be transmitted from parent to child than Conservative ones: "With Labour it's more of a tribal thing, a badge of honour." Not that the young Prior ever diverged very dramatically from his father. In fact, his political shifts have tended to reflect those of his father.

"In the 70s, my father was very much a Heathite, pro-Europe," attests Prior, "and I was absolutely in favour, too. Since then we've both become more disillusioned. It's terribly boring really..."

There was slightly more political aggro in the family of another former Conservative minister, Patrick Jenkin, whose son Bernard, shadow transport minister, says: "My father was one of the leading figures behind Thatcherism, and I took a long time to be convinced that that was right." Bernard disagreed with his father from within the party, but their debates could be noisy nonetheless.

"I called him 'lobby fodder' once," recalls Jenkin, of one of their more heated exchanges. "Fortunately, he's a very reasonable man."

Essentially, though, Jenkin respected his father's vocation. When he was six, he'd asked him the potentially tricky question, "What are MPs for?", and been impressed by the sonorous answer: "They make the law."

For more turbulent tales of parent-child political tensions, we might turn to recent memoirs. In Experience, Martin Amis writes of the time he attempted to skewer his reactionary dad by asking what exactly it felt like to be mildly anti-semitic, to which Amis Senior replied in commensurately precise terms. But political tensions only enrich the basic theme of Experience, which is the love of father for son, and vice versa.

The leftwing journalist Francis Beckett had a father who made Kingsley look like a Blairite, and he writes about him in his book, The Tragedy of John Beckett MP. Before the war, John Beckett had moved from being a promising Labour MP into blackshirted activism with Oswald Mosley. He was imprisoned during the war, and Francis was born in 1945.

"By the time I knew my father, he'd settled into a sort of Blimpishness," says Beckett, "although he would still come out with remarks about race, and it was shivery stuff. Even at 10 or 11, I knew that something was wrong." Despite an abhorrence for his father's views, Beckett can still affirm that his father was, on balance, "a nice man".

Perhaps the mechanism here is that, if you disagree with your parents' politics, you compensate by looking for their virtues in other areas. But conversely, it can be stifling to identify too closely with your parents' values, tempting you to provoke them on other fronts. Jackie Ashley, political editor of the New Statesman, is the daughter of the former Labour MP Jack Ashley. She is "left-leaning" herself, but in her teens she struck a note of disharmony through religion. "I was confirmed, slightly to the horror of my parents, who are atheists," she relates. "I sometimes think... was that my act of rebellion?"

In this area, things quickly become complicated. Who knows, for example, what energies are encapsulated in the remark of Hilary Benn MP, son of Tony, that he himself is "a Benn, and proud of it, but not a Bennite"? If he is promoted to a cabinet post - not unlikely on present form - the question will become pressing. In the US, meanwhile, young Al Gore III is captaining the American football team at St Alban's school in Washington just as his father did before him, and showing all the signs of someone who... Well, let's just leave it like that for now, shall we?

webTitle: Chronic shortage of midwives 'puts lives at risk'

fields.headline: Chronic shortage of midwives 'puts lives at risk'
fields.standfirst: Chronic shortages of midwives and huge regional variations in maternity services mean new mothers' needs are being neglected and lives put at risk, the Royal College of Midwives said today.
fields.trailText: Chronic shortages of midwives and huge regional variations in maternity services mean new mothers' needs are being neglected and lives put at risk, the Royal College of Midwives said today.
fields.body:
Chronic shortages of midwives and huge regional variations in maternity services mean new mothers' needs are being neglected and lives put at risk, the Royal College of Midwives said today.

MPs from all parties have joined forces to launch a new group which will investigate standards of maternity care throughout the country.

Midwives have been warning for months that low morale in the profession has contributed to worrying staff shortages and potentially dangerous working practices.

Last year only two thirds of deliveries were carried out by a midwife rather than an obstetrician, down from almost three quarters in 1996.

The Royal College of Midwives has warned that its members are being forced to work double shifts to make up for staff shortages, and many maternity units cannot offer women constant one-to-one care while they are in labour.

Caesarean sections now account for almost one in five births, despite evidence that unnecessary medical intervention can be harmful to mother and baby.

The government has pledged to supply an extra 20,000 nurses and midwives by 2004 but it is unclear how many of those will be midwives.

Recent research showed that out of the 5,744 midwives working in the NHS this year, 550 had joined in the last 12 months but 531 had left, making a net gain of just 19 staff.

The all-party parliamentary group on maternity care launched today will address standards of care and raise awareness of the problems.

Chairman Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, said: "Maternity services care for over 600,000 women and babies each year and yet there are huge variations in the quality of service women receive nationally.

"Some women may not receive specialist care when it is needed, while others may be put at risk by unnecessary medical intervention.

"Women's social needs are often neglected, especially in the postnatal period, often putting family relationships and even children at risk."

Health minister Yvette Cooper said: "Clearly, every woman should have a midwife present at birth - that is absolutely the bottom line.

"But under the last government, in fact, what happened between 1991 and 1997 the number of midwives working in the NHS dropped by over 1,000.

"Now since the election this government has increased the number of midwives working in the NHS. It has been going up, it has to go up further, and that is absolutely clear in the NHS plan.

"But it is clear as well that some areas face particular pressures and they are suffering as a result of the long-term underfunding that the NHS has experienced across the board. We are turning that round."

webTitle: Real lives: Gang violence in Peckham

fields.headline: 'It's lawless out there'
fields.standfirst:
On Monday, 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was stabbed to death in Peckham, south London. His death is just the latest tragedy for a community blighted by teenage gangs and violence, says Sarah Helm
More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Real lives: On Monday, 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was stabbed to death in Peckham, south London. His death is just the latest tragedy for a community blighted by teenage gangs and violence, says Sarah Helm.
fields.body:
They call it the Peckham frontline. It is a desolate stretch of road, lined by rundown shops. The children and teenagers who loiter along this stretch of Peckham high street, on their way to and from school, are used to violence. Backpacks slung over shoulders, they pass by, oblivious to the yellow police boards calling for witnesses to the latest assault or stabbing. They are also, by and large, oblivious to the drug dealing - often conducted openly on these streets, and often by youths much like themselves.

And just as they accept the violence here, the children accept that it will follow them into the school playgrounds. It is not uncommon for schools in this part of south-east London to have security guards patrolling their playgrounds and CCTV cameras monitoring their corridors.

But however accustomed these schoolchildren may have become to violence, nothing could have prepared them for the news that the blood of a 10-year-old had been spilt on these same streets. "He was just a tiny kid," says Ellen, 13, tears welling in her eyes as she stares towards Oliver Goldsmith primary school.

It is, of course, far too early to speculate about what led to the stabbing of Damilola Taylor as he was returning from the primary school's computer club to his council flat on the nearby North Peckham estate. His body was found just outside a social services office building where the Southwark's youth offending team is based.

Whatever led to Damilola's death, the killing must surely draw attention to what is happening to all the children of Peckham, and other parts of inner-city London. For Damilola's killing took place against a burgeoning subculture of youth violence which has been taking root, seemingly beyond the control of any agency, and beyond control of the police. To put it simply, this is the subculture of the gang and, as such, is nothing new for inner-city London. But the gang culture of today is perhaps more disturbing than ever because of the extreme youth of those it attracts - and the extreme youth of some of its victims.

In Peckham, where the black population is the majority, both gang members and their victims are usually black. "What we are seeing is more extremes of violence among teenagers and young kids. We are seeing extreme lifestyles and a willingness to use weapons. There is a thing among young people to use violence at the moment," says one black police officer, who works with families affected by violence in this area.

Nobody disputes that gang culture is spreading here. Not far from where Damilola bled to death, another teenager was stabbed and killed just a week ago. Seven people were injured at a nightclub shooting along the same stretch of road about a month ago. A 17-year-old, Andre Drummond, was knifed to death outside McDonald's in nearby Camberwell earlier this year. Andre had recently been excluded from school.

The latest statistics for the area show that while crime in general is down, violent crime is rising. In October 2000 there were 854 instances of violent crime in the London borough of Southwark, 54 more than occurred in October last year and part of a steady rise.

One local community worker explains what is happening: "Young people in these areas are more desperate than ever. Those who are black and excluded feel there is nothing in mainstream culture for them. They are lonely and uncared for. They are looking for a way of finding their identity and many cannot resist turning to the gangs."

Youth provision for children in areas such as Peckham is pitiful. The schools are usually too hard-pressed, trying to achieve targets to focus attention on youth clubs or other youth services. The borough of Southwark is one of the most deprived in the country, where vulnerable teenagers often come from broken homes and find little hope of breaking free of the cycle of poverty around them. "They feel they have to give 200% just to stand still," says a black youth worker.

As one former Peckham gang member puts it: "It's lawless out there on the street, but the laws are our laws, right. We want respect and we make sure we get it." The gang subculture also comes with its own ready-made economy: drugs. "It's easy money. I started selling puff to kids on their way to school. I was good at it," says another former gang member, now in Feltham prison for young offenders.

"They look around and feel there is no future for them," says another community worker. "But they are kids and like all kids they need to feel good about themselves. They are confused about their identity so they join a gang. It gives them a recognition. It gives them their own set of rules and relationships. It means you can hang out with those who are like you rather than those who want to change you."

There is also little doubt about the extreme levels of violence among the youth gangs, or that they are recruiting younger and younger members. At Kids Company, a young people's club on Camberwell Road, former gang members talk of joining gangs as young as 12 or 13. "It's the norm for kids like us. It's what everyone does. Maybe you go to prison. Maybe you don't. But if you do, you'll find all your mates there, so why not?" says one who says he has decided to leave the gang life behind. "It's good money for a few years but then what?" he asks.

The gang members say the recruiting grounds are often in the schools or among children excluded from schools. Southwark schools all have high numbers of children barred for disruptive behaviour. Many of these youngsters fall through the education net and are excluded several times before being effectively lost to the authorities. Some are as young as 14.

While the extent of the crisis among alienated children and teenagers is evident, however, nobody working in the field claims to have any answers. Police appear frustrated, unable to penetrate the operations of the gangs, and fear a community backlash should they probe too far. "They are like a defeated army. They don't know how to handle it," says one south London solicitor.

Community workers also despair of being able to reach the alienated youngsters who are attracted by the gangs. Two youth clubs in the Peckham area have recently had to close down due to gang violence on their premises. The schools, meanwhile, will play down any suggestion that youth violence spills on to their playgrounds for fear of destabilising their already vulnerable children. Headteachers prefer to turn a blind eye. The question is: where, after the killing of Damilola Taylor, will it be possible to turn a blind eye to?

webTitle: Rural white paper sets tests for services and policies

fields.headline: Rural white paper sets tests for services and policies
fields.standfirst: The rural white paper focuses on service standards and on making Whitehall departments pay attention to the countryside when drawing up policies, writes Crispin Moor
fields.trailText: The rural white paper focuses on service standards and on making Whitehall departments pay attention to the countryside when drawing up policies, writes Crispin Moor
fields.body:
The rural white paper has taken two long years to emerge from Whitehall. But rural policy has not stood still during this period. Changes include the creation of the Countryside Agency, reforms to the Common Agricultural Policy, the government's "right to roam" legislation, and the prime minister's decision to establish a rural cabinet committee. The white paper now sets out the government's "big picture" strategy on the future of the countryside.

For more than 50 years rural policy has dealt primarily with agricultural policy, with wildlife, protected landscapes and planning as add-ons. But this view is increasingly being challenged by rural policy makers and administrators, rural interest groups and academics. In this context the white paper does mark an important break with the traditional rural agenda. It represents a partial paradigm shift towards a rural policy based on social needs and on economic needs wider than agriculture -- such as the need for rural economies to benefit from information and communications technology and from farm diversification.

The big new themes of the white paper are a focus on social policy and public services, strengthening the contribution of parish councils to local governance; and reforming the "Whitehall wiring" to ensure that in future rural needs are considered when developing and implementing government policies.

The white paper sets out the government's rural services standard. This consists of a matrix giving detailed access to service commitments for most public services including schools, childcare, libraries, health and social care services, emergency services, transport services and so on.

Equitable access will be secured, according to the white paper, by a variety of means including published access standards, response time targets, monitoring access and setting improvement targets, telephone services, on-line access, help with transport costs and presumptions against closures. This charter tells rural citizens the levels of public services that they can reasonably expect.

There are also new policies on housing and transport including ending the automatic 50% council tax discount on second homes by giving local authorities the discretion to charge the full levy. Many of them are likely to do so in areas of acute housing need which have high levels of second-home ownership. These are the so-called rural "honeypot" areas. A substantial increase in the provision of affordable housing is planned. Rural transport and bus subsidies and schemes look set for continued substantial investment.

These commitments are intended as a major plank of the government's response to continuing, albeit dispersed, deprivation within rural communities. But these commitments are still given against a background of significant underprovision of many rural services. The additional costs of rural service provision - largely in terms of travel costs and time - often absorb the resources that should be reaching those in need of public services. The white paper is relatively quiet on this issue.

A new role for parish and town councils is outlined. Parish councils which meet certain criteria of competence will be classed as "quality parishes" and given a much greater role in working with other local authorities on service delivery, consultations, and access to information on public services.

Local authorities are also challenged to make a success of their new duty to prepare community strategies by working with local partners and working collaboratively with parish councils. The white paper is supportive of the contribution of local government and is peppered with examples of good practice by local authorities and other partner.

Reforms to the "Whitehall wiring" include underpinning the work of the new rural cabinet committee through:

 Cabinet Office rural checklists for Whitehall departments to help policy makers take account of the rural dimensions of policy
 annual reports by each department on how their policies have been rural proofed
 charging the Countryside Agency with providing policy advice and assistance and with drawing rural concerns to the attention of departments
 charging the agency with making an annual progress report on rural proofing within Whitehall for consideration by the rural cabinet committee

A national rural sounding board will be established bringing together ministers and organisations with an interest in rural policy. A rural sub group of the Central Local Partnership is proposed to bring together ministers and councillors from the Local Government Association to broker closer collaboration on rural policy.

Other important themes of the white paper include a focus on and resources in the region of £37m for market-town regeneration.

Agriculture is still a key part of the white paper, but this largely repeats the government's existing strategy as set out in A New Direction for Farming (1999) and the England Rural Development Plan (2000). There are some proposals for making the statutory planning system friendlier towards farm diversification proposals. There are also proposals offering rate relief to new farm diversification enterprises.

Finally the white paper sets out the government's policies in relation to the countryside environment and wildlife, on landscapes, on biodiversity, and also on access to the countryside and rights of way.

 Crispin Moor is rural policy officer at the Local Government Association.

webTitle: Councils can tax second homes at full rate

fields.headline: Councils can tax second homes at full rate
fields.standfirst: Prescott's new deal puts council tax change and release of best farmland at heart of countryside regeneration
fields.trailText: Prescott's new deal puts council tax change and release of best farmland at heart of countryside regeneration. Peter Hetherington reports.
fields.body:
Town halls will be able to levy the full council tax rate on second homes under a five point plan unveiled by John Prescott to transform the countryside with more affordable housing and improved services for remote communities.

The new deal for rural England, which will safeguard post offices, subsidise village shops, pubs and garages, improve public transport and bolster market towns, will also bring about wholesale changes to the post-war planning system which has kept intact the best farming land.

Unveiling a lengthy rural white paper, the deputy prime minister announced that the number of "social" homes let by housing associations would be doubled to 3,000 a year in three years time.

One housing charity said this move would merely bring the number to the level provided in 1996 by the last government.

However, the biggest uproar yesterday was caused by plans to let councils charge, after consultation, the full council tax for more than 200,000 second homes (a further 300,000 are let as holiday properties). At the moment second home owners get a 50% tax discount, which costs councils an estimated £150m annually in lost revenue.

While some Conservatives labelled the move vindictive, the chairman of the government's countryside agency, Ewen Cameron, who is effectively the prime minister's chief rural adviser, came close to accusing ministers of fighting shy of tougher measures.

Mr Cameron, a Somerset farmer who once chaired the Country Landowners' Association, said ministers should have forced councils to slap the full tax on second homes, rather than give them discretion to do so. He said: "People who have moved to a community because they think it is desirable have contributed very little to make it desirable and the least they can do is pay the full council tax."

Moria Constable, chief executive of the Rural Housing Trust, backed the criticism calling the move a fudge and warning that many councils would not increase the tax unless directed to do so.

But generally all parties welcomed many of the white paper's proposals.

Mr Prescott told the Commons that the government wanted a "living countryside with thriving rural communities and high-quality services...a working countryside". The plan, he said, was dedicated to tackling poverty, improving services and the economy, protecting the environment, and giving people a wider choice. Referring to Labour's measures to regenerate cities, with construction on brownfield sites, so saving perhaps thousands of acres of countryside, Mr Prescott warned against dividing town and country. He would study all proposals for building in rural areas. "We will build on urban brownfield first and greenfield last."

Some of the most adventurous proposals involve radical changes to the post-war farming policy. Funds will be diverted from agriculture to support other rural enterprises - a recognition that farming is in such steep decline that radical measures are needed to transform the countryside without damage to the environment.

By 2006, through a switch of EU common agricultural funds, about £1.6bn - 10% of total agricultural support - in Britain will go annually on other ventures, including tourism and alternative industries. Besides this, the agriculture ministry's veto on planning applications for agricultural land will be lifted. Since 1945, governments have stipulated protection of land classed as "the best and most versatile".

Mentioning the new legislation giving greater access to the countryside and its protection, Mr Prescott was at pains to underline the government's green credentials.

Other ministers weighed in yesterday to support the rural agenda of Labour, which now has more rural MPs than the Conservatives. David Blunkett, the education secretary, said the government had cut the number of village school closures to only four a year - from an average of 30 - and that this year £80m had been earmarked to support small country schools.

The main points

 Town halls to be given powers to levy the full council tax on second homes

 50% rate relief for village shops, pubs and garages which offer wider benefits to the community such as cash machines

 £100m for one-stop health centres in 100 communities

 Revitalisation of rural post offices with £270m of investment

 £240m for rural transport schemes in addition to a £15m special transport fund to support taxis, car clubs and community transport

 The strengthening of parish and town councils by awarding the best of them new powers to provide a range of facilities while drawing up local plans

Mr Prescott told the Commons that the government wanted a "living countryside with thriving rural communities and high-quality services...a working countryside". The plan, he said, was dedicated to tackling poverty, improving services and the economy, protecting the environment, and giving people a wider choice. Referring to Labour's measures to regenerate cities, with construction on brownfield sites, so saving perhaps thousands of acres of countryside, Mr Prescott warned against dividing town and country. He would study all proposals for building in rural areas. "We will build on urban brownfield first and greenfield last." Some of the most adventurous proposals involve radical changes to the post-war farming policy. Funds will be diverted from agriculture to support other rural enterprises - a recognition that farming is in such steep decline that radical measures are needed to transform the countryside without damage to the environment. By 2006, through a switch of EU common agricultural funds, about £1.6bn - 10% of total agricultural support - in Britain will go annually on other ventures, including tourism and alternative industries. Besides this, the agriculture ministry's veto on planning applications for agricultural land will be lifted. Since 1945, governments have stipulated protection of land classed as "the best and most versatile". Mentioning the new legislation giving greater access to the countryside and its protection, Mr Prescott was at pains to underline the government's green credentials. Other ministers weighed in yesterday to support the rural agenda of Labour, which now has more rural MPs than the Conservatives. David Blunkett, the education secretary, said the government had cut the number of village school closures to only four a year - from an average of 30 - and that this year £80m had been earmarked to support small country schools. The main points  Town halls to be given powers to levy the full council tax on second homes  50% rate relief for village shops, pubs and garages which offer wider benefits to the community such as cash machines  £100m for one-stop health centres in 100 communities  Revitalisation of rural post offices with £270m of investment  £240m for rural transport schemes in addition to a £15m special transport fund to support taxis, car clubs and community transport  The strengthening of parish and town councils by awarding the best of them new powers to provide a range of facilities while drawing up local plans

webTitle: ITV pins hopes on its own Big Brother

fields.headline: ITV pins hopes on its own Big Brother
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV is hoping to repeat Big Brother's success next year with a new real life daytime soap called Public Property, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV is hoping to repeat Channel 4's success with Big Brother with a new real life soap format, Public Property, for its daytime schedule next year.

In the show, six participants will submit themselves to public scrutiny over 12 weeks with viewers deciding what direction their lives should take.

The show's co-creator, Simon Goodman, said: "We'll take four individuals and one couple who are looking for a change - they might feel stuck in a rut, or trapped. The audience will write their life story for 12 weeks and shape their lives."

Each day the show will focus on a single participant, with viewers voting by phone on major life-changing decision.

They will be given three options drawn up by the production team. The decisions could be about moving from a small town to a big city, changing jobs or giving up smoking.

Viewers will also be able to vote on smaller decisions - such as what clothes each participant should wear each day - via the programme's website.

Each daily instalment of Public Property will feature edited highlights of how the participants are getting on.

There will also be a studio-based element in which the presenter and audience debate the three life options presented that day, before the phone vote is closed.

The participant who must abide by the resulting decision will also have an opportunity to appeal to the studio audience and viewers at home in order to sway the poll.

Jerry Glover, Public Property co-creator and co-founder of the show's producer, independent Gag Productions with Mr Goodman, said: "The whole thing is determined democratically. The audience is in effect the script editor in a real life soap."

Participants can refuse to accept the option chosen for them, but if they do this too many times, they risk being voted off the show and replaced.

In the final week, viewers will vote to eliminate Public Property participants and choose an overall winner, based on which person has been the best at rising to the challenges chosen for them.

The victor will receive a prize that fits their aspirations, such as help starting a business or to go travelling, rather than a straight cash prize.

Gag Productions has teamed up with Anglia to co-produce Public Property, which will go out daily in a late afternoon weekday slot on ITV.

The format has also been sold to ABC in the US.

Public Property was commissioned by ITV controller of daytime Maureen Duffy in a deal brokered by the William Morris Agency, which represents Gag.

webTitle: ITV gets cold feet over return of News at Ten

fields.headline: ITV gets cold feet over return of News at Ten
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: ITV has admitted for the first time that relaunching News at Ten may not be such a good idea, write Dan Milmo and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
ITV bosses have admitted for the first time that relaunching News at Ten may not be such a good idea after all.

Steve Morrison, executive chairman of Granada Media, has publicly hinted that the network is now secretly trying to persuade the ITC to allow it to either delay or scrap plans to bring back the bulletin.

But he has admitted that it is almost certainly a lost cause.

Mr Morrison said today: "We are coming up to an election and I don't think it's appropriate for the two channels to have news on at the same time.

"The question is, is it good for democracy that the two major channels have their news programmes on at the same time? It is a dialogue we are having with the ITC as to what is the best solution.

"We negotiated a good agreement originally, but the goalposts have moved and we don't know yet what the ITC will do."

The Granada chief said that the damage caused by the clash of the bulletins would be evident in the run-up to the general election.

"I don't think it is appropriate for the two channels to have news at the same time," he added.

The Granada chief's remarks reflect fears that the public will not be served by two prime-time news bulletins running head to head.

The scheduling clash will divide the nation with predictions that as few as 3m viewers tuning into either bulletin.

This could have a devastating effect on ITV's commercial revenue in the hours that follow News at Ten.

ITV programme director David Liddiment said last week that he was full-square behind the move to bring back News at Ten.

However, Mr Morrison's comments will carry much weight, given Granada's position as one of the two biggest ITV companies in the network.

He added that viewing figures will be the BBC's biggest test, with culture secretary Chris Smith keeping a close eye on the situation.

TV watchdogs ordered ITV in September to reinstate the News at Ten on at least three nights a week.

Mr Morrison admitted it would be difficult to see the ITC climbing down now.

"We have our agreement and it is harder to undo an agreement than to do an agreement," he said.

However, it was seen as an imperfect compromise driven through by new ITC boss Patricia Hodgson.

At the time the ITC was facing a High Court action brought by ITV bosses who were determined to challenge an earlier order by the regulator to bring forward the 11pm Nightly News.

webTitle: Radio 4 to broadcast eight-hour Harry Potter Boxing Day special

fields.headline: Radio 4 to broadcast Harry Potter special on Boxing Day
fields.trailText: 1pm: Radio 4 is clearing its Boxing day schedule for an eight-hour reading of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Radio 4 is clearing its Boxing day schedule this year for a eight-hour reading of JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.

The book will be read by Stephen Fry, a familiar voice to children and adults who have already bought the audio books.

Radio 4 controller Helen Boaden said that clinching the radio rights to the blockbuster children's book was at the top of her shopping list when she arrived at the station earlier this year.

"I was determined to get Harry Potter on radio 4," she said.

Speaking at the launch of Radio 4's winter schedule, Ms Boaden said that Boxing Day on the station would be "a feast of Harry Potter".

She added that the stories formed "part of the imaginative landscape of several generations of children".

"I want there to be children now who say in their 20s, 'Do you remember the Christmas when we sat around the radio to listen to Harry Potter?'.

"Only Radio 4 has the bottle to put Harry Potter on at Christmas unabridged."

Mr Fry, who is filming in Seville, welcomed the news that his Harry Potter reading would be broadcast in full.

He said: "Reading Harry Potter books out loud is more fun than I feel a single human being could ever deserve. It's like swimming in chocolate."

Other Christmas and winter highlights included a new production of Lewis Carroll Through the Looking Glass with John Bird and John Fortune playing Tweedledum and Tweedledee.

There will also be a 30-minute repeat extract from the Just William stories, with Martin Jarvis reading the moment when William first meets Violet Elizabeth Bott.

Stephen Fry and John Bird will star as two ex-BBC radio controllers in another series of Mark Tavener's Absolute Power.

webTitle: Granada boss bullish despite fears over ad prospects

fields.headline: Granada boss bullish despite fears over ad prospects
fields.standfirst:
Nov 29: ITV gets cold feet over News at Ten
Nov 29: Granada rethinks ONdigital float
Nov 29: ONdigital appoints interactive chief
fields.trailText:
4pm update: Granada Media boss Charles Allen has shrugged off fears that falling advertising revenues will continue to dog his company next year, writes Dan Milmo.
Nov 29: ITV gets cold feet over News at Ten
Nov 29: Granada rethinks ONdigital float
Nov 29: ONdigital appoints interactive chief
fields.body:
Granada Media boss Charles Allen has shrugged off fears that falling advertising revenues will continue to dog his company next year.

Despite posting a rise in full-year revenues and profits, analysts remain concerned about Granada's advertising prospects, reviving the concerns that pummelled the company's shares last month.

Granada reported a downturn in year-on-year advertising revenues for October, contributing to a stock market decline that sent the company's shares below 400p.

Mr Allen said: "All the companies which used advertising were affected by a downturn in the market, from TF1 to Carlton.

"You cannot just extrapolate one month's advertising performance when we had an 8.4% increase in advertising turnover for the whole year."

Granada Media's chairman added that it was "a bit too early to tell" how the advertising market would be affected next year as internet companies begin to run out of cash.

"We are in the midst of negotiating prices, but we are going into it more confidently than we might have done in October," he said.

However, analysts have predicted that advertising growth will be limited to 3.5% next year before returning to its usual range of 4% to 6%. Continuing uncertainty over such a vital revenue stream saw Granada's shares fall 3.5p to 378.5p by late afternoon.

Granada believes much of the downturn will be offset by the 2.5 extra minutes of peak-time advertising space that ITV will receive when the News at Ten returns in January.

The Independent Television Commission offered the space as a sweetener for demanding the return of the flagship bulletin.

Steve Morrison, chief executive of Granada Media, said: "The flexibility that the ITC has given us will be very helpful because we have the opportunity to have more or less breaks as we choose in our peak-time programmes.

"Advertisers have been very worried about the clutter around their adverts."

webTitle: Tenants back councils as landlords

fields.headline: Fair renting
fields.standfirst: Tenants back councils as landlords
fields.trailText: Tenants back councils as landlords
fields.body:
More than three in four council tenants would prefer to rent from their local authority than from any other landlord, a survey suggests. And more than a quarter of housing association tenants would rather live in council-owned property.

The findings, from the British Social Attitudes (BSA) annual survey, published yesterday, offer little support for the government's view that council housing is past its "sell by" date and should be transferred to other landlords. But the academic who has written up the findings says they do not disprove the case for such transfers.

According to the survey, which comprises more than 3,000 interviews with a representative social sample across Britain, more than half the public think councils provide better value for money than private landlords. Local authorities also score higher on providing long-term tenancy security, charging reasonable rents and providing good standard housing.

Council tenants themselves are especially likely to rate their landlord highly, with 78% saying they prefer to rent from the local authority. Among housing association tenants, this "loyalty" factor is only 63%, while 27% say they would rather rent from the council; and 46% agree they would "like to live in council housing if I could get it".

Where councils do seem to fall down in the public's mind is in relation to housing estates, rather than the accommodation itself. Only 32% of the public and 52% of council tenants regard most council estates as "generally pleasant places to live". Councils appear to have a poor reputation for carrying out repairs and maintenance, with 56% of their tenants saying the standard is poor.

One way in which the government is attempting to combat poor neighbourhoods is by increasing mixed tenure, encouraging homeowners and private renters to move into areas dominated by council housing. The survey shows that 59% of people favour council housing being made available to people on a range of incomes, rather than confined to the poorest sections of society. Among council tenants, 77% think there should be this kind of social mix.

However, despite the general vote of approval for council housing, the vast majority of people continue to aspire to buy their own home. According to the survey, 87% would choose to buy rather than rent if cost was not an issue.

Peter Kemp, professor of housing and social policy at Glasgow University and author of the BSA report's analysis of council housing issues, believes the findings should not be seen as an unequivocal warning against the government's drive to transfer council housing.

"The survey clearly shows council estates have a poor reputation," he says. "Because of limits on public spending, stock transfers may be the price that council tenants have to pay to improve their estates, even though most would currently rather rent from the council."

On more than 75 estates across the country, Kemp points out, council tenants have already voted to transfer to a not-for-profit landlord offering to guarantee rents and security of tenure, while promising a host of physical improvements.

 British Social Attitudes: Focusing on Diversity is published by Sage at £35

webTitle: Is Karpin the new Bosman?

fields.headline: Is Karpin the new Bosman?
fields.trailText: A Spanish judge has paved the way for another Bosman ruling by deciding that Celta Vigo's Russian midfielder Valery Karpin has the same rights as any European Union player.
fields.body:
A Spanish judge has paved the way for another Bosman ruling by deciding that Celta Vigo's Russian midfielder Valery Karpin has the same rights as any European Union player.

As the law stands in Spain, teams can play any amount of native EU players - but can only have five non-EU players on their books, and only three on the pitch at one time.

But the ruling by Madrid judge Fausto Gonzalez could change everything. Gonzalez has decided that Karpin must be counted as an EU player - and not as a foreign player - because of Russia's associate agreement with the European community.

The decision, while restricted to Karpin's case, could have far reaching consequences if followed on by other foreign players from Romania, Croatia, Turkey and Slovenia - countries that also have associate accords with the EU.

The ruling could also influence current rules in Britain where, while there is no quota on non-EU players, they must pass strict criteria before receiving a work permit. A successful challenge to the current rules would almost certainly result in a greater influx of foreigners into the Premiership.

Spain's official sports body, the Superior Sports Council, as well as the soccer federation and league committee said they would respect the ruling but would appeal it. They had previously denied Karpin's request to have EU status.

"I was always hopeful," Karpin admitted. "I took this decision because it benefited me, but I never thought I'd be a pioneer. It will be good for the league but bad for Spanish players," he added.

Celta said it planned to play Karpin as a community player in its next game on Saturday against Barcelona.

webTitle: Peace breaks out in pro-European Italy

fields.headline: Peace breaks out in pro-European Italy
fields.standfirst:
If the Italians can suspend vicious political feuding for the sake of EU integration, why can't we? asks Rory Carroll

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: If the Italians can suspend vicious political feuding for the sake of EU integration, why can't we? asks Rory Carroll in Rome.
fields.body:
If there was any doubt about the importance of next week's European Union summit in Nice, Italy just killed it. The government and opposition, breathless from hurling insults in a toxic election campaign, called a ceasefire to present a united front at Nice.

Foes who routinely trade accusations of corruption and political illegitimacy realised this was one challenge they could not afford to botch.

In a miracle of cross-party backing, only the far-left Refounded Communists voted against giving the ruling centre-left coalition a mandate for negotiations.

At stake is reform of EU decision-making, the entry of new members and a charter of rights. A knuckledusting clash is expected in areas where the 15 member governments' interests diverge.

Only last week it appeared that the summit, like so much else, would get sucked into the vortex of electioneering.

As fervent EU enthusiasts, Italians were happy with the government's strategy of deepening integration by seeking to limit the number of commissioners, curtail the veto, give teeth to the charter and allow groups of members to pursue enhanced cooperation.

That the head of the European commission was Romano Prodi, its former prime minister, was an added incentive for Italy's government to endorse integration.

Silvio Berlusconi, who leads the the centre-right opposition, is a Europhile - yet his first instinct was to block the charter. Slowly he shifted position, but supporting a government he denounced as communist and incompetent did not come easy.

Allying with enemies who wanted to destroy him was bad enough, and not so long ago Mr Prodi was his nemesis. But there was another difficulty.

His unpredictable electoral ally, Umberto Bossi, had taken to bashing the EU and the proposed charter, which he said was a communist plot to impose a constitution. Mr Bossi threatened to march on Nice with 100,000 members of his Northern League, prompting a slapping down by a mortified Mr Berlusconi, who craves mainstream respectability.

Polls suggest the media magnate's coalition will sweep back to power in elections due by next April.

The prime minister, Giuliano Amato, appeared to stir things up last week by saying a xenophobic party existed in Italy - widely interpreted as a dig at the anti-immigration Northern League. "Europe does not accept intolerance, xenophobia, racism," he said. "Neither does Europe accept every existing difference in the name of respect for all. It is crucial we proclaim this charter of rights at Nice."

Rancour bubbled through the debates in parliament but this week a bipartisan spirit emerged. The lower house backed Mr Amato's formal request for cross-party backing.

For an institution too divided to enact badly needed domestic reforms, it was astonishing. "It is a success of the centre-left coalition and of parliament,"said Mr Amato.

Marco Follini, of the opposition centrist CCD party, said: "With today's bipartisan vote, the idea of any division between the blocs on European policy has been removed once and for all."

Mr Berlusconi earned credit for taming Mr Bossi, at least for now. The Northern League said it would not tolerate any future plan for a European constitution without consulting citizens and the regions directly, especially on questions of immigration.

Praise too has been heaped on President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, who drained partisan bile with an article in La Stampa. "A European charter would serve to tell the world, and even more so ourselves, who we are and what we believe in."

For Italy such a collective effort is a major accomplishment which leaves Italians in no doubt about the significance of next week's summit.

Unlike the British, who until very recently were told by their government that it was just another meeting.

At stake is reform of EU decision-making, the entry of new members and a charter of rights. A knuckledusting clash is expected in areas where the 15 member governments' interests diverge. Only last week it appeared that the summit, like so much else, would get sucked into the vortex of electioneering. As fervent EU enthusiasts, Italians were happy with the government's strategy of deepening integration by seeking to limit the number of commissioners, curtail the veto, give teeth to the charter and allow groups of members to pursue enhanced cooperation. That the head of the European commission was Romano Prodi, its former prime minister, was an added incentive for Italy's government to endorse integration. Silvio Berlusconi, who leads the the centre-right opposition, is a Europhile - yet his first instinct was to block the charter. Slowly he shifted position, but supporting a government he denounced as communist and incompetent did not come easy. Allying with enemies who wanted to destroy him was bad enough, and not so long ago Mr Prodi was his nemesis. But there was another difficulty. His unpredictable electoral ally, Umberto Bossi, had taken to bashing the EU and the proposed charter, which he said was a communist plot to impose a constitution. Mr Bossi threatened to march on Nice with 100,000 members of his Northern League, prompting a slapping down by a mortified Mr Berlusconi, who craves mainstream respectability. Polls suggest the media magnate's coalition will sweep back to power in elections due by next April. The prime minister, Giuliano Amato, appeared to stir things up last week by saying a xenophobic party existed in Italy - widely interpreted as a dig at the anti-immigration Northern League. "Europe does not accept intolerance, xenophobia, racism," he said. "Neither does Europe accept every existing difference in the name of respect for all. It is crucial we proclaim this charter of rights at Nice." Rancour bubbled through the debates in parliament but this week a bipartisan spirit emerged. The lower house backed Mr Amato's formal request for cross-party backing. For an institution too divided to enact badly needed domestic reforms, it was astonishing. "It is a success of the centre-left coalition and of parliament,"said Mr Amato. Marco Follini, of the opposition centrist CCD party, said: "With today's bipartisan vote, the idea of any division between the blocs on European policy has been removed once and for all." Mr Berlusconi earned credit for taming Mr Bossi, at least for now. The Northern League said it would not tolerate any future plan for a European constitution without consulting citizens and the regions directly, especially on questions of immigration. Praise too has been heaped on President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, who drained partisan bile with an article in La Stampa. "A European charter would serve to tell the world, and even more so ourselves, who we are and what we believe in." For Italy such a collective effort is a major accomplishment which leaves Italians in no doubt about the significance of next week's summit. Unlike the British, who until very recently were told by their government that it was just another meeting. webTitle: Turner winner riles the Stuckists

fields.headline: Turner winner riles the Stuckists
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Turner prize 2000
fields.trailText: Photographer Wolfgang Tillmans beat an embroiderer, an artfully arranged pile of rubbish, and a painter accused of plagiarising the work of an obscure science fiction illustrator, to take the £20,000 Turner prize last night.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Photographer Wolfgang Tillmans beat an embroiderer, an artfully arranged pile of rubbish, and a painter accused of plagiarising the work of an obscure science fiction illustrator, to take the £20,000 Turner prize last night.

German-born Tillmans, who has worked and exhibited in London in recent years, has smashed the boundary between commercial photography and art: much of his early work was for fashion magazines, including a famous image of four of his friends sitting in the branches of a tree, not wearing any clothes at all.

The jury said his work engaged with contemporary culture, while challenging conventional aesthetics. The panel, headed by the Tate director, Sir Nicholas Serota, declared itself impressed by his ability to create striking images from everyday subjects, and said he was taking photography in new directions, not only in technique but also in presentation.

The triumph of a photographer was a bonus for the Stuckists, the anarchic art movement co-founded by Billy Childish, a former boyfriend of artist Tracy Emin - the name comes from her bitter insult that his art was stuck - who turned up in clown suits last night to picket the awards ceremony at Tate Britain in London.

The Stuckists are scathing about the Turner prize, and the Tate director, saying both have betrayed the traditional skills of drawing and painting. Sir Nicholas lashed back in his Dimbleby lecture last week: the new media - including video, sound pieces and conceptual art - were here to stay, he said; there was no chance that contemporary art would "come to its senses" and turn the clock back.

This year's shortlist was a poor platform for Stuckist protests, with Glenn Brown working in oil on canvas with a technique described as "old masterly", and Michael Raedecker's delicate figurative landscapes in paint and embroidery. But Tillmans's success was a gift to them. "Art is art and photography is photography," snarled co-founder Charles Thompson, a painter.

Tillmans's victory - he was an early favourite of the bookmakers - was overshadowed by bickering about whether imitation of one artist's work by another is flattery or plagiarism.

The Turner prize has lifted contemporary art on to a new publicity plane, partly by generating an annual row about the nature of art. In the past the dispute has been about Tracy Emin's rumpled bed (pipped for last year's prize), Chris Ofili's elephant dung (which took the prize two years ago) and Damien Hirst's pickled shark (a winner in 1995).

This year there seemed nothing to fight about except the fact that three of the four artists were not born in Britain, and that the shy Japanese Tomoko Takahashi works with carefully arranged piles of rubbish.

The calm was broken with the 11th-hour revelation, emanating from science fiction addicts with long memories, that a huge canvas by Glenn Brown borrowed heavily from a 1974 Pan book jacket by Anthony Roberts, for a novel called Double Star.

The fact that Mr Brown's other works on show borrowed equally heavily from Watteau, Auerbach and Salvador Dali, and that the painting was labelled "The Loves of the Shepherds (after Tony Roberts)" did nothing to quell the storm. Copyright experts and the Association of Illustrators said they were uneasy.

By last night Anthony Roberts had been tracked down in East Sussex, and seemed amused rather than outraged: he'd known nothing about it, he said, and this was the only Turner prize exhibition he'd missed in years.

Glenn Brown said he had tried to contact the publishers, but got no response. "I'm a fan of all the artists I refer to, including Tony Roberts. I pick artists I like and those that I feel aren't given enough credit, such as Watteau, John Martin and Chris Foss." He also maintained he had "radically altered Roberts's work in terms of scale and colour".

The critics may have come to blows, but this year's artists took an instant liking to one another. Usually the winner is swept off by his gallery to get on with the prime purpose of the Turner prize - selling at instantly inflated prices - while the losers skulk away. Last night, for the first time anyone can recall, the four artists held a joint party, at the old Shoreditch town hall.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief: Actor Ethan Hawke find director's chair uncomfortable
fields.standfirst: Plus: Plus, Liz Hurley re-signs to modelling contract; Geena Davis to marry for the fourth time; The Sound of Music child stars reunited for the first time in 35 years
fields.trailText: Plus: Plus, Liz Hurley re-signs to modelling contract; Geena Davis to marry for the fourth time; The Sound of Music child stars reunited for the first time in 35 years
fields.body:
 Ethan Hawke (pictured) has told of the tedium of being in the director's chair for his new project, Last Word on Paradise. He told the Sunday Times magazine, "It has been an unbelievable amount of work. I had no idea how tedious directing could be." An ensemble piece, the film, which follows the activities of 30 people staying in the infamous Chelsea Hotel in New York, will star his wife, Uma Thurman, Natasha Richardson and Kris Kristofferson, and features a score by Yoko Ono. Hawke will next be seen playing the dithering protagonist in a modernised version of Hamlet which will be released in the UK on 15 December.

 Following the news that Elizabeth Hurley is close to landing a $4.2m (£2.96m) deal to advertise a 'revolutionary' gel-filled bra, the Daily Mirror have reported that 35-year-old Hurley has, after weeks of speculation, also re-signed to her £2 million-a-year contract with Estee Lauder. The Bedazzled star is said to be 'ecstatic' over the deal after suggestions that she was perhaps a bit long in the tooth to front a cosmetics campaign. In the event the British star came out on top, beating off tough competition from her junior of seven years, Gwyneth Paltrow.

 Geena Davis is set to marry husband number four according to American film site Mr Showbiz. The 44-year-old Thelma and Louise star will marry Reza Jarrahy, a California surgeon who is 16 years her junior, after a two-year relationship. Davis was formerly hitched to actor Jeff Goldblum, director Renny Harlin and restaurant manager Richard Emmolo.

 The seven actors who played the all singing, all dancing Von Trapp children in The Sound of Music have been reunited for the first time since the film was released 35 years ago, according to the BBC website. The former child stars, who were aged between five and 21 when they last saw each other, were brought back together by Yorkshire Television for a documentary about the making of the musical which earned over £600 million at the box office and won five Oscars. The hour-long special of ITV's After They Were Famous, which features previously unseen footage about the making of the musical, will be screened at Christmas.

webTitle: Charlie's Angels fly to top of UK box office list

fields.headline: Charlie's Angels fly to top of UK box office list
fields.trailText: Debuting at number one on the UK box office chart, Charlie's Angels takes nearly six times as much money as its nearest rival
fields.body:
Charlie must be so proud of his trio of angels, who blasted their way straight to the top of the UK Box Office chart after a take-no-prisoners opening weekend. The immediate success of Charlie's Angels in Britain came on the same weekend that it reached the $100,000,000m (£70,500,000m) mark in America and continued to score strongly in territories across the globe.

Since the colourful update of the 1970s television series opened on Friday, the much-hyped movie has taken over £3m in ticket sales, according to figures from the screen daily website, making it the biggest opener since Scary Movie on September 8.

The combination of Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu was enough to earn nearly six times more than second-placed What Lies Beneath, but the Michelle Pfeiffer/Harrison Ford thriller is still showing an admirable durability, having spent an impressive six weeks in the top three.

The weekend's second highest opener was the teen thriller The Skulls, starring Joshua Jackson from the cult TV series Dawson's Creek. But with box office takings of £149,297, it failed to make the top ten and ended up in eleventh place.

Other releases over the weekend included the Holocaust documentary, Into The Arms Of Strangers, which took £14,304, and the controversial Australian thriller, Chopper, which earned £53,383 to reach number 16 in the chart.

Meanwhile, O Brother, Where Art Thou?, starring George Clooney, has become the first film by the Coen Brothers to pass the £3m mark in the UK. After 11 weeks on release, it has made £3,011,796. The last film by the critically-lauded brother partnership, The Big Lebowski, took only £1.89m in 1998.

webTitle: Con or cure: alternative medicine in the NHS

fields.headline: Con or cure?
fields.trailText: Well regulated therapies acceptable within the NHS
fields.body:
Well regulated therapies acceptable within the NHS

Acupuncture: Chinese practice of inserting small needles into the body to stimulate nerve impulses.

Chiropractic: Treatment of musculo-skeletal complaints by through adjusting muscles, tendons and joints using manipulation and massage techniques.

Osteopathy: Similar to chiropractic but underlying theory is that impairment of blood supply, rather than nerves, causes problems.

Herbal medicine: Using plant extracts to treat disorders and maintain good health.

Homeopathy: Treatment involves giving people tiny doses, much diluted, of substances that in larger doses would cause the symptoms that are the problem.

Feel-good therapies that can be used alongside convent-ional medicine and do no harm.

Alexander Technique: Improving general health by teaching good posture.

Aromatherapy: Plant extract oils inhaled or used as massage oil to alleviate symptoms or as relaxant. Common in France.

Hypnotherapy: Use of hypnosis to treat behavioural disease and dysfunction.

Reflexology: Massage of the feet on the theory that each organ has a corresponding location in the foot.

Shiatsu: Japanese massage aiming to increase body's healing ability with light pressure on points across the body.

Alternative treatments which the committee found scientifically unproven and unregulated

Ayurvedic medicine: Ancient Indian discipline based on mind-spirit-body interaction, employing natural herbs, usually in mixtures for treatment.

Naturopathy: Stimulating the body's natural responses through diet, herbs and exposure to sun and fresh air.

Traditional Chinese medicine: Theory that imbalance of yin and yang energy causes symptoms, using acupuncture, herbal medicine, massage and exercise for treatment.

Crystal therapy: Crystals, said to absorb and transmit energy, used to "tune" the body by being placed in patterns around it.

Iridology: Diagnosing health problems through studying the iris of the eye and noting marks and changes.

webTitle: Tribal DDB wins Revolution banner ad prize

fields.headline: Tribal DDB wins Revolution banner ad prize
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Digital agency Tribal DDB has won Revolution magazine's first ever banner advertising competition, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Digital agency Tribal DDB has won Revolution magazine's first ever banner ad competition.

The contest, which was set up to highlight the level of creativity possible within a banner ad, was in aid of children's charity Sparks.

Five agencies including Tribal DDB, Profero, Oasis Communications, Syzygy and Gluemedia took part in the competition. Their entries were posted across DoubleClick's sales network during October.

John Shanley, chief executive of Sparks, said: "We appreciate the time given by the agencies and all of the judges, as well as Doubleclick and Revolution.

"Tribal was my favourite entry as it captured everything we do - sports, kids and fund-raising."

The banners were judged on brand building and creativity, click-through rate and donations generated. Overall winner Tribal came top of all categories, followed by Gluemedia.

Judges were Graham Tolhurst, chief executive of Scoot-Loot online, Jim Rose, chief executive officer at QXL, Alex Kovach, managing director at Lycos UK and Ireland, David Kester of D&AD, John Shanley, chief executive of Sparks and Philip Smith, deputy editor of Revolution.
