webTitle: Anti-fakes campaign unveiled

fields.headline: Government launches fight against fake brands
fields.trailText: 2pm: The government today launched a clampdown on fake Gucci, knock-off Nike trainers and other counterfeit goods, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government today launched a clampdown on fake Gucci, knock-off Nike trainers and other counterfeit goods.

Well-known names including Four Weddings and a Funeral producer Duncan Kenworthy, author Joanna Trollope and Pokemon character Pikachu gathered in central London to kick off the campaign by destroying a giant pile of pirate goods with a 17-ton industrial shredder.

The battle against fake goods is being led by consumer affairs minister Kim Howells, who today opened a government conference dedicated to exploring the effect of counterfeiting on industry and consumers.

Mr Howells said: "I want more people to be aware of counterfeiting, not just big business. Fake goods are at best poor quality, at worst very dangerous.

"Counterfeiters cost jobs by putting legitimate retailers out of business and they help fund organised crime. It is only by making sure that consumers are properly informed that we can reduce the demand for fakes and drive the counterfeiters out of work."

Richard Puddephatt, chairman of the Anti-Counterfeiting Group, warned Christmas shoppers to be alert to the dangers of counterfeiters.

"If you are offered a product at well below its usual value, then it is probably a fake. If in doubt, don't buy it," he said.

webTitle: Chronic shortage of midwives 'puts lives at risk'

fields.headline: Chronic shortage of midwives 'puts lives at risk'
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian.co.uk: NHS staff
fields.trailText:
Chronic shortages of midwives and huge regional variations in maternity services mean new mothers' needs are being neglected and lives put at risk, the Royal College of Midwives said today.
SocietyGuardian.co.uk: NHS staff
fields.body:
Chronic shortages of midwives and huge regional variations in maternity services mean new mothers' needs are being neglected and lives put at risk, the Royal College of Midwives said today.

MPs from all parties have joined forces to launch a new group which will investigate standards of maternity care throughout the country.

Midwives have been warning for months that low morale in the profession has contributed to worrying staff shortages and potentially dangerous working practices.

Last year only two thirds of deliveries were carried out by a midwife rather than an obstetrician, down from almost three quarters in 1996.

The Royal College of Midwives has warned that its members are being forced to work double shifts to make up for staff shortages, and many maternity units cannot offer women constant one-to-one care while they are in labour.

Caesarean sections now account for almost one in five births, despite evidence that unnecessary medical intervention can be harmful to mother and baby.

The government has pledged to supply an extra 20,000 nurses and midwives by 2004 but it is unclear how many of those will be midwives.

Recent research showed that out of the 5,744 midwives working in the NHS this year, 550 had joined in the last 12 months but 531 had left, making a net gain of just 19 staff.

The all-party parliamentary group on maternity care launched today will address standards of care and raise awareness of the problems.

Chairman Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, said: "Maternity services care for over 600,000 women and babies each year and yet there are huge variations in the quality of service women receive nationally.

"Some women may not receive specialist care when it is needed, while others may be put at risk by unnecessary medical intervention.

"Women's social needs are often neglected, especially in the postnatal period, often putting family relationships and even children at risk."

Health minister Yvette Cooper said: "Clearly, every woman should have a midwife present at birth - that is absolutely the bottom line.

"But under the last government, in fact, what happened between 1991 and 1997 the number of midwives working in the NHS dropped by over 1,000.

"Now since the election this government has increased the number of midwives working in the NHS. It has been going up, it has to go up further, and that is absolutely clear in the NHS plan.

"But it is clear as well that some areas face particular pressures and they are suffering as a result of the long-term underfunding that the NHS has experienced across the board. We are turning that round."

Chairman Julia Drown, Labour MP for Swindon South, said: "Maternity services care for over 600,000 women and babies each year and yet there are huge variations in the quality of service women receive nationally. "Some women may not receive specialist care when it is needed, while others may be put at risk by unnecessary medical intervention. "Women's social needs are often neglected, especially in the postnatal period, often putting family relationships and even children at risk." Health minister Yvette Cooper said: "Clearly, every woman should have a midwife present at birth - that is absolutely the bottom line. "But under the last government, in fact, what happened between 1991 and 1997 the number of midwives working in the NHS dropped by over 1,000. "Now since the election this government has increased the number of midwives working in the NHS. It has been going up, it has to go up further, and that is absolutely clear in the NHS plan. "But it is clear as well that some areas face particular pressures and they are suffering as a result of the long-term underfunding that the NHS has experienced across the board. We are turning that round." webTitle: Feuding doctors making vengeful claims

fields.headline: Feuding doctors making vengeful claims
fields.trailText: Vindictive and unfounded allegations made by feuding doctors are pushing up the number of outside investigations commissioned by hospital authorities, the president of the Royal College of Surgeons said.
fields.body:
Vindictive and unfounded allegations made by feuding doctors are pushing up the number of outside investigations commissioned by hospital authorities, the president of the Royal College of Surgeons said.

Barry Jackson yesterday revealed that personality clashes between members of surgical teams accounted for a "significant minority" of complaints that prompted health trusts to call the college's rapid response teams in the last 16 months.

He called for a different culture in hospitals as a new system of professional conduct and appraisal was introduced. Teams from the college have conducted 30 investigations into alleged problems ranging from poor performance to specific surgical mistakes. A dozen more are under way.

One or two of the investigations had included recommendations that the trust involved should refer a surgeon to the General Medical Council. Others had led to calls for further training for doctors or management changes. But in at least five cases investigators could find nothing wrong.

Mr Jackson was worried about surgery investigations that found personality clashes had prompted allegations. "Sometimes it is a case of one surgeon being vindictive. They know that someone is having a short run of bad results and instead of talking to each other, because there is a personality clash, one of them makes a complaint or implies someone is performing poorly when they are not." Such clashes were "not infrequent" said Mr Jackson and he found them "upsetting and disturbing."

This month, an independent report commissioned by the NHS executive found rivalry between surgeons at the Oxford heart centre had helped bring the unit to its knees. The royal college sets educational and training requirements for surgeons and sets standards for good practice. But the GMC is the body responsible for discipline and good conduct.

webTitle: A new face for university heads

fields.headline: A new face for university heads
fields.trailText: A new name, a new leader, and a new era. The appointment of Professor Roderick Floud, provost of London Guildhall university, as the next leader of the country's university heads makes history in more than one way. Floud will be the first president of 'Universities UK' - the group formerly known as the Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals.
fields.body:
A new name, a new leader, and a new era. The appointment of Professor Roderick Floud, provost of London Guildhall university, as the next leader of the country's university heads makes history in more than one way. Floud will be the first president of 'Universities UK' - the group formerly known as the Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals.

He will also become the first head of a new university - established in 1992 -to champion the collective concerns of the whole academic sector, both old and new. It is, as well, a university only recently relieved from severe financial pressures. Floud's day to day management of London Guildhall is likely to be a very different experience to those of previous incumbents of the head of universities. The last three leaders have come from research rich Russell group institutions.

As a member of the coalition of modern universities, Floud is likely to bring a different emphasis to the job. He has been a strong advocate of the regional role played by universities. (Currently he is an observer on the London Development Agency.) Access and mature students are other major concerns for the 56 year old.

In a Guardian article this month, he argued that the £20m recently announced by the government for attracting more students from poor backgrounds onto degree courses was "but a drop in the ocean". The big expense, he said, will be helping these new students to get their degrees; adapting to more flexible study patterns, which will see the concepts of "term" and "vacation" wither as internet and intranet give access to learning 24 hours a day.

Floud was one of group of new university heads who wrote to the Guardian last month complaining that the latest performance indicators for academic institutions grossly underestimated "both the level of disadvantage in London and the contribution of the capital's universities in working to address this problem".

But to focus exclusively on these interests would be to belie his all-round academic credentials.

Another distinguishing feature of Floud, for example is that he is, unusually, a university chief still actively engaged in research. He is a respected member of the growing international band of auxologists, academics who study human growth, and argue that height measurement of children could be developed as a cheap and effective way to tell how aid programs are working in developing nations. Floud was also a member of the steering group overseeing the fundamental review of research by the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

He is also not unaware of the academic life enjoyed in more ancient surroundings. After a first degree at Oxford and later a DPhil at Nuffield College, Floud became fellow, tutor and director of studies at Emmanuel College. (According to one university guide, the bike riding habit continues to this day.) Floud came to London, to become Professor of Modern History in Birkbeck College, at the age of only 33. For the last 12 years he has been provost of London Guildhall university.

A big plus for the senior policy-making circuit, he also has international experience under his belt: including a stint at Standford, and membership of the Council of European Rectors Committee.

As CVCP vice president and chair of the England and Northern Ireland council, he is already a name to call for journalists. The calls are likely to intensify after 1 August 2001 when he becomes president - a position lasting until 31 July 2003.

There are some tough challenges ahead. Despite being popular and respected among other vice-chancellors, Floud won the election for presidency by only one vote. It is likely that the vote among university heads was largely divided along old and new university lines. Part of the job will be to retain a unified stance for universities with very different aims, traditions and localities at a time when the future funding of the academic sector is uncertain.

Floud faces the post-election debate on university fees and finance, an issue as divisive as any in higher education circles. Allowing universities to charge differential fees and recruit as many students as they want threatens to split the entire sector. That would be history making that Floud would definitely not want to be associated with.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief: Steven Soderbergh frets about Rat Pack remake
fields.standfirst: Plus: Welsh peaks may double for Himalayas; Dench and Gooding Jr add their voices to Disney musical; Kelly Preston joins Gwyneth Paltrow in comedy; casting for main roles in Spider-Man nearly complete
fields.trailText: Plus: Welsh peaks may double for Himalayas; Dench and Gooding Jr add their voices to Disney musical; Kelly Preston joins Gwyneth Paltrow in comedy; casting for main roles in Spider-Man nearly complete
fields.body:
 Steven Soderbergh (pictured) is worried that his remake of the Rat Pack film, Ocean's Eleven, will struggle to live up to the original. "It's going to require a set of skills which I don't think is inherent in me, and that's part of the challenge, that's what scares me about it," Soderbergh told reporters. "While it would be a mistake to do a literal remake, it will have to be a bit of a hybrid. It requires a certain slickness and a certain sheen, but at the same time it needs to be funky." In the director's tribute to the Las Vegas heist movie, the parts originally played by Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jr will be taken by George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Matt Damon, and Soderbergh's Erin Brockovich star, Julia Roberts, is also in the cast. However, the project has already hit problems as Brad Pitt is running over schedule on his current project, The Spy Game, which is holding up production on Soderbergh's remake.

 The Welsh valleys could become the setting for a number of Bollywood films if an advertising campaign in India is successful. The film commissions of north, mid and south Wales are targeting Bombay - the home of movie-making in India - in an attempt to spread awareness of the the benefits of using Welsh locations. Yvonne Cheal of the south Wales film Commission has just spent a week in Bombay meeting producers and directors and finding out how techniques differ on the subcontinent. "I was on a fact-finding mission to find out how they shot films and what sort of locations they need," she said.

 Judi Dench and Cuba Gooding Jr are to lend their voices to Disney's animated musical western Sweating Bullets, according to the The Hollywood Reporter The pair will join Sex in the City star, Sarah Jessica Parker, on the project which is to be directed by Will 'The Road to El Dorado Finn' and John Sanford. The film, which is about a group of cows who join together to save their farm, has been in development for several years, but has not yet started production.

 The Hollywood Reporter reports that Kelly Preston has signed up to star opposite Gwyneth Paltrow in the forthcoming comedy, A View from the Top. Preston will play an air-hostess who encounters the ambitious Paltrow as she rises from humble beginnings to reach the top of her trade. The film, which will be helmed by the Brazilian director Bruno Barreto, is due to start shooting next month.

 Sony Pictures have announced that James Franco is in final negotiations to play Spider-Man's best friend, Harry Osborn, in the forthcoming big-screen version of the Marvel comic. The relatively unknown actor, who recently finished filming the Martin Scorsese-produced Deuces Wild, will play the high school pal and college roommate of Spider-Man's alter ego, Peter Parker (Tobey Maguire), and the son of Norman Osborn/The Green Goblin (Willem Dafoe). The film is slated to begin shooting in Los Angeles in January, before moving to New York, and is due for release in May 2002.

webTitle: Train misery as derailment wrecks four miles of track

fields.headline: Train misery as derailment wrecks four miles of track
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Train passengers faced fresh travel misery today after four miles of track were damaged by a goods train derailment on a busy commuter  line.
fields.body:
Train passengers faced fresh travel misery today after four miles of track were damaged by a goods train derailment on a busy commuter line.

The freight train, from which two wagons were derailed, was blocking the south entrance to Northampton station causing the Silverlink train company to put on buses to ferry passengers from Northampton to Milton Keynes.

But the company said it did not have enough buses to cope with rush-hour demand and advised passengers to try to avoid peak-time travel.

Silverlink also warned that it would take "some days" for the train to be removed and the track repaired.

An hour after the 1.30am incident today at Northampton, another goods train derailed on a freight-only line near Filton near Bristol. The locomotive of the train, which was transporting coal, ended up on its side after derailing on a set of points just before 2.30am.

In a statement the firm operating the freight train, EWS, said it believed the driver may have passed a red signal. The Northampton incident involved a 27-wagon train travelling from Tilbury in Essex to Garston, Merseyside.

The driver, who was unhurt, appeared to have carried on for four miles without realising two of his wagons had derailed. "There's damage to four miles of track and although we are running a substitute bus service from Northampton to Milton Keynes, we can't get enough buses to accommodate everyone," said a Silverlink spokesman.

"We had been advising passengers to avoid peak-time travel even before this. Now passengers must expect their journeys in the Northampton area will take more than an hour longer."

The Bristol derailment, involving a locomotive and three empty coal wagons, was near the A38 close to Filton airfield and was not affecting passenger services. A fire service spokesman said: "When we got there we were faced with a diesel locomotive on its side and two of the empty trucks had jackknifed across the track.

"The driver had escaped and we met him on the road. He was OK. The main problem we faced was the large amount of diesel which was spilling from the locomotive unit into the ballast under the track. "We put down a foam blanket to guard against fire and now it will up to Railtrack to clear that up."

EWS said: "The derailment happened 100 yards from signals where there is single line working. Early indications are that a signal was passed at danger, although this was an unusual operating situation that we are investigating."

Almost a month ago, two trains operated by EWS collided at Lawrence Hill station near the city centre. In that incident the driver of a Royal Mail train had an amazing escape when his engine ploughed into the back of a stationary coal train, riding up over it and coming to rest against a road bridge.

And in July this year 200 passengers on a First Great Western express had to be led to safety from a nearby tunnel after the driver spotted a landslide ahead of him.

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: CHAMPIONS RELEGATED
fields.body:
CHAMPIONS RELEGATED

"It looks likely that John Jensen's side Herfølge, who won the Danish championship last season, are going to get relegated this season. Has that ever happened to any other team in Europe?" asks Peter Kargaard.

"I'm sure many Manchester United supporters will, like me, be delighted to inform Mr Kargaard that Manchester City achieved this feat in 1937-38, having been champions in 1936-37," says Brian Spurrell. "The really delicious thing about that season is that the City somehow contrived to be relegated while scoring more goals than anybody else in the division, even the champions Arsenal."

Gerard Sugrue points out that Lyn Oslo took the champs-to-chumps route in Norway. "As I remember they met Leeds United in the 1969-1970 European Cup competition, losing 10-0 and 6-0," he says. "And because the Norwegian season ran through the summer, Lyn had already been relegated when they made their appearance in the European Cup. Which prompts the follow-up question: how many second division teams have appeared in the European Cup?"

Also in 1968, 1.FC Nuremberg won the last of their nine German championships and were relegated the following season. "They have never really recovered from this blow," says Andreas Lorenczuk.

The strangest decline of them all however was in Finland, where Tampereen Pallo-Veikot won the title in 1994 and were relegated the next season only for the same fate to afflict the 1995 champions Valkeakosken Haka. "The distance between Tampere and Valkeakoski is less than 20 miles," says Kari Tuovinen, "So there must have been some kind of curse on that area at that time." Sounds reasonable to us.

ON THE OTHER HAND ...

Kari also wants to know whether any other club in Europe has matched the achievement of Kuusysi from Lahti, who won the Finnish championship in 1981, the season after they were promoted.

That honour also belongs to 1.FC Kaiserslautern who, according to Andreas Lorenczuk, won the Cup in 1996 and were relegated only to gain immediate re-promotion in 1997 and win the championship in 1998. "So it can be done the other way round, too," Andreas observes. Are there any other examples?

WHY DOESN'T BECKS TAKE PENALTIES?

"Has David Beckham ever taken a penalty in a competitive match? If not, why not, considering he is probably the best dead-ball specialist in the Premiership (and possibly Europe)?" asks Ben Homer.

"I do remember him taking one during a penalty shoot-out in Morocco in 1998 for England against Belgium after a 0-0 draw," says Dominic Birch. "He did score quite comfortably, and was on the list to take one in the World Cup against Argentina, but of course his sending-off rendered him ineligible. I have never seen him take one for Manchester United."

Meanwhile Dave Chapman says: "Taking a penalty and a free-kick are two different kettles of fish. For the former, you are expected to score at least nine times out of 10. You may be in front of thousands of baying opposition fans, all urging you to miss, so you need someone who is good under pressure and can be relied on. Man Utd already have this in Dennis Irwin.

"There is little doubt that Beckham is highly impressive at free-kicks, but that doesn't mean he will necessarily score penalties with the same ease," he adds.

WHERE'S JORDI?

"Could you resolve an office dispute for me. Whatever happened to Jordi Cryuff? Is he still at the Man U?" asks Matt Underwood.

Let peace reign in your office once more, Matt. Jordi left Manchester United in the summer and is now playing for Alaves in Spain.

DERBY DUO

"Which two football players have played in a Liverpool, Manchester and Glasgow derby? Andrei Kanchelskis is definitely one - does anybody know the other?" asks Jane Beeton.

So far we've had three suggestions, all of which fall woefully short. Tom Dempster reckons it's Imre Varadi. But although football's original journeyman has played for a lot of clubs in his career (Everton, Newcastle United, Sheffield Wednesday, WBA, Manchester City, Leeds United, Luton Town, Rotherham United, Oxford United, Mansfield Town and Scunthorpe United at the last count) he never played in the Glasgow derby. Ditto Paul Stewart, a suggestion from Phil McClean.

Finally Richard Grady reckons it might be Ray Wilkins, but he never played in a Liverpool derby. So maybe Andrei is the only one.

LOSING HAT-TRICK HEROES?

"Can you settle an argument that threatens to destroy the tranquility of our workplace? 'Who (if anybody!) has scored a hat trick in an FA Cup final but still managed to play on the losing team?'" asks R Mann.

"There have only been two FA Cup finals in which the losing team has scored three goals or more," says Vidura Gunapala, "the famous Matthews Final of 1953 and the 1990 final between Manchester United and Crystal Palace (which went into extra time), neither of which had hat-tricks for the losing team."

Can you help?

"Which team has the most support within their own town/city? (i.e. which team's average gate is the highest percentage of the total population of the town/city they are based in?)" asks Richard Yorke.

"My father is very keen to ascertain who is the most prolific goalscorer - including internationals and all cup competitions - at Wembley Stadium? Can anybody help?" asks Steven Osbourne.

"Who scored the first hat-trick in an European cup final?" asks Hendo Bairstow Eves West.

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

"So it can be done the other way round, too," Andreas observes. Are there any other examples? WHY DOESN'T BECKS TAKE PENALTIES? "Has David Beckham ever taken a penalty in a competitive match? If not, why not, considering he is probably the best dead-ball specialist in the Premiership (and possibly Europe)?" asks Ben Homer. "I do remember him taking one during a penalty shoot-out in Morocco in 1998 for England against Belgium after a 0-0 draw," says Dominic Birch. "He did score quite comfortably, and was on the list to take one in the World Cup against Argentina, but of course his sending-off rendered him ineligible. I have never seen him take one for Manchester United." Meanwhile Dave Chapman says: "Taking a penalty and a free-kick are two different kettles of fish. For the former, you are expected to score at least nine times out of 10. You may be in front of thousands of baying opposition fans, all urging you to miss, so you need someone who is good under pressure and can be relied on. Man Utd already have this in Dennis Irwin. "There is little doubt that Beckham is highly impressive at free-kicks, but that doesn't mean he will necessarily score penalties with the same ease," he adds. WHERE'S JORDI? "Could you resolve an office dispute for me. Whatever happened to Jordi Cryuff? Is he still at the Man U?" asks Matt Underwood. Let peace reign in your office once more, Matt. Jordi left Manchester United in the summer and is now playing for Alaves in Spain. DERBY DUO "Which two football players have played in a Liverpool, Manchester and Glasgow derby? Andrei Kanchelskis is definitely one - does anybody know the other?" asks Jane Beeton. So far we've had three suggestions, all of which fall woefully short. Tom Dempster reckons it's Imre Varadi. But although football's original journeyman has played for a lot of clubs in his career (Everton, Newcastle United, Sheffield Wednesday, WBA, Manchester City, Leeds United, Luton Town, Rotherham United, Oxford United, Mansfield Town and Scunthorpe United at the last count) he never played in the Glasgow derby. Ditto Paul Stewart, a suggestion from Phil McClean. Finally Richard Grady reckons it might be Ray Wilkins, but he never played in a Liverpool derby. So maybe Andrei is the only one. 'Who (if anybody!) has scored a hat trick in an FA Cup final but still managed to play on the losing team?'" asks R Mann. "There have only been two FA Cup finals in which the losing team has scored three goals or more," says Vidura Gunapala, "the famous Matthews Final of 1953 and the 1990 final between Manchester United and Crystal Palace (which went into extra time), neither of which had hat-tricks for the losing team." Can you help? "Which team has the most support within their own town/city? (i.e. which team's average gate is the highest percentage of the total population of the town/city they are based in?)" asks Richard Yorke. "My father is very keen to ascertain who is the most prolific goalscorer - including internationals and all cup competitions - at Wembley Stadium? Can anybody help?" asks Steven Osbourne. "Who scored the first hat-trick in an European cup final?" asks Hendo Bairstow Eves West. Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: New Express owners set the tone with Beckhams' visit

fields.headline: New Express owners set the tone with Beckhams' visit
fields.trailText: Most newspapers receive distinguished guests from time to time: Tony Blair has dropped in on the Sun, and Princess Diana once called on the Guardian. But last night staff at the Express got a taste of things to come when their new proprietor proudly showed off his star turns, David and Victoria Beckham.
fields.body:
Most newspapers receive distinguished guests from time to time: Tony Blair has dropped in on the Sun, and Princess Diana once called on the Guardian. But last night staff at the Express got a taste of things to come when their new proprietor proudly showed off his star turns, David and Victoria Beckham.

After issuing an edict banning any reference in his newspapers to Mrs Beckham as "Posh Spice" - the term was said to be demeaning - Richard Desmond guided the celebrity couple round the editorial floors at Ludgate House in London, the home of his new newspaper empire.

Posh and Becks, who regularly grace the pages of Mr Desmond's celebrity magazine OK!, were introduced to be mused hacks on the Daily Express and the Star.

The charm offensive was designed to show off the newspapers' new friendly face: there will, it seems, be no more bitching about Victoria's dress sense or David's intellectual prowess.

"The place has gone completely mad. It's just totally bizarre. God knows what Rosie [Boycott, the Express editor] thinks about this," said one veteran at the in-house newsletter, Crusader.

The couple are Mr Desmond's biggest assets: OK! have run regular features on them, including an exclusive picture spread on their lavish wedding.

It was expected that pictures of the visit will appear in today's edition of the Express and Daily Star newspapers, just in time to promote the David Beckham Story, a documentary about the footballer and his wife which is screened tonight on ITV.

Mr Desmond acquired the newspaper group last week in a surprise £125m cash deal with United News & Media.

He has promised to spend "whatever it takes" to restore the Daily Express to its dominant position in the middle market. There will be more celebrity interviews and close cooperation with OK!, which is moving its offices into the Express building.

Some journalists at Ludgate House have taken offence at Mr Desmond's arrival: columnist Mary Kenny and political editor Anthony Bevins quit at the start of the week. Ms Kenny said she could not work for someone who also published pornography: Asian Babes and Forum magazine are among the titles in Mr Desmond's stable.

His takeover of the Express has set nerves on edge at the newspaper's main rival, the Daily Mail, which has entered talks with Hello! magazine, OK!'s principal competitor, about a deal to share celebrity exclusives.

webTitle: Hollick's handouts

fields.headline: Hollick's handouts
fields.trailText: 4pm: Lord Hollick has said goodbye and thank you to staff with personal cheques for a select few, writes Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
He earned a reputation as "an absentee landlord" who showed little interest in his three national newspaper titles

But now former proprietor Lord Hollick has shown some emotion by handing out bonuses of around £40,000 to a select band of staff at the Express.

Among those to receive the farewell-and-thank-you cheques are editor Rosie Boycott and chief City correspondent David Hellier.

Insiders say that Express deputy editor Chris Blackhurst and columnist Peter Oborne may also benefit from the peer's largesse.

Lord Hollick sold the newspaper titles to OK! publisher Richard Desmond last week, netting £125m for his company, United News & Media.

One insider said: "If only Hollick shared a bit of his money around while he was here. Everyone is staggered here. The word is that about a dozen senior editorial staff got the cheques."

webTitle: November 18 ratings

fields.headline: All eyes on Corrie
fields.trailText: 12.15pm TV overnights: Four out of 10 viewers joined Coronation Street's 40th anniversary celebrations last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's Coronation Street 40th anniversary celebrations kicked off last night to the delight of four in 10 viewers.

The 90 minute documentary, 40 Years on Coronation Street, packed with star interviews and revelations from celebrity fans, including Sir Cliff Richard, Cilla Black and Frank Skinner, averaged 8.5m and a 41% share.

SIr Cliff confessed he once dreamed of a walk-on part in which he would marry dizzy barmaid Raquel, played by Sarah Lancashire, and rescue her from the clutches of Curly Watts.

But Sir Cliff's fantasies were still no substitute for the real thing. Earlier in the evening, a special Tuesday edition of Coronation Street pulled in 12.7m viewers - more than one in two of the audience.

The soap is running every night this week in the run-up to next week's full-flown anniversary celebrations.

Channel 4's coverage of the Turner Prize awards attracted a select viewership from 8-9pm last night. The Turner Prize, presented by art critic and author Matthew Collings, had just 0.6m and a 2% share of the available audience.

webTitle: Kaye stars in new game show

fields.headline: Alien game show for Kaye on BBC2
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Paul Kaye, the man behind Dennis Pennis, is lining up a new game show for BBC2, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Paul Kaye, the man behind Dennis Pennis, is lining up a new game show for BBC2.

A pilot for Alien Abduction features Mr Kaye as Bob Cosmos, who "abducts" three contestants to his spaceship.

Before an audience dressed as aliens, the game show participants will have to answer questions about human behaviour and the workings of the human mind in order to win a passage out of the spaceship-style studio set and back to earth.

The broadcast pilot for Alien Abduction is to be shot in a London studio on December 11.

The show is being executive produced by Tiger Aspect head of entertainment Mark Linsey.

webTitle: US election: Baroness flies to Florida's rescue

fields.headline: Baroness flies to Florida's rescue
fields.standfirst:
Margaret Thatcher is jumping on the US election bandwagon by coming to Florida to attend a business seminar, writes Duncan Campbell in Tallahassee

US election race
fields.trailText: View from Florida/29 November 2000: Margaret Thatcher is jumping on the US election bandwagon by coming to Florida to attend a business seminar, writes Duncan Campbell in Tallahassee.
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher is coming to Florida. Since everyone else - from the world's most expensive lawyers to all of America's leading politicians - has beaten a path down to the sunshine state to add their expertise to solving the great puzzle of the Florida poll, it seems only logical that the baroness should be coming too.

But although news of her imminent arrival appeared in the local press this week, it did so in the form of an advertisement for a business seminar at which the baroness and General Colin Powell will both be appearing "live and in person". Included in the programme is one session entitled: "How to make your own lucky breaks".

This event, Success 2001, is one of the many strings attached to the former prime minister's bow and it can be assumed that she will not be coming cheap. The ad that alerts people to next February's $225-a-head event in Tampa announces its credo thus: "Winners concentrate on winning. Losers concentrate on getting by."

If that is really the case, where does it leave Al Gore and George W Bush? Mr Gore is certainly concentrating hard on winning and Mr Bush, while he has announced that he has won and is only waiting for Bill Clinton to hand him the keys, still gives much more of an impression of just getting by, as though it has only just struck him what he may have let himself in for.

But perhaps the demeanour of both men is understandable as they consider that they are both far removed in Washington and Austin from where the real election activity is still going on: in Tallahassee.

The Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris, who certified Bush as the winner last Sunday, comes from a circus family and events this week have given all the impression of a three-ring circus: as one set of lawyers file a suit in the county court, just across the street, another set of lawyers are filing a different suit. As one group of Republican demonstrators pack up their placards and head home, a group of Democrat demonstrators take over and picket the state's supreme court.

There remain five major legal actions: the Gore team is still seeking to have counted more than 14,000 ballots from Miami-Dade and Palm Beach that they claim were wrongly excluded; individual voters are seeking a ruling on the "butterfly ballots" - the controversial ballot which caused problems in Florida - which they claim disenfranchised them in Palm Beach.

Individual voters are seeking to have excluded absentee ballots which were counted in Seminole county and which they claim Republicans wrongly authenticated; the Bush team is still going to the US supreme court on Friday to argue that hand counts should never have taken place; and the Bush team is seeking to include absentee military ballots from various counties.

The clock is ticking. By December 12, all of the legal battles have to be settled. Maybe Mr Bush and Mr Gore should enrol now to hear the baroness's formula for success.

webTitle: Death of a schoolboy

fields.headline: Death of a schoolboy
fields.standfirst: He came for a better life. He was killed on the streets
fields.trailText: He came for a better life. He was killed on the streets. Nick Hopkins reports.
fields.body:
Damilola Taylor collapsed on the concrete stairs in between the first and second floors of the bleak council block, less than five minutes walk from home. Lying in the cold and dark, the 10-year-old had no energy to go on.

He may not have understood why he was being bullied at school, or why some other children taunted him about being "gay" - the word meant nothing to him.

Living on one of the toughest council estates in south London, he may not have appreciated why his family had moved from Nigeria to give him "a better life".

But Damilola probably knew his life was slipping away. He knew the sight of blood. And blood was pouring from a wound to his left leg, drenching his school trousers, maroon pullover and trainers. It was trickling down the stairwell to the groundfloor.

He was alone in the urine-stained stairwell when he died.

Six passersby tried to stem the blood with their fingers and thumbs. Minutes later, a team of paramedics began a futile effort to revive him.

Detectives piecing together what happened to Damilola as he walked home from Oliver Goldsmith primary school in Southwark on Monday at 4.45pm had one clue.

A trail of blood which led them from the stairwell to a spot 100 yards away in Blakes Road.

This is where they assume Damilola was attacked, possibly by three youths, aged between 11 and 17, who were seen running away from scene.

Damilola was within sight of home when he was stabbed but the loss of blood was so severe he stumbled before he reached the first-floor shops in the North Hordle Promenade where he probably hoped to find help.

"His femoral artery was slashed," said one officer who is part of the murder inquiry.

"It's like the jugular vein. "Blood would have come out like a fountain. He didn't really stand a chance."

Damilola came to London four months ago with his mother Gloria - who had lived in the UK once before - his brother Tunde, 21, and sister Beme, 23. His father is still in Nigeria.

Southwark council placed them in a flat in St Braivel's Court, part of the North Peckham estate which was built in the late 60s and is now being bulldozed. Only half of the homes on the estate are now occupied.

Damilola seemed to settle well, but had recently confided to his mother that he was being bullied at school.

"He was being threatened by other students," said Mrs Taylor, 49. "Last Friday he said some boys had beaten him, boys from the school.

"I asked 'did you fight with them?'. And he said 'No mummy I did not fight with them'. He said he was in pain."

On one occasion, Damilola, who was normal, playful and boisterous, had asked his mother to explain the meaning of the the word "gay".

"Boys were swearing at him, saying lots of horrible words. They were calling him names." Mrs Taylor told teachers about the taunts and abuse, but felt they did not take her seriously.

On Monday, she walked her son to school in Southampton Way to make sure he was all right, and expected him home at 5pm - Damilola wanted to stay behind for an extra computer class.

By the time he left, it was already dark. As far as police know, he walked 100 yards into Diamond Street, then turned first left into Blakes Road, a corridor overlooked by an industrial park on the left, and the back of the North Peckham estate on the right.

With poor street lighting and few homes, it would have been an ideal place for a group of youths to attack someone.

When Damilola failed to come home, his mother went looking for him. First she went to the school, where she bumped into the headmaster Mark Parsons. He told her Damilola was not there.

"I told her to stop worrying," he said. So Mrs Taylor headed home. The police, however, had cordoned off the road.

"I met the police and they told me a child was stabbed. I did not realise it was my child. Then I went to the hospital. It was Damilola."

The boy's cousin, Jordan Fayemi, 29, admitted the family could not be sure whether Damilola was stabbed by a pupil or not, but thought the school should have taken their worries more seriously.

Mr Parsons said he was "deeply shocked" by Damilola's death and said he would do everything possible to help the police inquiry.

"I would have been proud if he was my child. I feel dreadful for his mother and for him, and I feel dreadful that I was standing here a few hundred yards from where it was happening."

However, Mr Parsons was sure the killers were not pupils at Oliver Goldsmith. "I don't believe this has anything to do with the children. We are immensely proud of the fact that we have virtually no violent bullying at all."

Others on the estate said the death, though tragic, was not a surprise.

"I have been stabbed twice, dragged by my hair and given a black eye," said Mohammed El-Nagdy, who runs a shop on the North Hordle Promenade.

"The youths come here to steal from the till and they'll stab you for peanuts."

Maynard Cox-George, who runs the Peckham Positive Project, a community action group, said crime on the estate had actually fallen in recent years, but admitted the stairwells and walkways were ideal territory for criminals.

"That's one of the reasons they are pulling the place down. I went outside when we heard what had happened. I saw the body. Poor boy. The ambulancemen were working on him, but I'm sure he was already dead. There was blood everywhere."

Teams of officers were sifting through the estate's rubbish chutes yesterday looking for a murder weapon. The police also want to find three boys wearing dark hooded tops who were seen close to where Damilola collapsed.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt, who is leading the investigation, said: "We believe he was trying to get away from his attackers. We are urgently appealing for more witnesses to come forward."

Superintendent Rob Jarman, the commander of south London police, added: "I immediately thought of my own children when I heard about this. We will do everything we can to find out what happened."

webTitle: BBC2 gives Review a regular Newsnight slot

fields.headline: BBC2 gives Review a regular Newsnight slot
fields.trailText: 10.45am: BBC2's arts round-up, Review, is to be incorporated into Friday night's Newsnight, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Review, the weekly BBC2 arts round-up presented by Mark Lawson, is to be rebranded Newsnight Review and moved to a year-round Friday night slot.

The move to a post-Newsnight Friday night berth at 11pm from February coincides with a doubling of the number of Review editions to 50 a year.

Mr Lawson and the Review production team will move into Newsnight's offices and the show will be broadcast from the current affairs flagship's studio.

Newsnight Review is to be a joint venture between BBC Arts and BBC News, with both departments contributing to the programme budget.

Roly Keating, BBC controller of arts commissioning, said: "We're moving Review partly because the show is always at its best late-night and live, and partly because we can be ahead of the weekend arts pages.

"For the first time ever BBC television will have a regular, weekly arts round-up as part of its core current affairs programming."

Newsnight editor Sian Kevill added: "There are some very exciting possibilities in fusing Newsnight's journalism with arts coverage, particularly with the extra time we've been given to do this."

The studio-based show, which covers the latest books, exhibitions, films, plays and openings, currently runs in a peak-time Sunday evening slot as part of the BBC2 Art Zone.

Regular Review panellists include Tom Paulin, Germaine Greer, Allison Pearson and Professor John Carey.

Review was originally launched in 1994 as Late Review, following the Late Show in the BBC2 schedule.

After the Late Show's demise in 1995, Late Review continued as a standalone show in the late evening BBC2 line-up. It was renamed Review and moved to Sunday night in March this year.

webTitle: How would you cope as a refugee?

fields.headline: How would you cope as a refugee?
fields.standfirst: In this season of goodwill, Marjorie Thompson urges us to put ourselves in the shoes of asylum seekers to understand their predicament
fields.trailText: The holiday season is upon us and the stores are filled with decorations. People fortunate enough to be in work and untroubled by health or economic problems are making plans to celebrate with office colleagues and loved ones.
fields.body:
The holiday season is upon us and the stores are filled with decorations. People fortunate enough to be in work and untroubled by health or economic problems are making plans to celebrate with office colleagues and loved ones.

True, it has been difficult recently for commuters and people who have lost their homes through flooding. And the government has had a rocky time faced with fuel protests and the impending annual NHS crisis.

But it could be worse. You could be a refugee or an asylum seeker.

I recently attended a gathering of concerned UN relief agency employees, business people, journalists and campaigners. Their sense of despair was palpable: how could they mobilise thinking, decent people to express moral outrage at the continuing tabloid onslaught on people seeking asylum in this country? How could they change the comments of irresponsible politicians and instead create a climate of empathy and understanding, and promote a true picture of what causes people to flee their countries in the first place?

It is ironic that, while countries across Europe are seeking to lure talented and skilled workers in industries like IT from the Indian subcontinent to help us meet skills shortages, some politicians, themselves the children of refugees, have cavalierly dismissed people seeking refuge from those countries as being "bogus".

These pillars of the establishment, along with their media masters whom they are always trying to impress with their tough stance, will no doubt piously attend religious services in the next few weeks. And whether they are Christians or not, they probably know the story of Joseph and Mary and the inn that had no room for them.

In a world of grasping materialism and conspicuous consumption, with some countries insisting on selling arms and wreaking havoc through mindless despoliation of the world's natural resources, is it too much to ask for genuine reflection on the fundamental values which make us human?

Native Americans have a saying: "Walk a mile in another man's moccasins." My own simple guideline has always been the golden rule - do unto others as you would have them do unto you.

What would you do if, because of war, famine, earthquake or the kind of floods that have been occurring in parts of Britain, you could no longer remain in your home? What would you take with you? Your documentation and degree certificates? Some family pictures and clothes appropriate for an office job?

How would you feel if you were even just on holiday in a foreign country and all your money was stolen and you didn't speak the language and you had no way of getting cash wired to you or a replacement credit card?

This is the kind of dilemma we should be thinking about this Christmas. And we should be doing all we can to revive a spirit of common solidarity with people who, through no fault of their own, have ended up without any of the things - basic shelter, food, and a sense of security - which all of us need to fulfil our potential.

Even if this argument has no moral resonance with opinion formers, there are economic reasonings to illustrate how many of these highly skilled people could make a positive contribution to Britain if they get the support and understanding they need.

Ultimately, there is the argument of self interest - someday, it could be you.

Vodafone is to end its association with Air Miles after research revealed that its customers would prefer cheaper deals on its services than collecting air miles.

Reuters is undertaking a shake-up of its marketing operations, including its £1m advertising account held by BMP DDB.

webTitle: China seeks graft king's return

fields.headline: China seeks graft king's return
fields.standfirst: Extradition of fugitive is sought as book details tales of corruption
fields.trailText: China is seeking the extradition from Canada of a man who enticed hundreds of government officials into a huge smuggling racket.
fields.body:
China is seeking the extradition from Canada of a man who enticed hundreds of government officials into a huge smuggling racket.

The attempt to extradite Lai Changxing, whose operations in Fujian province cost the Chinese state 30bn yuan (£2.5bn)) in lost tax revenue, is the latest episode in Beijing's never-ending struggle against corruption, and coincides with the publication of more lurid details of recent corruption cases. Mr Lai was arrested last week by immigration officials in Vancouver.

A collection of interviews with corrupt officials - two of whom have since been executed - and excerpts from their trials is on sale on bookstalls all over Beijing. The book provides a fascinating glimpse into the mixture of greed, lust and naivete which lay behind the most blatant episodes.

It features prominently the case of Cheng Kejie, the Communist party boss of Guangxi province who was executed in September. Cheng was found guilty of accepting 41m yuan in bribes in return for authorising bank loans, government contracts and promotions.

The critical moment, according to an interview with his mistress Li Ping, came when Cheng declared, while travelling in his chauffeur-driven car, that he would divorce his wife and marry her.

The chauffeur overheard the conversation and advised them not to do that unless they had acquired some funds first.

"What kind of love can live in a hovel?" he said. "It's best for you to make some money while Mr Cheng is still in power."

Cheng then told Ms Li to "go and see what business can be done". She offered a local property company a cheap land deal in return for a bribe of 20m yuan. Cheng approved a bank loan to enable the company to pay the bribe.

In another significant case earlier this year, the former Jiangxi provincial deputy governor, Hu Changqing, was executed for receiving 5.4m yuan in bribes. Interviewed less than a day before his death, he explained how he began talking gifts from a local businessman, Zhou Xuehua, who had gained his confidence by asking him to do some calligraphy, and then handed over $10,000.

"Zhou used sugar-coated bullets to overwhelm me", Hu said, "and I succumbed to them. He would always find some pretext, like saying 'why don't you buy a foreign car [with the money] for your wife?'"

Asked why he took bribes when he was already earning a comfortable salary as a senior official, Hu said he was tempted by the vision of a different lifestyle during a visit to Paris. "I saw that life there was quite relaxed, salaries were high and western culture was different from ours."

He said he also wanted to deposit some dollars abroad so that one day his son would be able to make good in the US.

The book, Telling Blows against Corruption, is based on material gathered for two popular e television programmes which have broadcast exposés of corruption by officials. The editors say they faithfully reflect the Communist party's "relentless struggle against corruption".

Those convicted - usually provincial rather than national figures - are usually portrayed as having succumbed to temptation, in the shape of sexual or financial favours. This contrasts with the widespread perception that corruption is a way of life rather than an individual lapse.

The official literature is more reticent about the Beijing party leader and former mayor, Chen Xitong, who was sentenced to 16 years imprisonment in 1998 for of accepting gifts and condoning corruption.

In the book, Chen admits receiving cameras, watches, and gold and silver ornaments, but the ramifications of the wider corruption case, said to exceed £2.7m, are not explored.

The sensational Fujian scandal has already led to the conviction of 84 senior government officials and employees of the Yuan Hua group, headed by the man whose extradition is being sought. Fourteen were sentenced to death last month.

The group, based in the coastal city of Xiamen, smuggled large quantities of cars, rubber, fuel, tobacco and other goods, with the connivance of several hundred senior police and customs officials. The case was cracked after Beijing sent a big team of special investigators to break through a local cover-up.

There is speculation that Mr Lai could name other senior figures who have so far escaped punishment. In September the Chinese news agency said that prosecutors had investigated 23,000 cases of corruption so far this year, recovering 1.6bn yuan in ill-gotten gains.

webTitle: Granada rethinks ONdigital flotation

fields.headline: Granada rethinks ONdigital flotation
fields.standfirst: ONdigital appoints interactive boss
fields.trailText:
11am: Granada Media is prepared to abandon the planned flotation of its ONdigital channel, writes Dan Milmo.
ONdigital appoints interactive boss
fields.body:
Granada Media is prepared to abandon the planned flotation of its ONdigital channel.

Henry Staunton, finance director of ITV's largest broadcaster, said the joint venture with Carlton Communications could be weakened if it launched on the stock market.

He said: "Now that we have ITV in the hands of two players, we see tremendous potential through cross-promotion from ITV.

"We see that ITV will become much stronger, so if you were to introduce a third party that would be mixing it the other way."

Speculation has been mounting that ONdigital was being held back from the market due to concerns over high "churn rates", meaning subscribers to the digital service have been switching to rival operators.

ONdigital has 878,000 subscribers and expects to sign up 1m by the end of the year, although BSkyB's didgital service is far ahead with over 4m customers.

Mr Staunton said: "If the value of ONdigital is being recognised by analysts, then there is no need to float it. We would be taking value out of the company."

His comments came as Granada announced its first set of results since floating in July. Granada has become the kingmaker of ITV since it snapped up United News & Media's TV assets for £1.75bn over the summer.

Turnover increased by 9% to £108bn, and pre-tax profits rose 8% to £253m, on the back of an 8.4% rise in advertising revenue.

Granada swiftly became a stock market darling on its flotation, rising from an initial price of 515p to a high of 675p and into the flagship FTSE 100 index.

However, a series of hard-hitting analysts' notes queried the stability of the company's advertising revenues and the share price tumbled below 400p.

The company admitted that advertising revenues for October had been weak, due to the absence of a major sporting event such as last year's rugby world cup, but said that turnover for November and December was "marginally" up.

Granada has a £1.9bn cash pile to fund further acquisitions.

webTitle: ONdigital director of interactivity appointed

fields.headline: ONdigital director of interactivity appointed
fields.standfirst: Granada rethinks ONdigital flotation
fields.trailText:
11am: Matthew Seaman has been appointed ONdigital's first director of interactivity as ONdigital launches its "netlink" ads, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Granada rethinks ONdigital flotation
fields.body:
Matthew Seaman has been appointed to be ONdigital's first director of interactivity.

Mr Seaman's appointment comes as the digital broadcaster launches its first "netlink" ads - which carry embedded web links.

The Granada/Carlton digital joint venture has lagged behind Sky's Open platform in the interactive stakes, hampered by the lack of "return path" capability, which would allow advertisers to get audience feedback.

But an ONdigital spokesman said that Mr Seaman's appointment would pave the way for new interactive programme commissions and more interactive ads.

Before joining ONdigital at launch, Mr Seaman was with Sky and its interactive shopping platform, British Interactive Broadcasting, now called Open.

webTitle: Analysis: urban plight

fields.headline: Urban plight
fields.standfirst: Contrary to some easy assumptions about employment and income, city-dwellers are less well off than their country cousins
fields.trailText: Contrary to some easy assumptions about employment and income, city-dwellers are less well off than their country cousins.
fields.body:
Overall there is less poverty and exclusion in rural districts than in urban ones. That - the conclusion of an exhaustive survey of income, schooling and employment carried out for the Countryside Agency* - should be it. A government intent on relieving poverty, which social security secretary Alistair Darling said the other evening was exactly Labour's priority, need only look to the cities. That is where poor people live. Policy should not stray far from inner London, Birmingham and the big cities of the north.

The chart is based on the survey of households with below-average income compiled by Mr Darling's department. If you look at each "percentile" on the distributions of income for rural and urban England, people living in the cities get by on less - nearly 10% a week less for the very poorest. That social fact alone ought to squash the hyperbolic campaign waged by the fox hunters and farmers.

The proportion of people living in poor households is higher in urban England; adults living off means tested benefits ditto. Similarly the proportion of 16-year-olds failing to make a baseline showing at GCSE and the proportion of people without a bank account (nearly 12% of households in urban areas v just over 5% in rural areas).

There are only two social indicators which get close to suggesting people living in rural areas are worse off. One is based on a calculation of how many more elderly people die in winter (December to March) than at other times of the year, averaged over a few winters. This shows that while there is not much difference for men, older women living in rural districts are more vulnerable, possibly because more of them live alone. The proportion of elderly women depending on the state pension or income support is greater in rural than in urban areas by a small amount.

But it is not clear what such figures say about the real conditions of people's lives, or the volume of brick and mortar around them. "Rural" and "urban" are statistical artifice. Around Barnsley there are greenfields with cottages and farmhouses included, for measuring purposes in the metropolitan district. Lowestoft, centre of the shire district of Waveney, Suffolk, feels pretty much like a town. In another part of the same district is Southwold, Hampstead on sea, they call it. Only in such villages as South Elmham St Peter does Waveney look and feel like "country" for the purposes of Countryside Alliance mythology.

It all depends on the strength of the magnifying glass you use to track income and grants. Take parliamentary constituencies, closest to our legislators' hearts. Here, the general picture is once again one of urban blight. After Belfast, the highest unemployment in the Commons is registered in two central Birmingham seats, Ladywood and Sparkbrook. Grantham and Stamford, Lincolnshire, to take a "rural" constituency (which of course takes its name from two sturdy market towns) is 479th on the list.

In some parts of Europe regions are identifiably rural but not in England. The north-west, which runs from Cheshire to Carlisle through rural Lancashire and Cumbria, has lots of countryside. Its unemployment is at the national average, just under 5%. In the eyes of Brussels, working out eligibility for receipt of European Union "structural funds", the worst off English regions are South Yorkshire and Merseyside - decidedly urban - and Cornwall, rural up to a point.

The Countryside Agency and the Cabinet Office divide England using district council boundaries. How they decide what is rural is one of the higher mysteries of Whitehall, a mixture of land use, settlement patterns and so on; it verges on the tautologous. The approved list includes such urban sounding districts as Rugby and Chester. Winchester is classed as a rural district: the city has a population of 30,000 while 80,000 inhabitants of the district live in the chocolate box Meon Valley. It is not poor. District unemployment is 0.9%.

Officially, the isle of Thanet in Kent is "remote rural" but most of its people live in the declining seaside towns of Margate, Broadstairs and Ramsgate - plus a rural hinterland embracing such villages as Minster and Sarre. webTitle: Anger at acquittals on death of Asian man

fields.headline: Anger at acquittals on death of Asian man
fields.trailText: The parents of an Asian man who died violently branded the Scottish criminal justice system "institutionally racist" yesterday after watching two men charged with their son's killing walk free from court. Vikram Dodd reports.
fields.body:
The parents of an Asian man who died violently branded the Scottish criminal justice system "institutionally racist" yesterday after watching two men charged with their son's killing walk free from court.

Andrew Coulter and David Montgomery were acquitted at Glasgow high court of murdering Surjit Singh Chhokar in Lanarkshire in November 1998.

The case has been described as the Scottish equivalent of the Stephen Lawrence case by campaigners, who yesterday said the country's police, prosecutors and courts had failed to learn the lessons of the Macpherson report.

After the verdicts Scotland's lord advocate, Colin Boyd, announced two inquiries into the case. Mr Boyd also referred to errors in liaison with the family and said the "ethnic background of the Chhokar family contributed to that."

Last year a judge criticised the crown after another man was tried and acquitted of Mr Chhokar's murder.

Yesterday Coulter, 19, and Montgomery, 23, were cleared of stabbing Mr Chhokar, but Coulter was convicted of assaulting the victim, who worked as a waiter, with a piece of metal-lined wood.

Coulter was sentenced to 15 months for that assault and stealing from Mr Chhokar, which will be added to a five year sentence he received in January for killing another man.

The prosecution told the judge, Lord Bonomy, that Coulter instigated a break-in at Mr Chhokar's house and the theft of a £100 giro cheque. When Mr Chhokar found out, he threatened to tell the police and Coulter had gone to see him on the night of the murder.

As the verdicts were read, the victim's parents, Darsham and Gurdav, bowed their heads, with the proceedings being punctuated by cries of "shame".

Both defendants named Coulter's uncle, Ronnie Coulter, in a special defence of incrimination. Ronnie Coulter, 32, alone stood trial last year for Mr Chhokar's murder and was acquitted. The trial judge, Lord McCluskey, said it was "extraordinary" that Montgomery, from Motherwell, and Andrew Coulter, from Wishaw, were not in the dock with Ronnie Coulter.

The jury in the later trial heard that Andrew Coulter arranged to meet Mr Chhokar after stealing from his flat. Drunk, he bragged he would gouge Mr Chhokar's eyes out, knee-cap him and throw him over a bridge.

He went to the meeting with Montgomery and Ronnie Coulter and pounced on Mr Chhokar as he returned to his girlfriend's house at 11.30pm.

Liz Bryce told the court that from a window she saw her partner waving up to her. She turned to open the door for him, heard a scream, and ran back to the window where she saw the three men manhandling Mr Chhokar across the street. She ran out and saw Ronnie Coulter swinging something into Mr Chhokar. The three men ran away when she shouted.

After the verdict, Aamar Anwar, spokesman for the Chhokar family, said: "The Chhokar family don't believe they would have been treated this way if they had been white. The real verdict is one of institutional racism."

The family say that police had dismissed any racial motive for the attack within hours of the murder. Police are also alleged to have failed to provide interpreters for the family, whose first language is not English, for the first trial.

webTitle: Lockerbie suspect loses appeal bid

fields.headline: Lockerbie suspect loses appeal bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: One of the Libyans accused of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie today lost a bid to have the case against him thrown out.
fields.body:
One of the Libyans accused of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie today lost a bid to have the case against him thrown out.

Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah will now have to face the remainder of the trial at the special Scottish court in Holland.

His lawyer, Richard Keen, spent yesterday arguing that there was no case to answer against 44-year-old Mr Fhimah, and the panel of judges considered their decision overnight.

Presiding judge Lord Sutherland said: "We have come to the view that having regard in particular to certain entries in the second accused's diary, his association with the first accused with whom he is charged with acting in concert and, crucially, the evidence of Majid Giaka, we are unable to be satisfied that there is no case to answer."

webTitle: C&W sacks six over emails

fields.headline: C&W sacks six over emails
fields.standfirst:
Employers stepping up electronic surveillance in the workplace
Net news
fields.trailText: Employers stepping up electronic surveillance in the workplace
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless has dismissed six staff for sending offensive emails and disciplined dozens of others.

The sackings, last Friday, highlight the trend among employers to crack down on the alleged misuse of electronic communications.

Last month Holset Engineering, a maker of turbo chargers, successfully defended its dismissal of two employees who were found to have sent smutty emails to around 40 other staff.

Holset, based in Huddersfield, trawled internal mailboxes when an employee complained after being sent a "joke" email.

Two staff members, David Pennington and Rupert Beverley, were accused of gross misconduct and sacked because they were alleged to have transmitted the highest number of emails with the most sexually explicit attachments, lawyers for the company said.

The employees said they were unaware of any company policy that outlawed smutty jokes in emails. Holset argued that its policy was clear and all staff had been sent on a training course that dealt with the harassment of colleagues via the email system.

At Cable & Wireless the staff concerned, who worked in the Birmingham sales office, were suspended immediately, with dismissal following a hearing one week later. One of those sacked said the email to which the company took exception contained an obscenity.

Several are expected to use the company's internal appeals procedure, claiming that misuse of the computer system is rife and they have been singled out unfairly.

All of the staff involved are understood to have been employed at C&W for less than a year and consequently will be prevented from appealing to an industrial tribunal.

The ruling in favour of Holset Engineering and the C&W case come amid confusion about what rights employers have to oversee staff emails.

New data protection rules and the Human Rights Act are untested in the courts but appear to prevent employers from opening any communications by staff unless the employees are suspected of criminal acts.

These rules are widely believed to be contradicted by government regulations that became law on October 24 allowing employers to access information in specific circumstances.

webTitle: Presidential election - just one vote in it!

fields.headline: Presidential election - just one vote in it!
fields.standfirst: British vice-chancellors have elected the head of a new university as their president for the first time.
fields.trailText: By the closest of US style-margins, Roderick Floud, Provost of London Guildhall University, gained 52 votes to pip Ivor Crewe, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Essex, by a single vote to the post.
fields.body:
By the closest of US style-margins, Roderick Floud, Provost of London Guildhall University, gained 52 votes to pip Ivor Crewe, Vice-Chancellor of the University of Essex, by a single vote to the post.

It has taken eight years since the former polytechnic directors joined the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals for the members to come round to being led by one of them.

Professor Floud, currently Chairman of the England and Northern Ireland Council of CVCP and a vice-president and member of the UK Board, will succeed Sir Howard Newby on 1 August 2001 for a two year term.

An economic historian, a graduate and post graduate of Oxford, he taught at University College London, Cambridge, Birkbeck and Stanford. He was appointed Provost of London Guildhall University 12 years ago.

webTitle: Wilkins and Rix axed by Chelsea as Ranieri puts his foot down

fields.headline: Wilkins and Rix axed by Chelsea as Ranieri puts his foot down
fields.trailText: Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix have been sacked by Claudio Ranieri in a dramatic cull of Chelsea's coaching staff.
fields.body:
Ray Wilkins and Graham Rix have been sacked by Claudio Ranieri in a dramatic cull of Chelsea's coaching staff.

According to reports from within Stamford Bridge, Ranieri felt that the coaching staff were creating divisions in the camp and were hindering the creation of a new team spirit after the departure of Gianluca Vialli.

Ranieri made the decision to act after the 2-1 defeat at Everton on Saturday, approaching managing director Colin Hutchinson with his proposals. Wilkins and Rix left by "mutual agreement" after a meeting with Ranieri yesterday.

A statement on Chelsea's official website said: "When Ranieri arrived he brought with him his own coaches and that meant a change of roles for Rix and Wilkins from their time working under Gianluca Vialli.

"Those roles have recently become increasingly peripheral and it's been decided it would be best for all parties if they went their separate ways. Their contracts were up in the summer and it's been agreed that they can leave now, paid up in full, to pursue other interests."

Meanwhile goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwecki and fitness coach Antonio Pintus have been given the option of going their own way too or carrying on working in their slightly changed positions.

There is also a doubt over the future now of reserve team manager Mick McGiven, although assistant manager Gwyn Williams is likely to stay.

webTitle: Revenue boost for 365 Corporation

fields.headline: Revenue boost for 365 Corporation
fields.trailText: 10.30am: 365 Corporation has posted a rise in revenues in its second-quarter results, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation moved to restore market confidence in its business this morning by reporting second-quarter revenues of almost £12m.

However, the digital media company, which provides communications services to businesses and runs a wide portfolio of websites, also reported a loss of £8.6m, against a deficit of £1.1m last year.

Chief executive Dan Thompson said he was very pleased with the results and emphasised overall growth in the company.

He said: "It's been a strong quarter for us with growth coming across all the group," singling out the mobile telephony business as the fastest growth area.

Revenues from the business division climbed 26% to £4.5m, while turnover from the consumer arm grew to £7.5m. Total users have tripled over the past 12 months and now number 2.4m.

During the quarter, 365 launched five new sites, including My365, Gay365, Formula1 in French, Rally365 and Future365.

Mr Thompson reiterated that the business was investing for long-term growth and that if 365 wished to end this, it would be profitable immediately.

Nevertheless, he added that 365 was on track to break even in the third quarter next year. The company has £41m left in the bank.

Asked about market sentiment and 365's recent demotion from the Techmark stock index, Mr Thompson said: "It's painful but part of life. Our valuation is incomprehensible. We've been performing consistently but we get swept along with the market."

Coinciding with its results, 365 unveiled a year-long spread betting deal with Sporting Index, in which the company becomes the exclusive spread betting provider across the 365 network.

Shares in 365 rose 6% to 49p this morning on the strength of the results, although a stock market technical hitch prevented it posting results to the exchange before markets opened.

webTitle: Pearson TV's Mike Southgate promoted

fields.headline: Pearson TV's Mike Southgate promoted
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Pearson TV's Mike Southgate is to head up RTL's technical broadcasting services, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Mike Southgate, managing director of Pearson Television operations, is stepping up to become chief executive of parent company RTL Group's newly combined technical broadcasting services.

In his new role Mr Southgate will oversee RTL's technical services centres in Luxembourg, Cologne and Paris, as well as Pearson TV's London-based operation.

RTL's technical centres provide TV and radio transmission services, as well as studio, outside broadcast and other production facilities, for the company's channels, programme-makers and clients.

The businesses employ around 1,000 staff and had combined sales of more than £103m in 1999.

Mr Southgate will be moving from London to Luxembourg, where RTL's corporate HQ is based, to run the newly combined technical services operation.

The heads of the regional businesses - including Pearson TV's Paul Evans, Cologne Broadcasting Center's Alain Flammang and Video Communication France's Pascal Farcouli - will also be based in Luxembourg.

Ewald Walgenbach, RTL chief operating officer, said: "Our broadcasting and production services are in leading positions in several markets. The combination of these businesses creates the first pan-European player within this industry."

webTitle: MacLaurin nets BSkyB consumer PR brief

fields.headline: MacLaurin nets BSkyB consumer PR brief
fields.trailText: 10.30am: BSkyB has hired PR firm MacLaurin Communications to handle a consumer PR brief, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BSkyB has hired MacLaurin Communications to handle a consumer PR brief, filling the gap left by rival PR agency Freud Communications.

Freud handled much of Sky's consumer PR until the beginning of this year, but now only looks after small projects for the broadcaster.

A BSkyB spokesman confirmed the appointment but said the company was also talking to other agencies.

Ian Monk, media director at MacLaurin, said: "We are delighted to be working with Sky helping them to maintain their pre-eminence in the digital TV marketplace."

Sky currently uses Bell Pottinger Financial for all its corporate PR.
