webTitle: Rory Carroll plays an extra in Martin Scorsese's new movie

fields.headline: Marty, Leo and me
fields.standfirst: When he got the chance to appear in Martin Scorsese's new movie, currently shooting in Rome,  Rory Carroll jumped at it. It would be 'such fun', he was promised. What he got was a dreary dawn start, a frugal breakfast, hours under a baking sun and a near-riot on set...
fields.trailText: When he got the chance to appear in Martin Scorsese's new movie, currently shooting in Rome, Rory Carroll jumped at it. It would be 'such fun', he was promised. What he got was a dreary dawn start, a frugal breakfast, hours under a baking sun and a near-riot on set...
fields.body:
Tacked to a noticeboard in the cinema foyer, jostling with offers of English lessons, second-hand bicycles and a kitten called Alberto, is a small poster. Typed black letters explain that a Hollywood blockbuster is coming to Rome and would anyone interested in participating please phone the number at the bottom. There is no number, or a bottom, just a jagged rip. Gotta move fast in this business.

It takes a while to track him down, but the voice at the end of the line is welcoming. "There are still some vacancies. You'll have such fun!" And so a few days later I am on a metro rattling east of Rome. Emerging from the station, a sliver of moon hangs over the darkness. It is a cold 5.45am.

Dozens, hundreds of silhouettes tramp down the road in silence. We stop at the gate of a walled complex and wait for a bearded man in denim to finish scratching. "Everything in good time, children." In groups of six we are allowed to enter the fabled Cinecitta studios. The magical world of movie making beckons.

Believe the hype (we do) and what awaits is the box-office hit of 2001. The Gangs of New York has a $90m budget, Martin Scorsese (pictured) directing, Leo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz, Daniel Day Lewis and Liam Neeson starring, and us. There isn't really a verb for us. We are extras. We be.

During the next few hours we will be part of Team Hollywood, giving our best in exchange for a peek inside the machine. Given the flight of productions from America to places where costs are lower, this could be a glimpse of the future. At this stage of production, secrecy is needed to allow suspense to build before the publicity blitz. Journalists and photographers are not welcome. Lucky for me that the producers want Irish-looking people. Freckles and red hair are gold dust.

Dawn seeps over us to unveil the day's first extraordinary sight. Ginger Romans. Perms, waves and buzz cuts are tinged orange. They glint in the sun, each strand painstakingly dyed. A hush of respect envelopes this minority. When returning to the real world they will be ridiculed. They will suffer for their art.

After signing away our rights to compensation should an act of God or Scorsese strike us dead, we file into three costume warehouses. The film is about rival immigrant gangs vying for control of 1850s New York. A few well-dressed Yanks are to be sprinkled among 600 soldiers and ragamuffins. We strip down to our underpants - boxer shorts for foreigners, Y-fronts for Romans - while dressers scour racks for coordinated outfits that fit. The female dressers affect a clinical, nurse-type demeanour. Their male colleagues, camp as a row of a tents, flirt. "You are a big boy; let's go to this dark corner and see what we find." Not even the tattooed Lazio fans dare object.

Attention to detail is fanatical. Shirt, waistcoat, jacket, trousers, socks and boots are matched. If the buttons don't look right, they are replaced. Archive pictures of Irish villagers during the famine are scattered on tables. My third outfit is deemed acceptable: brown boots, socks, trousers and braces, stripy white shirt, purple waistcoat and fudgey jacket. Everything itches. My hair is judged an asset so a bowler hat is discarded. Make-up teams smear grease on heads and three types of dirt on faces, hands and nails. Staring back from the mirror is what Oliver Twist would look like after being rammed up a chimney. In the trailer toilets a 20-year-old is desperately rinsing his tresses in the sink. "Ruined," he wails.

Breakfast is one, and only one, pastry each. Too late a veteran murmurs his wisdom. "Eat before make-up, then they won't recognise you when you go back for another." An extra with a handlebar moustache is caught taking a photo of his friend in leprechaun-green. The film is destroyed, the camera confiscated. Stuffing newspapers and books down trousers to read later, we are herded to the set.

Benito Mussolini wasn't totally daft. It was his idea in 1936 to turn 600 hectares of real estate into one of the world's greatest studios. After the second world war, Cinecitta incubated directors such as Fellini and Visconti and enjoyed a golden age with films such as Cleopatra, Spartacus, War and Peace, A Farewell to Arms and La Dolce Vita.

Dante Ferretti's set designs were famous. He is still here. Yawning up around us are New York tenement slums, bakeries, warehouses, docklands, ships. Streets are cobbled, laundry hangs from windows, stoves puff smoke. The lemons are real, the fish are not. The sign saying "P. Daily's Fish Market" is exquisitely faded. Green water laps the harbour. A blue screen blocks the horizon.

A production assistant on the verge of tears bellows at the milling crowd in Roman dialect. "Please, order, please." People in jeans, runners and sunglasses materialise from trailers, muttering into earpieces. They are the Americans. The director is on his way.

Scorsese made Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and Goodfellas, but has never won an Oscar or had a global box-office smash. Gangs, based on the book by Herbert Ashbury, could be the one to change that. He arrives driving a golf cart with two personal assistants who will never leave his side. Wearing jeans, runners and a blazer, he hops out and backslaps the cast. He is very small.

Despite being seven days behind schedule, the entire day is devoted to one complicated shot where a single camera will track DiCaprio walking past rows of seated customs officials, follow new arrivals being led away, skim past a battalion marching through a fish market, glide up on a crane to catch soldiers entering a ship and glide down to catch coffins being lowered onto the docks. A lesser director would use five cameras and an editing suite.

Scorsese is sprawling in a chair during a lull when my mobile trills. An assistant turns white. "Christ, turn it off, Marty will get his axe and cut your head off." The assistant is trembling, though Marty appears not to have heard. An extra sidles up. "He looks friendly, but that's only with the actors. We don't exist. Last week he was walking through us and we didn't get out of the way in time. He shouted that we should know who he was."

A sudden silence announces the arrival of DiCaprio. Beneath a top hat his face is pasty and bloated compared to the way it looked in his last film, The Beach. Too much pasta and nightlife, say the Italian papers. Scorsese has put him on a diet but tolerates his smoking, forbidden to others. DiCaprio leans on a pillar and plays "chicken", the hand-slapping game, with another actor. In the film his father, Liam Neeson, is killed by Daniel Day Lewis. In reality DiCaprio and Day Lewis can't stand each other, goes the gossip. The star of My Left Foot is liked for mixing with the crew in the canteen, though his penchant for maintaining his character's accent off camera is greeted with giggles. So too DiCaprio's query to the linguistic consultant. "To insult him, should I use motherfucker or cocksucker?" (The latter.)

By 1pm the sun is melting make-up and patience at yet another lull. Actors disappear into trailers while extras sit outside. Immigrants slump on their luggage, soldiers point rifles at Scorsese and the horse urinates for the fourth time. A group of crones wrapped in shawls, extras since the spaghetti westerns, lecture the youngsters on professionalism.

The director is unhappy with a customs official's style of granting citizenship."You're supposed to be bored, it's not a big deal, it's routine, don't lean forward. Sit back." DiCaprio and Day Lewis have no lines today but are praised for their body language.

My job is to amble towards one of the ships while soldiers march past. After 19 takes the boots begin to hurt. A female immigrant appears to collapse and is led away. "Water for background people," orders Scorsese.

Veteran extras warn neophytes to beware the purges. Chatting too much, squeezing into the shot and smoking can incur banishment. A female extra allegedly caught having sex on set with a supporting actor was fired.

Many extras are wannabe actors who dream of catching the producer's eye. Others come out of curiosity, and most come for the £50 a day. A pittance by American standards but irresistible to a shop assistant on £1.50 an hour. The catch is that a day can stretch to 18 hours, by which time they've missed the last metro and must pay for taxis. After one such marathon the only one to say thanks was Cameron Diaz, says one extra.

By 3.30pm the scene is still not right. It's late October but the sun is roasting and lunch has yet to appear. We look and smell increasingly authentic. Discipline breaks down. Soldiers are marching out of step, an officer wears his cap back to front, a copy of Gazzetto dello Sport is left on a barrel.

Another shout of "cut" sparks mutiny. Moans of protest ripple and swell into curses. Lazio fans start chanting. The Americans are shocked. This is not the Hollywood way. A producer grabs a megaphone and defuses a riot by promising we can leave after lunch. It's a lie. Assistants pounce during dessert and herd us back to the docks where we remain until sunset. The forest of stiff limbs which eventually shambles back to the changing rooms is quiet. We've peeked inside the machine and the mystery is gone.

webTitle: Reed closes Supermarketing magazine

fields.headline: Reed closes Supermarketing magazine
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Reed Business Information has blamed market conditions for the closure of Supermarketing magazine, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Reed Business Information has blamed market conditions for the closure of Supermarketing magazine.

The 25-year-old weekly business title aimed at the supermarket industry will publish its last edition on December 15.

Denis Hart, a spokesman for the Sutton-based business publishing company, said that advertising revenues "just weren't enough to sustain the magazine".

But he denied insider reports that the magazine had failed to sell any advertising on the most recent issue.

Mr Hart said the changing nature of advertising buying decisions had made it difficult for Supermarketing to sell enough ads.

"Buying decisions are now concentrated in just a very few hands," he added.

Five editorial staff will lose their jobs as a result of the move, but the spokesman said many of these would be found alternative jobs within Reed Business Information.

webTitle: Freelance snappers reject Scotsman fees deal

fields.headline: Freelance snappers reject Scotsman fees deal
fields.trailText: Freelance photographers working for the Scotsman are protesting at a new deal over fees paid by publisher Press Holdings. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
More than 100 freelance photographers working for the Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday newspapers have written to Press Holdings, saying that a new offer on fees is inadequate.

An NUJ representative said the sticking point was Press Holdings' refusal to pay reprographic fees on photographs used on its news pages and its website.

Although the newspapers have now made concessions to the photographers - agreeing to pay a reprographic fee for use in the two papers of £40 - insiders say the fees are considerably below market rates.

The Scottish Newspaper Association of Photographers (SNAP), was founded recently by a group of around 30 regular freelance photographers after Press Holdings demanded that they stop charging fees for pictures used on its website.

Freelancers were originally told that for an increase of £5 in their shift rates, Press Holdings would take all usage rights to photographers' work, which would be extended to work already held in the newspapers' library.

In response, SNAP, supported by the NUJ, boycotted a meeting set up by the Scotsman's picture desk. An NUJ representative attended the meeting.

Picture commissioners on the publications have since thrashed out the new contract which the NUJ says is inadequate.

webTitle: The Sun in Page 3 cybersquatting row

fields.headline: The Sun in Page 3 cybersquatting row
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The Sun has settled a row over the rights to the use of Page 3 on the internet, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Sun has settled a row over the rights to the use of Page 3 on the internet.

Thirty years after it first introduced the controversial slot for topless models, it has been forced to square up to a cybersquatter that was capitalising on its trademarked Page 3 name.

In what is fast becoming the norm in internet cybersquatting cases, the infringement was brought to the attention of News International by IT news website theregister.co.uk.

The domain-name spat centres on the website UKPage3.com, which the Daily Sport claimed was its official website. After a "amicable" legal wrangle last week however, the website was pulled down and the domain name is now expected to be transferred to News International.

The reason why News International got so hot and bothered about the domain name was because its very own topless website, page3.com, is its most popular website with almost 2m unique users. Once News International realised UKPage3.com existed, however, it moved fast to register the .co.uk version of the domain last Friday.

A spokeswoman for News International refused to go into any detail about the tabloid spat aside from saying action had been taken.

webTitle: Business: Express print plant stake under threat

fields.headline: Express print plant stake under threat
fields.trailText: The Telegraph Group is considering exercising its right to buy the 50% stake of the West Ferry printing plant acquired by Richard Desmond in his takeover of Express Newspapers last week.
fields.body:
The Telegraph Group is considering exercising its right to buy the 50% stake of the West Ferry printing plant acquired by Richard Desmond in his takeover of Express Newspapers last week.

A decision to use its pre-emption rights over the plant in east London would strip out one of the most lucrative parts of Express Newspapers. The printing plant has several large contracts, including the Guardian, and is understood to have accounted for a significant part of Express Newspapers profits last year.

Dan Coulson, deputy chairman of Hollinger, the Telegraph's parent company, said a decision had not yet been made on the future of the plant in which it already holds a 50% share. "We are looking very carefully at the agreement and considering our position. We will do whatever is in our own best interest," he said.

Insiders, however, said it would be "safe to assume" that the Telegraph Group would buy the rest of the plant. It sold a 50% stake to the Express some years ago but retains the right to buy back the stake in the event of a change of control.

Mr Desmond, who owns the Northern & Shell publishing group, has not yet made contact with the Telegraph Group to discuss the future ownership of the plant.

A number of journalists have already quit the Daily Express following Mr Desmond's £125m acquisition at the end of last week. Many are angry at being sold to Northern & Shell which also publishes soft porn magazines including Forum and Asian Babes.

The Telegraph Group was among the bidders for Express Newspapers and was angered at the way United News & Media conducted the sale. Other bidders for the papers included the Daily Mail & General Trust and the Indian businessmen, the Hinduja brothers.

webTitle: November 29 Media Briefing

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Richard Desmond has taken his celebrity proteges David and Victoria Beckham on a tour of The Express. P7
The Telegraph Group is considering exercising its right to buy the 50% of the Westferry printing plant bought by Richard Desmond last week. P26
John Menzies is suing WH Smith for abuse of market share. P26 Lara Croft owner Eidos said low sales of PlayStation games and delays in the arrival of the PlayStation 2 had contributed to losses of £82.3m. p28
The Racecourse Association has recommended a two-week period of exclusive negotiations with the Go Racing consortium over the media rights to Britain's horseracing. P33

THE TELEGRAPH

Villagers of Redmile, Leicestershire who objected to it being used as a backdrop for the new series of Crossroads have capitulated after a ballot. P2
Actress Sally Farmiloe accepted substantial libel damages and a public apology from the Mail on Sunday in the High Court yesterday over a newspaper article that gave the impression she planned to marry Lord Archer. P5
The BBC is to incorporate its arts show, Review, into Newsnight in an attempt to strengthen its arts coverage and lighten the heavyweight news programme. P7
EastEnders star Wendy Richard yesterday received her MBE. P8

THE TIMES

Madonna fans who tried to log into MSN to watch her play live were met only with the message, "Server too busy". P5
The author Stephen King has suspended publication of his internet novel, The Plant, after it failed to grab readers' attention. P9
The BBC paid £42m to retain the radio rights for English Premier League football for the next three year. P11

THE INDEPENDENT

More on the end of Stephen King's internet novel. P1
Fiona Macpherson, editor-in-chief of Harpers & Queen, died yesterday at the age of 61. P4
Trevor McDonald will front ITV's nightly news bulletin when it returns to a 10pm slot in January as well as more editions of his news programme, Tonight with Trevor McDonald. P7

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The BBC will today announce plans to launch digital channels in Canada as part of the expansion of its commercial arm, BBC Worldwide. P4
Radio 5 Live has won the rights to Premier League football. P4
Evolvebank, the internet bank being launched by Lloyds TSB, has put back its UK launch until next year. P30
The online sports network Sportal will today announce a deal with Fox Kids Europe to create the world's biggest internet sports service for children. P44

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

Replay TV is to stop selling to consumers and instead license its software to cable providers and other companies. P28
Ad agency holding companies are moving into the foreground as clients award accounts based on global marketing resources. P28
Guinness has briefed Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and Saatchi & Saatchi to pitch for its global account. P28

THE DAILY MAIL

Crossroads has gone glamorous with a host of attractive young characters. P27

THE DAILY EXPRESS

An investment bank has warned that Capital Radio DJ Chris Tarrant is too old to attract younger listeners. P6

THE SUN

The return of "Nasty" Nick is keeping EastEnders at the top of the TV ratings. P18

THE MIRROR

A businessman has attacked a pensioner he said "makes Victor Meldrew look like a saint". P20

webTitle: Housing groups feel urge to merge

fields.headline: Housing groups feel urge to merge
fields.standfirst: Faced with best value and government plans to cap rents, social landlords are merging to achieve economies of scale. But, as Radhika Holmstrom reports, there is a risk tenants could lose their say
fields.trailText: Faced with best value and government plans to cap rents, social landlords are merging to achieve economies of scale. But, as Radhika Holmstrom reports, there is a risk tenants could lose their say
fields.body:
In July, three London housing groups announced they were holding talks with a view to merging their operations. Central and Cecil housing trust, St Marylebone housing association and Octavia Hill housing trust joined an increasing number of social housing providers combining part or all of their operations.

The current drive to merge is partly the result of the housing green paper's proposal to restructure social housing rents, combined with best value. "There is a general issue that 'merger mania' will go through the roof if the government continues with its plans to cap rents to inflation," says Inside Housing editor Huw Morris. "Many social landlords out there will find themselves financially unviable, and will have to merge with larger, more stable partners."

The cynical view is that bigger organisations take over smaller ones, and the senior partner becomes the chief executive. Smaller specialist providers are certainly under increasing pressure to join bigger organisations. However, these are not the contested takeovers typical of the commercial sector.

In the social housing world, stakeholder groups have to be informed from the beginning. There are a number of potential pitfalls, starting with the consultation process. The Housing Corporation finds that a significant minority of potential mergers founder, and these tend to be because of "people problems".

Nevertheless, the overtones of a commercial takeover remain. This may be why many people prefer talking about "group structures", consisting of one parent body and diverse operating arms. "If you merge with someone, you risk losing your identity, whereas if you keep a group you can negotiate how much autonomy you have. I think there's a more positive feel all round," says Tony Cox, head of governance at the Housing Corporation.

Cox estimates that only around a quarter of the organisations coming together now opt for traditional "mergers".

James Tickell, deputy chief executive of the National Housing Federation, believes that "mergers are harder, but they provide more economies of scale. Group structures are easier to do".

He also questions the assumption that merging automatically removes duplication. "Some traditional organisations are spread over a lot of neighbourhoods and a merger doesn't necessarily solve the problem - two organisations with a small number of properties in a great number of areas may end up being a larger, inefficient organisation."

The big question with any structural change is: how will it affect tenants? A merger does not require a tenants' vote in favour, simply "broad evidence" of their support, and this support is often qualified. The merger between the three London providers is no exception. Tenants have been concerned with the speed with which it is going ahead, and their level of representation on the new association's board.

Local accountability becomes even more of an issue for structures where central control moves out of the area. Cox stresses the Housing Corporation's emphasis on "communities in control". He recommends the kind of graduated accountability of associations like Partington in the Manchester area. Partington, which effectively runs its local housing, is part of a registered social landlord that is in turn part of the Harvest Group - a big, financially strong organisation with local operating companies.

Paul Schofield of the Tenant Participation Advisory Service is unconvinced. "There are two contradictory pressures - local responsiveness and community-based landlords versus bigger and bigger landlords. Group structures get away from the idea of a housing monolith, but the overarching body, and individual business units, implement something that's already been decided. There's less and less room for tenants to determine overall priorities or strategy."

Schofield is particularly concerned about mergers which follow stock transfers from the local authority. "Management and culture go through a much bigger change and a whole link with major decision-making could be completely taken away, but tenants don't have a say."

Recent hints that rents might not be capped after all may slow the trend towards a "mania". The overall trend, however, looks set to continue despite "people problems" and tenants' concerns. How many providers will we have in 2010?

webTitle: Bell appointed as editor-in-chief of GU

fields.headline: Bell gets top editorial job at Guardian websites
fields.trailText: 9.30am: MediaGuardian.co.uk executive editor Emily Bell has been appointed as editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
MediaGuardian.co.uk's executive editor Emily Bell has been appointed to the wider role of editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian newspaper's network of websites.

The new position, the equivalent of an assistant editor's position on the paper, has been created to support GU's ambitious expansion plans in the coming year.

Ms Bell, who is on maternity leave until January, will be responsible for all editorial activities across the GU network, adding to her involvement in MediaGuardian.co.uk.

She will report directly to Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger and will work alongside Simon Waldman, head of Guardian Unlimited, who will focus much more on commercial, technical and strategic development.

Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian said: "The increasing relevance of the internet has created the need for a new position at Guardian Unlimited to ensure editorial cohesion between the paper and its web operations.

"Emily has a wealth of experience and talent and is perfectly positioned to build on the huge success of the site."

Ms Bell was previously business editor of the Observer. Prior to that she was deputy business editor and media business editor. She joined the Observer from advertising trade magazine Campaign in 1990.

webTitle: Peers say NHS could embrace alternative therapies

fields.headline: Peers say NHS could embrace alternative therapies
fields.trailText: A step was taken yesterday towards integration of complementary and alternative medicine into the NHS with a House of Lords select committee report that urged greater regulation but called for doctors and nurses to listen to patients' growing demands and recognise the potential for good of unconventional therapies.
fields.body:
A step was taken yesterday towards integration of complementary and alternative medicine into the NHS with a House of Lords select committee report that urged greater regulation but called for doctors and nurses to listen to patients' growing demands and recognise the potential for good of unconventional therapies.

After 15 months study the Lords select committee on science and technology produced a 140-page report that points a clear way forward through what has been a minefield for politicians in the past. It wants the NHS make it easier for patients to gain access to therapies that work and give patients more and better information about what works and what does not.

The Lords does not embrace all the therapies, some with a spiritual dimension, which have taken off in the UK, but thereport is careful not to tar any of them. Peers distinguish between those disciplines such as osteopathy and chiropractic that are well regulated and have good evidence to show they work, a second group of "feel-good" therapies which complement conventional medicine and do no harm, and a third group which "cannot be supported unless and until convincing research evidence of efficacy, based upon the results of well-designed trials, can be produced".

The one point of serious controversy in the report is likely to be the inclusion of traditional Chinese medicine and Ayurvedic medicine (an ancient Indian discipline) in the third list of unproven treatments. Both disciplines go back thousands of years and are extensively practised in China and India.

Asked if he would use any of the complementary and alternative medicine remedies, Lord Walton of Detchant, who chaired the sub-committee running the inquiry, said: "I would have no difficulty at all if I had troublesome back pain which was not helped by visits to the doctor in consulting an osteopath or a chiropractor. If I was in intolerable pain, I'd at least consider acupuncture. I'd be perfectly prepared to consider herbal remedies that are shown by research to be effective forms of treatment."

He would also consider aromatherapy and other complementary therapies listed in the report's second group. But he said: "I would not personally be willing to take advantage of any in group three."

The Lords acknowledged the rise of alternative medicine was driven by public demand, fuelled by distrust of conventional drugs and disillusion with doctors who could spare them only a few minutes. A therapist, by contrast, would spend up to an hour discussing the emotional as well as physical problems of the patient.

The committee felt there was a need for the public to be given better information and to be helped to find reputable, trained and accredited practitioners. Members recognised a danger that some people would turn their back on conventional drugs to embrace alternative "cures" that made them feel better but failed to tackle the underlying disease which might be killing them.

Much more research into alternative therapies was needed, the report said, recommending that the NHS and the Medical Research Council should put in money to develop centres of excellence akin to the successful National Center for Complementary Alternative Medicine in the United States. Randomised controlled trials, which were required of any conventional medicine, should be carried out to establish how well alternative therapies work.

There have been some such trials of herbal remedies, which have established that St John's wort or hypericum, for instance, is effective against depression. But most herbal medicines have not been tested in this way and problems can arise when mixtures are used. The committee said there was good evidence of the efficacy of osteopathy and chiropractic, which could be more effective than physiotherapy, and of acupuncture for pain relief and treatment of nausea.

Committee members were "sceptical about the modes of action of most of the others", said the report, but they accepted many of the group two therapies helped relieve stress. There was no reason why homeopathy, which was already provided on the NHS, should work - patients were given minuscule doses of whatever was deemed to be causing their problem - but they accepted that it might have a beneficial effect because patients believed it was helping them.

Tighter regulation of alternative medicine practitioners was vital, said the report, and only those disciplines which were well regulated should be accessible through the NHS. Acupuncture and herbal medicine should be subject to statutory regulation and there should be a clampdown on misleading labels on herbal medicines, which sometimes made unjustified claims.

The report found favour on all sides. The Royal College of Nursing was in favour of more regulation and training and the commitment to patient choice and protection.

Peter Fisher, clinical director of the NHS Royal London Homeopathic hospital, said: "We're quite happy with it. We can't really argue with their main points about high quality information, regulation, which has been a very high priority for us, and research and NHS provision."

webTitle: Cold comfort for village as housing market woos outsiders

fields.headline: Cold comfort for village as housing market woos outsiders
fields.standfirst: The Lake District has become a rich person's playground, writes Peter Hetherington
fields.trailText: The Lake District has become a rich person's playground, writes Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
After farming the steep hillsides and rocky pastures of Lakeland for over 30 years, Doreen and Roger Westmoreland should be looking forward to a happy retirement.

Unlike many struggling rural communities, their beloved village of Troutbeck, nestling below Kirkstone Pass on the winding road to Ambleside, has a string of amenities: village hall incorporating a post office and shop, two pubs, bus service, and an active neighbourhood forum.

"This is a wonderful place to live, with a tremendous spirit," said Doreen Westmoreland. "People really care for each other, meet and socialise regularly."

But like many villages in national parks, and in other protected areas, the beauty reflected on the Lakeland green slate conceals a deepening social problem. Tenant farmers like the Westmorelands can no longer find accommodation locally once they give up a National Trust holding.

The Lake District has become a rich person's playground. When the neighbourhood forum undertook a survey recently it found that 40 of the 105 houses in Troutbeck were either second homes or holiday lets, benefiting from a 50% council tax discount on the grounds that the buildings are occupied only part of the time.

"I'd charge them not just the full rate but double it," fumed Mrs Westmoreland. "If they can afford a second home, they can afford to pay that." Of three properties now on the market in Troutbeck the cheapest has a price tag of £340,000 in an area where annual incomes are often around £15,000.

Mrs Westmoreland is outraged that locals are being priced out of their community once retirement, or marriage, nears. "Older people would like to continue living in the valley where they were born and brought up," she said.

"Our lives are wrapped around this village and it would be sad if we had to leave. My parents were able to buy a house and retire and live nicely, but that's not so easy now." At one time retiring tenant farmers could rely on raising the price for a house from selling stock or farm machinery. Now that the bottom has fallen out of the farming market, animals and tractors are virtually worthless, leaving rented or social housing as the only option. And, sadly, not much is available in the Lake District. Only 4,000 council houses are left in the South Lakeland council area after 3,800 disappeared under the Conservative right to buy policy.

In a frenzied property market, some former council houses have changed hands for as much as £150,000 - to become second homes.

The district now has a house waiting list of 1,700. Increasingly, younger people, along with older couples like the Westmorelands, are being forced out to larger towns in Cumbria where cheaper housing is available.

Displaced from their communities, many of them have to commute back into Lakeland for their low paid work, further adding to household expenses.

Fraser Rae, the district council's director of housing and the environment, cannot contain his anger. "Some estate agents are offering preferential rates for second home buyers, yet people are wandering around with kids in tow looking for bedsits because they can't get a house."

South Lakeland has taken the lead in campaigning for authorities to be given the right to charge full council tax, and use the money raised to provide affordable homes.

The Rural Housing Trust, which helps to build affordable homes in the countryside, estimates that subsidising second home owners through the 50% discount costs £150m annually, compared with only £21m now going to social housing in the shires.

"The idea of so much help going to people who already have at least one home when so little is provided for ordinary local families is a cruel injustice," said Moira Constable, the trust's chief executive.

Like many rural campaigners, she is alarmed that ministers have backed away from abolishing the discount, leaving individual councils to make the decision instead.

webTitle: Go Racing first past post in TV tug of war

fields.headline: Go Racing first past post in TV tug of war
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Racecourse Association, representing Britain's 59 courses, has recommended that a two-week period of exclusive negotiation is entered into with the Go Racing consortium over the media rights contract.
fields.body:
The Racecourse Association, representing Britain's 59 courses, has recommended that a two-week period of exclusive negotiation is entered into with the Go Racing consortium over the media rights contract.

This does not mean that Go Racing, comprising Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure, has finally secured the contract, but it is all but signed and sealed. It will operate from March 1 of next year.

The Go Racing deal will be worth in excess of £750m, including revenue from interactive betting, over a 10-year period, although the minimum guarantee is £400m with £50m payable in the first year.

Carlton's rival bid, which was ultimately rejected, was very close and could have meant more cash on the table. However, the promise of greater terrestrial coverage on Channel 4 was considered of paramount importance.

Angus Crichton-Miller, chairman of the RCA, said: "It has been very difficult to pick between two excellent bidders. Ultimately, the more certain coverage both of quality and quantity by Go Racing was the deciding factor.

"There remain some important issues to be settled during the exclusivity period, but I will be disappointed if we cannot resolve them. It will ultimately be up to the racecourses to conclude the deal by December 15."

David Scott, for Go Racing, commented: "We warmly welcome the RCA's recommendation that its members should accept our offer and we look forward to working with all the racecourses to conclude the right agreement and to establish Go Racing as a strong business for the benefit of everyone."

It is thought that the RCA received far from a unanimous backing of the racecourses, but the big tracks under the RHT banner Northern Racing and Arena held sway and made up the necessary 70 per cent of total off-course betting turnover demanded by Go Racing.

In return, Go Racing promises to deliver 4,000 hours of live racing each year - increasing their current 104 days of terrestrial coverage on Channel 4 - and will include a daily Channel 4 lunchtime programme. There will also be improved coverage on Sky Sports with 60 Winning Post programmes (covering two meetings at a time).

Crucially, from the revenue point of view, there will be a dedicated Go Racing channel on digital TV with interactive global betting through the cable company NTL.

Crichton-Miller added: "As we get into the interactive era it becomes more important that we maximize our audience and therefore increase betting turnover and revenue."

Channel 4's link-up with Sky means five million satellite homes will receive the channel from day one and NTL will mean a further 12 million homes are located within its network.

webTitle: E4 signs cable carriage deal with Telewest

fields.headline: E4 signs cable carriage deal with Telewest
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Channel 4's new pay-TV service, E4, has clinched a deal to be carried on Telewest cable networks, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's new pay-TV entertainment service has clinched a deal to be carried on Telewest cable networks.

The deal means that E4 will be available to all of the cable giant's1.6m analogue and digital subscribers, except those taking the company's digital starter package.

E4, which is due to launch on January 18, has already secured access to NTL's 200,000 digital TV subscribers.

A distribution deal with ONdigital is also thought to be close.

webTitle: Menzies slaps writ on rival WHS

fields.headline: Menzies slaps writ on rival WHS
fields.standfirst:
Nov 28: Mirror/Telegraph rethink distribution
Nov 27: Distribution row escalates
Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WH Smith
fields.trailText:
8am: John Menzies has issued a writ against WH Smith's wholesale newspaper business for alleged abuse of market share, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 28: Mirror/Telegraph rethink distribution
Nov 27: Distribution row escalates
Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WH Smith
fields.body:
John Menzies has issued a writ against WH Smith's wholesale newspaper business for alleged abuse of market share and for pressuring magazine companies to break contracts with it.

The newsagent and wholesaler is also suing H Bauer and Magazine Marketing Company for breach of contract.

The move comes after WH Smith was told that Associated Newspapers, which publishes the Mail and Mail on Sunday, would terminate two-thirds of its distribution deals with the WH Smith within six months.

Publishers of newspapers and magazines claim that WH Smith is trying to strong-arm them onto its proposed national distribution system, and have criticised its "bully-boy" tactics.

webTitle: Bertelsman dials into European mobile market

fields.headline: Bertelsman dials into European mobile market
fields.trailText: 8.15am: German media group Bertelsmann is set for a major push into the European mobile phone market, writes Dan Milmo
fields.body:
German media group Bertelsmann is set for a major push into the European mobile phone market.

The group will become a "virtual mobile phone operator", sending music, print and TV content to customers' handsets.

The third generation mobile networks will provide customers with high-speed internet access and video images.

The unveiling of Bertelsmann's plans comes just weeks after merger talks opened with UK music giant EMI, which could lead to the creation of the world's largest music company.

The multimedia powerhouse is bidding for space on next-generation networks in Germany, with the view to expanding across the rest of the continent and into the UK.

A Bertelsmann spokesman said: "We are going to look into several markets. We are talking to several providers with international links."

The spokesman confirmed that Bertelsmann was negotiating with Deutsche Telekom, which bought a UK mobile phone licence earlier this year through its One2One subsidiary. Other companies involved in talks include Viag Interkom, which is owned by BT.

The company's music arm, BMG, has already signed a peace agreement with rogue internet site Napster, and music will play a key role in the new venture.

"It is the same as with Napster. We are trying to set up a platform which music customers can use," added the spokesman.

Third generation networks will not start operating in Germany until 2002, but today's announcement underlines the scale of Bertelsmann's new media ambitions.

The privately owned company controls the Cdnow, bol.com and barnesandnoble websites, and surprised the corporate music community with the Napster deal.

Earlier this month, Bertelsmann formed a strategic alliance with Napster to develop the website into a secure, membership-based service.

The current system lets web surfers download music files from the net without paying a subscription or royalties. So far, rival music companies have refused to follow Bertelsmann's lead.

webTitle: Morgan Stanley launches TV ads

fields.headline: Morgan Stanley credit card unveils TV ad blitz
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is launching a TV ad campaign with the aim of becoming the UK's most sought-after credit card company, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is launching a national TV campaign this week with the ambitious aim of becoming the UK's most sought-after credit card company.

Advertising agency Leo Burnett has created three TV ads and a national press campaign for the brand's second major advertising burst.

Tyrrell Schmidt, executive director of global marketing, said: "The aim of this campaign is to raise the profile of the card and make it the most desirable credit card you could have in your wallet."

The TV ads focus on the unconscious gestures made by customers in a bar. In one ad, a woman raises her eyebrows, another bites her lip, while a man hooks his thumbs in his belt. Viewers are told, "Only 7% of communication is verbal".

As a man puts his Morgan Stanley card on the bar, a woman looks impressed. The copy continues to read, "Make the other 93% count". A second commercial is set at a racetrack and the third at an airport.

Steve Jones, creative director at Leo Burnett, said: "The insight behind the campaign is that every day we send out hundreds of signals - a lot of the time without knowing it and most of the time without saying anything. The things we use, wear or carry with us say a lot about us."

There are four executions of the print campaign, which will use the taglines, "People appreciate being recognised", "With every gesture we make we give something away", "We all desire human contact" and "We're constantly sending messages".

Gerard de Thame directed the commercials and photography for the print campaign was by Henrik Knudsen.

webTitle: Guinness goes global

fields.headline: Guinness goes global
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Guinness, the brand behind last year's award-winning 'Surfers' commercial, is seeking its first global ad agency, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Guinness, the brand behind the award-winning "Surfers" commercial of last year, is looking for its first global ad agency.

Saatchi & Saatchi and Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, two of the company's existing roster agencies, will fight it out for the business, which will be worth many millions of pounds.

This year Guinness has spent £15m in the UK alone. In the 12 months to the end of June, the brand spent £233m on advertising and promotion worldwide.

It is not clear at this stage whether Guinness will invite any other agencies to compete but an appointment is expected by the end of the year.

AMV handles advertising for the brand in the UK, and was behind the "Surfers" ad, while Saatchi looks after the account in Africa and the Caribbean.

HHCL & Partners, which handles the brand in Ireland, will not pitch for the global account.

Jon Potter, global brand director for Guinness, is overseeing the pitch.

He said: "Guinness has an unmatched record when it comes to producing creative, compelling advertising.

"Moving to a single global agency will allow us to develop new and groundbreaking advertising in all of our markets, not two or three.

"Given the global diversity of the Guinness brand in terms of geography and format, this move will not necessarily lead to a single creative execution globally. If, over time, we are convinced that there is opportunity to do this, naturally we would consider it.

"For now, our priority is to build a strong partnership with an agency which can deliver excellent creative work that really connects with our consumers in all our major markets."

webTitle: Mytaxi.com rides again

fields.headline: Mytaxi.com rides again
fields.trailText: 8.15am:Shopping portal Mytaxi.com is planning a comeback, complete with a new business-to-business proposition. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Mytaxi.com, one of the UK's first online shopping portals, is to make a comeback, complete with a new business-to-business proposition.

The strategy rejig follows the £12m acquisition of parent company Taxi Interactive by Affinity Internet Holdings at the end of last year.

Mytaxi.com now boasts stronger personalisation features and a price comparison engine, pitching it against the likes of Kelkoo.com, shopsmart and easyValue.

A low-key online and viral campaign will support the staged relaunch, although there are plans to beef up the marketing activity over the next three years.

Titus Adams, mytaxi.com group director, said the service had been repositioned as an e-commerce resource. The company is also working to extend its involvement with co-venture websites.

He added: "We were one of the first in the e-commerce space and because Affinity allows us to now tap into telephony, gaming, recruitment and internet services, it seemed logical to provide a total business-to-business solution."

Mytaxi.com was set up in 1997 as a personal web organiser that users had to download to desktops. Since then it has had a number of revamps and moved away from being a downloaded application to a web-based portal.

webTitle: Asahi abandons cheesy ad campaign

fields.trailText: 8am: Asahi Beer, the brand immortalised by ads starring B-list celebrities including Bonnie Langford and Henry Kelly, is getting a makeover, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Asahi Beer, the brand immortalised by a string of B-list celebrities including Bonnie Langford and Henry Kelly, is getting a makeover.

All three have appeared in ads across billboards and London Underground stations in a recent Asahi Super Dry campaign.

Mr Kelly, donning a white bathrobe, looked comfortable in the knowledge that his naffness provided the punchline.

Now the marketing executives at Bass, the brand's parent company, have decided that Asahi needs a new approach.

McCann Erickson has been appointed to handle all future advertising for the brand. In total the business is worth around £3m.

A pitch was called after its previous ad agency, WCRS, split with Bass earlier this year.

webTitle: Business: Governor says joining euro means return to tax and spend policy

fields.headline: Governor says joining euro means return to tax and spend policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, said yesterday the government would have to rely more on taxation and spending policy to control the economy if Britain joined the euro.
fields.body:
Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, said yesterday the government would have to rely more on taxation and spending policy to control the economy if Britain joined the euro.

In remarks likely to fuel the political debate over membership of the monetary union, Sir Eddie told Treasury select committee MPs that ceding control over interest rates to the European Central Bank would shift the burden to fiscal policymaking.

"We would have to look more to fiscal policy ... and that would involve recognition by the people of this country that their behaviour would have to be driven by the need to control control inflation," said Sir Eddie. "That could affect the behaviour of the labour market."

If Britain joined the euro, say economists, it would be even more important to exercise wage restraint to prevent cost increases feeding through to higher inflation.

Without the ability to control interest rates the Treasury may have to increase taxes or cut public spending to prevent a wage-price spiral.

In the Bank of England's latest inflation report Sir Eddie said economic convergence would have to be a condition of UK entry to the euro zone.

Business for Sterling, the anti-euro lobby group, said spiralling wage claims in Ireland proved Sir Eddie's point.

Chief executive Nick Herbert said: "The last thing Britain's modern economy wants is a return to the nightmare days of rising inflation and failing pay policies. If we had joined the euro two years ago and lost control of interest rates, we would now be suffering a job-destroying inflationary boom."

But Britain in Europe, the pro-euro lobby group, argued that joining would mean "safer jobs, more inward investment and greater prosperity". Pointing out that Sir Eddie had told a House of Lords committee in October that there was "no question" that joining the single currency would bring potential economic advantages, Kitty Ussher, the organisation's chief economist, said: "Decisions on tax would still be up to the British government if we joined the euro - the German government has recently decided to cut taxes."

Sir Eddie cautioned yesterday's Commons hearing against generalising from the experience of Ireland. It was a small economy suffering from the double impact of euro weakness and its large exposure to the UK.

Turning to the outlook for UK interest rates, pegged at 6% since February, Sir Eddie said the Bank was unconcerned about the spending increases announced in the pre-Budget report.

The chancellor had simply recycled the extra tax receipts unexpectedly harvested by the Treasury since the last Budget, he said.

But the Bank would not hesitate to raise interest rates if the chancellor made large tax cuts next March, threatening the inflation target - even on the eve of a general election. "It would be our duty, our legal duty, to do what we had to do [to deliver the government's inflation target]," Sir Eddie said.

webTitle: The best extra-marital scene - Wonder Boys

fields.headline: The best extra-marital scene - Wonder Boys
fields.trailText: English professor and once-ascendant novelist Grady Tripp (Michael Douglas) stands with his mistress - and university chancellor - Sara Gaskell (Frances McDormand) in the latter's bedroom, as a literary party goes on downstairs. The room is stuffed full of baseball memorabilia belonging to Sara's husband Walter. Grady nods at a vintage New York Yankees' pennant.
fields.body:
English professor and once-ascendant novelist Grady Tripp (Michael Douglas) stands with his mistress - and university chancellor - Sara Gaskell (Frances McDormand) in the latter's bedroom, as a literary party goes on downstairs. The room is stuffed full of baseball memorabilia belonging to Sara's husband Walter. Grady nods at a vintage New York Yankees' pennant.

"New?"

"Walter just got it back from the framer today."

Sara takes Grady's hand, leading him away from the pennant and towards the bed. They sit beside one another. Sara turns to Grady.

"You go first."

"Alright," Grady shrugs. "Well, this morning_"

"I'm pregnant."

A burst of laughter can be heard from downstairs.

Grady stammers in panic.

"Uh... ah ... uh... ah..."

"I'm sure."

Grady exhales.

"Well. This is ... surprising. Does Walter ...?"

"I think Walter would find this a little more than surprising."

Grady nods, then rolls onto his back.

"Emily left me this morning."

"She's left before."

"She's left the room before. She always came back."

Sara nods. There is a brief silence before she speaks again.

"So, I guess we just divorce our spouses, marry each other, and have this baby, right? Simple."

Grady stares at the ceiling.

"Simple."

Don't see also: The Scarlet Letter, Random Hearts

Pointless trivia: Frances McDormand once shared an apartment in New York with Sam Raimi, Holly Hunter, and her future husband, director Joel Coen.

webTitle: News: Turner winner riles the Stuckists

fields.headline: Turner winner riles the Stuckists
fields.trailText: Photographer Wolfgang Tillmans beat an embroiderer, an artfully arranged pile of rubbish and a painter accused of plagiarising the work of an obscure science fiction illustrator to take the £20,000 Turner Prize last night.
fields.body:
Photographer Wolfgang Tillmans beat an embroiderer, an artfully arranged pile of rubbish and a painter accused of plagiarising the work of an obscure science fiction illustrator to take the £20,000 Turner Prize last night.

German-born Tillmans, who has worked and exhibited in London in recent years, has smashed the boundary between commercial photography and art: much of his early work was for fashion magazines, including a famous image of four of his friends sitting in the branches of a tree, not wearing any clothes at all.

The jury said his work engaged with contemporary culture, while challenging conventional aesthetics. The panel, headed by the Tate director, Sir Nicholas Serota, declared itself impressed by his ability to create striking images from everyday subjects, and said he was taking photography in new directions, not only in technique but also in presentation.

"I sort of thought I could have a good chance," said Mr Tillmans after accepting the cheque, which he may spend on an even bigger and better camera.

Citing the old masters Caravaggio and Pontormo as major influences, Mr Tillmans was a popular winner. Norman Rosenthal, sharp-tongued secretary of the Royal Academy, said: "An artist of whom I approve has won - that's a very rare thing to happen."

Mr Tillmans's triumph was a bonus for the Stuckists, the anarchic art movement co-founded by Billy Childish, a former boyfriend of the artist Tracy Emin - the name comes from her bitter insult that his art was stuck - who turned up in clown suits last night to picket the awards ceremony at Tate Britain in London.

The Stuckists are scathing about the Turner Prize , and the Tate director, saying both have betrayed the traditional skills of drawing and painting. Sir Nicholas lashed back in his Dimbleby lecture last week: the new media - including video, sound pieces and conceptual art - were here to stay, he said there was no chance that contemporary art would "come to its senses" and turn the clock back.

This year's shortlist was a poor platform for Stuckist protests, with Glenn Brown working in oil on canvas with a technique described as "old masterly", and Michael Raedecker's delicate figurative landscapes in paint and embroidery. But Tillmans's success was a gift to them. "Art is art and photography is photography," snarled co-founder Charles Thomson, a painter.

Tillmans's victory - he was an early favourite of the bookmakers - was overshadowed by bickering about whether imitation of one artist's work by another is flattery or plagiarism.

The Turner Prize has lifted contemporary art on to a new publicity plane, partly by generating an annual row about the nature of art. In the past the dispute has been about Emin's rumpled bed (pipped for last year's prize), Chris Ofili's elephant dung (which took the prize two years ago) and Damien Hirst's pickled shark (a winner in 1995).

This year there seemed nothing to fight about except the fact that three of the four artists were not born in Britain, and that the shy Japanese Tomoko Takahashi works with carefully arranged piles of rubbish.

The calm was broken with the 11th-hour revelation, emanating from science fiction addicts with long memories, that a huge canvas by Glenn Brown borrowed heavily from a 1974 Pan book jacket by Anthony Roberts, for a novel called Double Star.

The fact that Mr Brown's other works on show borrowed equally heavily from Watteau, Auerbach and Salvador Dali, and that the painting was labelled "The Loves of the Shepherds (after Tony Roberts)" did nothing to quell the storm. Copyright experts and the Association of Illustrators said they were uneasy.

By last night Roberts had been tracked down in East Sussex, and seemed amused rather than outraged: he'd known nothing about it, he said, and this was the only Turner Prize exhibition he'd missed in years.

Brown said he had tried to contact the publishers, but got no response. "I'm a fan of all the artists I refer to, including Tony Roberts. I pick artists I like and those that I feel aren't given enough credit, such as Watteau, John Martin and Chris Foss." He also maintained he had "radically altered Roberts's work in terms of scale and colour".

webTitle: Key worker homes plan leaves deeper issues unanswered

fields.headline: Key worker homes plan leaves deeper issues unanswered
fields.standfirst: Few would argue with the idea of affordable housing for essential workers. But many are questioning why this measure has become necessary in the first place, writes Radhika Holmstrom
fields.trailText: Few would argue with the idea of affordable housing for essential workers. But many are questioning why this measure has become necessary in the first place, writes Radhika Holmstrom
fields.body:
A newly qualified grade D nurse working in London is eligible for a mortgage of £51,000. The cheapest one-bedroom properties in London still cost around £10,000 more than that. There is a recruitment crisis in the NHS. Are the two related?

The staffing crisis extends to services such as education and the police, and beyond London to the rest of south-east England, as well as areas such as York and East Anglia. Government housing and regeneration strategies aim for an ideal of mixed, stable communities, and recognise the role "key workers" ought to play. But at the moment there are not enough key workers do the work in the first place.

The housing green paper proposes to help key workers access accommodation and £250m should be available from April 2001. The paper outlines proposals for a starter home initiative, working with registered social landlords and others, and also suggests possibilities for other schemes, which could include mortgage relief.

To some extent this kind of provision is already available. Islington and Shoreditch Housing Association has just started work on a £14m regeneration scheme in the inner London area of Hackney, with Kensington Housing Trust providing 34 clusters of key worker accommodation for Moorfields Eye Hospital. Elsewhere, local authorities such as Newham ringfence some social housing specifically for teachers.

The Starter Home Initiative is expected to build on these models. However, the new proposals are meeting a considerable degree of scepticism. Housing agencies are broadly in favour, but they have some serious questions.

The first is over the form the scheme will take. Mortgage relief could upset the tax system without delivering the housing results. Shelter adds that working with private landlords could skew the definition of "affordable" accommodation.

Shelter, like the National Housing Federation (NHF), advocates some form of shared ownership and/or flexible tenure, to provide a "staircase" between renting and ownership.

The London Housing Federation, which has extensive experience of shared ownership schemes, cites existing projects with housing associations such as Tower and Hyde. Tenants buy a share of a property, pay rent on the other part, and buy more shares if they choose. Tim Southall, of the NHF, suggests developing this and linked forms of shared ownership into a "common product" which could meet the needs of lower-income workers.

However, not all lower-income workers are key workers. Housing agencies are keen that others in housing need are not displaced in favour of key workers - this would not do much for "mixed communities" in any case. And this leads to the central question - who is a key worker?

Hospital porters and ambulance drivers might fall outside the definition, but they are crucial parts of the service. Developments like NHS trusts complicate the issue further, even before the recent moves to outsource some NHS operations into the private sector. The situation is further clouded by the increasing numbers of self-employed or agency staff who support different aspects of the key services.

One housing specialist described the dilemma: "You can keep the definition very restricted - or widen it and skew the whole housing market." Mr Southall suggests that one way round this could be "key worker" definitions at local or unitary authority level.

The biggest issue with the key worker housing proposals is, of course, whether they will actually do what they are supposed to. Although the Royal College of Nursing advocates specific provision for nurses, it is clear that this is only part of a wider problem. The reason nurses qualify for shared ownership is they cannot afford the costs in the private housing market. Accommodation will solve that part of the problem, but will not compensate for overall salary levels.

The National Union of Teachers is even more direct. A spokeswoman said: "The profession is struggling to recruit not because housing is expensive, but because the salaries, working conditions and hours make teaching an unattractive profession to young graduates." This accords with the feeling from areas which already provide subsidised housing for new teachers - the measures they are taking do not solve the underlying problem.

Few people, if any, will query the need for key workers and most are in favour of helping them through shared or low cost ownership schemes. However, at the moment the other questions far outweigh any answers on the table.

webTitle: Boy's murder should be wake-up call - Straw

fields.headline: Boy's murder should be wake-up call - Straw
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The killing of a 10-year-old boy in south London should be a wake-up call to British society, the home secretary said today.
fields.body:
The killing of a 10-year-old boy in south London should be a wake-up call to British society, the home secretary said today.

The murder of Damilola Taylor, who was stabbed to death in Peckham, south-east London, should alert the country to the urgent need for a new culture of responsibility to turn back the tide of thuggery, bullying and violence, Jack Straw said.

Police are hunting for three boys seen near Damilola as he bled to death. He was stabbed as he walked home from school, where he had allegedly been bullied. Detectives are carrying out forensic tests on a broken bottle believed to have been a possible murder weapon.

In the House of Commons this afternoon the prime minister, Tony Blair, told MPs that the whole country was "shocked and outraged" at Damilola's "appalling and brutal murder". "We must do everything we can to bring his killers to justice," he said.

Earlier Mr Straw told an Institute for Public Policy Research conference in London that clamping down on street violence will be a key task of the next Labour government. His speech followed the publication of statistics which show that while property crime has declined since 1997, violent offences have soared.

The home secretary called for a new sense of responsibility in British society to counter the so-called "lad" culture of excessive drinking, irresponsibility and violence.

Mr Straw was backed by the education secretary, David Blunkett. He criticised passersby who failed to come to the aid of Damilola as he bled to death after being stabbed by older youths. "We have got to create a society where people do not run away from anything, but face up to it and are prepared to be engaged and involved," Mr Blunkett said.

Offering his condolences to Damilola's family, Mr Straw added: "This tragedy is one that must teach and affect us all and one from which we have to draw very important lessons."

Mr Blunkett also had critical words for the TV quiz show Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, which he said undermined social responsibility by fostering a culture in which material wealth and consumption were all-important.

Outlining government plans for new measures to tackle disorder on the streets, Mr Straw restated the government's commitment to fixed penalty notices for anti-social behaviour, which were widely derided when the prime minister, Tony Blair, first proposed that drunken louts could be marched to cash dispensing machines for instant fines.

Mr Straw said: "Over the last three years we have shown that we can start to win the war against crime - especially burglary and vehicle crime, which we have specifically been targetting. The next three years, we have to turn the tide against violent crime as well.

"I believe that we can do it. We will give the police the resources and tools that they need. But at the end of the day, it is each individual's sense of social responsibility rather than external sanctions that ultimately will control people's behaviour one towards another."

Mr Straw promised new laws to regulate nightclub bouncers. He also new powers to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs; to stop on-street drinking; more investment in town centre surveillance cameras.

webTitle: Cambridge homeless

fields.headline: The cold shoulder
fields.standfirst: Alexander Masters walks bleak Cambridge streets with homeless people affected by the government's decision not to fund winter shelters and  David Brindle looks at the council line
fields.trailText: Alexander Masters walks bleak Cambridge streets with homeless people affected by the government's decision not to fund winter shelters and David Brindle looks at the council line
fields.body:
For three nights, I've been walking among the cemeteries and dank toilets of Cambridge with Sam, a homeless Gypsy who lives in the back of a broken down van. He and his wife have been on the streets for a year, and they are frightened half to death because this year - for the first time in a decade - there will be no government funding for emergency winter shelters for homeless people in the city, or indeed anywhere else outside London. Winter shelters, it seems, are bad for the homeless.

Sam is 22, a car mechanic and part-time gardener. He has been sleeping rough since his family kicked him out for marrying a non-Romani. His wife, a slight woman also in her early 20s, has eight GCSEs.

Each night we met in the same place, outside a public lavatory, with the steeples of King's and Jesus colleges silhouetted by city lights in the distance. On the first night, five people, including two women, are getting ready to sleep here, on a small concrete porch overlooking the playing fields. When the rain gets too hard, they move into the toilet cubicles, or clamber over the fence to huddle in the changing rooms of the nearby outdoor swimming pool.

Across the park, there is another public toilet where an old lady sleeps; she likes to keep the place clean, so she washes the floor during the day. Some of the homeless are mentally ill, many are illiterate; a few are former businessmen or have degrees.

Up in the cemetery I find the most tragic couple I have ever seen - crouched in an abandoned outhouse, blankets spread out on the mud floor. An umbrella propped against the sodden wall deflects the flow of water coming through the roof and empty windows. She is about 25, pleasant, polite and ludicrously swaddled. I cannot see his face clearly. He has bowel cancer and is not expected to survive the winter.

"Look where he's lying, sir," says Sam. "There must be somewhere open where they could at least temporarily house him and his wife. Look, how can you sleep with an umbrella above your head?" The rain splatters across everything.

You don't have to be around the city long to get to know how ill or disabled some of these people are. One, familiar to Cambridge people, cannot hear or speak and grunts when he begs for money; another is blind and is often beaten up or has his stick stolen; a third has muscular dystrophy.

The city council's latest estimate - based on a count in early October - is that there are 18 people sleeping on the streets. The figure has caused widespread scepticism among homelessness workers and is thoroughly disbelieved by the homeless themselves. "There's loads more than that," retorts the woman in the cemetery. "About 40." Sam and I find 30 in one night, and that is in just two-and-a-half hours, covering about a fifth of the official counting area.

There is a lot of money riding on these figures. The government has insisted that it will reduce the number of street sleepers by two-thirds by the year 2002, and Cambridge council housing department relies on government approval to secure funding. It has not gone unnoticed that the council's headcount comfortably meets the target decrease: a 40% reduction over the past three years.

"I've been everywhere in the country as a Romani," says Sam, "but I've never seen so many homeless people as in Cambridge. The trouble is that the council and police don't know about many of the places where the homeless sleep. There's a derelict barge on the river somewhere, for example, and an old hut by the railway station."

"Is that the one where you can hear all the rats?' asks one person begging at the University Church. "Nah," replies Sam, "they've found another skipper since then."

One place I especially wanted to see was described to me as a strange hole in a wall, where you have to squeeze through a narrow gap to get inside. It is apparently behind a lamp post, but nobody would tell me where in case the word got out. In the absence of a winter shelter, it is particularly important that the best locations remain secret.

The other week, at the beginning of the rain storms, the police said that anyone found sleeping on the underground floors of the covered car park near Emmanuel college would be arrested. This was especially bad news because the subterranean floors are among the most popular spots in the city, with up to 15 people sleeping there. They are warm, quiet and almost safe.

Then there are the locked places, which nobody thinks the homeless have a key to. As the weather worsens, the fuller they become. Sam knocks on one of them. "Bunker, it's Sam," he shouts. I can hear faint voices, but nobody responds. "They won't answer," explains Sam. "The homeless don't believe that anyone would do anything for them. They think you want to steal their sleeping bags. They think you're the police."

There is a medieval quality about street life here - not just in the way these people live, but in the brute intensity of their fears: money, sex and death, in that order.

It is standard for somebody to come on to Sam's wife when they are out begging. "'If you let your girlfriend suck me off, I'll give you a fiver.' You get that one about every half hour,' Sam says. The other day, a man offered her a flat. "Don't mind about the rent," he said. "Just move in and we'll come to some arrangement."

Another popular joke is to pull out a handful of money and give only a penny. People frequently shout abuse, and sometimes Sam argues back. He and his wife cannot get work because no employer will take them without an address. They cannot get an address because landlords demand a deposit and a month's payment in advance, whereas housing benefit - for which they would be eligible - does not cover a deposit and pays only two weeks in arrears. Now they are also finding it difficult to beg, because the government has decreed that begging, too, is bad for the homeless.

Across the street, by the city's new £3m swimming pool, is another multi-storey car park. We find nobody there, but we do see some clothes and a book. These belong to Sally, missing for about a week. Nobody knows where she is, but the rumour is that she has been taken down to London to be a prostitute. Apparently, she was nice looking.

As we walk back through the city, we pass a fight brewing among eight rough sleepers in the bus shelter. One is accusing the others of stealing his bike. Sam tries to calm them down, because two are his friends and the man accusing them is supposed to have contacts with Jamaican gangsters. He and another person - I keep well back, so I don't see who - start trying to stab each other with syringes, while a third takes a drink of lighter fluid and threatens to burn the accuser's face off. Eventually, Sam's devotion to his friends pays off, and the rumpus ceases.

As we walk away, he says: "It is a rough old world out there, mate. There's the world that other people survive in and there's this world. That's why we need winter shelters, to keep the weaker ones alive."

But Cambridge is adamant that it will toe the New Labour line: providing the homeless with warmth and a place to lie down off the streets encourages them to remain homeless.

What are the options? One approach, used in Brighton, is a "rolling shelter". An existing hostel sets aside a certain number of beds, which are made available to rough sleepers on the coldest days. But the Cambridge hostels are full every night.

In Manchester, charity workers have discovered they can get money for winter accommodation, provided the homeless are not allowed to lie down while they are there. It's what the Victorians used to call a "penny sit up": for a penny, somebody living on the streets could sit indoors on a wooden bench. In Cambridge, though, there is no money even for this ploy.

Another rough sleeper died the other day: Taz, a middle-aged alcoholic. Nobody knew much about him - he'd been in Cambridge a little over a week - but the word is that he had come to the city because he expected to find shelter during the cold months. His life ended down by the bus station, on the first night of the winter frosts.

Sam and I finish our walks at about 2.30am, after checking the pavilion by the tennis courts and the toilets next to the DSS offices and recycling bins. "What would you do if you got the van fixed?" I ask, as he clambers back inside and slides beneath his thin duvet. The material is damp, because of condensation dripping from the roof. "I'm a Romani," Sam says. "I know about seasonal work. I'd go to Penzance to pick flowers."

 Alexander Masters is a freelance journalist whose clients include a homelessness charity in Cambridge

Official line: It's time to move on
David Brindle

Naisha Polaine, Cambridge council's housing needs manager, vehemently denies any deliberate undercounting of numbers sleeping rough in the city. When the October count yielded a figure of 18, she says, local homelessness charities put the true total no higher than 25.

"There is no political line in terms of doing what central government wants us to do," insists Polaine. "The local politicians in Cambridge say they want us to sort out street homelessness - and that's just what we are trying to do."

Last winter, the government provided £280,000 for a 28-bed winter shelter that was open for four months. "We know that 50% of those bed spaces were used by people who came specifically to Cambridge because of the shelter," says Polaine. This winter, the council has spent £20,000 on move-on accommodation to free 21 beds in year-round hostels, available from next Monday. "To me, that's trying to make best use of public resources, it's trying to be inventive and to find different solutions."

Polaine, who says she has £250,000 "new money" from the government to help the street homeless, dismisses accusations of heartlessness. "I'm trying to help our people who are the most entrenched rough sleepers," she says. "There are seven or 10 of them, and I know their names."

 Alexander Masters is a freelance journalist whose clients include a homelessness charity in Cambridge
