Some of the homeless are mentally ill, many are illiterate; a few are former businessmen or have degrees. Up in the cemetery I find the most tragic couple I have ever seen - crouched in an abandoned outhouse, blankets spread out on the mud floor. An umbrella propped against the sodden wall deflects the flow of water coming through the roof and empty windows. She is about 25, pleasant, polite and ludicrously swaddled. I cannot see his face clearly. He has bowel cancer and is not expected to survive the winter. "Look where he's lying, sir," says Sam. "There must be somewhere open where they could at least temporarily house him and his wife. Look, how can you sleep with an umbrella above your head?" The rain splatters across everything. You don't have to be around the city long to get to know how ill or disabled some of these people are. One, familiar to Cambridge people, cannot hear or speak and grunts when he begs for money; another is blind and is often beaten up or has his stick stolen; a third has muscular dystrophy. The city council's latest estimate - based on a count in early October - is that there are 18 people sleeping on the streets. The figure has caused widespread scepticism among homelessness workers and is thoroughly disbelieved by the homeless themselves. "There's loads more than that," retorts the woman in the cemetery. "About 40." Sam and I find 30 in one night, and that is in just two-and-a-half hours, covering about a fifth of the official counting area. There is a lot of money riding on these figures. The government has insisted that it will reduce the number of street sleepers by two-thirds by the year 2002, and Cambridge council housing department relies on government approval to secure funding. It has not gone unnoticed that the council's headcount comfortably meets the target decrease: a 40% reduction over the past three years. "I've been everywhere in the country as a Romani," says Sam, "but I've never seen so many homeless people as in Cambridge. The trouble is that the council and police don't know about many of the places where the homeless sleep. There's a derelict barge on the river somewhere, for example, and an old hut by the railway station." "Is that the one where you can hear all the rats?' asks one person begging at the University Church. "Nah," replies Sam, "they've found another skipper since then." One place I especially wanted to see was described to me as a strange hole in a wall, where you have to squeeze through a narrow gap to get inside. It is apparently behind a lamp post, but nobody would tell me where in case the word got out. In the absence of a winter shelter, it is particularly important that the best locations remain secret. The other week, at the beginning of the rain storms, the police said that anyone found sleeping on the underground floors of the covered car park near Emmanuel college would be arrested. This was especially bad news because the subterranean floors are among the most popular spots in the city, with up to 15 people sleeping there. They are warm, quiet and almost safe. Then there are the locked places, which nobody thinks the homeless have a key to. As the weather worsens, the fuller they become. Sam knocks on one of them. "Bunker, it's Sam," he shouts. I can hear faint voices, but nobody responds. "They won't answer," explains Sam. "The homeless don't believe that anyone would do anything for them. They think you want to steal their sleeping bags. They think you're the police." There is a medieval quality about street life here - not just in the way these people live, but in the brute intensity of their fears: money, sex and death, in that order. It is standard for somebody to come on to Sam's wife when they are out begging. "'If you let your girlfriend suck me off, I'll give you a fiver.' You get that one about every half hour,' Sam says. The other day, a man offered her a flat. "Don't mind about the rent," he said. "Just move in and we'll come to some arrangement." Another popular joke is to pull out a handful of money and give only a penny. People frequently shout abuse, and sometimes Sam argues back. He and his wife cannot get work because no employer will take them without an address. They cannot get an address because landlords demand a deposit and a month's payment in advance, whereas housing benefit - for which they would be eligible - does not cover a deposit and pays only two weeks in arrears. Now they are also finding it difficult to beg, because the government has decreed that begging, too, is bad for the homeless. Across the street, by the city's new £3m swimming pool, is another multi-storey car park. We find nobody there, but we do see some clothes and a book. These belong to Sally, missing for about a week. Nobody knows where she is, but the rumour is that she has been taken down to London to be a prostitute. Apparently, she was nice looking. As we walk back through the city, we pass a fight brewing among eight rough sleepers in the bus shelter. One is accusing the others of stealing his bike. Sam tries to calm them down, because two are his friends and the man accusing them is supposed to have contacts with Jamaican gangsters. He and another person - I keep well back, so I don't see who - start trying to stab each other with syringes, while a third takes a drink of lighter fluid and threatens to burn the accuser's face off. Eventually, Sam's devotion to his friends pays off, and the rumpus ceases. As we walk away, he says: "It is a rough old world out there, mate. There's the world that other people survive in and there's this world. That's why we need winter shelters, to keep the weaker ones alive." But Cambridge is adamant that it will toe the New Labour line: providing the homeless with warmth and a place to lie down off the streets encourages them to remain homeless. What are the options? One approach, used in Brighton, is a "rolling shelter". An existing hostel sets aside a certain number of beds, which are made available to rough sleepers on the coldest days. But the Cambridge hostels are full every night. In Manchester, charity workers have discovered they can get money for winter accommodation, provided the homeless are not allowed to lie down while they are there. It's what the Victorians used to call a "penny sit up": for a penny, somebody living on the streets could sit indoors on a wooden bench. In Cambridge, though, there is no money even for this ploy. Another rough sleeper died the other day: Taz, a middle-aged alcoholic. Nobody knew much about him - he'd been in Cambridge a little over a week - but the word is that he had come to the city because he expected to find shelter during the cold months. His life ended down by the bus station, on the first night of the winter frosts. Sam and I finish our walks at about 2.30am, after checking the pavilion by the tennis courts and the toilets next to the DSS offices and recycling bins. "What would you do if you got the van fixed?" I ask, as he clambers back inside and slides beneath his thin duvet. The material is damp, because of condensation dripping from the roof. "I'm a Romani," Sam says. "I know about seasonal work. I'd go to Penzance to pick flowers."  Alexander Masters is a freelance journalist whose clients include a homelessness charity in Cambridge Official line: It's time to move on David Brindle Naisha Polaine, Cambridge council's housing needs manager, vehemently denies any deliberate undercounting of numbers sleeping rough in the city. When the October count yielded a figure of 18, she says, local homelessness charities put the true total no higher than 25. "There is no political line in terms of doing what central government wants us to do," insists Polaine. "The local politicians in Cambridge say they want us to sort out street homelessness - and that's just what we are trying to do." Last winter, the government provided £280,000 for a 28-bed winter shelter that was open for four months. "We know that 50% of those bed spaces were used by people who came specifically to Cambridge because of the shelter," says Polaine. This winter, the council has spent £20,000 on move-on accommodation to free 21 beds in year-round hostels, available from next Monday. "To me, that's trying to make best use of public resources, it's trying to be inventive and to find different solutions." Polaine, who says she has £250,000 "new money" from the government to help the street homeless, dismisses accusations of heartlessness. "I'm trying to help our people who are the most entrenched rough sleepers," she says. "There are seven or 10 of them, and I know their names."  Alexander Masters is a freelance journalist whose clients include a homelessness charity in Cambridge

webTitle: White paper tackles social exclusion in rural areas

fields.headline: White paper tackles social exclusion in rural areas
fields.trailText: The government has unveiled a raft of policies designed to tackle social exclusion and improve services in rural areas. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
The government has unveiled a raft of policies designed to tackle social exclusion and improve services in rural areas.

The long awaited rural white paper promises a five-point plan including measures to protect the countryside and give parish councils wide-ranging powers to increase the choice available to rural communities.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott told the Commons: "The white paper is about tackling the real issues that matter to people - jobs, housing, health, education and transport - and giving them a real say in what is happening in their town or village."

In a move that signals a shift away from the traditional rural policy pre-occupation with agriculture and countryside issues, ministers have used the white paper to tackle a wide range of social problems faced by the countryside. Among these are proposals to improve rural life through a set of minimum targets for all public services, including schools and transport.

The paper also proposes an injection of extra money into rural development, including a £37m fund to regenerate market towns, £270m of investment to retain threatened local post offices, and a range of funds to improve rural transport.

It sets measures to protect community services such as shops and pubs from the possibility of closure - they could have their business rates slashed by half, and could also benefit from a £15m fund designed to promote local services that benefit rural people.

The white paper attempts to tackle rural housing needs, promising to provide 9,000 affordable homes a year across all rural districts and using the planning system to secure a higher level of affordable housing in towns and villages.

Shire councils may gain more power to help deal with local housing needs with extra money raised by scrapping the 50% council tax discount on second homes. Ministers say they will consult on the proposals.

The government proposes to protect the countryside through legislation to maintain commons, and a £35m fund for improving the environment.

The white paper also suggests a range of measures to put rural issues at the heart of the policy-making process. These include a new rural advocate to argue the countryside's case within government, an annual report from the Countryside Agency setting out the impact of major new policies, and new rural sounding boards at the national and regional level.

This document is a high-profile attempt by the government to counter accusations from the Conservatives and groups such as the Countryside Alliance that ministers do not understand the countryside.

The Tories claim that the government has not pulled this off, pointing out that farming bankruptcies have risen by 18% since the election, country pubs are closing at the rate of six a week, and post offices are shutting at the rate of two a week. They believe Labour had underestimated the extent of the crisis facing the countryside.

Regeneration professionals, however, welcomed the paper. Vincent Watts, who speaks for England's nine regional development agencies at a national level, said: "The rural white paper presents a great opportunity to take a new direction in the rural economy - helping rural businesses, creating stronger communities and encouraging better links between town and country."

webTitle: New IT opportunities for disadvantaged communities

fields.headline: Training gets kick start
fields.standfirst: New IT opportunities for disadvantaged communities
fields.trailText: New IT opportunities for disadvantaged communities
fields.body:
A premiership football club is setting up an online centre to bring more than 4,000 local people into contact with information technology. The project, led by Sunderland FC and based at its Stadium of Light, is particularly targeted at older unemployed men and disabled people and their carers.

The project hopes to encourage people to attend classes by offering tours of the stadium and opportunities to meet the club's football players who are enthusiastic about the initiative, according to Sunderland's community manager, Bob Oats.

Some 15,000 young people are already coming through the stadium's classrooms each year. A new opportunities fund (NOF) grant of £259,736 will enable Sunderland to launch an adult learning programme in conjunction with the University of Sunderland.

The NOF is this week awarding a total of more than £6m to 46 schemes across the UK designed to help people from "deprived and disadvantaged communities" to access information and communications technologies (ICT). The Stadium of Light is one of three projects in the north-east receiving a total of £1.1m.

A project based at the National Centre for Popular Music, in Sheffield, is receiving £180,000 to train 5,000 local people in computing, numeracy, and literacy and linking these to media and creative skills.

You're Worth IT is one of five schemes in London to receive funding. Led by Harrow council, the project is being awarded £485,130 to deliver training across north-west London in partnership with seven organisations.

Awards worth £1.7m are also going to 10 schemes in the north-west; and nine in the south-west are receiving a total of almost £1m. Rural isolated communities are targeted by a Cornish project which involves a roving van, complete with computer equipment and tutors, offering basic IT classes to far-flung fishing villages.

Schemes in Scotland receive £742,871; Wales £425,624 and Northern Ireland £313,658.

Since the launch of its ITC grants programme in spring 1999, the NOF has awarded more than £300m.

Stephen Dunmore, NOF chief executive, says: "Learning these [ICT] specific skills brings not only knowledge vital for living in the 21st century but also the can-do confidence needed by so many disadvantaged communities."

webTitle: A fresh look for local democracy

fields.headline: Polls apart
fields.standfirst: Paul Humphries  on a fresh look for local democracy
fields.trailText: Paul Humphries on a fresh look for local democracy
fields.body:
For the first time, young people aged 15 and 16 are to go to the polls alongside adults and cast their votes in an official election. The people of Burngreave, in Sheffield, have decided to let the teenagers help choose the community's representatives on the body that will decide how up to £50m is spent on the area under a New Deal regeneration scheme.

Government guidelines make clear that schemes benefiting from the New Deal for communities must be "community-driven and inclusive" - and Burngreave has taken the civil servants at their word.

At a public meeting to decide how the community elections would be held, it was overwhelmingly agreed that the electoral register would not be the deciding factor in setting the franchise. The voting age would be lowered from 18 to 15 and, in addition, people not on the electoral roll - whether by oversight, choice or because they might be seeking asylum - would still be allowed to participate in the January postal ballot.

The move has not been without difficulties. A spokesman for the Burngreave New Deal project says the regional government office was initially "highly sceptical" of the idea. But the meeting voted overwhelmingly to go ahead and the Electoral Reform Society, which is organising the ballot through Electoral Reform Services, its commercial arm, was "positively enthusiastic".

The elected representatives will join others from Sheffield council, statutory agencies, the voluntary sector and the city's business community. No previous New Deal ballot has extended to 15 and 16-year-olds, but young people aged 17 were allowed to both vote and stand in the recent election on the Ocean estate in Tower Hamlets, east London - with a 17-year-old, Shahama Begum, elected female youth representative.

The Burngreave election will be based on a special electoral roll, comprising all residents over age 15 irrespective of nationality. Community research workers are assembling the register in collaboration with ERS.

The massive investment that New Deal will bring to this deprived area of Sheffield is long overdue. More than 40% of households in the district are claiming income support - double the city's average. One in five is out of work and 30% of theunemployed have never had a job. Life expectancy is relatively short and the suicide rate high. Burngreave also has a reputation for drugs, shootings and illegal drinking dens. But the vast majority of the multicultural community is law abiding and knows the district desperately needs the help that New Deal can bring.

No one knows it more than the young. The district has almost 1,300 people between 15 and 24, representing 14% of the local population. Sixteen-year-old Aman Quassim believes the local environment should be a top priority. "There must be improvements," she says. "A cleaner environment is essential, as is better housing. People deserve far better than they have. It's very good that we have been given the vote, and myself and my brother [Samia, also 16] will definitely use it to try and win these things for Burngreave."

The case for a cleaner environment is echoed by Mark Keyworth, 15, who says: "The whole area needs cleaning up and keeping in shape. We want a better place to live in and these elections give us the chance to voice our opinions. Now we'll have to wait and see what the candidates have to say."

Ali Dirir, 16, says he was excited to learn he is to have a vote. "It's a big step. I'll have to find out where each candidate stands and I'll no doubt discuss the issues with my family. Young people here need better facilities, especially sporting facilities. That would make a big difference to young people in Burngreave."

All three of these teenagers attend Fir Vale, the comprehensive school covering the district. Its recently announced 6% improvement in GCSE results is an indicator that it is turning itself round after being designated a government "fresh start" school two years ago.

Hugh Howe is head of Fir Vale. He believes the decision to lower the voting age to 15 for the elections is an important step for the community. "As a fresh start school, we've been given the opportunity to move ourselves forward and we're making good progress," he says. "It's good to see another investment coming, in the shape of New Deal. If you like, there's a fresh start for the community as well as the school. There are new funds, new opportunities and new ways of bringing democracy together. People are being given a say in how the New Deal money will be used - especially the 15, 16 and 17-year-olds."

The school sees itself as a focal point in the community, and learning about the democratic process is an important part of Fir Vale's curriculum, according to Howe. "The students learn about citizenship. They've been to the city's council chamber and to parliament. We have taught them how to be politically literate. They understand the voting process.

"They never dreamed that while still at school they would be part of that voting process. They thought they would have to wait until they were 18 for the chance to register their vote. But in January they will be given that chance. It's good news for them and it's good news for the community."

webTitle: The problem of low demand for social housing

fields.headline: Living room
fields.standfirst: How will bringing in the bulldozers solve the problem of low demand in social housing?  Alison Benjamin  reports
fields.trailText: How will bringing in the bulldozers solve the problem of low demand in social housing? Alison Benjamin reports
fields.body:
The Dick Lane estate stands three miles east of Bradford in the suburb of Tyersal. A concentration of 620 properties, it began as traditional, 30s, council-style housing and expanded in the 70s to include flats and bungalows. More than £2.5m is being pumped into the area to modernise homes, improve the environment and fund youth and community work. Yet the landlord is about to bring in the demolition squad.

This radical step is the result of a new approach that the landlord, the William Sutton Trust, is taking to tackle low demand and other housing issues across its 70 estates. In all, it is to bulldoze 418 homes, including 14 one-bedroom flats on Dick Lane.

The trust is one of the oldest housing providers in the country. Since its inception a century ago, it has been known for a somewhat paternalistic approach to its task of housing some of the poorest people in society. Now, though, that is about to change with the introduction of what it is calling its "property reinvestment strategy model" (Prism).

The model has been designed to enable the trust to target its repairs and modernisation expenditure on estates that are sustainable - rather then leave it ploughing money into homes that may end up lying empty in five years' time.

Low demand is plaguing many social landlords, notably in the north and the west midlands. Nationally, about 92,000 housing association homes (8% of the total) are reported to be unpopular for reasons ranging from poor reputation, and rising crime, to low housing costs that enable tenants to buy their own homes or rent privately.

Until now, many social landlords have been reluctant to acknowledge that certain neighbourhoods cannot be regenerated by their efforts alone, and might be irretrievable. But proposals in the government's housing green paper to link future capital funding to housing demand have focused minds, with some associations starting to consider demolition of certain homes on individual estates. In Newcastle upon Tyne, North British housing association has already demolished 50 homes, just three years after they were built, and the city council is proposing a 6,000 reduction in property numbers across the city.

What is new about the Prism model - officially launched today as a management tool for other housing associations to use - is its strategic approach across an entire housing stock, not just those pockets currently suffering low demand.

"For some years the trust had recognised the potential significance of changing demand and its impact on stock reinvestment," says Mike Morris, trust chief executive. "We felt that our properties, where it was becoming increasingly difficult to sustain tenancies, reflected an irrevocable decline of a local area and we needed an holistic way of deciding how to prioritise estates for stock reinvestment - and to decide in some areas whether that reinvestment was appropriate. Prism allows us to do this by comparing estates, like for like."

Prism is a four-stage process. The first two stages identified "at risk" estates. This was done by piecing together a social economic profile of an estate over the past year - looking at issues such as housing demand, unemployment, and the local authority's investment in the area - followed by a five-year profile. Each issue was given a benchmark against which to determine risk. Although some statistics cover a whole ward, not neighbourhoods, the model was able to identify 19 "at risk" estates. They went forward to a third stage, where reinvestment proposals were put forward in the light of the estate's profile and subjected to a cost/benefit analysis, taking on board non-monetary, "social" costs and benefits. Those proposals were then put to tenants and other stakeholders, including the council, to agree a preferred option.

The two-year process across William Sutton's 15,700 houses and flats threw up a number of surprises, not least the identification of two of the trust's London estates as at risk, because of crime and anti-social behaviour, and the highlighting of a further 10 estates in Milton Keynes and Bedford as borderline cases.

Spurred on by an independent steering group of housing professionals, the Prism team, led by Angela Garrard, trust reinvestment strategy manager, came up with radical solutions such as partial demolition on estates. As a result, the 418 homes will be pulled down, but a further 576 will be modernised, and a raft of environmental and social improvements will be introduced over the next 10 years at a total cost of £84m.

"We were aware that the cheapest option would not necessarily be the most cost effective in terms of social benefits, once our tenants' views had been taken on board," says Garrard. "The council is crucial to the process. Our estates are not satellites; they are part of a wider community and we need to encourage partnership with the council and other partners to make areas sustainable."

Dick Lane is one example of where a local authority has poured money into regenerating a neighbouring area - in this case, Holmewood, creating knock-on benefits for the trust's tenants such as a new leisure complex where some of them now work. The council is also contributing towards highway and parking improvements on the estate, and is supporting a community plan for the whole of Tyersal that includes attracting shops to an area poorly served by supermarkets.

Tenant Betty Waterhouse, who is both secretary of the residents' association and chair of the estate management committee, which comprises tenants and trust officers, professes herself thrilled that the demolition option has been agreed.

"Other options included spending money on the flats in Woodvale Close, but we were pleased that they decided to take such a radical measure because it will solve a big problem," says Waterhouse.

In the last couple of years, she explains, the flats have been let to single young tenants owing to lack of demand from elderly people, for whom they were originally designed. She says: "There were quite a few drug problems and burglaries and they didn't take care of the properties, so they became run down."

Roy Thirlwell, trust regional director, favours the development of two-bedroom bungalows, in partnership with the council, as there is demand city-wide for this type of accommodation. webTitle: Profile:  Chris Mayer, winner of community nurse of the year

fields.headline: A fun view of taboos
fields.standfirst: Chris Mayer, winner of community nurse of the year
fields.trailText: Profile: Chris Mayer, winner of community nurse of the year
fields.body:
When an 11-year-old boy sticks his hand up in class and asks, in sweet but not quite convincing innocence, what a condom is, how should you react? Do you ignore him, squirm with embarrassment or give him a ticking off for being cheeky?

If you are Chris Mayer, a school nurse in Chester, you might be a little surprised at the question. But you would certainly encourage the boy and his classmates to chat without embarrassment about sex and body changes.

It is this frankness that will tonight see Mayer, 32, collect the community nurse of the year title in the annual awards run by Nursing Standard, the weekly magazine of the Royal College of Nursing. The judges were impressed with Mayer's commitment to increasing the knowledge of puberty among younger boys - an often-neglected group when teachers are planning their lessons on the vagaries of the adolescent body.

Mayer, something of a rarity as a male school nurse, works for the Countess of Chester NHS trust in primary and high schools in the Chester area. He has written Boys Talk, a leaflet about puberty for 10 to 12-year-old boys, and Let's Talk About Sex, which, with a linked website, enables older boys and girls to find information about contraception, sexually-transmitted diseases and relationships.

Before going into schools two years ago, Mayer was a paediatric nurse. But he wanted to get involved in health promotion and was surprised - and concerned - at the lack of information on puberty and sex for younger boys. The Boys Talk leaflet was born, dealing with such sensitive and taboo issues as involuntary erections, wet dreams and body hair. It remains the basis of his work with the younger age group.

"We usually do it in the last term before they go on to high school," he says. "If the weather's good, we go outside and sit under a tree. I tell them that at the moment they're the biggest and the oldest at school but when they get to high school it's going to be different. We talk about the changes that are happening to the big boys.

"Most of them are a bit shy to ask questions and we don't really have a discussion like I do with the older children. Some of them have heard about puberty and what's likely to happen, but if they haven't, that's OK. It's good to know that they might be a little bit prepared."

Sandra Rote, one of the award judges and a health visitor of many years' experience, agrees that younger boys often miss out and that the bewildering changes puberty brings can come as a shock.

"What impressed me about Chris's entry was that it targeted a group that is often neglected in health education and health promotion," she says. "There's a lot of information out there for women and young girls, but there's very little for boys.

"I think some of it is to do with being a male in a particularly female workforce - school nurses are predominantly women. Chris has come at the lessons with that viewpoint and it shows. School nurses can learn a lot from him."

Government guidelines on sex education stipulate that primary school children should not be taught about sex. Mayer is keen to work within the guidelines, but if a child asks an awkward question he cannot ignore it.

He says: "Last year a lad said to me: 'What's a condom for?' And he was only 11! He threw the question at me as if he knew the answer. I asked if anyone else knew and one lad put his hand up and said: 'It stops girls getting pregnant and boys getting Aids.' I was amazed."

Chatting to younger children about sex is a minefield, as Leeds school nurse Sue Brady found to her peril. She became a cause celebre six years ago when a 10-year-old child asked her a question about oral sex which she answered as honestly as she could. One of the children's parents found out, complained to the school and Brady was headline news - reducing media pundits and politicians to near apoplexy.

Things may have calmed down a little since then, but Mayer is aware of the need to tread carefully. "In one of my high schools there's a parent from Holland, where the whole ethos and approach to sex education is different," he says.

"I wouldn't have a problem discussing drugs and contraception with 11-year-olds, even though I don't because of the guidelines. Because you talk about something it doesn't mean they're going to go off and do it."

Generally, parents are eager for their children to learn about puberty, he says. "Most schools send a letter out a couple of weeks before, saying that I'm going to be talking about puberty and if they want to take their child out of the class they can. I've never had any parent do that. We have a parent day where I show them the video and tell them about what's going to happen. I think some of them might be relieved that I'm discussing this with their kids, rather than them having to do it."

As he collects his prize this evening at the Café Royal in London, Mayer hopes he is setting an example for other school nurses to follow. "Now I've won, I would like to get more people doing what I do," he says. "What I'm trying to get across to other school nurses is that it's not that hard to teach children about these things. It's actually really good fun."

webTitle: Mencap's new scheme

fields.headline: Advice with an edge
fields.trailText: In a new scheme run by the charity Mencap, volunteers are being recruited to give information and advice to people with learning disabilities and their families. And one of the first to come forward has a learning disability himself
fields.body:
In a new scheme run by the charity Mencap, volunteers are being recruited to give information and advice to people with learning disabilities and their families. And one of the first to come forward has a learning disability himself.

The role of a "family adviser volunteer" is to offer guidance through the benefits and education systems, provide details of services available locally and offer a listening ear and moral support. But having a learning disability gives a volunteer an extra dimension.

Ronnie, 40, is such a volunteer in north-east Hampshire. He has taken part in presentations about the scheme at a number of local day centres for people with learning disabilities, and mans an information desk at the centres for a couple of hours every fortnight.

Along with a dozen or so other recruits, Ronnie spent 16 evenings on a training course for potential volunteers. He and Peter, who also has a learning disability, had help from a "millennium enabler" - funded by the millennium award scheme - who attended the course with them to offer extra support during and after the sessions and with their homework.

Unusually for volunteer training, the family adviser course is accredited by an external organisation - in this case, the Open College Network - and it ties in with a number of NVQ qualifications. Independent assessors from local colleges mark the volunteers' portfolios and assess their learning.

"Volunteers come from a variety of backgrounds," says Arlene Honeyman, Mencap's head of voluntary strategy. "Some are carers themselves; others have no particular experience but are just interested in doing this, perhaps with a view to pursuing a career in this area.

"The training course covers topics such as listening skills, problem-solving skills, confidentiality and detailed information about the types of services that a person with learning disability and their families could receive from cradle to grave. It is a comprehensive training package and they have to complete a lot of work themselves, so when they come out the other end they are particularly skilled people."

Training is usually delivered by family advisers, who are paid members of Mencap's staff, with the help of outside speakers who give sessions on specialist topics.

For Peter, the most difficult aspect of the course was taking notes during the sessions. Ronnie says: "I coped OK. There was a lot of work and some of the information was hard to understand, but if I found it difficult I would speak to the enabler or the family adviser. It was interesting."

Ronnie, who also has a part-time paid job in office administration, enjoys volunteering. As well as being a family adviser, he helps out in the Mencap office and contributes to a newsletter. "I like meeting people and helping people," he says. "I like the other volunteers and sometimes we socialise together. It has taught me things and made me more confident about speaking in a group."

Peter, however, decided not to continue. He wanted to spend more time volunteering with a local advocacy group instead. "He had other commitments - the same reason why other volunteers sometimes give up," says Heather Markin, who supervises the Aldershot-based service.

Family adviser services are run where Mencap can secure external funding from social services, education departments or health authorities. There are now 50 services in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, each with the capacity for a team of seven volunteers attached to a full-time paid worker.

Mencap wants to see other voluntary organisations recruiting people with learning disabilities, but acknowledges they are likely to need extra help in the early stages, and some special consideration throughout. Going to such trouble may, however, be a small price to pay for the added value a volunteer with learning disabilities can bring.

 Further information about Mencap's family adviser service from 020-7454 0454

webTitle: How do charities ensure they are providing the right services?

fields.headline: Ask the people
fields.standfirst: How do charities ensure they are providing the right services?  Roger Cowe looks at the benefits of social auditing
fields.trailText: How do charities ensure they are providing the right services? Roger Cowe looks at the benefits of social auditing
fields.body:
There are few similarities between small voluntary organisations and huge multinationals, but a report published today has identified one: both can benefit from social auditing.

This is an approach developed during the 90s as a means of making private companies - usually huge multinationals such as Shell - accountable to the people and communities they touch. It is an attempt to answer the question: "Is this organisation doing the right things in the right way?". And the point is to get the answer from the people who matter - those affected by its operations.

Some in the business world have attempted to turn the increased scrutiny back on those who put pressure on them, asking about the accountability of organisations like Greenpeace. There is also growing scepticism about donations to charities and what they do with the money. And many a voluntary organisation faced with apparently conflicting demands needs a means of understanding the different perspectives of its stakeholders and developing appropriate strategies.

Social auditing could help in these circumstances, according to the report of a pilot exercise among 13 widely varied groups - ranging from local arts groups, such as Coventry's Belgrade theatre, to substantial national organisations, such as the Industrial Society. The report, Charitable Trust?, concludes that this means of scrutinising social impacts is a valuable addition to voluntary sector management across this range of size and activity.

The report is published by the New Economics Foundation, the think-tank behind social auditing, and the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo). Stephen Bubb, the latter's chief executive, says: "In time, social audits should become as natural as reporting in the financial area."

But they should be more valuable. Financial reports and audits are necessary, but tell little about an organisation's effectiveness. Social reports, on the other hand, should reveal the extent to which objectives are being fulfilled - and whether they are the right objectives.

The process begins by identifying stakeholder groups - those involved in or affected by an organisation, such as employees, suppliers and customers. These groups identify key issues and the indicators to measure performance, and then provide their assessment. Thus social auditing is a judgment by those an organisation affects, on criteria they have specified.

The process itself is usually carried out by the organisation, but independently audited. That external involvement can be key to ensuring an open, honest dialogue, and a comprehensive report back to stakeholders.

For a company like Shell, the point is to answer criticisms of its behaviour. In successive social reports (which have won awards for their thoroughness and innovation) the oil giant has mapped out a path to social and environmental responsibility and presented measures of its progress along that route. But few charities face such controversies, so why subject themselves to this process?

Bubb says there is no reason why charities should not be subject to the same scrutiny as businesses. "It's not good enough for charities to say, 'Everything we do is fine.' There are some funny old practices going on out there. We should accept the same standards as the private sector."

He acknowledges concerns about this becoming an added bureaucratic burden, when it is already hard enough for most organisations to raise adequate non-project funding. But he believes an effective audit model can be developed for organisations of all sizes, and says there are good management reasons for adding a social audit to the financial one. "The main benefits are more professionalism in the sector, accountability, and analysing objectives and aspirations," he argues.

The organisations involved in the pilot project hoped to deal with these issues - in many cases, as part of an approach to quality management. "To expand our approach to quality and to measure the social impact our services have on our client group" was one objective. "We wanted to make sure our services were addressing the needs of our stakeholders," said another participant.

Steve Cranston, of the Arts Factory in the Rhondda, south Wales, says the community service organisation aims to carry out a social audit every year. Dialogue with stakeholders is an important element for Cranston, but so is the involvement of independent external auditors, which gives the process credibility. "We want a genuine, open, honest dialogue. We really want people's views," he says. "This is not a PR exercise."

Engaging in this kind of process for the first time was tough for most of the organisations involved. Some were nervous about stakeholders' ability to define realistic targets. Some stakeholders felt overwhelmed and were reluctant to be engaged. Most organisations had never tried to measure their performance against specific indicators.

Resources - financial and people - were also a big issue for many participants. Sense West, the Birmingham-based region of deaf-blind charity Sense, found it could only achieve part of what it set out to do. It did not manage to include the service users - the primary stakeholders - in dialogue, and the charity felt too little time was devoted to tailoring the process and gaining commitment from those who administered the questionnaires.

Nevertheless, Sense found that, because of the involvement of an external consultant, "the feedback was more frank and comprehensive than that gained in other audits". Similarly, Stephanie Draper, of the Industrial Society, which has just launched its own social audit service, says: "It was an amazing learning experience."

Today's report concurs that all the pain (for participants) was worthwhile. "It can assist with the development of social objectives, strategic planning, evaluation, building trust and the demonstration of accountability and transparency," say the authors, Peter Raynard and Sara Murphy.

They set it firmly in the context of quality management and recommend that the quality standards task group of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations examines social auditing as a means of ensuring accountability. They also suggest that funders could come to look on it "as a tool for accountability, transparency and evaluation".

Or, as Bubb puts it: "This could be quite a neat tool to demonstrate ethical standards."

In successive social reports (which have won awards for their thoroughness and innovation) the oil giant has mapped out a path to social and environmental responsibility and presented measures of its progress along that route. But few charities face such controversies, so why subject themselves to this process? Bubb says there is no reason why charities should not be subject to the same scrutiny as businesses. "It's not good enough for charities to say, 'Everything we do is fine.' There are some funny old practices going on out there. We should accept the same standards as the private sector." He acknowledges concerns about this becoming an added bureaucratic burden, when it is already hard enough for most organisations to raise adequate non-project funding. But he believes an effective audit model can be developed for organisations of all sizes, and says there are good management reasons for adding a social audit to the financial one. "The main benefits are more professionalism in the sector, accountability, and analysing objectives and aspirations," he argues. The organisations involved in the pilot project hoped to deal with these issues - in many cases, as part of an approach to quality management. "To expand our approach to quality and to measure the social impact our services have on our client group" was one objective. "We wanted to make sure our services were addressing the needs of our stakeholders," said another participant. Steve Cranston, of the Arts Factory in the Rhondda, south Wales, says the community service organisation aims to carry out a social audit every year. Dialogue with stakeholders is an important element for Cranston, but so is the involvement of independent external auditors, which gives the process credibility. "We want a genuine, open, honest dialogue. We really want people's views," he says. "This is not a PR exercise." Engaging in this kind of process for the first time was tough for most of the organisations involved. Some were nervous about stakeholders' ability to define realistic targets. Some stakeholders felt overwhelmed and were reluctant to be engaged. Most organisations had never tried to measure their performance against specific indicators. Resources - financial and people - were also a big issue for many participants. Sense West, the Birmingham-based region of deaf-blind charity Sense, found it could only achieve part of what it set out to do. It did not manage to include the service users - the primary stakeholders - in dialogue, and the charity felt too little time was devoted to tailoring the process and gaining commitment from those who administered the questionnaires. Nevertheless, Sense found that, because of the involvement of an external consultant, "the feedback was more frank and comprehensive than that gained in other audits". Similarly, Stephanie Draper, of the Industrial Society, which has just launched its own social audit service, says: "It was an amazing learning experience." Today's report concurs that all the pain (for participants) was worthwhile. "It can assist with the development of social objectives, strategic planning, evaluation, building trust and the demonstration of accountability and transparency," say the authors, Peter Raynard and Sara Murphy. They set it firmly in the context of quality management and recommend that the quality standards task group of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations examines social auditing as a means of ensuring accountability. They also suggest that funders could come to look on it "as a tool for accountability, transparency and evaluation". Or, as Bubb puts it: "This could be quite a neat tool to demonstrate ethical standards." Links  Stephen Bubb will be online at 2.30pm tomorrow. fields.trailText: Horse sense
fields.body:
Horse sense Two reindeer booked to pull Santa's sleigh at a ceremony to switch on Cheltenham's Christmas lights caught pneumonia and were replaced by a horse.
Gloucestershire Echo, 15.11.00 (Roy Lewis, Cheltenham)

Masked symptoms Five women who work at a hairdressers in Carlisle became pregnant after their boss hung up an oriental fertility mask in the shop.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 14.11.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Sticky solution A firefighter averted a potential disaster at an old people's home in Croydon, Surrey, by plugging a hole in a leaking gas pipe with a blob of gum he was chewing.
Express and Star, 11.11.00 (Anne Smith, Brierley Hill)

Sheffield Star, 1.11.00 (S Pybus, Sheffield)

Birmingham Evening Mail, 9.11.00 (A Lamont, Smethwick)

Getting the needle Residents of Corsham, Wiltshire, have accused a councillor of being disrespectful because she sat knitting a bobble hat during a council debate on a controversial housing plan.
Southern Daily Echo, 4.11.00 (M Hobbs, Southampton)

Laundered money A robber who snatched a bag from the owner of the wine shop as she left the premises in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, didn't realise that it contained dirty linen she was taking to the laundrette.
Manchester Evening News, 8.11.00 (Vera Holmes, Swinton)

Mold and Buckley Chronicle, 27.10.00 (L Sylvia, Wrexham)

Perfect match Thirty minutes after he was married in Ely, Cambridgeshire, the bridegroom left the reception to turn out for his local football team after receiving a call to say they were a man short.
Brighton and Hove Leader, 10.11.00 (John Beeken, Saltdean)

Northern Echo, 9.11.00 (V Piekosz, Northallerton)

Chain reaction Salisbury's ceremonial chain of office is being replaced at a cost of £5,000 after the current chair of the council complained that it is unladylike and is so heavy that it gives her backache.
East Anglian Daily Times, 31.10.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

News North West, 8.11.00 (N Asghar, Stockport)

Master stroke An old kitchen table put up for auction in Brigg, Lincolnshire, fetched £53,000 after it was identified as a 170-year-old antique made by a master craftsman in the reign of William IV.
Midlands Metro, 30.10.00 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

webTitle: The pressure on NHS managers

fields.headline: Too great expectations
fields.trailText: Andrew Wall, ex-NHS chief executive, on the expectations resting on NHS managers
fields.body:
The NHS is in chaos and management is to blame - so goes the story. Long waits, misdiagnoses, cruelty, incompetent or quarrelling doctors, overspending, failure to implement government policy; all are laid at the managers' door. Are they a bunch of incompetents, or are we expecting too much?

Most senior managers in the NHS are trained specifically in management and will have had wide experience in primary and secondary care, but few are clinicians. The task they face makes single-purpose industries like the railways look simple.

They have to implement government policy whether they think it practicable or not. For years, managers have been telling governments that concentrating on waiting numbers, rather than priorities, is a bad principle - but do it they must or face loosing their job.

They are expected to overcome problems such as winter pressures and providing joined-up care for the elderly, working across organisational boundaries. Overspending is a cardinal sin, but responding to seemingly unlimited demand makes this difficult to avoid. British hospitals seem to work much harder than their counterparts elsewhere in the developed world.

Recently, managers have been held accountable for clinical performance - not easy with up to 200 consultant staff in any one hospital, especially if you are a layman.

Managers must spend time listening, explaining and persuading. An average general hospital will have more than 500,000 outpatients a year. Several thousand staff need motivating and ongoing training if they are to give these patients their best.

All this has to achieved within constantly changing structures which, whatever politicians say, still have many of the hallmarks of a command and control hierarchy.

Too often, managers find themselves endeavouring to satisfy the unrealistic ambitions of health ministers. Under this pressure tempers fray and blaming and shaming becomes endemic.

What's to be done? Blame the managers for everything and many will give up as soon as they can, wasting years of valuable experience. Luckily, despite everything, there are still eager recruits. But if we want to maintain our NHS - scarcely now the envy of the world - we will have to be more realistic.

The public deserves the best and NHS staff want to give it, but expectations as to what is possible are currently too great.

 Andrew Wall, visiting fellow at Birmingham University, used to be an NHS chief executive

webTitle: Great-grandmother jailed for trying to save ancient forests

fields.headline: Price worth paying
fields.standfirst: Great-grandmother jailed for trying to save ancient forests
fields.trailText: Great-grandmother jailed for trying to save ancient forests
fields.body:
I'm writing from prison, a long way from the mists and moss of the ancient forests in British Columbia that I have been imprisoned for trying to protect. British Columbia Supreme Court Justice Glen Parrett has sentenced me to one year in prison without parole. My crime? I stepped out on a road in the Elaho Valley to stop the logging trucks of International Forest Products (Interfor). [The Elaho contains thousand-year old trees and is home to the southern-most population of grizzly bears on the west coast of north America.]

A solid year is a big whack out of a 72-year-old great-grandmother's remaining years, but I accepted that possibility the morning I stood on the road to try to protect some of the last intact temperate rainforests on the planet.

At 72, some people think I'm too old to risk a jail sentence, but I tell them the temperate rainforests are a lot more fragile than I am and at much greater risk. These coastal Canadian forests are among the most rare and most endangered forests on earth. I will do what I can to protect them.

We need a revolution in our forests. Here in British Columbia "tree farm" licences are still given out to the largest corporations. Not only do they get the right to liquidate our ancient forests, but taxpayers have to pay for cleaning up the mess they leave behind in the forests and salmon streams.

And, to add insult to injury, we have to pay for the lengthy mass trials brought against protesters like me, but which are speedily taken over by the government - which in turn results in lengthy prison sentences also paid for by the taxpayers.

The eco-systems on this continent are extremely fragile. And so is democracy. If we really want these twin wonders, these incredible gifts that make life worth living, then we must fight for them over and over again. If we don't, the alternatives are complete corporate rule and a trashed, logging-induced desert of a continent to leave to our grandchildren.

These forests are a global treasure and a legacy to the planet. I want to be home with my family. But I'm prepared to spend a year of my remaining life in jail for the "crime" of defending these ancient forests from the corporate clearcutters.

Please, will you spend 10 minutes of your time to help as well? Write to the premier of British Columbia and the CEO of Interfor. Ask them to protect Canada's remaining temperate rainforests from the ravages of industrial logging. Ask them for a moratorium on logging these last intact valleys. And please ask them to stop criminalising people trying to stop the destruction.

 Betty Krawczyk, inmate number 03793924, is at the Burnaby Correctional Centre for Women, 900 Fraser Park Drive, Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada V5J 5H1

webTitle: Sutton council's environmental promise

fields.headline: Open lines of communication
fields.trailText: Sutton, in south London, has been one of the most active local authorities on environmental issues and set up a local Agenda 21 forum in 1994
fields.body:
Sutton, in south London, has been one of the most active local authorities on environmental issues and set up a local Agenda 21 forum in 1994. The idea, which emerged from the Rio earth summit in 1992, was to bring together representatives of the council, businesses and the community to develop and implement sustainability strategies locally.

By 1998, there was a growing feeling that the forum needed revamping, but the nature of the partnership made it difficult to achieve progress.

The Centre for Environmental Initiatives (CEI), one of the most active members of the forum, raised funding to carry out a social audit of the initiative. This was a particular challenge because the forum is "an organisation which is not an organisation", as Trevor Lancefield, of CEI, puts it. But it turned out to be exactly the right approach, and has helped to stimulate the reshaping of the partnership.

"We felt there was a lack of adequate communication," Lancefield says. "We wanted a mechanism for engaging stakeholders in dialogue. Social auditing seemed interesting because of the external element. All comments have to be included."

The CEI is about as small an organisation as you can get. It had 1.5 staff last year when the audit process began. But with about 20 active volunteers, the work of organising workshops and interviews was not too onerous, especially because they adopted what might be called an "intelligent" approach. Rather than spreading questionnaires around the borough like confetti, the dialogue focused on key people and groups and developed a suitable approach for each.

"If you use the right approach, people open up quite well," Lancefield says. "If you take the time to develop relationships, then people can contribute a great deal. It's worth doing that rather than adopting a blanket approach."

He is convinced that social audits can help in similar situations. "It has potential to be replicated in other communities where there is an impasse," he says.

"All over the country there are situations where people or organisations are not opening up. Then you need a mechanism that will enable people to come forward and say what they think."

webTitle: Isle of Wight's footprints

fields.headline: Map of your life
fields.standfirst: Could ecological footprinting save the Isle of Wight from rising sea levels?
fields.trailText: Could ecological footprinting save the Isle of Wight from rising sea levels?
fields.body:
Yarmouth in winter is quiet. Without the crush of summer tourists to the Isle of Wight, there are few people and lorries on the ferries to the mainland. The quayside car parks and shops are almost empty. On calm days, the Solent laps the harbour walls, but in bad weather - and there is much of it - gardens well inland are lashed by the sea, winds batter the downs, and the islanders and their sea defences are both severely tested.

They face worse weather still. In the next 100 years, say scientists, the Isle of Wight could become the Isles of Wight, as land becomes regularly, even permanently, overwhelmed by water. Without strengthening coastal defences, the river Yar will severely flood, cutting off the far western tip of the island. Sea level rise could lead to loss of beaches, yet more major flooding, and the loss of environmentally sensitive areas.

Angela Mawle, who works for the Isle of Wight council, says the inhabitants understand the uniqueness of the island and are anxious not to lose it. As a first step, the council has contributed money and masses of data to help quantify and map the "ecological footprint" of the island's 125,000 inhabitants to see how sustainable their lifestyles are in global and local terms. It has involved looking at the islanders' energy consumption, waste, transport habits, food and drink imports and exports, the fossil fuels they burn, how they use water and all the other impacts the inhabitants have on the island's natural resources.

Ecological footprinting was devel oped by William Rees and Mathis Wackernagel at the University of British Columbia in the early 90s. It is increasingly seen as a way to show people the impact they have on both the local and global environment, but so far very few full studies have been done on large communities. The island study is one of the largest and most advanced of its kind.

The best way to understand ecological footprinting is to imagine every person on the planet having their own "earthshare", or area needed to live off. This is calculated by dividing the amount of productive land and sea worldwide by the global population. This "share" is taken to represent the maximum sustainable use of resources per person. Recent studies have estimated this to be about 1.9 hectares - or just under the size of two football pitches - per person. However, the current global average demand is a very unsustainable 2.28 hectares.

For the Isle of Wight, Oxford-based sustainability experts Best Foot Forward and Imperial College, London, took vast amounts of data about the resources used by the islanders and calculated the area needed to provide them.

They estimated average car kilometres per person (7,035 per year, compared with the south-east England average of 11,300km a year per person), the average number of black binbags of rubbish produced by each islander (40 each, adding up to over 5m across the island), the land resources required for the Isle of Wight's consumption of alcohol (5,074 hectares), washing powder (3,441 hectares), paper (18,357 hectares), furniture and carpets (9,892), and so on.

The "footprints" for fossil fuels and renewable energies were based both on their direct use of land and also the "forested" land required to reabsorb any carbon emitted. Sustainability was then assessed by comparing the footprint with the amount of land available on the island and with the global "earthshare".

The figures were revealing. The Isle of Wight consumed 753,368 tonnes of materials in 1998-99, or 5.8 tonnes per person. More than half of this was in the form of bulk stone and aggregates, of which two-thirds was imported from the mainland. Meanwhile, they sent 33,337 tonnes (250kg per capita) of domestic waste to landfill. Some 43% of that was diverted away from landfill by being recycled, composted or incinerated for waste recovery - much more than the national average of 18%. But a further 108,951 tonnes (838kg per person) of commercial waste was collected, of which 97% went to landfill. When it came to transport, the island was seen to be very dependent on cars: 71% of all passenger kilo metres travelled were by car, compared to 0.7% by bus, or 7.7% by ferry. The total footprint for the Isle of Wight, combining figures for the use and production of materials, food, passenger transport, energy, freight transport, built land and water, was calculated as 648,808 hectares, on an island with a capacity of just 219,106 hectares. This meant the islanders' footprint was 4.47 hectares per resident.

If everyone in the world consumed as much as the residents of the Isle of Wight, the report says, we would need just under 2.5 earths to support the lifestyle. Put another way, if the Isle of Wight was to become self-sufficient, while maintaining current lifestyles, it would need to be about 2.25 times its actual size - or the population would need to reduce consumption by 56%.

This figure is slightly better than the figure for UK resource use as a whole, which would require just over 2.5 planets to sustain it. And if the population of the globe lived in the manner of the affluent residents of Oxfordshire, we would need nearly four planets.

If we are to counter global warming and many other environmental ills, it is widely accepted that northern countries, especially, must shrink their footprints. How can that be done? The report suggests regional self-sufficiency is a start and, in the case of the island, goods produced there should be consumed there as far as possible. It advises the use of CFLs (compact fluorescent lightbulbs), the insulation of houses, the buying of energy-efficient appliances.

The island could also profit by exploiting its considerable natural potential for renewable energy - wind farms (offshore or onshore) could be combined with land used for agriculture, some of the arable and pasture land on the island could be used for the growing and use of biomass energy crops, and businesses and homes could switch to solar photo-voltaic electricity generation. However, a combination of better waste recovery, energy efficiency and renewables could reduce the islanders' footprint by almost half a hectare, or 10%, the report says.

 Island State, An Ecological Footprint of the Isle of Wight, can be downloaded from www.bestfootforward.com

Recent studies have estimated this to be about 1.9 hectares - or just under the size of two football pitches - per person. However, the current global average demand is a very unsustainable 2.28 hectares. For the Isle of Wight, Oxford-based sustainability experts Best Foot Forward and Imperial College, London, took vast amounts of data about the resources used by the islanders and calculated the area needed to provide them. They estimated average car kilometres per person (7,035 per year, compared with the south-east England average of 11,300km a year per person), the average number of black binbags of rubbish produced by each islander (40 each, adding up to over 5m across the island), the land resources required for the Isle of Wight's consumption of alcohol (5,074 hectares), washing powder (3,441 hectares), paper (18,357 hectares), furniture and carpets (9,892), and so on. The "footprints" for fossil fuels and renewable energies were based both on their direct use of land and also the "forested" land required to reabsorb any carbon emitted. Sustainability was then assessed by comparing the footprint with the amount of land available on the island and with the global "earthshare". The figures were revealing. The Isle of Wight consumed 753,368 tonnes of materials in 1998-99, or 5.8 tonnes per person. More than half of this was in the form of bulk stone and aggregates, of which two-thirds was imported from the mainland. Meanwhile, they sent 33,337 tonnes (250kg per capita) of domestic waste to landfill. Some 43% of that was diverted away from landfill by being recycled, composted or incinerated for waste recovery - much more than the national average of 18%. But a further 108,951 tonnes (838kg per person) of commercial waste was collected, of which 97% went to landfill. When it came to transport, the island was seen to be very dependent on cars: 71% of all passenger kilo metres travelled were by car, compared to 0.7% by bus, or 7.7% by ferry. The total footprint for the Isle of Wight, combining figures for the use and production of materials, food, passenger transport, energy, freight transport, built land and water, was calculated as 648,808 hectares, on an island with a capacity of just 219,106 hectares. This meant the islanders' footprint was 4.47 hectares per resident. If everyone in the world consumed as much as the residents of the Isle of Wight, the report says, we would need just under 2.5 earths to support the lifestyle. Put another way, if the Isle of Wight was to become self-sufficient, while maintaining current lifestyles, it would need to be about 2.25 times its actual size - or the population would need to reduce consumption by 56%. This figure is slightly better than the figure for UK resource use as a whole, which would require just over 2.5 planets to sustain it. And if the population of the globe lived in the manner of the affluent residents of Oxfordshire, we would need nearly four planets. If we are to counter global warming and many other environmental ills, it is widely accepted that northern countries, especially, must shrink their footprints. How can that be done? The report suggests regional self-sufficiency is a start and, in the case of the island, goods produced there should be consumed there as far as possible. It advises the use of CFLs (compact fluorescent lightbulbs), the insulation of houses, the buying of energy-efficient appliances. The island could also profit by exploiting its considerable natural potential for renewable energy - wind farms (offshore or onshore) could be combined with land used for agriculture, some of the arable and pasture land on the island could be used for the growing and use of biomass energy crops, and businesses and homes could switch to solar photo-voltaic electricity generation. However, a combination of better waste recovery, energy efficiency and renewables could reduce the islanders' footprint by almost half a hectare, or 10%, the report says.  Island State, An Ecological Footprint of the Isle of Wight, can be downloaded from www.bestfootforward.com

webTitle: Myths and memories

fields.headline: Myths and memories
fields.standfirst: World record planting bid to mark National Tree Week
fields.trailText: World record planting bid to mark National Tree Week
fields.body:
This is National Tree Week and all across Britain tens of thousands of spades, from Haringey to Hampshire and Humberside, are stabbing into muddy, saturated soil in a world record attempt to increase our tree cover. With up to a million trees expected to be planted, these schemes are an attempt to involve people in local woodland creation.

More trees are valuable to local communities, wildlife and the environment. But there is a cultural and spiritual dimension which is just as important, although this reverence for trees is now largely confined to old ones.

Take, for instance, when the royal oak at Boscobel in Shropshire was split in half by the recent gales. The wind knifes over the plain, between the Clee and Wrekin hills, and the first thing it hits when it reaches the edge of the high plateau is this tree.

It is the tree that launched a thousand pub signs; the tree that on September 6, 1651, King Charles II famously hid in. Now a huge gash exposes the old tree's dark innards and the wind has got into its cracks. Huge branches have crashed to the ground, but it still points a craggily defiant finger at the sky.

In fact, this is probably not the original tree in which King Charles hid, but a young pretender which grew nearby - the original having become furniture and snuff boxes after snuffing it itself in 1706, as recorded by John Evelyn.

No matter; the legend is scratched deep into the bones of Britishness and the tree stands for something, even if we're not sure exactly what. In reality, this oak stands for itself, for all oaks and for the wonderful and beautiful struggle of life in a world of powerful indifference.

Next to the royal oak is an offspring planted in 1951 to continue the tradition. Valerie Tooby remembers: "I went to the planting ceremony when I was a child and the Chelsea pensioners were there. It was wonderful." She has seen it grow over the years. This oak too was split in half by the same storm.

All the trees battered by the storms have a story, and many of the trees planted this week will, in their turn, enter our lives. The veracity of our myths seems less important than the trees which embody them, especially when we see them broken and twisted.

But there are new myths to make and new trees to hide them in. Although old trees are irreplaceable, the new ones being planted this week need a similarly powerful purchase on our culture if they are to matter in ways which reach beyond world record attempts and environmental gestures.

 Paul Evans is a Guardian country diarist For details of the tree planting campaign, visit www.treecouncil.org.uk or tel: 020 7828 9928.

webTitle: Eco soundings

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Counting the cost of your carbon emissions
fields.body:
Counting the cost

The climate talks in the Hague have collapsed in recriminations. It is now up to individuals to emit less. Eco Soundings brings you your own ready reckoner of how much carbon you emit:

1. Gas central heating: an average-sized house for six hours a day - around 2kg.

2. One kettle of boiling hot water: 0.006kg; one cupful: 0.001kg.

3. Cooking a full breakfast on a hob or grill: 0.23kg.

4. A dishwasher with a full load: 0.33kg.

5. One full load of washing: 0.68kg; two half loads: 1.36kg.

6. Drying your weekly laundry: 1.17kg for a full load, or about 2kg if you do two half loads.

7. Daily emissions from a modern fridge freezer: 0.7kg per day; average fridge: 1.08 kg.

8. Keeping your food frozen: 0.51kg a day in a modern chest freezer, or up to 2.16kg a day in an average, large counter freezer.

9. Lighting your hallway for eight hours: 0.36kg with incandescent lighting, or 0.04kg with energy efficient light bulbs.

10. Leaving a computer on standby for two hours: 0.03kg.

11. Leaving a TV on standby for two hours: 0.01kg.

12. Leaving a stereo on standby for two hours: 0.01 kg.

13. Driving 20 miles to work:: 4.47kg in an average petrol car, or 3.63kg in an average diesel car.

14. Taking the bus five miles to work: 0.47kg per passenger.

15. Cycling or walking to work: negligible (use 0kg).

16. Taking the train to work (for example, Oxford to London): 10.67kg.

17. Takeaway lunch: more than 1kg.

18. Takeaway evening meal: more than 3kg.

19. Cooking an evening meal: around 1.3kg on an average electric oven or 0.45 on a modern electric oven, and about 0.28 on a modern gas oven.

20. One return flight to Brazil: 2,391kg.

21. One return flight to the Hague: 162kg.

22. One return to Paris on Eurostar: 72kg.

23. The average for a Briton, over a year, is around nine metric tonnes, or 9,000kgs.

24. This compares to a world average of 4,000kg per person and an African average of 1,200kg.

25. Britain (population approaching 60m), emits roughly the same amount of carbon as almost 700m people in Africa.

 These figures were calculated for Eco Soundings by Bestfootforward, an Oxford-based company. To calculate your own,or a company's, carbon emissions, go to www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/globalwarming

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Harnessing the elements
fields.body:
Harnessing the elements

Sue Dalton and friends castigate wind power as intermittent, and then advocate solar power (Letters, November 22).

Surely solar power is the most intermittent source there is, being unavailable just when you most need it - on a cold winter's night.

The two ecologically-sound power sources are waves (almost always) and the tides (unstoppable), both of which we have in abundance in the UK. Both of these can be harnessed in environmentally-friendly ways, including the necessary element of energy storage.

However, if power is to be generated locally, then there is a good case for using solar power for air-conditioning, particularly in the tropics. It needs little more than an ammonia-cycle refrigerator, which is low-maintenance and non-polluting.

Tim Gossling

Cambridge

 Wind farms are an important part of future energy generation. I agree that we need large-scale subsidisation and investment in solar power. However, being geographically challenged as we are in the UK, when we most need solar energy the sun is not shining.

The current technology would be hard pushed to provide us all with sufficient heating in winter. Conversely, the wind resource is often largest in winter. If we are going to continue using energy at the current rate, we need to utilise the range of renewable resources at our disposal.

Regarding the aesthetics of wind turbines, they should be judged within the context of their industrial counterparts. I personally believe they are rather beautiful compared to a nuclear or coal-fired power station.

Ag Stephens

Norwich

 When we wanted to erect a turbine to provide power for our Welsh home in the Black Mountains, we were mortified at the distorted and malicious criticism levelled at us by a vocal faction in the valley. Luckily, we canvassed opinion locally and were delighted to find a large majority in favour of our turbine, and the planners gave their support too.

In our case, a mains connection would have been too expensive. Our photovoltaic panels are of limited benefit, especially in winter (and at night), but linked to our new turbine they will help us make a small contribution to saving fossil fuel. The wind power output is indeed intermittent, like other natural forces, but certainly not pitiful nor pointless industrialisation. How about some positive thinking, you nimbys? Such hatred helps no one with an eye to global warming.

Simon Marr-Johnson

London

A climate of blame

While the rise in racist crime you report is disturbing (Forward march, November 22), I am concerned that you do not indicate whether there has been any increase in the incidence of racial harassment by individuals from the ethnic minority population on members of the indigenous one.

I live in a borough where many of the indigenous population feel threatened by the growth of the ethnic minority community, and point to a significant number of assaults by ethnic minority youths on their indigenous peers as reported in the local press (which is a rising problem recognised by the local police). This is so much so that many in the indigenous community perceive areas of the borough where ethnic minorities are concentrated as "no go" areas, even though the reality does not bear this out.

All racially-motivated crime is unacceptable and unforgivable, but while the tenor of reporting appears to lay the onus on the indigenous community only, it carries the danger of creating resentment among the indigenous community and unintentionally promoting resistance to the acceptance of living in a multicultural society.

Jeremy Sutcliffe

Oldham

Charity checks

As the author of the research into cancer charities at Manchester Business School, I would like to respond to Stuart Etherington's letter (November 22).

By necessity, only the highlights of my 275-page research into the changes in the top 25 cancer charities in the period 1992-97, including the "charitable efficiency" ratio, have been publicised. The majority of feedback from the charities able to take time to listen to, and discuss, more than just the highlights has been that the research is a worthwhile contribution to the debate on the future of cancer charities.

The level of reported cooperation between cancer charities formed part of my research and I would certainly agree with Etherington that all charities could do more to publicise how they work together. One of my main conclusions is that more cooperation would be beneficial to the patient. This would also reassure the public that the money they donate is being used to maximum impact, while minimising confusion over the proliferation of brands.

We hope to organise a seminar to present the research to London-based cancer charities and representatives of umbrella organisations. If the National Council for Voluntary Organisations would be prepared to host such an event, I believe the benefits of joint working would continue to be seen, supported by more detailed research than appears to have previously been undertaken.

Hugh McDonnell

Manchester

 While the principle of charities grouping themselves under a general cause is a sensible one, it would not work in the cases of mental health charities Mind and Sane, which have differing views on many issues - particularly care in the community.

Richard Kidd

Andover Mind

But if the figures are correct and there are 37 charities to help seafarers and their families, then that is, by far, too many and the charity commission should inquire into it.

 Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited
