webTitle: Barak calls early election

fields.headline: Barak calls early election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
An early election was announced in Israel last night by
the prime minister, Ehud Barak, short-circuiting an
opposition plan to shut down his government in stages.
fields.body:
An early election was announced in Israel last night by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, short-circuiting an opposition plan to shut down his government in stages.

Harangued by the Israeli right for being too soft on the Palestinians during the past two months of undeclared war, pilloried from abroad for using excessive force, and deserted by even his coalition partners, Mr Barak was under siege. The election call is his breakout attempt.

Last night, after an uproarious day in the Israeli parliament, the knesset, he was left clinging to just one thing: the chance to dictate the timing of his government's exit.

In a defiant speech given at very short notice, Mr Barak said: "I am not afraid of elections. If you say you want elec tions, I say: Let there be elections, for prime minister, and for the knesset."

In the parliamentary corridors last night, predictions were for a poll between March and May next year, with most leaning towards the latter date.

For Mr Barak, who last week hit his lowest point yet in opinion polls, the timing is crucial. Despite two months of violence, in which more than 280 people, mainly Palestinian, have been killed, Israel's prime minister continues to believe that he can reach a peace agreement with Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

But by the standards of the past weeks, recent violence appeared to be ebbing. The past week has seen the start of tentative efforts by Israeli and Palestinian diplomats and security officials to resurrect various broken ceasefires.

Israeli newspapers reported yesterday that Mr Barak was preparing a new proposal for an interim peace agreement with the Palestinians.

The proposal is a modest affair - especially for a prime minister who had a landslide election victory in May last year, promising to storm the citadels of peace.

It is limited to transferring areas of the West Bank to Palestinian control, and securing Israeli recognition of a Palestinian state, and does not touch on the most contentious issue: the status of Jerusalem.

Israel has yet to approach the Palestinians with the proposal. But Nabil Shaath, a senior Arab negotiator, said after last night's election announcement: "Barak still has six months until the coming elections, and if he wants, he can stop his aggression and adopt a new policy that will enable him to go to his people with progress in the peace process."

That is clearly what Mr Barak is calculating. The latest opinion polls show he would lose a contest against the Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, and the former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu.

But with a peace pact Mr Barak would have a chance. Even so, the delay could also afford Mr Netanyahu precious time to make a political comeback and wrest the Likud leadership from Mr Sharon. He would be a tough opponent.

The hardline Mr Sharon is widely blamed for igniting the Palestinian uprising with his provocative visit to the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem on September 28.

As the casualties have mounted since then, he has tried to reap maximum gains from this calculated act. But last night Mr Sharon was clearly discomfited by the Barak election call, which put in prospect a leadership challenge against him in the Likud. One ageing ex-general, Mr Sharon, appeared plainly outwitted by another, Mr Barak.

It was Likud that precipitated yesterday's announcement, tabling and passing bills for early dissolution of parliament. These could eventually have brought down the curtain on the government.

The stalemate at last July's Camp David peace summit seems to have started Mr Barak's fall from popular grace, and the related descent into violence: the collapse of these talks appears to have shattered Palestinian confidence in Mr Barak's sincerity in negotiating peace, and antagonised his rightwing Israeli opponents, who accused him of sacrificing old Jerusalem.

Israeli government

fields.headline: Final showdown as peers vote on air traffic sale
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government's compromise deal for the partial privatisation of the air traffic control system (Nats) won a 97-vote Commons majority last night, only to be bounced back to the Lords for a final showdown later today.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall, Michael White  and Keith Harper
fields.body:
The government's compromise deal for the partial privatisation of the air traffic control system (Nats) won a 97-vote Commons majority last night, only to be bounced back to the Lords for a final showdown later today.

Liberal Democrats joined Tory MPs in denouncing the government's last-minute concession to delay the Nats sale for three months as "spin and nothing more than that", in contrast to the seven-vote Lords majority to delay the partial sell-off until after the expected May general election.

In a series of votes the Commons rejected the Lords amendment by 305 to 217, a majoirty of 88, votes and then endorsed the government compromise - designed to show that ministers "are listening" - by 302 to 205, a majority of 97.

As in the Lords, where only three Labour peers held out this week, the Labour revolt lost support.

But Labour's Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairman of the Commons transport select committee, warned that the government was "made up of ordinary people who make mistakes. "The partial privatisation of Nats is a mistake," she said. "This is a core service for aviation. It is not something that can easily make a profit.

"Putting more and more planes into the sky is not an option. Those who seek to buy its assets know that, all of them, have a particular vested interest," she added.

The Liberal Democrat spokesman, Michael Moore, warned: "The public sector could certainly find the funds and we believe it could underwrite this particular project." He added that the public distrusted the government on the issue.

Last night's vote came as sources close to the bid revealed that one of the main bidding companies is proposing to replace 70% of the engineering staff with contract staff.

The facilities management and support services company, Serco, is planning to sub-contract much of its engineering maintenance work, in much the same way as Railtrack. This could affect almost 1,000 of Nats engineering staff, who are strongly opposed to the move on safety grounds, as well as the threat to their jobs.

Senior Nats staff have already threatened to resign if the bid goes ahead. They say that Serco is the least suited to the job, although it is known that it is one favoured by the government.

Iain Findlay, national officer of the air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said: "This would lead to a total collapse of the NATS safety system because there would be no control over the quality of work being done by sub-contractors. It would be a repetition of what has happened at Railtrack."

Last night's Commons debate followed Monday's vote by peers, backed by thre Labour rebels, for the sell-off to be delayed until after the general election, which is widely expected to be at the start of May.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, swiftly offered a concession which would see the transport bill - with its crucial plans to revive the railways and introduce congestion charging in cities - become law by the end of this week but the Nats sale delayed for three months.

webTitle: Portillo: I don't want to lead Tories

fields.headline: Portillo: I don't want to lead Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, darling of the Thatcherite right, last night stunned MPs who have been urging him to depose William Hague after the coming general election by stating almost categorically that he has no wish to become the next Tory leader.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, darling of the Thatcherite right, last night stunned MPs who have been urging him to depose William Hague after the coming general election by stating almost categorically that he has no wish to become the next Tory leader.

In a statement to the Daily Telegraph, house magazine of Conservative activists, the former defence secretary even hinted that he might leave politics altogether because he no longer enjoys it as he once did.

"Mr Portillo wants to continue to play his full part in the shadow cabinet in helping the party to beat Labour and looks forward to being a member of the next government," said a statement on his behalf.

It came in the wake of in-party speculation that he is upset by rightwing criticism of his "touchy feely" efforts to re-position the party as a more compassionate "post-Blair" Conservative party, in contrast to the gut instincts of the Ann Widdecombe tendency within the Tory ranks.

Lady Thatcher is reported to have said that her former protege has become "very confused" in his efforts to refashion the party following her departure. Mr Portillo's nine months as shadow chancellor, trying to damage the formidable Gordon Brown, have been demoralising - though he did curb the more reckless aspects of Mr Hague's "tax guarantee" package.

Behind Mr Portillo's claim that he has "no ambitions to be the leader of the Conservative party" lies a history of defeat - at Enfield in 1997 - and personal trauma as his gay experiences as a student were revealed in a series of newspaper reports.

He had already indicated in less specific form that he no longer had the appetite he once showed for politics - despite winning Alan Clark's bomb-proof Kensington and Chelsea seat just over a year ago.

webTitle: Worthington Cup: Ipswich 2 - 1 Coventry

fields.headline: Buoyant Ipswich set sights on Europe
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 2 - 1 Coventry
As if occupying a Champions League spot in the Premiership is not enough, Ipswich last night edged towards a Uefa Cup with this victory.
fields.body:
Ipswich fans must be tempted to dig out their passports. As if occupying a Champions League spot in the Premiership were not enough, George Burley's team edged towards the Uefa Cup place this competition offers last night.

Well below their best in a poor match, Ipswich won thanks to two men who have been stuck on the bench of late, Titus Bramble and David Johnson scoring either side of Craig Bellamy's penalty equaliser for Coventry. Manchester City or Wimbledon await in the next round.

Coventry had arrived with a determination which many clubs seem to abandon for the Worthington Cup. A last-minute home defeat by Ipswich last week had given them incentive. "It's a revenge mission for us," said their captain Paul Williams. "We are still trying to understand how we lost."

Most Ipswich supporters, though, must have expected another victory even without Richard Wright, who was ruled out by injury after 200 consecutive appearances in goal.

That belief was strengthened when Ipswich took the lead after six minutes. Youssef Chippo did little to impress the Coventry fans dressed as sheikhs in his honour by trying to dribble out of his penalty area from a corner; Bramble interrupted to shoot low into the corner. It was a finish which betrayed the centre-back's former status as a striker.

Stung into action by that error, Chippo forced Wright's replacement Keith Branagan into an impressive save within 90 seconds. Not long after David Thompson had curled a free-kick on to the roof of the net from a tight angle the former Liverpool midfielder wasted a good chance after Jamie Clapham had failed to clear.

Bramble, starting for the first time in four weeks, headed just wide from a Martijn Reuser corner at the other end but Ipswich lacked their usual verve against highly committed opponents and were grateful that John Eustace shot at Branagan after chesting down Thompson's fine pass just before half-time.

Coventry, though, did not have to wait long after the interval for an equaliser. Fabian Wilnis ended Chippo's burst down the left by fouling him inside the area and Bellamy tucked away the penalty for his first goal in two months. As a former Norwich player he was doubly unpopular.

Smiles were soon back on Ipswich faces, however. A fine pass by the substitute Marcus Stewart released Johnson, who chested down and ran on to shoot through the legs of Chris Kirkland. Only good saves then kept Johnson and Clapham out.

Ipswich Town (4-4-2): Branagan; Wilnis, Bramble, Scales, Hreidarsson; Reuser (Stewart, h-t), J Wright, Holland (Croft, h-t), Clapham; Johnson, Scowcroft.

Coventry City (4-4-2): Kirkland; Breen, Konjic, Williams, Quinn; Thompson, Eustace, Telfer, Chippo (Hadji, 71min); Aloisi, Bellamy.

Referee : P Durkin (Portland).

webTitle: Worthington Cup: Sunderland 2 - 1 Man Utd

fields.headline: Yorke off as United pay penalty
fields.standfirst:
Phillips strikes from the spot as fledgling feathers get ruffled
Obituary: Len Shackleton
fields.trailText: After a breathless cup tie and a flurry of thunderous tackles Sunderland muscled their way past Manchester United's second string with a penalty scored by Kevin Phillips when most of United's youngsters should have been tucked up in bed.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
After a breathless cup tie and a flurry of thunderous tackles Sunderland muscled their way past Manchester United's second string with a penalty scored by Kevin Phillips when most of United's youngsters should have been tucked up in bed.

By then they had lost one of their more experienced players, Dwight Yorke seeing red during normal time. It has left the United manager Sir Alex Ferguson with a nagging headache. Yorke will now miss Premiership matches against Aston Villa, Ipswich and Liverpool; the legacy of this match could cost him dear.

Yet for 75 minutes United's youngsters strutted around, comfortable with the lead earned by Yorke's first-half goal. Then Julio Arca stooped low to head past Raimond van der Gouw and, in the final 15 minutes of normal time, all composure drained away.

After seeing his side denied what Ferguson described as a "stonewall penalty", when Thomas Sorensen caught Jonathan Greening, Yorke lost his head. Desperately trying to atone for a heavy first touch, he lunged two-footed at Emerson Thome. The red card that followed prompted an outcry on United's bench; the striker's season of fits and starts will now incorporate a suspension. Thome hobbled off and will have a scan on his knee today.

"Dwight did go in high," said Ferguson. "It's uncharacteristic for him and a more capable referee would have recognised as much. He got a lot of abuse from Thome all night and got no protection but now he'll miss three important games. With Andy Cole out, that presents us with a bit of a problem."

In extra-time red mist descended as weary legs flew into increasingly fearsome challenges. The substitute Michael Stewart floored Alex Rae and was lucky to see only yellow before John O'Shea's tug on Phillips presented Sunderland with a penalty. The striker, without a goal since mid-October, dispatched the kick confidently to Van der Gouw's left.

Then Danny Weber and David Healy hit the bar as Wearside held its breath. Peter Reid conceded: "It was a tight one and we got the breaks."

The night had started sombrely with a twice-taken minute's silence for Len Shackleton, Sunderland's leading post-war scorer, who died earlier in the day at 78. The clown prince would presumably have chuckled at the bizarre repetition, due to advertising slots on live television.

The home side stuttered on to the offensive. United's reserves boasted the confident grace of their seniors, zipping passes in neat triangles. It was little surprise when Quinton Fortune's reverse pass sent Ole Gunnar Solskjaer sprinting forward after 31 minutes, the Norwegian squaring the ball for Yorke as he entered the area. Jody Craddock's tackle checked the striker's progress, the ball fell to Greening and, as he feigned to shoot, Yorke recovered to slam the ball into the top corner. Yet, with Wearmouth gnashing in frustration, the home revival was sparked by Phillips' 44th-minute curled shot which thumped against a post. Don Hutchison, Phillips and Arca so nearly restored parity before the teenage Argentine dived on to Phillips' cross to head home.

Sunderland (4-4-2): Sorensen; Makin (McCann, h-t), Craddock, Thome (Varga, 87min), Gray; Hutchison, Rae, Williams, Arca; Dichio. Phillips.

Manchester United ( 4-4-2): Van der Gouw; Clegg, Johnsen, O'Shea, P Neville; Chadwick (Healy, 96), Wallwark, Greening, Fortune; Solskjaer, Yorke.

Referee: M Halsey. (Welwyn Garden City).

webTitle: Late brace takes Canvey through

fields.headline: Late brace takes Canvey through
fields.trailText: Canvey Island of the Ryman League sent Second Division Port Vale crashing out of the FA Cup on their own patch with two goals in extra-time after a goalless 90 minutes.
fields.body:
Canvey Island of the Ryman League sent Second Division Port Vale crashing out of the FA Cup on their own patch with two goals in extra-time after a goalless 90 minutes.

The part-timers, who fought back from 4-2 down to force a replay with two goals in the last two minutes nine days ago, battled resolutely to send the game into an extra half-hour.

But, rather than fade, the minnows went ahead through the Zambian-born striker Neil Gregory at the end of the first period and a wonderful run and finish from Wayne Vaughan sealed matters.

There was still time for Tony Naylor to give Vale a glimmer of hope but the Islanders went through to the second round for the first time in their history - a derby game at home to Southend, who beat Torquay 2-1 also after extra-time.

Adie Mike came back to haunt his former club with the goal which sent Bury crashing out at the Drill Field.

The Northwich Victoria forward enjoyed a loan-spell at Gigg Lane in 1993 but he showed the Shakers no favours. His close-range volley on 72 minutes was enough to secure a second-round tie at home to Leyton Orient.

Another League side to fall to Conference opposition were Hull, beaten 1-0 at home by Kettering. Matt Fisher's strike on 57 minutes set up a trip to Bristol City.

There was no such trouble for Kidderminster, who ran out 4-2 winners at Burton Albion to ensure a home tie against Carlisle. Peterborough thumped Mansfield 4-0 and will be at home to Oldham.

webTitle: Radio 5 Live strikes a blow for BBC with £14m deal for Premiership rights

fields.headline: Radio 5 Live strikes a blow for BBC with £14m deal for Premiership rights
fields.trailText: Radio 5 Live will continue with live coverage of Premiership matches after the BBC secured a £14m agreement for radio broadcasting rights over the next three years.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday pulled out the stops to hang on to the radio broadcasting rights for the Premiership with a £14m agreement for continued coverage on Radio 5 Live over the next three years.

The payment is around three times higher than the last deal struck with the Premiership and reflects the pressure on the BBC to win the radio rights.

The corporation was left smarting over the summer when it lost the television Premiership highlights package to ITV from next season, spelling the end for Match of the Day. The Radio 5 Live deal, at around £80,000 per match, is thought to be one of the highest amounts ever paid for sports rights on radio.

The BBC saw off competition for the radio rights from Kelvin MacKenzie's Talksport and a couple of production companies hoping to sell the programming on to other stations.

Radio 5 Live will increase its coverage from 120 matches to 180 matches per season from next year. It claims to attract audiences of nearly 3m on Saturdays.

Bob Shennan, the controller of BBC Radio 5 Live, said: "Five Live has covered the Premier League since its inception and we have contributed a great deal besides cash to the growth of the competition on the radio."

There was, however, a consolation for Talksport, which won access to matches to provide score flashes to its listeners in 30-second slots.

MacKenzie said: "I'm very pleased we have access to the Premier League for the first time and in three years I'll have another go for the main rights. But it ain't easy beating the taxpayer."

The BBC lost the rights to the TV highlights package when ITV offered to pay £183m over three years against the corporation's £123m. The result was embarrassing for the director-general Greg Dyke who had vowed to restore the BBC's reputation in sport.

Meanwhile racing's 59 British courses look all set to accept a deal from Go Racing for the media rights contract.

The deal will be worth in excess of £750m over a 10-year period, although the minimum guarantee is £400m with £50m payable for the first year.

Go Racing, a consortium comprising Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena Leisure, beat Carlton for the contract that will be officially signed in two weeks' time and will operate from March 1 next year.

Racing fans will be treated to 4,000 hours of live racing each year and there will also be a daily Channel 4 lunchtime programme.

webTitle: Court threats to planning system

fields.headline: Court threats to planning system
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Four test cases which go to the high court today threaten to throw Britain's planning system into disarray as an unforeseen consequence of the Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
Four test cases which go to the high court today threaten to throw Britain's planning system into disarray as an unforeseen consequence of the Human Rights Act.

The cases will challenge the basis of the post-war planning structure under which decisions are ultimately taken by the environment secretary.

Lawyers are arguing that the system under which decisions are made by the executive breaches the right to a fair hearing by an independent tribunal in article 6 of the European convention on human rights. The convention was incorporated into UK law last month. The Scottish courts have already ruled that the planning system breaches the human rights convention, in a judgment last July. The convention rights have applied to the Scottish executive since 1999, under the Scotland Act.

webTitle: Obituaries: Caroline Benn

fields.headline: Caroline Benn
fields.standfirst: Letters
fields.trailText: Caroline Benn (Obituary, November 24) was a renowned expert on comprehensive schools, but also an excellent tutor of adults.
fields.body:
Carlie Newman, director, Greater London Forum for the Elderly, writes: Caroline Benn (Obituary, November 24) was a renowned expert on comprehensive schools, but also an excellent tutor of adults. In the days when there was still something called an adult education service, she taught young adults who had not passed examinations earlier and now wanted to progress academically. She was committed to helping them achieve their aims, and encouraged many to go on to more rewarding futures.

In 1986, she became involved with the home-tutor scheme for housebound elderly that I ran in the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham. When she heard of the pilot project, Caroline offered herself, and was a tutor in a variety of subjects, from literacy to comparative religion. She brought the same enthusi asm to her class of one person in their home as she did to the rest of her endeavours.

Through Caroline, I was introduced to the Socialist Education Association, when she asked me to write about the scheme for an SEA publication. As president, she chaired and spoke at SEA conference meetings and at Labour party conferences. Small gathering or large, her husband, Tony, attended to support her. At his own meetings, he would often mention our very small scheme, and say that his wife worked for Carlie Newman!

When Caroline attended an SEA meeting a few months ago - pushed in a wheelchair by Tony - she sat, taking notes in her usual fashion, and giving us her full attention, even though she knew she would not be with us for much longer.

When I became a grandmother two years ago, she offered advice on how to achieve good relationships with the wider families of our children's partners. She was remarkable in keeping in touch with a wide range of existing relations, and new relations of her children. She was a great educationalist, a truly committed socialist and a generous friend.

Sheila Yeger writes: In 1990, I was commissioned by the Theatre Royal, Stratford East, to write a play commemorating Keir Hardie's centenary. Caroline Benn's acclaimed biography was not yet published, but, with characteristic generosity, she invited me to read the manuscript.

In Tony Benn's office, I trawled through her scholarly and profoundly human text, and discussed Hardie with them both, thus forming a picture of the first Labour MP, whose preoccupations, including internationalism, women's rights and vegetarianism, are still relevant today.

At the first night of A Better Day, Caroline, resplendent in red silk, engaged in animated debate with a hostile theatre critic. She inscribed her biography to me: "United by Keir Hardie and much more." It was a pleasure and a privilege to know her.

Sylvia Ayling writes: In 1992, the year that her biography of Keir Hardie was published, the East London Historical Society invited Caroline Benn to unveil a memorial plaque to the founder of the Independent Labour party, one of a number which make up the Bow Heritage Trail. It marks the former site of the East London Federation of Suffragettes' women's hall, and honours Sylvia Pankhurst and Norah Smyth, both of whom were active in the area.

As Caroline's researches had revealed, the ELFS was a breakaway group from Emmeline Pankhurst's increasingly autocratic WSPU, led by Sylvia, whose demand, as "a citizen of the world who owed no barrier of race or nation", was not merely for votes for women, but for an economic, as well as a political, democracy.

Caroline duly appeared, outside the Lord Morpeth public house in the Old Ford Road, resplendent in red. Her riveting address was a wonderful summary of the campaigning life of Sylvia, whose family had enjoyed a close relationship with Hardie from their Manchester days.

Afterwards in the pub, she revealed that she had only just come out of hsopital, having been badly injured in a car crash. Whatever the physical and psychological cost to her personally, it did not show. Pure joy was the order of the day.

Later still, she spoke to members of the ELHS about her Hardie biography, bringing the past, and the characters she described, vividly to life, proving, as her husband has remarked, that if you will only blow on the embers of history, they will surely burst into flame. She was greatly admired, and her loss is deeply felt by those whose lives she touched.

K Evans writes: The death of Caroline Benn reminds me of the occasion when she was a contributor to a residential course for teachers at the City of Worcester Training College in the early 1960s. I recall the course as being innovative and, above all, inspiring. Her involvement in seminars and informal discussion is something I remember with gratitude and admiration.

webTitle: PlayStation2 delay does nothing to console Eidos

fields.headline: PlayStation2 delay does nothing to console Eidos
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games publisher whose characters include Lara Croft, yesterday added games console problems to the difficulties which have contributed to its declining fortunes.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games publisher whose characters include Lara Croft, yesterday added games console problems to the difficulties which have contributed to its declining fortunes.

Shares in the company at one stage dropped to a year's low of 177p before recovering to close 5p down on the day at 194p.

The company said low sales of PlayStation games such as Tomb Raider 4 and Fighting Force 2 contributed to losses of £82.3m, as did delays in arrival of Sony's PlayStation2 console.

The company plans to market 19 products for PlayStation2, but only one will be available for Christmas.

Eidos also announced it will be publishing the computer game version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? in six countries.

A deal with Celador International gives Eidos publishing rights in Germany, France, Spain, Norway, Denmark and Sweden. The company intends to move into other countries such as Australia, Italy and Ireland.

The interim loss before tax widened by 117% year on year from £37.9m. Eidos said the headline figure included exceptional losses of £54.1m.

It said one-off costs included a fall in value of its $55m investment in Express.com, a consumer entertainment internet company. Eidos wrote off its 12.6% stake in Express.com after difficult trading conditions for business-to-consumer internet companies meant high levels of growth were not achieved.

Eidos still has a shareholding in the company but no longer has to plough further funding into it. Legal and professional fees of £900,000 were also incurred as a result of bid talks, and were written off as exceptional.

"There are some exceptional issues which need to be discussed but the company is starting to recover," Michael McGarvey, Eidos' chief executive officer, said.

But not all "exceptional" items were classed as such by analysts. Beeson Gregory analysts said the £16.9m write-off on stock returns because of poorer than expected sales were not one-off charges and could not be written off as exceptional.

"That will happen in the future," Peter Read, an analyst at Beeson Gregory, said.

However, not everything was bad news for Eidos. Analysts said they were impressed by the company's prediction that it can recover and move into profitability by 2002.

Pre-exceptionals sales were 23.1% higher than last year's figure, up from £44.1m to £54.3m and in line with Eidos' expectations.

Mr McGarvey said: "The pre-exceptional results show a significant improvement in like-for-like trading on the corresponding period of the previous year. This demonstrates the levels of success that high-quality titles such as Deus Ex, Sydney 2000, Code Veronica and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? can still achieve despite a difficult market."

Eidos is also trying to reduce its costs: Fixed selling and marketing spend was down 14.6% to £8.9m, compared to £10.4m for the previous year.

Eidos has a £50m overdraft facility which, Mr McGarvey said, is sufficient for its current demands.

webTitle: Obituaries: Len Shackleton

fields.headline: Len Shackleton
fields.standfirst: Gifted inside-forward whose maverick approach limited his England success
fields.trailText: Gifted inside-forward and Sunderland legend Len Shackleton has died aged 78.
fields.body:
Len Shackleton, who has died aged 78, called his autobiography, not inappropriately, Clown Prince Of Soccer. It became famous for a chapter headed The Average Director's Knowledge Of Football and consisting of a blank page.

Shackleton, a perennial maverick and an enormously gifted inside-forward, won a mere five caps for England, and was eternally "agin the government". The roots of his dissent might perhaps be found in his experiences as an Arsenal apprentice, just before the second world war. A Yorkshireman, he was spotted by Arsenal, brought down to London and parked at what was then their nursery club at Enfield. "This then frail boy," was how a match programme described him during the war.

Those words were probably written by George Allison, Arsenal's orotund manager, more journalist than football man, who offended Shackleton so deeply and irremediably when he called him in to say the club was letting him go. Allison made the mistake of showing Shackleton a television set in his office; a rarity, then. Far from being grateful or impressed, Shackleton reacted bitterly. This, he felt, was adding insult to injury; the provincial yokel was condescendingly being shown a marvel of new technology.

So "Shack" returned to Bradford, signed for Bradford Park Avenue, and, during the war, went into the mines as a Bevin boy. He continued to play for his club, and made a big impression as a gifted all-round attacker. Arms slightly akimbo in his characteristic stance, a master of ball control, a maker of jewelled passes, and often a scorer himself, he was first picked for England in a victory international against Scotland, in 1946, at Hampden.

That was not a happy day for Shackleton. England lost 1-0, and it was he who gave away the free kick which let Jimmy Delaney score the Scottish goal. Shack would not play for England again till September 1948, when he took part in a goalless draw against Denmark, in Copenhagen.

Big clubs circled him; Newcastle United got him. In 1946, they paid Bradford City what was then the huge sum of £13,000, and he made a spectacular debut at Gallowgate. Newcastle beat Newport County 13-0 in a second division game, and Shackleton scored no fewer than six of the goals. That season, Newcastle were not only promoted to Division I; they also reached the semi-final of the FA Cup.

But Shack would not stay long at Newcastle United. He relates in his book how a director told him, more or less, to box clever, implying that were he to accept a transfer, there would be money in it for him. Before 1947 was out, he had made the short move to Wearside and Sunderland.

Though Sunderland never won anything of consequence in those years, their expensively assembled team played much fine football. Shackleton teamed up with another gifted player, the Londoner Ivan Broadis, though his relations with the powerful Welsh international centre-forward, Trevor Ford, were less happy.

Shackleton took a malign delight in giving Ford what appeared to be perfect passes, which, in fact, had such a fiendish bias on them that the ball was impossible to control; back-spun chips which defied mastery. Once, during a friendly match in Holland, Shack dribbled through the whole of the opposing defence, finally rolling the ball back to Ford in the goalmouth with a cry of, "Don't say I never give you a pass." Despite his talents, he was too idiosnycratic for a regular place in the England team, where it was always so important that the face should fit.

It is told that once, when he was training with the England squad, Walter Winterbottom, the pedagogic England manager, said: "I want all you five forwards to run down the field, interpassing the ball, until you come to the goal, where there'll be no goalkeeper. Then put the ball into the net." Shackleton, lying on the ground, looked up sardonically: "Which side of the net, Mr Winterbottom?" he inquired.

By coincidence, the only three caps he won in the British international tournament were all against Wales; in 1948, 1949 and 1954. He never figured in a national World Cup squad. Probably his finest game was at Wembley in the autumn of 1954, against West Germany, who had just won the World Cup in Switzerland.

Stricken by jaundice, they had a weakened team. England, by contrast, were strengthened by the withdrawal of several regulars, obliging them to pick a brilliant side of ball players, of whom Shackleton was one. In a 3-1 victory, obtained with much fine football, his goal was the pièce de resistance. Luring the German keeper out of goal, he beat him with an exquisite chip. But 1954 would be the last year that he ever played for England; and by then, he was 32 years old.

He was, however, no rolling stone. Sunderland, who had paid what then seemed a whopping £20,500 for him, kept him for the rest of his career. He would go on playing for them until his sole appearance in the 1957-58 championship. Only three times, in the league, did he get into double figures as a goalscorer, but, in his best season, 1951-52, he scored 22 goals in 41 appearances, missing just the one league game.

For Bradford, he played only seven "official" games in the Second Division, scoring four goals, before he went to Newcastle; but, of course, there were many appearances for Bradford during the war. Altogether, Shackleton played 384 league games for 126 goals.

While playing for Sunderland, he opened a barber's shop in the town. On retirement, he became a sports journalist. He moved to Grange-over-Sands, in Cumbria, and suffered a heart attack in August. He had recently completed Return Of The Clown Prince, with his son Roger, who survives him, as do his wife, Marjorie, and two other sons.

Brian Glanville

webTitle: Scrap the case says Lockerbie trial QC

fields.headline: Scrap the case says Lockerbie trial QC
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The case against one of the Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing teetered on a knife edge last night as judges retired to consider whether they would throw it out.
fields.body:
The case against one of the Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing teetered on a knife edge last night as judges retired to consider whether they would throw it out.

Counsel for Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah told the Scottish court in the Netherlands there was "not a jot of evidence" against his client on some charges. Even prosecution lawyers agreed they could not directly prove that Fhimah was at the airport where the bomb was alleged to have been planted.

Prosecution lawyers claim the bomb, which blew up Pan Am flight 103, was placed on a plane which left Malta's Luqa airport, and then transferred to the New York-bound jumbo at Frankfurt airport on December 21, 1988.

But the advocate depute, Alastair Campbell, conceded yesterday there was no direct evidence to prove Fhimah was at Luqa airport on that date. He asked the judges to infer Fhimah's involvement in the bombing from circumstantial evidence - a request that was ridiculed by Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah.

"Your lordships are being asked to infer that a man who wasn't there did, by a means we do not know, smuggle a bomb into Luqa airport," Mr Keen said.

In the biggest mass murder trial in British history, Fhimah - along with his co-accused Abdelbaset Al Megrahi - faces charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and a breach of the Aviation Security Act.

Before the defence had even begun its case, the trial judges were yesterday asked by Mr Keen to throw out the charges faced by Fhimah, on the basis of insufficient evidence to sustain any of them.

Last night the judges retired to consider the application. It is likely they will return with their decision this morning. If they uphold the submission, Fhimah will be free to go home to Libya immediately - and one half of the £2m-a-month trial will have collapsed.

The judges' decision, however, will not affect Megrahi; his lawyers have indicated that their defence will blame Palestinian terrorist organisations for the atrocity.

In the late 1980s, Fhimah worked as station manager for Libyan Arab Airlines at Luqa airport, though he had given up the position months before the Lockerbie bombing. The prosecution claimed he used the post as a front for his activities with the Libyan intelligence service, the JSO. But Mr Keen said yesterday there was no evidence to suggest Fhimah had been associated with JSO.

webTitle: Police officer forced from job because of pregnancy

fields.headline: Police officer forced from job because of pregnancy
fields.trailText: A police officer who was forced to retire after becoming pregnant won a sex discrimination case yesterday against her former force.
fields.body:
A police officer who was forced to retire after becoming pregnant won a sex discrimination case yesterday against her former force.

Jeanette Lundy, 27, who was told "this stage of your life is over" by senior officers when she revealed that she was expecting a child, will be awarded damages at a later hearing of a Leeds industrial tribunal.

She won her claim after the tribunal heard of a "sea change" in attitudes while she was being assessed for a return to duty following a patrol car accident two years ago. She was due for a scan in January to check her whiplash injuries when she found she was pregnant.

Mrs Lundy, who was a passenger in the patrol car when it crashed, said that senior officers and a police doctor had started the process of medical retirement five days later.

Mrs Lundy, of Horbury, had served in the force for six years. She was medically retired on a £15,000 annual pension.

The tribunal heard that Mrs Lundy had suffered terrible pain after the crash, and was still unable to hold her three-month-old baby with her right arm. But she had been determined to return to work, and had wanted to take the scan once her pregnancy was over.

The tribunal chairman, Anthony Simpson, said: "We are satisfied that the retirement was by reason of her pregnancy."

webTitle: Porton 'guinea pigs' to sue MoD

fields.headline: Porton 'guinea pigs' to sue MoD
fields.trailText: Human "guinea pigs" who were subjected to painful chemical warfare experiments are to sue the Ministry of Defence for assaulting them, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Human "guinea pigs" who were subjected to painful chemical warfare experiments are to sue the Ministry of Defence for assaulting them, it was announced yesterday.

Lawyers said the MoD had left them no alternative after the ministry rejected proposals to compensate them.

Many military personnel claim that they were tricked into taking part in the experiments at the chemical warfare establishment at Porton Down, Wiltshire, because they were led to believe that they were volunteering for research into the common cold.

They say they were not told what they were going to be tested with before the experiments. They believe that Porton Down failed to obtain their informed consent to participate in the poison gas tests and, in effect, assaulted them.

The experiments are already being investigated by Wiltshire police.

Yesterday Alan Care of solicitors Russell Jones and Walker, who represents the human guinea pigs, accused the MoD of treating them with contempt. He is to start legal action claiming damages for hundreds of the volunteers.

At a meeting on Monday MoD officials rejected his suggestions for compensating the volunteers.

Around 25,000 military personnel have been experimental subjects at Porton Down since the first world war in what is the longest running programme of chemical warfare tests on humans in the world.

Many were exposed to chemical weapons such as nerve gas, mustard gas, and tear gas. Many have complained that the tests ruined their health for years afterwards.

Under growing pressure, the MoD announced last week that the volunteers could have free medical check-ups, but the volunteers are instead demanding an independent inquiry into their health complaints.

webTitle: Tobacco smuggling at record level

fields.headline: Tobacco smuggling at record level
fields.standfirst: Organised gangs take control of illegal trade
fields.trailText: Customs officers expect to seize a record 2bn smuggled cigarettes this year as organised gangs using giant containers increasingly take over an illegal trade once dominated by bootleggers and white van man.
fields.body:
Customs officers expect to seize a record 2bn smuggled cigarettes this year as organised gangs using giant containers increasingly take over an illegal trade once dominated by bootleggers and white van man.

The number of smuggled cigarettes captured at ports has already soared above the 1.3bn uncovered in 1999, according to customs sources, with container fraud accounting for an estimated three-quarters of those detected.

Seizures have risen from 32m barely five years ago to the current level and some se nior figures in customs suspect they are only stopping a tenth of the smuggled cigarettes flooding into Britain.

Treasury ministers calculate they are losing £2.5bn in taxes but claims by Imperial Tobacco that one in every three cigarettes smoked are smuggled or bought overseas suggests that the total could be much higher.

As many as half the cigarettes seized by customs are believed to have been made by Bristol-based Imperial Tobacco which this week reported surging demand on the continent as sales continue to fall in the UK.

A container labelled children's knitwear inspected in August at Avonmouth was found to contain nearly 5m cigarettes, half of them Imperial's Superking brand and half Gallaher's Sovereign make.

A week later at Portbury docks, another container was found to carry 7m cigarettes, a third of them packs of Imperial's Regal and again the rest were Gallaher's Sovereign.

An investigation into tobacco smuggling by the television company HTV screened last night in the west country named Imperial as one of the biggest exporters to Cyprus, which anti-smoking campaigners claim is at the hub of a smuggling ring.

British companies, said HTV, have transported an estimated 12bn cigarettes to Cyprus - a country with a population of about 600,000 - over the past two years and many are believed to have illegally found their way back into Britain.

Dawn Primarolo, the Treasury's paymaster-general responsible for customs and excise, told the programme: "It does raise questions about whether all those cigarettes actually stay in Cyprus, whether they go somewhere else legitimately, moving on to another country or whether there is something else going on."

Cyprus is an important staging post for legitimate exports to the Middle East and an Imperial spokeswoman yesterday said the company and its wholesalers, shippers and other contacts acted lawfully.

"Customs know exactly where we are exporting and the name of the customers," she said. "We take great care in the agents and distributors we use and all our products are exported perfectly legally."

Sales to Cyprus are thought to have grown dramatically after European customs effectively ended huge sales to Andorra where every man, woman and child would have had to smoke 140 a day if they had not been smuggled back to Britain and other countries.

The government has launched an investigation into evidence that British American Tobacco has exploited smuggling and tobacco companies are facing growing public scrutiny.

webTitle: Model is remade for Playboy as Brazil goes under the scalpel

fields.headline: Model is remade for Playboy as Brazil goes under the scalpel
fields.trailText: The fashion for plastic surgery in Brazil has reached new limits with a model preparing to change her entire physique to reappear in the country's best-selling monthly magazine.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The fashion for plastic surgery in Brazil has reached new limits with a model preparing to change her entire physique to reappear in the country's best-selling monthly magazine.

Carla Perez, 23, is being marketed like a new line of Barbie doll for her appearance in next month's Playboy.

"New hair. New nose. New breasts. New tummy. New bottom. Don't miss Carla Perez's new body," says an advertisement for the magazine.

Plastic surgery was pioneered in Brazil and has long been flaunted by the rich and famous. But the announcements of Ms Perez's operations mark a new level of ostentation.

It is Playboy's second consecutive scoop, after this month's issue contained the first photographs of dancer Scheila Carvalho's enlarged cleavage.

The pictures were launched with a billboard advertising campaign featuring a pair of giant breasts and the unambiguous phrase: "If she used half-cups, they'd spill over."

Ms Carvalho's dark features and ample rear have made her a popular symbol of Latin beauty. For her to implant silicone in her chest was little less than a national event.

Ms Perez used to dance alongside Ms Carvalho in the same pop group and their rivalry is now being played out on the surgeons' operating table.

"I can understand how an other culture might find it grotesque, but in Brazil at the moment it's acceptable," says Cynthia de Almeida, Playboy's editor-in-chief.

"We are playing with the idea of reforming one's body. Both women have already featured in the magazine. If we put them in again we want to show that they are different than before."

Beautiful women are seen as a symbol of Brazil's identity, and Playboy - with an average local circulation of 500,000 - is probably the best barometer of this national pride.

Other specialist magazines are catching up. The editor of Plastic Surgery and Beauty, Katia Neves, says no celebrity has ever refused the chance to be on its front cover. "Plastic surgery used to be elitist. Now you can have operations for just over £1,000. The scars are almost invisible. Any middle-class person can do it," she adds.

Brazil has more plastic surgeons per capita than any country in the world, according to the profession's trade association.The weeks leading to Carnival at the end of February are the surgeons' busiest time of year.

Professor Ivo Pitanguy, who many consider to have started Brazil's craze for cosmetic surgery, is reluctant to say that the desire to alter one's body has gone too far. He says plastic surgery has an important role in society. "It's is not about fashion, we are improving people's self esteem," he argues.

webTitle: Giant turtle found in Sydney sewers

fields.headline: Giant turtle found in Sydney sewers
fields.trailText: An endangered American turtle with an oversized jaw and a taste for fishermen's fingers has been discovered living down a drain in Sydney.
fields.body:
An endangered American turtle with an oversized jaw and a taste for fishermen's fingers has been discovered living down a drain in Sydney.

Six council workers needed a wheelbarrow to drag the 25kg (55lbs) alligator snapping turtle from a gutter in the suburb of Alexandria, where it was found at the weekend after recent heavy rain.

Rescuers named the reptile Cowabunga, after the call-to-arms of the television cartoon characters, the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, who emerged from the New York sewers in the early 1990s.

The snapping turtle is the world's largest freshwater turtle. Native to the USA's south eastern states, it is on the WWF's (formerly the World Wide Fund for Nature) endangered list, and can grow up to a hefty 99.3kg (219lbs) during its 60-year life span.

Unable to withdraw its head into its preternaturally spiny shell, the turtle uses its tough, beak-like jaw to defend itself and has been known to bite prying fishermen's hands. "They're pretty dangerous," reptile expert Brad McDonald told Sydney's Daily Telegraph.

The Australian Reptile Park in Sydney believes the turtle could be one of a batch of babies stolen from the park in 1979.

Mr McDonald said Cowabunga could have survived in Sydney's waterways and drainage system for years, and predicted there might even be a whole family of snapping turtles living in the drains.

Wild snapping turtles stalk fish, snakes, ducks and small mammals, but will also scavenge dead meat, rotting vegetation and snails. Sydney's snapping turtle could have feasted on rats and stray cats.

Cowabunga is now resting in one of the Australian Reptile Park's pond. He will soon be paired up with a widowed female, dubbed the Terminator after she was found alive in the ashes of a fire which killed her mate several months ago. "Hopefully, there'll be romance," said park spokesperson Mary Rayner.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: German terrorist trial opens
fields.body:
German terrorist trial opens

A woman thought to be a member of Germany's Red Army Faction terrorist group went on trial at Stuttgart's high-security Stammheim prison yesterday.

Andrea Klump, 43, denied ever being a member of the leftwing terror gang and two charges of attempted murder, including the botched bomb attack on US soldiers at a Spanish Nato base 12 years ago and the killing of a German bank chairman in 1984.

Ms Klump was arrested after a gun battle with police in Vienna in September, in which her known terrorist companion, Horst Ludwig Meyer, was shot dead.

Yesterday, she said she had simply been involved in providing support to jailed faction members through a letter-writing campaign. "I went underground to escape the atmosphere of growing state repression against the political left in Germany," she told the court.

Klump and Meyer are thought to have spent years hiding out in Germany before fleeing to Norway, where they lived in a tent. German police claim that a convicted Red Army Faction terrorist, Birgit Hogefeld, helped them to gain sanctuary in Lebanon with Palestinian freedom fighters.

Ms Klump's trial was described in Germany yesterday as "probably the last involving a suspected Red Army Faction member". The terrorist group disbanded itself two years ago.

If convicted, Ms Klump could face life imprisonment.
Tony Paterson, Berlin

Aristide bid to win over Haiti critics

Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former slum priest now preparing to return as president of Haiti, yesterday tried to win over critics who boycotted Sunday's poll and accused him of plotting a return to dictatorship.

In his first press conference since the end of his first term in 1996, and long before the final tally of votes was announced, Mr Aristide was conciliatory. "There will be a place for everyone in my government," he said. "To have a peaceful Haiti, the opposition is indispensable ... It is part of our democratic fate."

His priority, he said, would be to bring about national reconciliation: "I will work to bring peace to everyone - whatever economic level - as long as you are Haitian. We have problems which will be addressed by Haitians ... We have to protect our dignity," he said.

Mr Aristide did not declare victory, but he spoke as if he were president-elect. The electoral council, which his opponents claim is packed with his supporters, said the electoral turnout in the poor Caribbean state was 60.5%. Opposition groups alleged that ballot boxes had been stuffed with false votes and that the turnout was very low. "They are hallucinating," the opposition leader, Hervé Denis, said. "The election was illegitimate. Aristide does not have a mandate to govern."

But in a sign that the international community was set to give Mr Aristide a second chance, the United Nations spokesman Fred Eckhard said: "We're glad [that the elections] went ahead as planned and that there was relatively little violence."

After becoming president in 1990, Mr Aristide was toppled in a 1991 military coup, only to be restored in 1994 after a US-led invasion to halt a flood of refugees to Florida.

Facing a constitutional ban on consecutive terms, he reluctantly ceded power to a handpicked successor in 1996.
Owen Bowcott

New Jersey stops racist searches

At least 80% of motorists who were stopped and searched by police on a main road into New York city over the past decade were black or Hispanic, according to newly released documents.

The policy of racial profiling - or targeting minorities - was aimed at furthering the war on drugs, despite the fact that 70% of the non-whites stopped were not carrying any.

"The effect of that kind of ratio is devastating," said John Farmer, the attorney general of New Jersey, who released more than 100,000 pages of state records. "This may have been effective in law enforcement terms, but from a social policy point of view, that's a disaster. We have basically measured the cost of that policy and decided it wasn't worth it."

A deputy district attorney wrote in a memo 20 months ago that racial profiling existed as part of the culture: "The assumption is that minorities are drug dealers, and cops are encouraged to stop them."

The issue rose to national prominence in 1998 when two state troopers shot three unarmed black men on the New Jersey turnpike. It was claimed that the ex-attorney general, senior policemen and state officials knew about the practice but did not stop it.

But Mr Farmer said there was no proof in the records that the state had hidden evidence of racial profiling.

Governor Christie Whitman, who sacked a police chief last year for claiming minorities were more likely to deal in drugs, said: "While racial profiling did not begin in this state or under this administration, history will show the end of racial profiling in America did indeed begin in New Jersey under this administration."
Michael Ellison, New York

Arms link to spymaster's Swiss cash

Swiss authorities shed new light yesterday on the scandal surrounding Peru's former spy chief, saying they suspected that most of the funds frozen in Swiss bank accounts came from arms deals with Russia.

"Much of the $48m [£33m] blocked in Swiss bank accounts linked to the former Peruvian secret service leader, Vladimiro Montesinos, very likely originates from payments of commissions connected to arms transactions between Russia and Peru," said a statement from Zurich's district attorney's office.

It said investigators had tracked down and frozen an extra $22m in funds flowing from the Russian-Peruvian arms deals. It gave no details.

Switzerland has begun a money-laundering investigation into Mr Montesinos. Peru has also launched an investigation into the fugitive spymaster.
Reuters, Zurich

"Much of the $48m [£33m] blocked in Swiss bank accounts linked to the former Peruvian secret service leader, Vladimiro Montesinos, very likely originates from payments of commissions connected to arms transactions between Russia and Peru," said a statement from Zurich's district attorney's office. It said investigators had tracked down and frozen an extra $22m in funds flowing from the Russian-Peruvian arms deals. It gave no details. Switzerland has begun a money-laundering investigation into Mr Montesinos. Peru has also launched an investigation into the fugitive spymaster. Reuters, Zurich

webTitle: Moscow blocks OSCE's Chechen 'lecture' on rights

fields.headline: Moscow blocks OSCE's Chechen 'lecture' on rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Foreign ministers of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe had to drop plans for a declaration aimed at resolving the conflict in Chechnya yesterday because of Russian objections.
fields.body:
Foreign ministers of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe had to drop plans for a declaration aimed at resolving the conflict in Chechnya yesterday because of Russian objections.

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, who left the meeting in Vienna on Monday to return to Moscow, accused western countries among the 55 members of the organisation of holding a one-sided dialogue in which they lectured east European countries on human rights.

The OSCE, which is responsible for conflict prevention and human rights in Europe, ended its two-day meeting having secured relatively little other than a declaration welcoming Yugoslavia back into the fold and resolutions on human trafficking and reducing the trade in small arms.

A resolution was passed to make more effort to combat human trafficking, mainly in the sex trade, but the amounts of money committed were small.

Britain promised £200,000 for a problem which the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, described as "the modern version of slavery".

He said: "It is a scar on our European values that trafficking in human beings as commodities is on the increase."

The Austrian foreign minister, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, who chairs the OSCE, said there would be no final declaration on Chechnya and the former Soviet republics of Georgia and Moldova because it was not possible to reach a consensus.

Russia, which regards Chechnya as an internal problem, has so far failed to honour promises it made last year to allow an OSCE mission into Chechnya and withdraw troops from Moldova and Georgia.

The OSCE is scheduled to renew attempts to secure an agreement next year. Meanwhile Russian diplomats have insisted that Moscow will fulfil its promises.

webTitle: Wheels fall off Daimler's American dream

fields.headline: Wheels fall off Daimler's American dream
fields.standfirst: News analysis: Rebellion in the air as leading shareholder demands independence for Chrysler
fields.trailText: News analysis: Rebellion in the air as leading shareholder demands independence for Chrysler
fields.byline: Mark Milner  and  Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
It was billed as "the right idea at the right time" - a merger of two of the top motor industry names - Daimler Benz of Germany and America's Chrysler. Together they would embody everything that was best about European and north American automotive making.

Two years on, the wheels appear to be falling off. Daimler boss Jürgen Schrempp's American dream threatens to turn into a nightmare. Chrysler has been hit by a series of top executive departures. The business has fallen into the red, losing $512m (£361m) in the third quarter. The share price has plunged. At peak, just after the merger, the combined company had a market capitalisation of more than €90bn (£54bn). Today it is barely half that figure.

Finally, last week, Chrysler chairman Jim Holden joined the exodus. Stuttgart sent out two German executives to take over the driving seat at Chrysler HQ in Auburn Hills. There are now two Americans left on DaimlerChrysler's 12-strong management board.

US shareholders are rebelling. Kirk Kerkorian, who has ruffled a few corporate feathers in his time, is suing for $8bn. Through his Tracinda Corporation, Mr Kerkorian owns some 4% of DaimlerChrysler, having been Chrysler's largest single shareholder before the tie-up. He claims shareholders were deceived because the deal was promoted as a merger of equals. Now, he argues, Chrysler looks less a partner, more a division. He wants Chrysler to be given back its independence.

DaimlerChrysler dismissed Mr Kerkorian's claims as being without merit. It argues that the problems with the American half of the business have stemmed from what has been happening in the north American market. Demand is weakening and, with prices under pressure, Chrysler has been forced to offer heavy discounts in order to sell older models while the cost of bringing replacements to the market has been higher than expected.

The light truck - vans to sports utilities - sector has been a particular area of concern. Chrysler was a front-runner in spotting the sector's potential but there are signs that the market may be maturing with too much capacity chasing slower sales growth. The unfolding saga is also coming to be seen as an illustration of what can go wrong with mega-mergers.

Globalisation has spawned a string of mergers and acquisitions where the companies involved are not simply one large one swallowing a smaller one but more where the two are of the same or similar size. The two may get together because they believe they are a good fit, either in terms of products, geographic reach or both.

But getting two strong, successful managements with different approaches to run in harness can be difficult. "The trick is not to be a colonial power but to marry the two cultures. That is easier said than done," said one motor industry executive yesterday. DaimlerChrysler has not always helped its own case. Though the new set-up had two headquarters - Stuttgart and Auburn Hills - and two chairman, Mr Schrempp and Robert Eaton, it was incorporated in Germany. That meant it did not get into the Standard & Poor's 500 in dex. As a result funds which tracked the index could not hold the stock - at least one reason why the proportion of DaimlerChrysler stock held in the US has fallen from 44% at the merger to only 20% now. US shareholders were also unhappy about the German company's decision to clamp down on US standards of disclosure. Soon after the merger, for example, the company stopped releasing details of individual executive pay packages. The crisis has put the spotlight on Mr Schrempp. Under his leadership Daimler has shifted from being a somewhat sprawling transport/technology conglomerate to a business with a much greater focus on the automotive sector. As well as the Chrysler deal Mr Schrempp has been shopping in Asia, buying stakes in Mitsubishi in Japan and Hyundai in South Korea.

But while DaimlerChrysler can sport some impressive credentials to be a global automotive group it has to show that it is more than the sum of the parts. Though Mr Schrempp is now under fire from Mr Kerkorian it is the attitude of the group's biggest shareholder, Deutsche Bank, which is likely to prove crucial. Germany's biggest bank has almost 12% of the group. Earlier this month its chairman Rolf Breuer said the merger had been the right move. As long as Deutsche is supportive Mr Schrempp's vision is likely to carry the day. If Deutsche loses faith Chrysler could turn out to be Daimler's equivalent to BMW's Rover - though on a rather larger scale.

webTitle: Turkish spy chief urges end to ban on Kurdish TV

fields.headline: Turkish spy chief urges end to ban on Kurdish TV
fields.trailText: The head of Turkey's national intelligence agency, MIT, has said that his country should end a ban on Kurdish television broadcasts and not execute the jailed guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan.
fields.body:
The head of Turkey's national intelligence agency, MIT, has said that his country should end a ban on Kurdish television broadcasts and not execute the jailed guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan.

Senkal Atasagun's comments, published yesterday in local newspapers, mark a new phase in the debate about how Turkey should deal with the Kurdish issue which has blighted the country for so long.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said Mr Atasagun's argument should be "considered carefully", but other members of the government and the military high command are known to oppose it.

An end to the broadcasting ban and the abolition of the death penalty are among conditions set out by the EU for Turkish membership.

Since Turkey became a formal candidate for membership a year ago arguments have been raging within the Turkish establishment about the speed of proposed reforms.

Mr Atasagun, however, said that Turkey should simply act in its own interests. He pointed out that the official ban on broadcasting in Kurdish was leaving the field open to Medya TV, a satellite channel based in Europe which supports Ocalan's Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and is widely watched in Turkey's mainly Kurdish south-east.

"They are telling many lies, and everyone is watching these broadcasts by satellite," Mr Atasagun said. "If we want to win the trust of our [Kurdish] citizens, we have to make them understand us."

The spy chief was quoted as saying that the army agreed with him, but there has never been any public support from senior generals for meeting Kurdish cultural demands. The military has made it clear that it will oppose anything resembling a concession to the PKK.

Since Ocalan was captured and put on trial last year, the number of violent incidents in south-eastern Turkey has fallen dramatically. By and large, the PKK has followed its jailed leader's orders and redirected its energies into a political struggle.

It has been hard for Ankara to accept the political demands of even more moderate Turks, because of the sensitivity of dealing with the PKK. Even so, this month Mr Ecevit admitted that Turkey would "sooner or later" have to think about allowing Kurdish broadcasts. But the prime minister's deputy, Devlet Bahceli, who leads the rightwing Nationalist Action party, argued that such a move would "fuel ethnic clashes and division".

Yesterday the defence minister, Sabahattin Cakmakog, chipped in. The personal opinions of the head of the MIT "are not binding on the state", he said.

Turkey is waiting to hear how the European court of human rights will rule on an appeal lodged by Ocalan against his death sentence. Although many senior Turkish leaders believe that executing him would be counter-productive, they will not take kindly to another lecture on human rights from a European institution.

The government is already at loggerheads with Europe on several issues. Last week Mr Ecevit accused the EU of deceiving Turkey about the terms of its membership application, and he argued that plans for a new European defence force were "trampling on Turkish rights".

Relations between Turkey and Europe will never be plain sailing, but a real debate is now under way about proposed reforms which were completely off limits until quite recently.

In another sign that some things are changing for the better, 15 youths were found not guilty yesterday of membership of an illegal organistion, after a previous ruling that their confessions had been obtained by torture nearly five years ago.

The trial of the "Manisa children" has been watched by human rights groups at home and abroad as a test of how serious Turkey is about cracking down on torture. Ten policemen involved in the case have been jailed.

webTitle: 12 deaths in Kashmir mock Indian ceasefire

fields.headline: 12 deaths in Kashmir mock Indian ceasefire
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: India's attempt to introduce a Ramadan ceasefire in its battle with Muslim separatists in Kashmir ran into deep trouble in its first day when rebels exploded a landmine under an army truck, killing three soldiers and injuring 12.
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy in Islamabad and  Luke Harding in New Delhi
fields.body:
India's attempt to introduce a Ramadan ceasefire in its battle with Muslim separatists in Kashmir ran into deep trouble in its first day when rebels exploded a landmine under an army truck, killing three soldiers and injuring 12.

Another nine people died in an exchange of fire between Indian troops and separatists near the Pakistani border. Two soldiers and five separatists were killed and two civilians died in the crossfire, the Indian army said. Five soldiers were injured.

Hizbul Mojahedin, the main separatist group, said that it planted the mine in the village of Duru, 34 miles south of Srinagar. It said it would defy the truce announced by New Delhi, which began at dawn yesterday with the start of Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting.

"We have taken recourse to the gun because India has displayed intransigency and obduracy for the last 53 years," its leader, Syed Salahuddin, said. "The mojahedin are causing tremendous casualties to the Indian forces. They are psychologically depressed, that is why they proposed a ceasefire. Kashmir is not an internal problem. We want tripartite talks - India, Kashmiris and Pakistan."

A smaller militant organisation, Al-Badar Mojahedin, said it too was beginning a new military offensive against the Indian forces last night.

Pakistan's military regime has also dismissed the truce, describing it as "tactical." Shortly after the ceasefire was announced the foreign ministry said it was "part of India's effort to impose a military solution. A ministry spokesman, Riaz Mohammed Khan, accused Indian security forces of repression in the area and said New Delhi had exploited a ceasefire proposed earlier in the year by Hizbul Mojahedin.

The month-long unilateral ceasefire was announced by the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, 10 days ago. Indian troops have been instructed to cease all combat operations against militant "outfits", but to retaliate if they are fired on.

Soldiers posted on the line of control, which divides Indian and Pakistani parts of the state, were put on high alert, in readiness for further attacks.

Last week Hizbul Mojahedin and other hardline militant groups based in Pakistan rejected the ceasefire as propaganda and vowed to step up their campaign of violence.

But the move was cautiously welcomed by the Kashmir-based All Parties Hurriyat Conference, and the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, though they expressed doubt about New Delhi's sincerity.

India and Pakistan, the world's two newest nuclear states, both claim the whole of Kashmir, which has a majority of Muslim inhabitants. They have fought two wars over it since independence in 1947, and clashed again for 10 weeks in the mountains of Kargil last summer.

Pakistan denies giving the fighting groups anything beyond political and moral support, but some senior figures in Pakistan are beginning to suggest that the armed forces should be giving a more positive response to the Indian initiative.

Sardar Abdul Qayyum Khan, a former prime minister of Pakistani Kashmir, said that Islamabad should not dismiss the ceasefire. "Otherwise the whole world would say that we don't believe in the peaceful settlement of the Kashmir dispute," he said.

In August, the Hizbul Mojahedin unexpectedly announced its own three-month ceasefire, only to withdraw it acrimoniously two weeks later. It blamed the collapse of peace talks on India's decision to rule out Paklistani involvement in any discussion of Kashmir's future.

Ms Vajpayee's latest offer follows behind-the-scenes exchanges between senior Pakistani and Indian diplomats.

The informal talks, dubbed "track two diplomacy", are designed to bring Pakistan and India to the negotiating table.

An American of Pakistani origin, Mansur Ijaz, is in Delhi as part of the process, as the informal envoy of President Bill Clinton.

webTitle: Chrétien secures third term as Canadian PM

fields.headline: Chrétien secures third term as Canadian PM
fields.trailText: The Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, has won his third consecutive election, it was confirmed yesterday, making him the first prime minister to do so in 50 years. His Liberal party emerged from the weekend general election with an increased overall majority.
fields.body:
The Canadian prime minister, Jean Chrétien, has won his third consecutive election, it was confirmed yesterday, making him the first prime minister to do so in 50 years. His Liberal party emerged from the weekend general election with an increased overall majority.

The Liberals won 41% of the popular vote, giving them 173 of the 301 seats in the House of Commons. The party dominated Ontario, the richest and most populous province, and gained eight seats in the mostly French-speaking Quebec, evenly splitting the seats 37-37 with the separatist Bloc Quebecois.

The bloc, which eventually hopes to win a referendum on seceding from Canada, got 40.5% of the Quebec vote, compared with the Liberals' 43.6%.

The overall result was the biggest majority Mr Chrétien, 66, has won in the three elections since 1993. But the election highlighted a growing gulf in political allegiance between the western Atlantic provinces and the rest of the country.

It was a sobering day for Stockwell Day, the former preacher with an affinity for sporty photo opportunities who took over as leader of the rightwing Canadian Alliance this summer.

The party, which changed its name from the Reform party in an attempt to attract conservative voters, won 66 seats, a gain of eight, but took only two of the 103 seats in Ontario, where it continued to split the right-of-centre vote with the Progressive Conservatives, allowing the Liberal candidates to sneak up the middle.

"We offered a balanced and moderate approach in accordance with our fundamental values," Mr Chrétien said.

"Tonight, the people of Canada renewed their confidence in our programme, with our team and my leadership."

Mr Chrétien's victory comes after one of the most negative campaigns in Canadian history. He was accused of putting his personal ambition before the best interests of his party and the country by refusing to retire.

This victory will make it much harder for the Liberals to push him out.

"I think the question of leadership is now settled by the Canadian people," the health minister, Allan Rock, said on television.

The New Democratic party won 13 seats. Its leader, Alexa McDonough, won her Halifax constituency, beating a Liberal cabinet minister. The Progressive Conservatives also appeared to win the 12 seats they needed to be recognised as an official party.

Official parties receive extra money to run their offices and carry out research, and are allowed to take the floor for the daily parliamentary questions.

Of the nearly 13m votes cast, the Liberals received 41%, the Alliance 25%, the Bloc Quebecois 11%, the Progressive Conservatives 12% and the New Democrats 8.5%.

The turnout, 62.8% of the 20m registered voters, was the lowest in recent history, taking that distinction from the 67% recorded in 1997.
