It was a sobering day for Stockwell Day, the former preacher with an affinity for sporty photo opportunities who took over as leader of the rightwing Canadian Alliance this summer. The party, which changed its name from the Reform party in an attempt to attract conservative voters, won 66 seats, a gain of eight, but took only two of the 103 seats in Ontario, where it continued to split the right-of-centre vote with the Progressive Conservatives, allowing the Liberal candidates to sneak up the middle. "We offered a balanced and moderate approach in accordance with our fundamental values," Mr Chrétien said. "Tonight, the people of Canada renewed their confidence in our programme, with our team and my leadership." Mr Chrétien's victory comes after one of the most negative campaigns in Canadian history. He was accused of putting his personal ambition before the best interests of his party and the country by refusing to retire. This victory will make it much harder for the Liberals to push him out. "I think the question of leadership is now settled by the Canadian people," the health minister, Allan Rock, said on television. The New Democratic party won 13 seats. Its leader, Alexa McDonough, won her Halifax constituency, beating a Liberal cabinet minister. The Progressive Conservatives also appeared to win the 12 seats they needed to be recognised as an official party. Official parties receive extra money to run their offices and carry out research, and are allowed to take the floor for the daily parliamentary questions. Of the nearly 13m votes cast, the Liberals received 41%, the Alliance 25%, the Bloc Quebecois 11%, the Progressive Conservatives 12% and the New Democrats 8.5%. The turnout, 62.8% of the 20m registered voters, was the lowest in recent history, taking that distinction from the 67% recorded in 1997.

webTitle: Runcie's parting shot at Thatcher

fields.headline: Runcie's parting shot at Thatcher
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Lord Runcie, the former archbishop of Canterbury who died in July, has left a timebomb for his critic Lady Thatcher in the shape of a television interview criticising her policies, recorded a week before his death.
fields.body:
Lord Runcie, the former archbishop of Canterbury who died in July, has left a timebomb for his critic Lady Thatcher in the shape of a television interview criticising her policies, recorded a week before his death.

The former archbishop was attacked by the government and tabloid press for his sermon praying for the dead of both sides after the Falklands war and for the Church of England's criticisms of policy in the inner cities. But he will have gentle posthumous revenge in a documentary made by his son James to be broadcast by Channel 4 on December 16.

In it Lord Runcie, who was dying of cancer, confirmed he had directed the Falklands sermon, attacking the attitudes of "those who stay at home, most violent in their attitudes and untouched in themselves" at the government of the day.

The sermon, at what the government had seen as a triumphal service at St Paul's Cathedral after the Falklands war in 1982, provoked attacks on the archbishop for a supposed lack of patriotism, all the more aggravating for ministers because, having won the Military Cross as a tank commander in the second world war, he could not be depicted as ignorant of warfare.

During the interview at his home in St Albans, Lord Runcie admitted he had been surprised by the attacks and says the tone of the sermon was provoked by a newspaper article by the former Liberal leader Lord Grimond predicting his homily at the service would be full of trite establishment banalities.

He felt "you are not going to get that from me" so he "disobeyed my normal rule of saying that you should never think of a particular person to get at".

Lord Runcie, archbishop from 1980-91, said: "In the 80s there were huge events with which one could not fail to be associated...

"For me there was a government that was successful in strengthening the economy and dealing with the unions and yet at the same time I could look out of the window at Lambeth Palace and see the fires of Brixton burning.

"There was a difficulty in recognising firm government but [also] recognising the damage done to the casualties of change and I had to speak up for them.

"I wasn't wholly convinced she [Lady Thatcher] was wrong but I was convinced something had to be done about the effects of her policies that turned me into a wet, someone who was wobbly."

Lord Runcie also spoke of his wartime experience, including a visit to Belsen concentration camp just after its liberation, and of his role in royal events, including the ill-fated marriage of the Prince and Princess of Wales in 1981.

"With Princess Diana I think that archbishops of Canterbury were irrevocably linked up with school chaplains ... and often figures of fun ... it was very difficult for me to touch that other side of her which went to more curious avenues of help in times of real difficulty... astrology and so on."

He said the attacks by the tabloid press were unfair, although James Runcie confirms there was some truth in the story that Lord Runcie and his wife, Lindy, came close to living apart because she disliked his public role.

At the end of the interview, the former archbishop admitted: "Somebody said 'The thing I like is that there is quite a lot of you that isn't a clergyman' _ I am not ashamed of that because our Lord wasn't particularly kind to clergymen. Well, they don't seem to have been his favourite characters in those days."

My Father is scheduled to be shown on Channel 4 on December 16 at 8pm.

webTitle: Blair: railway crisis to get worse

fields.headline: Blair: railway crisis to get worse
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The prime minister has alerted railway leaders to a worsening situation throughout the country with an astonishing revelation that Railtrack is finding more track problems than it is solving, industry sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
The prime minister has alerted railway leaders to a worsening situation throughout the country with an astonishing revelation that Railtrack is finding more track problems than it is solving, industry sources confirmed last night.

Tony Blair has told management from Railtrack, the shadow strategic rail authority and rail passenger groups that he is "seriously concerned" at the crisis and the industry must pull together.

His comments came as a 105-minute rail trip from London to Nottingham turned into an all-night journey after a power cut marooned 30 passengers for hours.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority and one of those present at Downing Street's third crisis meeting on Monday, accused the industry of having a "nervous breakdown" after the Hatfield crash.

According to those at the meeting, Mr Blair told managers: "You seem to be increasing the number of speed restrictions rather than diminishing them. Why is that?" One source told the Guardian: "Nobody could give him a satisfactory answer and he was very angry."

The health and safety executive revealed yesterday that the weekend derailment near Motherwell was probably caused by the rails moving apart when the train passed over them, although the track was inspected last Wednesday.

webTitle: Leader: The countryside

fields.headline: Broad acres, long faces
fields.standfirst:
Can Labour be the countryside's friend?
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The church is still there, though nowadays it shares its vicar with several neighbouring parishes; some weeks you have to drive four or five miles to a service. But the village school has gone, doomed by its falling numbers - not least because houses which might have gone to young families have been snapped up by second-home owners from nearby cities.
fields.body:
The church is still there, though nowadays it shares its vicar with several neighbouring parishes; some weeks you have to drive four or five miles to a service. But the village school has gone, doomed by its falling numbers - not least because houses which might have gone to young families have been snapped up by second-home owners from nearby cities. Few remember the station, which Beeching did for: there's a bus now and then, but not at times when most people want to use it. The village shop closed its doors a couple of years ago. It had long since lost its battle with the supermarkets in town, and once the school was shut the young mums who used to call on the way home took their custom elsewhere. One of the three working farms has gone and another will go in the next 12 months. There is still one pub left in the village (30 years ago there were three) but takings are down and the landlord mutters most nights that any further restrictions on drinking when you are driving will put him out of business. In the bar of an evening the complaint is always the same: Labour is the party of urban Britain. Whatever its rhetoric, this government does not care about life in the countryside.

The rural white paper published yesterday does its honest best to address the complaints of the many communities up and down Britain which feel this way. Having felt for years that they needed a voice, some now believe they have found one in the Countryside Alliance, which has orchestrated their genuine fears and apprehensions - though its core complaint that hunting, which it came into life to defend, is as much a staple of village life as church, school and pub is pure pretence. It is also undeniably true, as is pointed out in today's Analysis report, that the problems of poverty and social exclusion are worse in big towns and cities than they are in the countryside. Poverty is indivisible. Yet in terms of human happiness, social cohesion and even economic efficiency, these threatened communities deserve to be rescued.

There will be muttering in the pub about some of John Prescott's proposals. Will the 20mph signs at the end of the village street be any better observed than the 30mph signs so widely ignored at present? Not unless the traffic is policed: and who will do that? The white paper says councils should be free to levy full council tax on second homes. That change is long overdue. But will councils do it? As unradical an authority as Ewen Cameron, chairman of the Countryside Agency, thinks the rule should be mandatory. As for the stipulation that money thus saved will go to build affordable homes - a form of hypothecation which rural Britain will welcome - most country-dwellers will only believe that when such homes have been built and local people are moving into them. Some farmers, too, will be unimpressed by promises of extra help for those who diversify. They've been told for years to diversify. What used to be farmworkers' cottages have been turned into B & Bs, but since everyone else has diversified in just the same way, it is hard nowadays to find enough holidaymakers to fill them.

These plans will be judged in the end on two assessments. First: will they have helped to assuage a tide of rural dissatisfaction which could well rob Labour next May of some of the rural seats which, rather to its surprise, it captured in 1997? But second: will declining rural communities, from struggling market towns to scattered hamlets, be healthier a decade from now for what was in this package? The answer remains uncertain; but that is the test that matters.

webTitle: Leader: Romania's entry to the EU

fields.headline: Haider, but more so Romania's unlovely presidential aspirant
fields.trailText: Romania, and by extension, the European Union, have just had a brutal wake-up call. Almost a third of Romanian voters have just marked their presidential ballot in favour of an extremist candidate whose virulent statements on minority groups and foreigners make Austria's ultra-rightwing Freedom party leader, Jorg Haider, sound almost moderate.
fields.body:
Romania, and by extension, the European Union, have just had a brutal wake-up call. Almost a third of Romanian voters have just marked their presidential ballot in favour of an extremist candidate whose virulent statements on minority groups and foreigners make Austria's ultra-rightwing Freedom party leader, Jorg Haider, sound almost moderate. Vadim Tudor, who heads the Greater Romania party, came second in a contest of five candidates, and one opinion poll suggests that on this form he could win the run-off in 10 days' time.

This would be a disaster. Just when Europe had begun to hope that the Balkans were entering a period of stability after the downfall of Yugoslavia's Slobodan Milosevic, it could face a new hotbed of tension. For Romanians, the danger of a Tudor presidency is that it would bring its negotiations for entry into the EU to an abrupt end. If the EU reacted harshly against Austria when the Freedom party entered government, it is not going to look kindly on a hardline nationalist who stirs up hatred against Hungarians, Jews and Roma in the magazines he edits as well as in his speeches.

There are some caveats against despair. Even if Mr Tudor became presi dent, the electorate has put the social democratic party of Ion Iliescu in first place in parliament, where he is likely to be able to form a coalition or run a minority government backed by centrists and without Mr Tudor's MPs. As president Mr Tudor's writ would be limited. Secondly, the vote for the Greater Romania party was a protest against the country's entire post-Communist political class rather than necessarily a sign of an upsurge in racism. People were angry over corruption and the decline in living standards of the last 10 years. Some voters were also unhappy with the west for creating problems. Romania suffered heavily from the blocking of the Danube by Nato bombing last year and its chance of attracting foreign investment was also damaged by the Kosovo war.

The best hope now is that Mr Tudor's first round success will shock enough Romanians into ensuring his defeat in the run-off. The politicians who lost last Sunday should surmount their jealousies and swing their support clearly to Mr Iliescu. He may be less committed to market reforms than the centrists, but he is a democrat, a moderate, and pro-European. The appalling Mr Tudor is none of those things.

webTitle: Letters: No reason for treason

fields.headline: No reason for treason
fields.trailText: With respect to Peter Shore (Traitors to their nation, November 28) I think that patriotism in any guise is never benign, because it facilitates the development of faultlines between "us" and "them".
fields.body:
With respect to Peter Shore (Traitors to their nation, November 28) I think that patriotism in any guise is never benign, because it facilitates the development of faultlines between "us" and "them". All of the European wars of the last 100 years, from the first world war to Kosovo, were only feasible because individuals in the respective populations honoured such a dubious sentiment. The sooner that we can ditch emotive concepts such as patriotism and treason, the sooner the world will be a better and safer place.

As I understand it, the European project is not primarily motivated by the potential economic advantages to member states, but rather to ensure that there is such close political, economic and cultural integration that further wars in Europe are no more likely than, for example, wars between Cornwall and Devon. This seems a wholly admirable objective.
Andy Smith
Kingston-upon-Thames, Surrey
Andy@phoenixsystems. demon.co.uk

It is wearisome to see Peter Shore joining the list of commentators attempting to purloin the legacy of George Orwell for their own purposes. Orwell was not a Eurosceptic; in the late 1940s he was promoting the far-left call for the United Socialist States of Europe as a counterweight to both Moscow Stalinism and western capitalism. And should not the left today revive that call to help build an alternative to both the "little England" Eurosceptics and the apologists for the bosses' Europe of the EU?
Paul Flewers
London
hatchet.job@virgin.net

webTitle: "Letter:Drug Abused"

fields.headline: Drug abused
fields.trailText: You report: "Thames Valley police officers will visits schools in Reading, Berkshire, to warn sixth form girls about the dangers of sex attackers using date-rape drugs such as Rohypnol over Christmas" (Date-rape drug warning, November 21).
fields.body:
You report: "Thames Valley police officers will visits schools in Reading, Berkshire, to warn sixth form girls about the dangers of sex attackers using date-rape drugs such as Rohypnol over Christmas" (Date-rape drug warning, November 21).

There have been no convictions in the UK for sexual assault facilitated by the use of Rohypnol. Indeed a Metropolitan Police report, published in June this year entitled "Drug Assisted Sexual Assault" states that "Rohypnol (flunitrazepam) has not been detected in any suspected drug rape samples submitted to the Forensic Sciences Service".
Sarah Ridout
Roche Products Ltd

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The graphic accompanying our report about the misspelling of a tattoo on David Beckham's arm, giving his wife Victoria's name in Hindi, page 1, yesterday, itself had a mistake in it. In transcribing the erroneous tattoo we inserted an extra character, thereby simply adding to the confusion. The fact remains, that the tattoo on Beckham's arm is wrong (but not as wrong as our version).
fields.body:
The graphic accompanying our report about the misspelling of a tattoo on David Beckham's arm, giving his wife Victoria's name in Hindi, page 1, yesterday, itself had a mistake in it. In transcribing the erroneous tattoo we inserted an extra character, thereby simply adding to the confusion. The fact remains, that the tattoo on Beckham's arm is wrong (but not as wrong as our version).

 In a column, page 22, yesterday, we declared, "Ehud Barak is not an Afrikaaner." What we should have said is that he is not an Afrikaner, and his language is not Afrikaans.

 In a caption, page 2, Education, November 21, we identified the young woman in the smaller picture, holding a poster saying "Let Natasha stay", as Natasha Matembele (spelt Matambele in the piece). In fact, the picture showed Rebecca Akinsanmi.

 The ski guide referred to in the headline on our report of the fatal accident inquiry into the mountaineering disaster in Scotland, page 8, yesterday, was, in fact, a mountain guide. Skiing was not involved.

 In our article on the jazz musician Albert Ayler, page 8, Friday Review, November 24, we suggested that the music of Charles Mingus could be heard in a TV advertisement for a credit card. The product in question is, in fact, beer.

 Homophone corner, from Commuter diary, page 7, yesterday, "A weekend of track remodelling... had meant suspended services... which did not auger well for a swift resumption of the normal timetable."

 And a near homophone (only if badly pronounced), from our television notes, page 24, G2, yesterday, "The film focuses on a team of security guards, now employed to diffuse such problems."

webTitle: Letters: Transport in the UK

fields.headline: Integrated transport policy is going nowhere fast
fields.trailText: It doesn't seem as if it's just the cracks in the lines or the floods or even the leaves that are causing train disruptions.
fields.body:
It doesn't seem as if it's just the cracks in the lines or the floods or even the leaves that are causing train disruptions. On Saturday morning I left Totnes to go to Derbyshire. The train was stopped at Gloucester "with a defective speedometer" although the engineer I spoke to said he had authorised the train to go on to Birmingham but had been over-ruled. We were to go to Edgbaston. This was later changed. We were to stay where we were for an hour until another engine arrived. "The left hand doesn't appear to know what its right is doing," said the voice down the speaker. Indeed it didn't.

On the return journey, the 6.20pm from Derby to Totnes was cancelled (no reason given). The next train was declared defective while it was standing still in Derby sta tion; no one knew why, although there were some oil-splashes along the side; the replacement an hour later could only go as far as Bristol Temple Meads (no reason given). We boarded coaches but the coach driver had not been authorised by Virgin trains to go to Totnes so at Exeter we left the coach and took a taxi. Arrival back home 4.45am, just before dawn. For someone who paid £80 for a ticket and had to be at work by 9am and had taken the train to be green it was not encouraging. Could it be that the glare of publicity means no train moves unless it is 100% perfect? Could- it be that management has realised that the only way to ensure complete safety is not to run any trains at all?
John Daniel
Totnes, Devon

 Recent events show that the governance of this country is not capable of delivering the integrated transport policy. The September fuel crisis threw millions of people onto public transport, which could not supply travel information and collapsed under the extra loads.

Then a train derails at Hatfield and, in order to make the railways safer, train speeds and services are reduced. This makes millions get out their cars again and travel on more dangerous roads. It is hardly joined up thinking to make the already safe railways safer, by making the transport system overall less safe.

We need less political hysteria and a period of quiet analysis to allow professional transport operators and engineers to sort out the prob lems. We need a sustainable alternative to car use to reduce the loss of life from crashes and air pollution, most of which results from road transport.

I for one would be more confident in the integrated transport policy if the full panoply of government ministers and the health and safety executive swung into action every time a car came off the road at a curve.
Prof Lewis Lesley
Liverpool JM University
transport-science@rapid.co.uk

 To echo the famous remark about Doris Day, usually attributed to Groucho Marx, I've been around so long I knew the trains before they were Virgin's.
David Hellawell
Bromsgrove, Worcs
dehelwell@bromsgrover.u-net.com

webTitle: "Letter: A case of cross wires."

fields.headline: A case of crossed wires
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson (Wire we waiting, November 27) indulges in the tedious middle-class pastime of moaning about "builders from hell". As a self-employed electrician with 16 years experience of middle-class clients, I would like to see some stories about "clients from hell".
fields.body:
Michele Hanson (Wire we waiting, November 27) indulges in the tedious middle-class pastime of moaning about "builders from hell". As a self-employed electrician with 16 years experience of middle-class clients, I would like to see some stories about "clients from hell".

I only ask two things of the people I work for: that they give clear instructions and pay their the bills promptly. I am offended when they conduct vicious arguments with their partners in my presence, expect me to feed their cats, take in their deliveries, do a few "little extras" for nothing, or make them an interest-free loan by waiting months to be paid.

Portraying all builders as greedy and selfish simply discourages anyone of intelligence from entering an occupation which is held in such low regard.

If Michele can't find anyone reliable to sort out her "dangling wires", feel free to pass on my address. I can promise not to attack her, swear at her, leave the job half finished, or take any sums in cash. But I should warn her, professionals don't come cheap; they may even expect to be paid as much as journalists. After all, if I make a mistake in my work, I could kill somebody - if she does, she could seriously irritate somebody.
David Jones
Rochester, Kent jones@elecserve.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Posh, Becks and Beryl
fields.trailText: So Becks chose Hindi for his tattoo of Vihctoria (sic) because he liked the look of the language (Tattooist's own goal, November 28).
fields.body:
So Becks chose Hindi for his tattoo of Vihctoria (sic) because he liked the look of the language (Tattooist's own goal, November 28). He is in good company: George ("Turned out nice again") Formby supposedly had a mantelpiece on which were carved in Chinese characters the words "George" and "Beryl".
Paul Sharples
Cheltenham, Glos
paul@sharples36.freeserve.co.uk

 Eight column inches on page one for Beckham's "Vihctoria" - 11 column inches of corrections and clarifications on page 23. Guardian ahead on goal difference, I think.
Paul Thompson
Scone, Tayside
Bookseeker@scone17.freeserve.co

 Good to see, what with the front page news of Beckham's tattoo, that there's no danger of the Guardian dumbing down.
Jody Lammas-Daniell
London

 Homophony or euphony? Presumably the best place for the daily repetition of the liturgy described by AN Wilson (The poisoned chalice, November 25) by quires (sic) would be in the great Cathedral of Reams?
Prof Annabelle Sreberny
University of Leicester
as19@leicester.ac.uk

 After half a page describing how Malcolm Bradbury had lived in Norwich for the last 35 years and thrown himself into East Anglian cultural life (Obituary, November 28), it was a bit much in the final sentence for your obituarist to claim that London literary life is much poorer for the loss of its own History Man.
Ian Payn
London
Ian.Payn@dga.co.uk

 Did it really need a study to inform us that deprivation and depression are linked (In Brief, November 28)?
Jill Hall
London

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •The ante-post favourite glides smoothly to the front of our Stupid MP 2000 field. It is Sir Archie Hamilton, the former 1922 committee chairman, who once considered our request that he take a linguistics challenge against a "talking chimp". The Tory MP excels himself this time with two replies to letters from constituent Mrs M Salter of Epsom, an animal rights campaigner, about the evils of fox hunting.
fields.body:
The ante-post favourite glides smoothly to the front of our Stupid MP 2000 field. It is Sir Archie Hamilton, the former 1922 committee chairman, who once considered our request that he take a linguistics challenge against a "talking chimp". The Tory MP excels himself this time with two replies to letters from constituent Mrs M Salter of Epsom, an animal rights campaigner, about the evils of fox hunting.

 In August 1997, Archie revealed that he planned to vote against Mike Foster's hunting bill. "A fox killed by hounds dies quickly," he wrote, adding the usual guff about this being the most humane way to kill them. This October, Archie replied to another missive. "There is no question that hunting is cruel," he says. "It is also wrong to suggest that foxes are pests. There is no difference between hunting and the barbaric practices of bear-baiting and cock-fighting ..." What the sap has done is sign one of those form letters, as all MPs do all the time. However, perhaps because they can read English, most tend not to sign ones stating views diametrically opposed to their own. Archie is now an unbackable 1/4 for the title.

Hats off to my colleague Jonathan Freedland, whose pro-republic Bring Home the Revolution is the preferred Christmas book of Mohamed Al Fayed. When the book (which Tony Blair cannily had on display at Chequers the day Johnnie went to interview him) came out, Mr Fayed rang up and asked to have 100 copies biked round. Somehow he has managed to mislay the lot, because in Tatler he names the book as the one he would most like in his stocking. What a very careless man he is.

It seems that having a porn magnate as proprietor does little for original thought at the Express. "According to new research, soup is more than a winter warmer," read a standfirst above some chicken stock-based recipes yesterday, "it has healing properties." You're very kind. Ignoring the plagiarism, let's recap my mother's chicken soup recipe so far. 1) Buy a boiler, 2) quarter and clean it, 3) place in large saucepan full of water, 4) boil it quickly, 5) turn the flame down and simmer, skimming at least thrice. Now simmer very slowly, with lid half on, half off, for at least two hours. This is essential, the slow process "bringing out the goodness". Tomorrow, finally, to those giblets.

Unhappily, the inauguration of one of Richard Desmond's porn titles as Magazine of the Month is delayed due to failure of nerve in the newsagent. While loitering and feigning close interest in the car magazines, however, I noticed that someone who did manage to buy one of Mr Desmond's more embarrassing titles left the shop in the traditional manner, with the Express carefully folded up and hidden between the covers of Readers' Wives.

I am saddened to read in Tribune that Shahid Malik, the chameleon would-be New Labour MP with strong local and snooker links to every seat he applies to represent, is being investigated by Haringey council over a possible conflict of interest. Councillors are irked, it seems, that while employed to run its regeneration programme, Shahid is too busy pursuing his parliamentary ambitions to attend meetings.

Whispers from "sources close to O'Mandy Mandelson" suggesting he wants transport after the election upset his friends. Our hearts have long been set on the Foreign Office, and grand weekends at Chevening with Carla Powell doing her political salon hostess bit and Liz Murdoch playing coquettishly with the dogs. Weekends at Spaghetti Junction and Crewe lack a certain savour - so let us hope this transport nonsense (very Mandy, all those intricate details about rail gauges) is a ruse to destabilise Patsy and belatedly punish him for the crab joke.

webTitle: Letters: Macho John Prescott

fields.headline: Less macho than moved
fields.trailText: Whether a weak deal on greenhouse gas emissions is better than no deal is a complex topic, worthy of substantial coverage and discussion.
fields.body:
Whether a weak deal on greenhouse gas emissions is better than no deal is a complex topic, worthy of substantial coverage and discussion. But whether John Prescott is an unreconstructed sexist, and whether it matters, is a minor sideshow (Prescott the 'macho man' refuses to back down, November 28).

Anyone, male or female, who makes it to cabinet level in European government should be thick-skinned enough to rise above personal comments, and concentrate on discharging the responsibilities which they are paid to discharge.
Nik Holmes
Uttoxeter, Staffs
nik@cict.co.uk

 I do not have a problem with John Prescott calling female secretaries "love" (Leader, November 28). In the north of England we call all sorts of people love, dear, pet, duck, treasure. My overriding impression of Prescott comes from the anger, frustration and despair on his face in the numerous photos over the weekend, feelings experienced by millions worldwide at the failure of the climate change conference.
Val Mainwood
Wivenhoe, Essex

 Your leader describes John Prescott as "an unreconstructed, Labour stalwart of the old school". The kind that always believed in private ownership of the railways, air traffic control and London Underground, no doubt?
A F Bennett
Chichester
tonben.chi@virgin.net

 It is unfair to take Mr Prescott's comments at face value. He had been working all night and was quite clearly exhausted and emotional when he stormed out of the meeting.
DJ Cockcroft
Stroud, Glos
dave@cynatech.co.uk

 The real problem is not that Prescott is abrasive, not that some of his policies are mistaken, not even the fact that he is guilty of male chauvinism. The subtext rings out loud and clear. "This is what happens when you allow a working-class northerner to get above himself and rise to the position of deputy prime minister."
Nick Blackstock
Bradford

 For an English politician to be publicly attacked by a French politician - even better a female French politician - and for being macho is surely the sort of career boost that they can usually only dream of.
Keith Daborn
Zufikon, Switzerland
kdaborn@access.ch3

 It's bad enough that Ms Voynet gets herself all tired and confused, without going on to throw a temper tantrum about it.
Dick Temple
Catterick, North Yorks
RTEMPLE@smyril.freeserve.co.uk

 What a pity "Two Jags" isn't more macho in his dealings with Railtrack.
Richard Cotton
Wembley, Middx

 Prescott's comments may have been foolish, offensive, unhelpful and misguided, but that does not necessarily make them sexist. If he had been referring to a male colleague reactions would have been quite different. As far as I can see none of his criticisms were based on Voynet's gender (or do I also unwittingly use "classically sexist terms" every time I describe myself as tired and exhausted?)

To blow this tirade of personal insults into a debate about sexism only undermines and discredits the real case for gender equality. But then perhaps I am unable to "understand" the issues of sexism because I am a man.
Matthew Page
Loughborough, Leics

webTitle: FDA forces Glaxo to withdraw key drug

fields.headline: FDA forces Glaxo to withdraw key drug
fields.trailText: The US food and drug administration yesterday forced Glaxo to withdraw Lotronex, a treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, introduced in the US in March.
fields.body:
The US food and drug administration yesterday forced Glaxo to withdraw Lotronex, a treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, introduced in the US in March.

The drug, described by Glaxo as its "most important regulatory submission in 1999", is estimated to have cost £350m to bring to market and was expected to pull in sales of £200m a year by 2003. It was the first medicine specifically marketed for treatment of IBS.

But last night, after the stock market closed, Glaxo revealed that the FDA had taken action following some fatalities. The British drugs group said most of the problems were related to constipation. The drug was intended for use by female IBS patients with diarrhoea, but the company said that US physicians had prescribed it for constipation. Glaxo urged the FDA to give it time to re-educate doctors so that the drug was properly prescribed, but the FDA did not believe proposals to be adequate.

Dr James Palmer, Glaxo's director of medical, regulatory and product strategy, said: "We believe that Lotronex is effective, that its side effects are manageable and the benefits of the product outweigh risks. Thousands of women who have benefited from Lotronex will have to resort to therapies which do not adequately treat their symptoms."

Lotronex has been approved but not yet marketed in four other countries and regulatory submissions were pending in 30 other countries. These will now be withdrawn.

webTitle: Business: Investment needed to cope with climate change

fields.headline: Severn Trent flood warning
fields.standfirst:
More investment needed to cope with climate change

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Britain's second largest water company yesterday warned that the UK sewage system may soon be unable to cope with wetter winters brought about by climate change.
fields.body:
Britain's second largest water company yesterday warned that the UK sewage system may soon be unable to cope with wetter winters brought about by climate change.

Severn Trent - which has more than three million customers - is to ask the new water industry regulator, Philip Fletcher, to increase the amount that water companies are able to invest in order to protect their sewerage networks from flooding.

Its chairman, David Arculus, said the storms earlier this month had reinforced concerns about climate change.

"Our work with the Meteorological Office's Hadley Centre for Climate Change Forecasting demonstrates that wetter winters and drier summers will become characteristic weather patterns in the first half of the century," he said.

"Regulators and governments will need to address these impacts more pro-actively in the future than they have done to date."

For prolonged periods earlier this month several of the group's water treatment plants and more than 50 sewage treatment works and sewerage pumping stations had been unable to operate.

Mr Arculus criticised Sir Ian Byatt, the last Ofwat director-general, for not taking sufficient account of the group's spending plan for 2000-05.

"We were very disappointed by Ofwat's response to our resource plans for the period," he said. "In a similar way, the lack of funding made available for upgrading the sewerage infrastructure was of concern."

But Severn Trent, which provides water and sewerage services in the midlands and mid-Wales, said flooding had resulted in few disruptions to its services to customers.

Brian Duckworth, managing director of the group's regulated water business, Severn Trent Water, said that much of the UK's sewerage network did not have the capacity to handle the very heavy downpours seen earlier this month.

He said that 19th century sewers could not cope with 21st century storm conditions.

"Once-in-30-years storm events are now happening twice in a year," he said.

"It is not just these recent storms. Most water companies have seen a greater incidence of sewage flooding over the past five years."

Ofwat, during its last price review, rejected Severn Trent's £80m proposals for making better use of water resources and removed £400m from its capital investment plan for sewerage improvements and asset renewals.

Mr Duckworth said the extra funding necessary to cope with the impact of climate change could be raised either through a small increase in charges to customers or through a reappraisal of environmental priorities.

"For example, should improving river quality have a higher priority than preventing sewage flooding?" he said.

Robert Walker, Severn Trent's new chief executive, said that the group had no plans to follow the example of other water companies, which are seeking to split the management and ownership of their regulated water assets. He believed the integrated businesses where the owners of the assets also ran the business were the best model.

The group's first half pre-tax profits were £56.3m lower than last year's at £112.8m - largely as a result of the 11.8% net reduction in water charges imposed by Ofwat and increased interest charges. The interim dividend has been maintained at 17p a share.

"We were very disappointed by Ofwat's response to our resource plans for the period," he said. "In a similar way, the lack of funding made available for upgrading the sewerage infrastructure was of concern." But Severn Trent, which provides water and sewerage services in the midlands and mid-Wales, said flooding had resulted in few disruptions to its services to customers. Brian Duckworth, managing director of the group's regulated water business, Severn Trent Water, said that much of the UK's sewerage network did not have the capacity to handle the very heavy downpours seen earlier this month. He said that 19th century sewers could not cope with 21st century storm conditions. "Once-in-30-years storm events are now happening twice in a year," he said. "It is not just these recent storms. Most water companies have seen a greater incidence of sewage flooding over the past five years." Ofwat, during its last price review, rejected Severn Trent's £80m proposals for making better use of water resources and removed £400m from its capital investment plan for sewerage improvements and asset renewals. Mr Duckworth said the extra funding necessary to cope with the impact of climate change could be raised either through a small increase in charges to customers or through a reappraisal of environmental priorities. "For example, should improving river quality have a higher priority than preventing sewage flooding?" he said. Robert Walker, Severn Trent's new chief executive, said that the group had no plans to follow the example of other water companies, which are seeking to split the management and ownership of their regulated water assets. He believed the integrated businesses where the owners of the assets also ran the business were the best model. The group's first half pre-tax profits were £56.3m lower than last year's at £112.8m - largely as a result of the 11.8% net reduction in water charges imposed by Ofwat and increased interest charges. The interim dividend has been maintained at 17p a share.

webTitle: Business: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: AT&T names new president
fields.body:
AT&T names new president

US telecoms group AT&T yesterday appointed David Dorman as president. Mr Dorman is chief executive of Concert, AT&T's venture with British Telecom.

Concert said Gary Weis, its president and chief operating officer, had been appointed acting chief executive officer with immediate effect. In this temporary role, Mr Weis will report to BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance, who is also chairman of Concert.

Setback for condom maker

Condom maker SSL International warned yesterday that a glut of extra bandages and dressings in the market would affect its performance for the next two years.

The health-care firm also said its merger last year would cost £60m more than expected, triggering accusations that it had failed to keep the City properly informed. SSL announced a 12% increase in underlying half-year profits, although exceptional costs pushed it into the red with a pre-tax loss of £47.3m.

Exchanges stay on merger path

Stockholm's OM Gruppen, whose unsuccessful bid for the London Stock Exchange scuppered plans for an alliance between the British and German exchanges, is in talks with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse.

While Euronext, the result of a merger between the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges, continues to insist the door remains open for the LSE to join the alliance.

Menzies sues WH Smith

WH Smith has run into deeper trouble over magazine and newspaper distribution with legal action for abuse of market share being started against it by rival John Menzies.

WH Smith, the country's largest retail and wholesale newsagent, is already reeling from a decision by Associated Newspapers to axe a £100m distribution contract.

webTitle: Business: B&B windfalls scaled back

fields.headline: B&B windfalls are scaled back to £650
fields.trailText: Windfalls for the 2.7m members of Bradford & Bingley are expected to be as little as £650 each when the building society floats on the stock market on Monday, a third lower than initial expectations.
fields.body:
Windfalls for the 2.7m members of Bradford & Bingley are expected to be as little as £650 each when the building society floats on the stock market on Monday, a third lower than initial expectations.

According to forecasts by leading analysts, Bradford & Bingley will make its debut on the stock market in the region of 260p, at the bottom of the range predicted by Goldman Sachs, the investment bank which is leading the share sale.

Each member of the B&B is to receive 250 shares as a result of its decision to become a bank. The B&B revealed yesterday that 38.5% of its members intend to sell their shares immediately. This is one of the largest initial sales to be registered at the demutualisation of a building society.

Analysts at HSBC calculate that at previous demutualisations of building societies between 25 and 40% of members have sold their shares at the outset.

A spokesman for B&B insisted the bank was pleased with the uptake of shares. "We have to factor Christmas in this year," the spokesman said.

The 38.5% of shares are to be sold at an auction on Friday, when institutional shareholders are expected to buy shares, ahead of Monday's listing on the stock exchange.

Analysts at Merrill Lynch warn they would not be "surprised to see initial weakness in the shares post-flotation" because they cannot identity where buyers will come from. Merrill Lynch forecasts a price range of 260p to 280p.

HSBC's analysts pointed to an indicative price range of 255p to 280p and said they expected the shares to trade a discount to other mortgage banks because its strategy was yet to be proved. B&B, which recently bought John Charcol, is aiming to distribute products such as mortgages rather than designing its own.

Analysts at SG are more optimistic, setting a price target of 330p.

webTitle: Councils can tax second homes at full rate

fields.headline: Councils can tax second homes at full rate
fields.standfirst:
Prescott's new deal puts council tax change and release of best farmland at heart of countryside regeneration

Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Prescott's new deal puts council tax change and release of best farmland at heart of countryside regeneration
fields.body:
Town halls will be able to levy the full council tax rate on second homes under a five point plan unveiled by John Prescott to transform the countryside with more affordable housing and improved services for remote communities.

The new deal for rural England, which will safeguard post offices, subsidise village shops, pubs and garages, improve public transport and bolster market towns, will also bring about wholesale changes to the post-war planning system which has kept intact the best farming land.

Unveiling a lengthy rural white paper, the deputy prime minister announced that the number of "social" homes let by housing associations would be doubled to 3,000 a year in three years time.

One housing charity said this move would merely bring the number to the level provided in 1996 by the last government.

However, the biggest uproar yesterday was caused by plans to let councils charge, after consultation, the full council tax for more than 200,000 second homes (a further 300,000 are let as holiday properties). At the moment second home owners get a 50% tax discount, which costs councils an estimated £150m annually in lost revenue.

While some Conservatives labelled the move vindictive, the chairman of the government's countryside agency, Ewen Cameron, who is effectively the prime minister's chief rural adviser, came close to accusing ministers of fighting shy of tougher measures.

Mr Cameron, a Somerset farmer who once chaired the Country Landowners' Association, said ministers should have forced councils to slap the full tax on second homes, rather than give them discretion to do so. He said: "People who have moved to a community because they think it is desirable have contributed very little to make it desirable and the least they can do is pay the full council tax."

Moria Constable, chief executive of the Rural Housing Trust, backed the criticism calling the move a fudge and warning that many councils would not increase the tax unless directed to do so.

But generally all parties welcomed many of the white paper's proposals.

Mr Prescott told the Commons that the government wanted a "living countryside with thriving rural communities and high-quality services...a working countryside". The plan, he said, was dedicated to tackling poverty, improving services and the economy, protecting the environment, and giving people a wider choice. Referring to Labour's measures to regenerate cities, with construction on brownfield sites, so saving perhaps thousands of acres of countryside, Mr Prescott warned against dividing town and country. He would study all proposals for building in rural areas. "We will build on urban brownfield first and greenfield last."

Some of the most adventurous proposals involve radical changes to the post-war farming policy. Funds will be diverted from agriculture to support other rural enterprises - a recognition that farming is in such steep decline that radical measures are needed to transform the countryside without damage to the environment.

By 2006, through a switch of EU common agricultural funds, about £1.6bn - 10% of total agricultural support - in Britain will go annually on other ventures, including tourism and alternative industries. Besides this, the agriculture ministry's veto on planning applications for agricultural land will be lifted. Since 1945, governments have stipulated protection of land classed as "the best and most versatile".

Mentioning the new legislation giving greater access to the countryside and its protection, Mr Prescott was at pains to underline the government's green credentials.

Other ministers weighed in yesterday to support the rural agenda of Labour, which now has more rural MPs than the Conservatives. David Blunkett, the education secretary, said the government had cut the number of village school closures to only four a year - from an average of 30 - and that this year £80m had been earmarked to support small country schools.

The main points

 Town halls to be given powers to levy the full council tax on second homes

 50% rate relief for village shops, pubs and garages which offer wider benefits to the community such as cash machines

 £100m for one-stop health centres in 100 communities

 Revitalisation of rural post offices with £270m of investment

 £240m for rural transport schemes in addition to a £15m special transport fund to support taxis, car clubs and community transport

 The strengthening of parish and town councils by awarding the best of them new powers to provide a range of facilities while drawing up local plans

webTitle: New safety fears raised in air traffic showdown

fields.headline: New safety fears raised in air traffic showdown
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rebel Labour MPs were last night preparing to delivering another snub to the government by voting against controversial plans to part-privatise the national air traffic control services (Nats), as sources close to the bid revealed that one of the main bidding companies is proposing to replace 70% of the engineering staff with contract staff.
fields.body:
Rebel Labour MPs were last night preparing to delivering another snub to the government by voting against controversial plans to part-privatise the national air traffic control services (Nats), as sources close to the bid revealed that one of the main bidding companies is proposing to replace 70% of the engineering staff with contract staff.

The facilities management and support services company, Serco, is planning to sub-contract much of its engineering maintenance work, in much the same way as Railtrack.

This could affect almost 1,000 of Nats engineering staff, who are strongly opposed to the move on safety grounds, as well as the threat to their jobs.

Senior Nats staff have already threatened to resign if the bid goes ahead. They say that Serco is the least suited to the job, although it is known that it is one favoured by the government.

Iain Findlay, national officer of the air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said: "This would lead to a total collapse of the NATS safety system because there would be no control over the quality of work being done by sub-contractors. It would be a repetition of what has happened at Railtrack."

With just two days to get the measures on the statute books before the Queen's speech on December 6, Labour backbenchers were threatening to vote against the government for the third time last night.

Last night's Commons debate followed Monday's vote by peers, backed by thre Labour rebels, for the sell-off to be delayed until after the general election, which is widely expected to be at the start of May.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, swiftly offered a concession which would see the transport bill - with its crucial plans to revive the railways and introduce congestion charging in cities - become law by the end of this week but the Nats sale delayed for three months.

But last night the former transport minister, Gavin Strang, described the concession as "not significant".

webTitle: Berated Sir Eddie says MPs are too rude

fields.headline: Berated Sir Eddie says MPs are too rude
fields.trailText: Top economists could be deterred from serving on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee if MPs persist in hurling personal abuse at prospective members, Bank governor Sir Eddie George warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Top economists could be deterred from serving on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee if MPs persist in hurling personal abuse at prospective members, Bank governor Sir Eddie George warned yesterday.

In defence of colleagues who have suffered at confirmation hearings before the Treasury committee, Sir Eddie said the pool of talent was small and might dwindle further if the tone of remarks did not improve.

"If the committee goes on like that, it is going to make it very difficult for us to persuade people that it is worth the trouble," Sir Eddie told the committee while giving evidence on the MPC's latest inflation report.

Sir Eddie said that two confirmation hearings in particular had given him cause for concern, although he did not name thevictims.

One is thought to be Christopher Allsopp, one of the MPC's four outside experts, who Labour's Brian Sedgemore described as being "more Kidderminster Harriers than Manchester United". DeAnne Julius, was criticised by Mr Sedgemore for her former links with the CIA and Shell. Both have gone on to become MPC members.

webTitle: Cold comfort for village as housing market woos outsiders

fields.headline: Cold comfort for village as housing market woos outsiders
fields.standfirst: Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: After farming the steep hillsides and rocky pastures of Lakeland for over 30 years, Doreen and Roger Westmoreland should be looking forward to a happy retirement.
fields.body:
After farming the steep hillsides and rocky pastures of Lakeland for over 30 years, Doreen and Roger Westmoreland should be looking forward to a happy retirement.

Unlike many struggling rural communities, their beloved village of Troutbeck, nestling below Kirkstone Pass on the winding road to Ambleside, has a string of amenities: village hall incorporating a post office and shop, two pubs, bus service, and an active neighbourhood forum.

"This is a wonderful place to live, with a tremendous spirit," said Doreen Westmoreland. "People really care for each other, meet and socialise regularly."

But like many villages in national parks, and in other protected areas, the beauty reflected on the Lakeland green slate conceals a deepening social problem. Tenant farmers like the Westmorelands can no longer find accommodation locally once they give up a National Trust holding.

The Lake District has become a rich person's playground. When the neighbourhood forum undertook a survey recently it found that 40 of the 105 houses in Troutbeck were either second homes or holiday lets, benefiting from a 50% council tax discount on the grounds that the buildings are occupied only part of the time.

"I'd charge them not just the full rate but double it," fumed Mrs Westmoreland. "If they can afford a second home, they can afford to pay that." Of three properties now on the market in Troutbeck the cheapest has a price tag of £340,000 in an area where annual incomes are often around £15,000.

Mrs Westmoreland is outraged that locals are being priced out of their community once retirement, or marriage, nears. "Older people would like to continue living in the valley where they were born and brought up," she said.

"Our lives are wrapped around this village and it would be sad if we had to leave. My parents were able to buy a house and retire and live nicely, but that's not so easy now." At one time retiring tenant farmers could rely on raising the price for a house from selling stock or farm machinery. Now that the bottom has fallen out of the farming market, animals and tractors are virtually worthless, leaving rented or social housing as the only option. And, sadly, not much is available in the Lake District. Only 4,000 council houses are left in the South Lakeland council area after 3,800 disappeared under the Conservative right to buy policy.

In a frenzied property market, some former council houses have changed hands for as much as £150,000 - to become second homes.

The district now has a house waiting list of 1,700. Increasingly, younger people, along with older couples like the Westmorelands, are being forced out to larger towns in Cumbria where cheaper housing is available.

Displaced from their communities, many of them have to commute back into Lakeland for their low paid work, further adding to household expenses.

Fraser Rae, the district council's director of housing and the environment, cannot contain his anger. "Some estate agents are offering preferential rates for second home buyers, yet people are wandering around with kids in tow looking for bedsits because they can't get a house."

South Lakeland has taken the lead in campaigning for authorities to be given the right to charge full council tax, and use the money raised to provide affordable homes.

The Rural Housing Trust, which helps to build affordable homes in the countryside, estimates that subsidising second home owners through the 50% discount costs £150m annually, compared with only £21m now going to social housing in the shires.

"The idea of so much help going to people who already have at least one home when so little is provided for ordinary local families is a cruel injustice," said Moira Constable, the trust's chief executive.

Like many rural campaigners, she is alarmed that ministers have backed away from abolishing the discount, leaving individual councils to make the decision instead.

webTitle: Red card for Straw's 'British team' idea

fields.headline: Red card for Straw's 'British team' idea
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw last night sparked a furious reaction in Scotland and in the world of football by suggesting it was now time to field a single united British football team to play in international competitions.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw last night sparked a furious reaction in Scotland and in the world of football by suggesting it was now time to field a single united British football team to play in international competitions.

"We might starting winning some games," explained Mr Straw, who went on to provoke every paid up member of the Tartan army by adding that a single British team "might do the Scots some good" as well.

The home secretary was even more scathing about the Scots ability to play cricket, saying a British team in this sport was less of a viable proposition because the Scots "didn't play cricket - at least not very well".

Mr Straw said he would be happy to see the English, Scots and Welsh national football teams carrying on "for domestic purposes", but it was hard to see last night what games they would actually play since the home internationals were abandoned more than 15 years ago.

Some commentators thought the change would make little difference in practical terms, apart perhaps from the addition of Ryan Giggs of Wales.

When he was asked whether he was serious about a British football team, Mr Straw replied: "I am, but it is just a personal opinion. I am English and have been to loads of England games. I thought it might do the Scots some good as well.

"One of the greatest goals I have seen was during Euro 96, when Paul Gascoigne scored the finest I have ever seen when he lobbed the ball over Colin Hendrie. It was absolute magic."

The home secretary put forward his "personal opinion" at a London conference marking the first anniversary of the establishment of a 1,000 strong network of black and Asian civil servants working in his department.

He suggested that a British football team would be one example where combining the diversity of Britain's talent would strengthen the country's performance.

But the proposal was flatly rejected by both the English and Scottish football associations. The FA in London moved quickly to quash an idea that could weaken British football's influence in football's international councils.

He said: "Each of the British nations has its own national association, always has done, and as such we compete as individual countries at football competitions.

"We are happy with the status quo, and to be honest I'm not sure how it would go down with the football public, because part of our British football culture is based on the rivalries between various home nations."

A spokesman for the Scottish FA was even more dismissive of the idea. "It's a complete non-starter with no grounds of support whatsoever in Scotland. The idea comes up from time to time, usually from someone in England."

Mr Straw raised the issue by saying it was time for people to think seriously about the fact that the one field of sport in which the country had been consistently successful was athletics, in which there was an inclusive British team.

He said that strong regional loyalties in Germany had not stopped them fielding a single national football team. "Regional loyalty is as strong in Bavaria as it is in parts of the UK and yet they have a German football team."

webTitle: Witness testimony in Bloody Sunday inquiry

fields.headline: Witness recalls chilling warning over civil rights march
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: On the first day of witness testimony at the Saville inquiry into the Bloody Sunday killings, a milkman recalled being given a chilling warning to stay away from the civil rights march because the paratroopers "were coming in and meant to do serious damage and even kill people".
fields.body:
On the first day of witness testimony at the Saville inquiry into the Bloody Sunday killings, a milkman recalled being given a chilling warning to stay away from the civil rights march because the paratroopers "were coming in and meant to do serious damage and even kill people".

Yesterday was a symbolic day for the inquiry, now in its 52nd day, as this was also the first time that the people of Derry had been given a formal platform to relive the terrors of that afternoon.

John Roddy said he was given the advice by a soldier at Ebrington barracks in the week before the march on January 30 1972 which ended with 13 unarmed civilians being shot dead.

On his visits to the barracks he had befriended the soldier and regularly breakfasted in the canteen. As well as the specific warning, the soldier added: "If I knew anyone in the republican movement who had control of the march on that Sunday then I should get word to them that it should not go ahead."

Mr Roddy said that the word on the street was that the IRA was not going on the march; and two civil rights activists, including a former SDLP mayor of the city, Leonard Green, insisted that the IRA never used the organisation as a cover to shoot soldiers.

Mr Green, mayor in 1983, is from Salford. A telephone engineer, he had moved to Northern Ireland after leaving the Royal Navy. The march was against internment and there were strong feelings on the day, he said. Leaving work for the first part of the march, he came across a group of unionist counter demonstrators waving union flags.

He heard a soldier tell them: "OK, boys, don't worry about it. We'll take care of the bastards today." He returned to work and only heard of the shootings from colleagues at the telephone exchange. The next day he was passing Rossville flats where several people had been killed. He was drawn to a crowd examining bullet holes in the brickwork and one which had seared through the metal of a telephone conduit.

Peering through the hole in the cable he realised it aligned with an army observation post high on the Embassy Building several hundred yards away. The other bullet marks had a clear downward projectory. "They couldn't have been fired by a soldier on the ground," he said. "I have never heard of anything that mentions this particular evidence." Edwin Glasgow QC for the soldiers said that there was no proof that a shot had been fired from the observation post.

Recalling the gerrymandering on Derry council, which denied Catholics their natural majority, Mr Green said he joined the civil rights movement when it was formed in 1968. In answer to the question of whether the IRA ever tried to used the civil rights marches as a cover to attack the army, he said: "Never. It would have destroyed the civil rights movement."

Sinead McNicholl was secretary of the North Derry committee of the Northern Ireland civil rights association. She recalled the "great brutality" of the parachute regiment at a march at Magilligan the week before. People were beaten to the ground by soldiers and rubber bullets fired at close quarters. The inquiry watched a grainy film of the day with the young John Hume, later SDLP leader, remonstrating with a young British officer.

On Bloody Sunday Ms McNicholl did not see the killing but she saw the terror of the demonstrators when the shots were fired and heard Bernadette Devlin, one of the firebrand speakers, telling everyone to duck.

She ended her statement with these words: "I believe that day I was still extremely naive and look back on it now as the last day of my innocence. I had always believed in justice. I didn't like the army being in Northern Ireland but thought that up until the day of Bloody Sunday there was a chance for civil rights to prevail. Bloody Sunday was the greatest step back in Northern Ireland history."

webTitle: Comment: We need  a new world environment organisation

fields.headline: Multilateral thinking
fields.standfirst:
After the failure of international nerve at the Hague, it is surely time to set up new global institutions

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: After the failure of international nerve at the Hague, it is surely time to set up new global institutions
fields.body:
At least the broadcasters are happy. An international conference, which has been on the edge of collapse for several days, finally goes belly-up. Tired and angry, the participants head for the airport, blaming bone-headedness among the other delegations for the failure of the talks. It made great TV in Seattle a year ago, and it happened again last weekend in the Hague.

Ironically, the environmental groups who were angered by the failure of the politicians to settle their differences over global warming were those whooping for joy when mutual loathing and mistrust derailed the world trade talks. But there is a common thread linking Seattle and the Hague - a crisis of multilateralism. The international superstructure that is supposed to enhance global governance - the gatherings of world leaders at conferences held under the auspices of the United Nations, the World Trade Organisation, the International Monetary Fund - is creaking.

Moreover, at a time when the intensification of globalisation has made effective multilateral institutions more important than ever, supra-national bodies have rarely been held in lower esteem. The framework that was established in the aftermath of the second world war no longer seems capable of finding solutions to the problems that an increasingly integrated and connected world throws up.

Why is this? In part it is something to do with the growing power of corporate capital and the dwindling effectiveness of elected politicians. At the birth of the modern international system, business was tainted by memories of the depression and fascism. Statesmen, fresh from running planned wartime economies, were in the ascendancy and were able to set the terms of the debate.

What's more, the institutions that were set up - the UN, the World Bank, the IMF - allowed nation states a large degree of autonomy. The veto for permanent members of the UN security council, for example, meant that the great powers engaged with the UN in ways that they were never prepared to with the League of Nations between the wars. Capital controls meant that countries could enshrine full employment as the prime economic goal; subsidies and controls on trade meant that threats to particularly vulnerable industrial sectors could be mitigated.

Big business and big capital are now in the ascendancy. The intense lobbying in the run-up to Seattle made it abundantly clear that the talks would be driven by what multinationals wanted rather than what the bulk of the WTO's 140 members -poor countries for the most part - needed to hasten development. In the Hague, the big American polluters effectively had a veto on the radical measures needed to reduce carbon emissions. Even worse, the belief system of multinational capital - minimal regulation, a messianic belief in markets, the primacy of low inflation and budget discipline over all other economic variables - has found an echo in the multilateral institutions.

America exemplifies the change. There is no comparison between the generation of Roosevelt, Truman and Marshall and that of Clinton, Bush and Gore. The result is that America's enormous power and potential to make things happen is being squandered or misused.

So what is to be done? One answer is to give up on multilateralism altogether, a natural enough reaction given recent events. The IMF has failed developing countries? Then abolish it. Unesco is unable to show the leadership necessary to deliver global targets for primary education? Scrap it.

But rejecting multilateralism is not really the answer, as most of those campaigning to change the terms of globalisation recognise. Barry Coates, director of the world development movement, says: "WDM is not anti-trade. But we are concerned with who makes the rules and who gets the benefits. We agree that there has to be a rules based system for governing global trade. The alternative is a world of might-is-right protectionism. However we think the aims and the rules of the current system are the wrong ones."

This is a sensible approach. If we want a deal on greenhouse gases, if we want debt relief for the poor, if we want curbs on speculation, then we need effective multilateral institutions. The answer is not to go down the route of unilateralism, which would only leave the weak even more exposed to the naked power of the strong, but to change the goals and working practices of the institutions we have, and to set up new institutions - a world environment organisation with teeth, for example - to deal with new problems.

Perhaps we should hijack the language of the market and impress on our politicians and international bureaucrats that we, the consumers, no longer find the existing product range to our liking. The IMF, the World Bank, the UN, the WTO are not providing what we want. Unless they can diversify, make themselves more relevant and deliver some tangible benefits they face going out of business.

webTitle: Train offers opportunity to become acquainted with fellow passengers...close up

fields.headline: Train offers opportunity to become acquainted with fellow passengers...close up
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences with Britain's collapsing rail system

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences with Britain's collapsing rail system
fields.body:
Yesterday, just for a moment, I thought all my commuting troubles might be over. By agreeing to chronicle my experiences for a week, I was almost certainly ensuring there would be nothing of note; a week free from constant delays, cancellations and misery stretched out before me. "What if nothing happens?" I worried. Needless worry as it turned out.

For the journey home on Monday I arrived at Leeds city station to be greeted by a now familiar level of pandemonium and the introductory chimes of a doom-laden "We are sorry to announce ..." message. The announcements reeled off changed platforms, delayed and cancelled services in quick succession.

In time for the already-delayed 18.13 train home I followed a crowd pushing on to its platform - one of many platform alterations being announced. As is now usual at these times (i.e. the busiest services at the peak times) Northern Spirit had chosen to provide seemingly the smallest train available - an inadequate two carriage bus-like contraption - rather than the usual three (but still inadequate) carriages.

I stood and waited to board the train while passengers were forced to scramble for some small, undignified space into which they could squeeze themselves.

The sight of someone at tempting to board with a mountain bike in tow, the upturned wheels spinning near the faces of bemused travellers, persuaded me to abandon the scrum and wait.

Leeds station is a pretty soulless place at the best of times. Currently it is a huge construction site while Railtrack attempts to drag it into something approaching the 20th never mind the 21st century. Queues of passengers snaked round the platforms in the cattle pen-like "holding areas", presumably created to prevent platform overcrowding but which in fact serve only to make matters worse and to reinforce the impression of a system in the midst of crisis.

The station monitors blinked out the list of delays and cancellations like some bizarre parody of Christmas decoration. Delays and can cellations spanning the entire network - Penzance to Edinburgh 60 minutes late, Scarborough to Liverpool 30 minutes late, Newcastle to Bristol cancelled, and so it went on.

After an interminable wait for an "available platform" I boarded the "late running" 18.43 for home.

Email your rail horror stories to the Guardian: home@theguardian.com

webTitle: Passengers' nine-hour journey from hell

fields.headline: Passengers' nine-hour journey from hell
fields.standfirst:
The train leaving St Pancras was only 18 minutes late - then came the nightmare stoppage and a 4.15am bus ride from rainswept car park

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The train leaving St Pancras was only 18 minutes late - then came the nightmare stoppage and a 4.15am bus ride from rainswept car park
fields.body:
The sight of the cold and dirty double decker bus in the car park of a rainswept Kettering station just after 4am yesterday was the straw that broke the camel's back. The 30 bleary-eyed passengers had descended gingerly on to the platform, stretching aching limbs after spending the night trying to get as much sleep as it is possible to slumped in the seats of a Midland Mainline train.

Of all the nightmare journeys from hell since the rail network went into virtual meltdown after the Hatfield crash, few can compare with what those on the 10pm departure from St Pancras to Nottingham on Monday night had to endure.

The journey from London to Nottingham once took one hour 45 minutes. Even with the speed restrictions imposed for track inspections and repairs it should have taken less than three hours. When the train reached Kettering the passengers had been on board for seven hours after a power failure between Elstow and Bedford affected the signals, leaving the train stranded for almost four hours. They had been promised a luxury coach would take them to their destination.

But as the train crew climbed into taxis at the station the passengers were herded aboard the bus. It is hardly surprising that as tempers started to fray one male passenger threatened to hit the driver.

The journey had an inauspicious start - with no driver available the train left St Pancras 18 minutes late. But as it travelled through the London suburbs and into Bedfordshire the passengers relaxed. Then at 11.20pm, just south of Bedford, the train halted. As the minutes ticked by frustration grew.

"We just sat there," said Ian Hawkins, 25, a computer analyst from Nottingham. "We were given no information, we simply sat and looked at each other." Eventually the intercom issued the first of several apologies for the delay and said the train would move as soon as possible.

Diane Adams, from Nottingham, whose husband had taken her to London for a birthday treat, said: "It was awful.

"The way we were treated was disgusting. They kept coming over the public address system with this excuse and that excuse, but we were stuck there not knowing what was happening."

As passengers used mobile phones to tell their families they would be late home, they were told they were entitled to one free drink and a snack from the buffet car.

With the hours passing and the train still stationary, some passengers tried to sleep.

Finally at 1am they were told a signal failure was to blame for the delay, but it took two hours for the train to move.

After stopping at Bedford and Wellingborough the remaining passengers, many bound for Nottingham, were told the train would terminate at Kettering because the line ahead had been closed for maintenance.

While the train crew departed in their taxis the passengers sat on the bus for 20 minutes as it waited for passengers from two other Midland Mainline trains which had also been delayed by the power failure. With more than 60 furious people on board, the bus went to Nottingham, arriving at the main station just after 7am, nine hours after the train left London.

But the agony was not over. Mrs Adams said staff told her the passengers would have to pay for their taxis home.

The station staff eventually agreed to pay the fares, but that failed to placate many passengers.

"This is not good enough. Privatisation was supposed to improve the service, but we are left with a shambles," said Janice Burke, who had been due to visit her father in hospital.

"An apology is not sufficient. I will pursue compensation."

Where to go in nine hours

 Depart from London at 0915, fly to Barcelona in 80 minutes, have lunch, do a spot of shopping, and return home.

 Leave Manchester in a hot air balloon travelling at an average speed of 8mph and, with the help of a westerly wind, arrive in York with an hour to spare.

 Travel by train the 240 miles between New Delhi and Amritsar in India.

 Drive from Los Angeles to Las Vegas (five hours), get married, and fly to Arizona in time to see the sun set over the Grand Canyon.

 On Concorde you could have flown from London to Barbados in 4 hours, 15 minutes, had a "paddle under the palms" and flown back.

 Take a leisurely stroll from the east coast to the west coast of Menorca.

 Fly from London to Bermuda in 7 hours, 20 minutes, or to Bombay - in nine hours .

Sally James Gregory
