webTitle: Bush adopts softly softly approach

fields.headline: Bush adopts softly softly approach
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration agreed to provide 15 national security briefings to both camps contending for the White House yesterday after George W Bush backed away from making a high profile effort to blast Al Gore out of his path.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration agreed to provide 15 national security briefings to both camps contending for the White House yesterday after George W Bush backed away from making a high profile effort to blast Al Gore out of his path.

Mr Bush remained in Austin, Texas, yesterday, working on building an administration-in-waiting with the man he has named as his White House chief-of-staff, Andrew Card.

The Bush team gave several indications that it has settled on a low key advance on Washington, at least until the US supreme court delivers its verdict on the voting in Florida next week.

The political atmosphere in the US remained strikingly calm yesterday, the day after Mr Gore went on television to ask for patience as he pursues his court challenges to the declared result in Florida.

But Republicans believe that public opinion is moving steadily in their direction and that Mr Bush only has to wait a few days for his victory to acquire an air of inevitability.

The latest opinion polls seemed to support that claim, a Gallup poll yesterday showing that only 37% of Americans were willing to "wait a little while longer" for the result to be settled, compared with 62% who thought the contest had gone on too long.

More than one in three Gore supporters said that he should concede the election, the poll found, and only 15% thought Mr Gore was "the real winner", compared with 51% for Mr Bush.

Mr Bush's spokeswoman Karen Hughes told reporters that he wished to continue to be addressed as "governor" rather than "president-elect".

More aggressive Republicans failed to take the hint. The party's whip in the House of Representatives, Tom DeLay, issued a statement praising "President-elect Bush".

When he arrived at the Texas state capitol building yesterday Mr Bush confined his comments to the waiting media and the watching crowd to: "Good to see you all, is what I say." He then entered the capital for three hours of meetings with Mr Card and Clay Johnson, whom he has appointed executive director of his transition team.

As part of the measured approach, Mr Bush is believed to have delayed for a few days the announcement of any further major appointments to his putative administration.

The appointments of the former chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, General Colin Powell, as secretary of state and Condoleeza Rice as national security adviser are thought to be likely next week, but Gen Powell was reported to have told Mr Bush that he did not want to be used as a pawn in the battle with Mr Gore.

"We can move fairly rapidly in a couple of areas, but he [Mr Bush] has to decide the timing," the vice-presidential candidate, Dick Cheney, who chairs the transition effort, said yesterday.

He said there was a "good possibility" that a Bush cabinet would include Democrats. The main indication so far, however, is that it will contain many of the Republicans who worked in his father's cabinet in 1989-93.

The White House agreed yesterday to set up daily national security briefings for both teams after Mr Gore had suggested the arrangement.

webTitle: Wall-to-wall service for dot.com punters

fields.headline: Wall-to-wall service for dot.com punters
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The new media deal widens the scope for punters (eventually throughout the world) to have a bet through their digital television sets.
fields.body:
The new media deal widens the scope for punters (eventually throughout the world) to have a bet through their digital television sets.

What is termed the interactive facility on such sets enables viewers, at the touch of a button from a handset, to access the internet and find the sites of bookmakers offering fixed odds or a pool betting medium such as the Tote.

As well as the terrestrial television channel screening racing on certain days - as at the moment - there will be a dedicated racing channel with a wall-to-wall service every day.

The simple mechanics of placing an interactive bet are that, having found the required online outlet, the would-be punter registers his name and address and opens a "deposit account" with the bookmaker against a credit card.

There is no limit to the amount of the deposit. However, similar to the normal betting procedure, there is a likely to be a limit to the amount of money staked.

Any losses are automatically deducted from the original deposit while winnings are credited.

As with a bank, the customer can withdraw money from the deposit as and when required.

The natural safeguard of the system is that no one under age can bet because they do not have a credit card.

Eventually, it is estimated that there will be 20 million homes in this country with either digital televisions or the internet facility, although the figure at the moment is nearer six million.

webTitle: Property prices feel the chill

fields.headline: Property prices feel the chill
fields.trailText: The recent slowdown in the property market has seen house prices decline in several areas and come to a virtual standstill in London, according to official figures out today.
fields.body:
The recent slowdown in the property market has seen house prices decline in several areas and come to a virtual standstill in London, according to official figures out today.

The data from the Land Registry reveals that the average price of a home in England and Wales edged up only slightly to £106,850 in the third quarter of this year, compared with £103,115 in the second quarter.

But this 3.6% increase hides wide regional variations: Wrexham saw prices soar 13% over the same period from £60,434 to £68,420; while in Hartlepool they plummeted 14% from £56,230 to £48,114.

The average London home increased in value by just £483 between the second and third quarters from £177,182 to £177,665, though prices declined in six boroughs including Barnet, Westminster and Tower Hamlets.

Other areas which have seen prices fall in recent months include former high fliers Reading and Bath, as well as Portsmouth, North Lincolnshire, and Redcar and Cleveland. However, when property values are compared with a year earlier, all the 10 regions of England and Wales have shown an increase, though the Land Registry found that annually, house prices are rising five times faster in East Anglia than they are in the north of England.

The average home in East Anglia is now worth £94,316, 19% more than a year ago - a rate of inflation well ahead of London (14.1%), and which dwarfs the 3.8% annual price growth notched up in the north of England, where the typical price now stands at £64,259.

In the south-west, a typical property costs £108,121, or 18.2% up on a year earlier, while the south-east has seen the average price climb 16.1% to £136,135.

The figures confirm the slowdown in the market has spread beyond London. Bath and Reading had previously both notched up annual house price growth of more than 30%, but have now started to go into reverse.

The average home in Bath is now worth £134,574 compared with £135,649 in the second quarter of this year, while the new figure for Reading is £132,276, down on the £136,753 achieved in the second quarter.

The Land Registry survey also revealed that of the 335 homes costing more than £1m sold in London between July 1 and September 30, almost a third (105) were located in Kensington and Chelsea.

Westminster accounted for 68 of the £1m-plus properties and Wandsworth 44.

Earlier this week a report from Team, Britain's biggest network of independent estate agents, said there was virtually no change in house prices between October and November in most regions of the UK.

Of the 16 regions surveyed, 13 reported price rises or falls of less than 1% during the period, with only east London, north London and Devon bucking the trend by showing increases of more than 1%.

webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tesco sales surge 5%
fields.body:
Tesco sales surge 5%

Supermarket group Tesco yesterday reported strong growth in the past three months with like-for-like UK sales up 5.1%.

Tesco reported a 4.9% increase in sales volumes and inflation continued at 0.2%. International sales were ahead 49% as Tesco continued to expand in central Europe and Asia. It has opened 29 hypermarkets in these regions this year. Its shares rose 1p to 267p.

Galen counts on therapy approval

Northern Irish health care company Galen said yesterday that it might have its new hormone replacement therapy approved within weeks, as it announced a 28% rise in annual profits to £24.4m. The firm, which recently became Ulster's first £1bn quoted company, has developed an intra-vaginal ring which gradually releases hormones to be launched in 2001.

OFT issues red alert

The office of fair trading warned consumers yesterday not to "become another debt statistic" as spending surges in the run-up to Christmas.

Pop star Louise helped the OFT open the festive season campaign, Don't Let Credit Turn Into Debt.

According to official figures, consumer credit increased more than 60% in the past four years and is running at £159bn a year; the average debt per person on unsecured lending, excluding mortgages, is around £2,500.

Irish bank back on the market

Irish state-owned ICC Bank said yesterday it was in talks with several potential buyers. Bank of Scotland has been tipped as one possible purchaser, with ICC expected to be valued at around £170m in any deal.

The Irish government put ICC Bank, which specialises in loans to small and medium-sized businesses, up for sale last March, but disposal plans collapsed after preferred bidder Bank of Ireland pulled out.

webTitle: Wire fences spoil Poland's view of EU membership

fields.headline: Lace curtain spoils Poland's view of EU membership
fields.standfirst:
Strict controls on eastern border are price of entry

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: A new line of division is being carved through the heart of Europe. It will consist of wire fences, a force of border guards thousands strong and a network of watchtowers stretching 745 miles from the Carpathian mountains in the south of Poland to the Baltic in the north. Passage through it will be gained by visas, logged by computers and vetted by a data bank.
fields.byline: David Hearst in Ustrzyki Gorne, on the Poland-Ukraine border
fields.body:
A new line of division is being carved through the heart of Europe. It will consist of wire fences, a force of border guards thousands strong and a network of watchtowers stretching 745 miles from the Carpathian mountains in the south of Poland to the Baltic in the north. Passage through it will be gained by visas, logged by computers and vetted by a data bank.

This time it is nothing to do with the Russians, who are horrified to see their "systema", the Soviet barrier of double wire fences, pressed back into service. This is not an eastern empire keeping vassal states in, but a rich western market keeping the poorer states of eastern Europe out.

It is called the Lace Curtain and, despite the deep misgivings it arouses in Poland, policing the EU's longest land border is the price Warsaw will have to pay when enlargement of the European Union - the core agenda item at next week's Nice summit - embraces Poland from 2005, or even sooner if Poland has its way.

The thinking behind the demands for tighter border controls is simple, viewed from Berlin, Paris or London: Poland is welcome to join the European club but the invitation is not extended to millions of Russians, Belarussians, Lithuanians and Ukrainians across Poland's all too leaky border. Yet viewed from Warsaw, membership of the EU was not supposed to be like this. It was hailed as the end of history, finally awarding Poland the cast iron guarantee of statehood - which its flickering presence on the 20th century map of Europe had so lacked - as a reward for bringing down communism and joining Nato.

A six-hour train ride away from Warsaw, in the thickly forested valleys of the Bieszczady mountains at Ustrzyki Gorne, the latest watchtower was being blessed this month. Everyone was crammed into the village church, including Poland's interior minister, its chief of police, the head of the fire service and the border guards, plus a bevy of bishops. An honour guard filled the aisle; a regimental band was in the gallery.

Poland's border with Ukraine is only just beginning to open again after the collapse of the rouble stopped millions of shuttle traders from the east. The border has been fought over and ethnically cleansed several times in the last century, the last being in 1948 when more than 650,000 Ukrainians were deported from the foothills after a bitter partisan war fought by a Ukrainian nationalist army, the UPA.

Bitter memories

The scars of the conflict are still raw. In the villages outside the regional capital, Przemysl, monuments are clandestinely raised to the UPA, which the Poles vow to tear down. In the Carmelite garrison church of Przemysl, the monument to the war dead still causes indignation. A double-headed eagle with a Nazi swastika under one wing, it has the following text under the other: "To commemorate innocent Polish people bestially murdered by UPA bands in the south-eastern borders of Poland in 1942-8." A Ukrainian newspaper, the High Castle, meanwhile refers to this area as "Polish-occupied Ukraine".

Across the border in Lviv (or Lvuv as the Poles call it), a parallel dispute is simmering away over the graves of Polish soldiers who defended the city against the Ukrainians in November 1918. The original inscription on the Lyczakowski cemetery memorial, read: "To commemorate those who died in defence of Lvov [as Russians call it] and Polish south-eastern border." The Ukrainian proposal of "to unknown Polish soldiers" was unacceptable. Lengthy negotiations produced: "For those who died for the independence of their country", without specifying which one.

Only last month, Przemysl took its first tentative step in setting up a "high speed" bus with Lviv. As it is, the 56-mile journey takes five hours - 30 minutes to the border, three hours at the border bribing Ukrainian border guards, and an hour and a half to Lviv.

It is into this sensitive border zone that Brussels now treads. "The tightening of the border can only be bad," Marian Majka, the president of Przemysl city council, says without hesitation. "The crime rate will rise, so will the bandits. Trade will drop, unemployment will rise. Reform-minded Ukrainians would not have a chance to see what is going on here. We will, in short, be slipping back in the past, and we all know how difficult that has been."

Poland's foreign minister, Radek Sikorski, an old Solidarity man who was granted political asylum by Britain when martial law was declared, is hard put to contain his frustration. "In real terms we did the most to bring down communism, and western Europe has benefited over the last decade from the peace dividend which we have made possible, which is far bigger than any cost of an enlarged EU," he says. "Now we are under a contradictory directive. On one hand, we are told to keep good relations with the Russians; on the other, to impose visas on them."

Border guards

Mr Sikorski makes the point that one of the reasons for the failure of communism in eastern Europe was that it was possible to travel to other countries. "Not only to Bulgaria, but to west Berlin, Vienna, Sweden and London. Millions of Poles learned that free market democracy worked. That is exactly what we want to show Belarus and Ukraine," he says.

Poland will do all it can to sweeten the pill for those living along the newly fortified border. But it is still wincing at a proposal to station German and Austrian border guards on the EU's eastern front.

"I heard it as an idea. But I think we would have to look very carefully at it. Certainly nothing has been approved by the government," Mr Sikorski says.

Regardless of any concessions, the new border controls are bad news for those such as Miroslav Sydor, an ethnic Ukrainian whose parents were deported in 1947 and who runs a bus company between Lviv and Przemysl.

"If you want division, bandits, the mafia, get visas. The two communities - and there's a lot to forget - are just about getting on with each other, and now we are told to be good Europeans and, as the price of entry, to make the border more difficult to cross. But what are we creating? A market for western Europe to enjoy," he says.

Back at the new watchtower in Ustrzyki Gorne, the post's new ski-mobile was driven in and out of its garage and the cell door banged shut for the benefit of the cameras. But the observation deck on the new tower turned out to be purely ceremonial. It was a dining room with a rather pleasant view. "You see, the Ukrainian border is nine kilometres away," said Captain Tomasz Darzynkiewicz.

webTitle: Orange is not the only fruit for the French

fields.headline: Orange is not the only fruit for the French
fields.standfirst: Snook bequeaths a solid structure
fields.trailText: It is inevitable that the departure of Hans Snook will cast a shadow over the forthcoming flotation of Orange. For more than six years Mr Snook has steered the mobile phone operator through a series of ownership changes (one stock market flotation, two takeover bids and a trade sale) without losing sight of the real goal: maintaining Orange's ability to compete in the day-to-day rough and tumble of mobile telephony.
fields.body:
It is inevitable that the departure of Hans Snook will cast a shadow over the forthcoming flotation of Orange. For more than six years Mr Snook has steered the mobile phone operator through a series of ownership changes (one stock market flotation, two takeover bids and a trade sale) without losing sight of the real goal: maintaining Orange's ability to compete in the day-to-day rough and tumble of mobile telephony.

Now, as Orange prepares to return to the stock market in the first quarter of next year, Mr Snook is preparing to lay down executive responsibilities, although he will retain some links as a special adviser. Mr Snook insists he is not departing in high dudgeon and that, on the contrary, he could have opted for continued high office.

His decision to step down, however, means that when the roadshows start potential investors will not be able to look to the presence of Mr Snook which, given his record, would surely have offered a degree of reassurance in what is at present an extremely uncertain sector.

Nevertheless, the Snook factor should not be overdone. The business that France Telecom will offer some time early next year is rather a different animal to the one which Mr Snook built. True enough, Orange plc will be a crucial part of the company on offer. But it will include other of France Telecom's mobile phone businesses: Itineris in France, for example, and the 28.5% holding in Mobilcom in Germany. It might need a more conservative approach as phone companies try to earn a return on their huge investments in third-generation mobile phone licences. At least Orange will be spared the otherwise inevitable speculation about who really runs new Orange.

Rich ironies

Clever chaps, those Cazenove charmers. Deep within their wood-panelled walls in the shadow of the Bank of England, they are scheming to have their corporate cake and eat it. The blue-blooded bankers want all of the benefits of a flotation - raising money, share options and limiting their liabilities - and none of the associated headaches, such as disruptive shareholders or, heaven forbid, an unwanted takeover bid.

They are working on a clever wheeze to ensure that they will remain an independent company. So far the details are sketchy, but it is understood they are putting restrictions on the way their shares can be transferred between investors.

It is little wonder they are so busy. With half of the FTSE 100 as clients, Cazenove would be a prize catch for any of half a dozen of the world's biggest investment banks.

As a partnership they have been able to resist all advances made so far, as a normal listed company it would be almost impossible. They are already taking the precaution of making sure that most of the shares will be held by friendly forces, particularly staff and former partners.

They will turn to their closest allies for the 10% share sale ahead of the float. Restricting the sale of a further 10%-15% at an IPO will be more difficult.

To stop the staff succumbing to lure of vast amounts of silver being passed across their palms, they must maintain the loyalty and the special culture Cazenove has nurtured - which essentially means pushing huge amounts of cash in their direction, and regularly.

Money is certainly not a dirty word at Cazenove, even if it is spoken about in hushed tones. The employees have helped to make the fortunes of many top bosses and leading fund managers, and reaped the rewards themselves.

For the first time they are going to have to admit now exactly how large the rewards have been - one of the downsides of being a public company.

They can do little to get around the disclosure requirements, and there is no suggestion that they would. But where they can control their own destiny is in coming up with a sophisticated anti-takeover device.

Should they manage that, it is likely to become a blueprint for future floats - until some equally highly paid City lawyers discover how to take it apart.

Rainfall profits

Severn Trent's appeal to the water regulator, Ofwat, that it needs extra funding in the light of global warming resonates with the sound of a bandwagon being jumped upon very firmly. So, with tongue firmly in cheek, let us back the move and recommend that Ofwat take action immediately.

With floods and storms adding to Severn Trent's water reserves, Ofwat should indeed make changes. There is now so much more of the raw material available that some of Severn Trent's customers have, literally, been swimming in it. The laws of supply and demand suggest prices should be cut, forthwith.

webTitle: Schroder tipped for Homebase

fields.headline: Schroder tipped for Homebase
fields.trailText: Venture capital group Schroder Ventures has emerged as favourite to take over Sainsbury's Homebase DIY offshoot in a deal likely to raise some £800m for the supermarket chain.
fields.body:
Venture capital group Schroder Ventures has emerged as favourite to take over Sainsbury's Homebase DIY offshoot in a deal likely to raise some £800m for the supermarket chain.

Homebase has been for sale since August and at least four potential buyers emerged. It was thought that Britain's second-biggest DIY chain might fetch up to £1.2bn, but analysts' expectations have declined as the weeks have slipped by without a deal.

Last week, reporting an expected dip in profits, Sainsbury chief executive Sir Peter Davis said he hoped to finalise the sale by Christmas.

Yesterday one City analyst said that if the chain were sold outright for £800m "it would be a disappointment", but there is speculation that Sainsbury might retain a small stake, so the overall valuation would be £1bn.

A spokesman for the group said Sir Peter had always made it clear that "if it is not the right price then he won't sell it", and it was possible Sainsbury would keep a stake in the business.

US private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts recently dropped out of the bidding. Private equity company Duke Street Capital also backed out, turning its attention to the smaller Great Mills chain.

webTitle: Ofgem delay may add £1.5bn to bills

fields.headline: Ofgem delay may add £1.5bn to bills
fields.trailText: Leading backbench MPs yesterday voiced angry concern at delays to new electricity trading arrangements, Neta, which could cost consumers an extra £1.5bn this winter.
fields.body:
Leading backbench MPs yesterday voiced angry concern at delays to new electricity trading arrangements, Neta, which could cost consumers an extra £1.5bn this winter.

Martin O'Neill, chairman of the Commons trade and industry committee, said customers would be "ripped off" because of delays caused by the failure of energy regulator, Ofgem, to bring in Neta on time.

"We as customers will continue to pay for what's been an unsatisfactory trading arrangement which didn't work - and now we'll have to pay a bit more for the delays," he told Callum McCarthy, Ofgem's director general.

Neta, which replaces the exiting electricity "pool" arrangement, was due to start operations this month but IT problems have caused Ofgem to postpone its introduction until March 27, at the earliest.

The new system, designed to balance demand and supply more promptly, should save 29m electricity customers be tween 10% and 20% on their bills - according to ministers, who wanted it in place long before the general election.

Lisa Waters, a regulatory analyst at Dynegy, a US energy trading company, said the six-month delay would cost customers £1.5bn, or £57 each - a figure that Mr McCarthy did not challenge.

"The government must be worried that bills won't come down soon enough, particularly for domestic consumers, and that gas bills are set to rise too," she said. Mr McCarthy said he deeply regretted the delays but added he could not guarantee the March 27 date for "going live", even though it was "entirely realistic".

Neta will have more than 100 participants compared with the handful in the pool, and has cost Ofgem £100m to set up.

It estimates Neta's cost per customer at 50p a year and the cost of delay at 7p a year over five years, compared with big savings under the new system. But Mr O'Neill said: "The generators will not suffer because of delays, but customers will."

webTitle: Eisner eclipses Britons with Disney magic

fields.headline: Eisner eclipses Britons with Disney magic
fields.standfirst: Disparity It's increasingly rewarding to be a boss in the US
fields.trailText: Britain's bosses earn one tenth of the amount of their US counterparts - despite complaints about the size of their pay packets - says a survey published today.
fields.body:
Britain's bosses earn one tenth of the amount of their US counterparts - despite complaints about the size of their pay packets - says a survey published today.

The research, which appears in the Economics Journal, says the difference is accounted for by a greater use of share options to reward executives in the US.

Based on data from more than 2,000 firms in the two countries, the survey established that in 1997 Britain's corporate elite earnt a total of £330m, an average of £660,000 per executive. This included £74m from exercising share options.

In contrast chief executives of the top 500 US firms made £3.2bn, including £2bn from options, giving an average of £6.3m each.

Disney's Michael Eisner exercised share options worth some £348m, single-handedly earning more than the combined pay of the 500 top UK bosses.

Sam Chisolm - then running Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB and the highest paid UK boss in 1997 - was a mere pauper by US standards. His £6.8m package would have ranked 97th highest in the US that year.

The study, conducted by Martin Conyon, professor of economics at the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, along with Warwick University Business School and Kevin Murphy, professor of economics at the University of Southern California, says that share option gains were driven by the extraordinary performance this year of the US stock market.

But they say it suggests there are important underlying cultural differences between the US and UK.

Even allowing for the fact that US firms tend to be bigger, or in faster growing industries, the pay gap is significant. Adjusting for these differences, the salaries of US chief executives are on average 45% larger than those in the UK, and total compensation packages are 190% larger.

"The US has historically been more tolerant of income inequality - especially if it is driven by differences in effort, talent or entrepreneurial risk taking," say the authors.

"We believe that corporate tax deductibility rules - which encourage share option compensation in the US while discouraging option compensation in the UK - help explain the observed differences in pay structure.

"Ultimately, however, the differences largely reflect subtle political and cultural differences. In the US, the controversy over chief executives' pay has led to tighter links between pay and performance - exacerbating wage inequality, given the robust US stock market.

"In the UK the pay controversy has led to statutory and non-statutory policies that discourage large share option grants, lessening pay performance and leading to a relatively compressed wage structure."

webTitle: Blair tells cabinet to spread EU message

fields.headline: Blair tells cabinet to spread EU message
fields.standfirst:
Ministers ordered to explain enlargement benefits to sceptical public

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has ordered ministers to mount an offensive over Europe before the Nice summit by selling the benefits to Britain of an enlarged union to contrast with Tory "isolationism".
fields.body:
Tony Blair has ordered ministers to mount an offensive over Europe before the Nice summit by selling the benefits to Britain of an enlarged union to contrast with Tory "isolationism".

In a move designed to rebuff charges of a sell-out on national vetoes, the prime minister urged cabinet colleagues to explain that while he firmly opposes majority voting on tax and social security, he does back it in other areas.

Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's official spokesman, said in Brussels yesterday that next week's EU summit would be "tough" but the prime minister would be the "unashamed champion" of enlargement to the east.

In the past Britain has been accused of wanting to widen Europe in order to avoid having to integrate more deeply. But Nice must agree reforms - on national votes, vetoes, commission size and other matters - to avoid paralysis when newcomers start joining.

Poland, Hungary, Estonia, Cyprus and the Czech republic are the front runners in a process that could see an EU of 27 members within a decade. Poland will have as many votes as Spain when it joins, probably in about 2005.

Mr Blair is meeting the French president, Jacques Chirac, for dinner tomorrow to try to nail down final details, but the summit could well run into extra time, so vital is the need to secure a new EU treaty.

"We have to get across to the public that enlargement, the reason for the complicated negotiations at Nice, is not some dry subject concerning far away countries of which we know little, but vital to the future peace, prosperity and strength of Britain and the EU," Mr Blair wrote in a memo distributed yesterday.

Rubbishing Tory and media "scaremongering," and anticipating criticism from William Hague that he is surrendering more powers, the prime minister said the government should attack the opposition leader for hypocrisy and inconsistency.

"The Conservatives risk looking narrow-minded and isolationist. Their past record on defence and extending qualified majority voting allows us to present Europe as just one more issue for the Hague bandwagon.

"The Tories have given up on the economy, given up on presenting any vision for British society, and all they have left is scaremongering on Europe."

Britain says it is ready to accept majority voting on trade and services, allowing the EU to negotiate more effectively with the World Trade Organisation; on the free movement of professionals such as engineers and lawyers; on transport policy, financial regulation and structural funds.

Surrendering the national veto on all these issues is opposed, to a greater or lesser degree, by one or more other member states. If Mr Blair does stand alone, it could be on aspects of his opposition to majority voting on social security provisions.

British opposition to majority voting on indirect taxes, shared fully by Ireland, Luxembourg and Sweden, is based on "sound constitutional reasons", Mr Campbell said.

But since the French presidency of the EU is not calling for tax rates to be subject to majority voting, but rather for coordinating anti-fraud measures within the single market, the argument is more about avoiding a slippery slope that could lead to a greater role in future for the supranational commission.

webTitle: At this price?  NXT

fields.headline: At this price?  NXT
fields.trailText: As Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan will doubtless recall, shares in UK audio equipment firm NXT have been tipped before. But yesterday's news of two licencing agreements for the company's flat panel speaker technology merits further comment.
fields.body:
As Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan will doubtless recall, shares in UK audio equipment firm NXT have been tipped before. But yesterday's news of two licencing agreements for the company's flat panel speaker technology merits further comment.

Interest from General Motors will go some way to ease investor concerns about the actual technology. The US motor heavyweight plans to use five NXT speakers in its Buick Bengal concept car to be launched at January's Detroit motor show.

Steve Liechti, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "Big names like GM put a lot of money into their brands. They cannot afford to be linked to a product that is not working smoothly." With DaimlerChrysler already a licencee, there is the prospect of the technology trickling down to middle marque cars in about four years.

NXT has also licensed its technology to electronic products maker TDK in the US. It intends to launch three multi-media PC models incorporating two panel speakers designed by NXT early next year. This is one of the most commercially viable uses of the technology -known as SurfaceSound - to date, although NXT is not revealing how much it expects to gain in royalties from this sort of application. David Pearson, NXT's chief executive, described the two licencing deals as "an extremely positive foot in the door", but added that it was too early to make revenue predictions.

But developments in large-screen, third-generation mobile phones may prove one of the richest seams for the Huntingdon-based firm - the SurfaceSound technology is able to combine screen and speaker functions.

Shares in NXT peaked at £8 on yesterday's announcement, but ended down 20p at 725p thanks to another poor day for hi-tech stocks.

Looking at the company's fundamentals, it appears a good buy at this price. But its stock market fortunes may be pinned to the fluctuations of the Nasdaq for some time yet.

webTitle: College boy has a hard act to follow at GE

fields.headline: College boy has a hard act to follow at GE
fields.standfirst: End of era New tenant for the house that Jack built
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Immelt will be 45, the same age as his predecessor was, when he takes over as the head of General Electric - the world's largest company.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Immelt will be 45, the same age as his predecessor was, when he takes over as the head of General Electric - the world's largest company.

When Jack Welch was appointed chairman and chief executive in 1981, GE was a traditional manufacturing business with $25bn in annual sales. This year it is expected to earn more than $170bn from operations as diverse as finance, television and light bulbs.

The house that Jack built, as GE has been dubbed, will employ more than 400,000 people by the time Mr Immelt takes over at the end of next year. After a share price increase of nearly 10,000% during the past 19 years, the company ranks as the world's most highly valued by stock market investors.

Mr Immelt, a strapping former college football player, wore a similar outfit to his boss at a press conference this week to announce his appointment. Nobody believes that replacing Mr Welch will be as easy as donning a casual blue shirt, however.

Robert Friedman, equity analyst at Standard & Poors, the ratings agency,said: "I don't think anyone will be able to match Mr Welch's record or unique combination of business acumen and managerial skill." But Mr Welch called him "the right guy to take us forward for the next 20 years".

Several analysts pointed to Mr Immelt's age - he was the youngest of the three contenders - as crucial to his chances. Mr Welch has long said that the head of GE should have at least 10 and preferably 20 years to make his mark. Mr Immelt will be only the ninth chairman in the company's 122-year history.

Mr Immelt, a native of Cincinnati spent most of his career with the company's plastics division, where Mr Welch had his start as a blue-collar worker. However, Mr Immelt is the son of a GE veteran and a teacher, and went to the Ivy League colleges of Dartmouth and Harvard.

He tells friends that his life revolves around GE and his family; he spends little time on other pursuits. His wife, Andrea, is a former GE saleswoman and the couple have a teenage daughter.

Since taking over as head of GE's medical systems division three years ago, Mr Immelt has expanded the business. Revenues have risen nearly 80% while profits have doubled as he cut costs and purchased rivals in imitation of a man called Neutron Jack by his critics.

Mr Immelt also realises the importance of the internet to GE's business. Robert Gariano, a former GE employee who is now an executive recruiter for Russell Reynolds Associates, said: "He grew up with a laptop on his desk. Jack [Welch] and I grew up with slide rules."

However, Mr Welch was one of the earliest and most passionate apostles of the internet among US businessmen. When asked what his most effective attributes were, analysts cited Mr Immelt's managerial and people skills. He is liked by colleagues, who admire his dedication and sense of humour.

Although Mr Immelt was saying little about his plans, he is expected to increase diversity at GE, where few women or people from ethnic minority backgrounds hold senior positions. Dennis Dammerman, a senior board member, described the division meetings headed by Mr Immelt as "like a meeting of the United Nations".

"I don't think about following Jack," Mr Immelt said. "I assume there's going to be no honeymoon and people are going to look for us to meet our commitments. The company is in an excellent position to do that."

Nobody believes that replacing Mr Welch will be as easy as donning a casual blue shirt, however. Robert Friedman, equity analyst at Standard & Poors, the ratings agency,said: "I don't think anyone will be able to match Mr Welch's record or unique combination of business acumen and managerial skill." But Mr Welch called him "the right guy to take us forward for the next 20 years". Several analysts pointed to Mr Immelt's age - he was the youngest of the three contenders - as crucial to his chances. Mr Welch has long said that the head of GE should have at least 10 and preferably 20 years to make his mark. Mr Immelt will be only the ninth chairman in the company's 122-year history. Mr Immelt, a native of Cincinnati spent most of his career with the company's plastics division, where Mr Welch had his start as a blue-collar worker. However, Mr Immelt is the son of a GE veteran and a teacher, and went to the Ivy League colleges of Dartmouth and Harvard. He tells friends that his life revolves around GE and his family; he spends little time on other pursuits. His wife, Andrea, is a former GE saleswoman and the couple have a teenage daughter. Since taking over as head of GE's medical systems division three years ago, Mr Immelt has expanded the business. Revenues have risen nearly 80% while profits have doubled as he cut costs and purchased rivals in imitation of a man called Neutron Jack by his critics. Mr Immelt also realises the importance of the internet to GE's business. Robert Gariano, a former GE employee who is now an executive recruiter for Russell Reynolds Associates, said: "He grew up with a laptop on his desk. Jack [Welch] and I grew up with slide rules." However, Mr Welch was one of the earliest and most passionate apostles of the internet among US businessmen. When asked what his most effective attributes were, analysts cited Mr Immelt's managerial and people skills. He is liked by colleagues, who admire his dedication and sense of humour. Although Mr Immelt was saying little about his plans, he is expected to increase diversity at GE, where few women or people from ethnic minority backgrounds hold senior positions. Dennis Dammerman, a senior board member, described the division meetings headed by Mr Immelt as "like a meeting of the United Nations". "I don't think about following Jack," Mr Immelt said. "I assume there's going to be no honeymoon and people are going to look for us to meet our commitments. The company is in an excellent position to do that."

webTitle: Snook quits Orange amid rumours of France Telecom row

fields.headline: Snook quits Orange amid rumours of France Telecom row
fields.standfirst: Trading places Eccentric departs for enigmatic alternative
fields.trailText: Hans Snook, the eccentric chief executive of mobile phone business Orange, ended months of speculation yesterday when he announced plans to quit the company.
fields.body:
Hans Snook, the eccentric chief executive of mobile phone business Orange, ended months of speculation yesterday when he announced plans to quit the company.

Mr Snook, 52, said he wanted time to pursue his interests in alternative medicine, entertainment and music. That could range, he noted, from developing health food stores via becoming involved in homeopathy to colonic irrigation - of which is he is famously fond.

Mr Snook will leave the company after its flotation on the Paris and London stock markets early next year but will retain an advisory role in the group.

His departure has been widely expected amid reports of tensions between the British management and the new owner, France Telecom.

Many observers have questioned how Mr Snook might deal with answering to new bosses after building the Orange brand from scratch.

Mr Snook yesterday denied his ambitions had been frustrated and said there had been no acrimony between them. He duly posed for pictures and conducted interviews with his French colleagues, asking: "Do you think I would be doing this if there had been?"

He will receive no severance package, and a spokesman said his remuneration for the advisory role had not yet been worked out.

Mr Snook said he had been offered a variety of positions in the enlarged Orange, including both the chief executive and chairman roles. As recently as October Mr Snook was known to be considering the post of executive chairman.

"It's not an issue of who owns what. It was a difficult decision, but I had to try to find a balance to allow myself time for my other interests, which I desperately wanted to do. There would have been an expectation among shareholders, if I had taken an executive role, for me to stay three, four or five years after the flotation and I simply couldn't commit to that."

Mr Snook has been with Orange since its launch in 1993, and the announcement of his departure yesterday shaved 4% off the France Telecom share price. France Telecom bought Orange for £26bn in May. Mr Snook said the conversations with France Telecom's chairman and chief executive, Michel Bon, began some time ago. "We've had these discussions from quite an early stage - although we didn't know how they would conclude."

He said the amount of time he would spend on Orange business would be flexible, depending on what was needed at any time.

"I'm not on the board as a non-executive because my personality is such that I wouldn't be able to resist getting involved in executive decisions." he said.

Mr Snook has not had a conventional career path - having held positions in the hotel industry and real estate sales in Canada. At the age of 35, he took a job in a Hong Kong paging business to help fund further backpacking. That company was bought by Hutchison Whampoa, which brought him to Britain for the launch of Orange. When Mannesmann of Germany bought Orange last year, however, he made £45m.

Mr Snook evangelises about technology and is known by favourite catchphrases, such as "wirefree future".

In his mid-Atlantic accent Mr Snook has never missed a chance to use the company's advertising slogan at the end of a conversation - and did so again yesterday. "The future's still bright."

As part of the advisory role he will continue to articulate group strategy.

The enlarged Orange will include the mobile phone assets of France Telecom, chiefly its domestic business Itineris, making it the second largest mobile phone operator in Europe.

Mr Snook's departure leaves French executives in most of the company's more senior positions. Orange has suffered a number of executive exits - including chief operating officer Bob Fuller, who left to join Telewest, and Colin Tucker, the head of Orange's network operation who joined Hutchison 3G.

Graham Howe, deputy chief executive and finance director of Orange, is staying in his post, however.

The chief executive's role will be filled by Jean-François Pontal, at present in charge of France Telecom's mass market products division. Mr Bon also becomes chairman of Orange.

Mr Bon said he appreciated the disappointment among some investors over Mr Snook's departure, but added: "I am confident that with Jean-François's wealth of experience and Graham's unique understanding of Orange, we have a formidable team going forward."

webTitle: Back to the future

fields.headline: Back to the future
fields.trailText: It is three years since Barclays, up 17p to £18.99, parted company with its investment banking division BZW, to the delight of leading shareholders who were sick of seeing the high street clearer pour millions of pounds into a dud venture.
fields.body:
It is three years since Barclays, up 17p to £18.99, parted company with its investment banking division BZW, to the delight of leading shareholders who were sick of seeing the high street clearer pour millions of pounds into a dud venture.

But market chatter suggests that new chief executive Matt Barrett is searching for a way back in. This Friday, Barclays is hosting a conference for leading analysts in the City and, according to the gossips, the topic of conversation will be the future of Barclays Capital, the capital markets business created from the remnants of BZW.

In a recent interview, Mr Barrett indicated that he likes the advisory side of investment banking. Large institutional shareholders must be hoping Barclays confines any further forays in investment banking to bonds and lending, the niche that has made Barclays Capital such a success in recent years.

webTitle: Business: Kingston forced to rein in spending

fields.headline: Kingston forced to rein in spending
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Kingston Communications is seeking partners to help shoulder the cost of its planned £1bn national network of television and broadband services.
fields.body:
Kingston Communications is seeking partners to help shoulder the cost of its planned £1bn national network of television and broadband services.

The Hull-based company yesterday said it has opened discussions with potential investors in the media, telecoms and financial sectors in response to shareholder concerns about the size of the investment. The aim is to pipe services along the telephone network after British Telecom's local monopoly is broken up next year.

Kingston said yesterday its own liability would be capped at £150m over three years, probably leaving it with little more than 20% of the equity.

Steve Maine, Kingston's chief executive, admitted some disappointment but said the company needed to take a more realistic attitude to funding in the present climate.

"Nine months ago I could have easily have raised £1bn if I wanted to. But it's realistic to acknowledge that given the state of the equity markets that is simply beyond us today. Rather than scale back our ambition we decided on a community of partners.

"The feedback from investors and brokers was that the £1bn figure was the biggest detractor from the value of the company."

The ceiling on funding was welcomed by the market which gave Kingston shares their first fillip in some time. They closed 11.6% higher at 270p.

Kingston aims to set up two joint ventures, one content-based and the second to share the costs of building a DSL network, the technology which converts copper telephone wires for broadband use including pay-TV.

On the content side Kingston has held discussions with media groups including ONdigital, Telewest and BSkyB, its partner in a pilot DSL service in Hull. BSkyB has made no secret, however, of its rival discussions with BT.

"Inviting partners in will not only contribute equity but will also add scale, media and content management skills and a national brand presence for marketing and dsitribution." Mr Maine said.

ONdigital, the joint venture between Carlton Communications and Granada Media, has also been keen to find a strategic partner and might be considered the most natural ally for Kingston.

The retrenchment reflects the stark change in attitude toward the telecoms sector and an unwillingness among in vestors to support big-budget projects with uncertain returns. In line with the rest of the telecoms sector, Kingston shares have suffered a sharp fall - in its case from a 12 month high of £16.09.

Yesterday's announcement should act as a "watershed" for Kingston, Mr Maine said. The company also assured investors that it would not be returning to them for more cash.

Mr Maine warned that some telecoms companies were still burning cash and faced funding issues in coming months.

Kingston reported a 17% in crease in revenues for the first half of the year to £108.7m. Added investment turned a pre-tax profit of £3.2m last year to a loss of £2.7m.

The business, which began life as the local council-owned telephone company, has built seven regional networks outside Hull to target corporate telecoms clients. The division, called Torch, saw 22% growth during the first half to earn £40m. Kingston said it was on target for 20,000 pay-TV customers in Hull by the year end. Average revenue is £20 per customer for the service.

Scipher has a £400,000 contract to provide high-speed links for school pupils in Cumbria and is talking to education authorities in other counties. webTitle: TV: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What people in Birmingham are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What people in Birmingham are watching on TV
fields.body:
Faith Heeler: "Ooh, let me think. My mind's gone blank. Oh yes, I really like Frank Skinner. I think he's very funny and he does ask the right sort of questions; he's very nosey but not in a rude way. Do I like David Baddiel? Well, not as much to be honest, he's a bit of a wet blanket, isn't he? I also like Victor Meldrew, he really makes me laugh. It's sad this is the last series, I could watch it forever. Do I fancy Victor? No!"

June Vallance: "I can get a bit addicted to TV and need to get out to the shops, or else I find I get completely glued in and won't stop watching. I like the daytime programmes like Live Talk. I like the debates on TV. No, I don't think they're all the same. It's about different issues. I think Richard and Judy has gone boring, it's very serious now as they think they're top-raters and it's gone to their head. Hunkiest person on TV? My husband better not read this! Er I quite like that bloke who's on with Alan Titchmarsh. Is it John? The tall one. He's a bit of all right. Very strong, too."

Eric Port: "I watch a lot of the news programmes and Question Time, and sometimes some sport, some rugby. Is this for a survey? I don't really like drama or adverts. I don't like people wearing costumes or doing anything outrageous. I don't like documentaries, the soap opera-type ones. Who's that woman? Jane McDonald, I can't stomach her. I think it's a shame you can be on TV one minute and then be famous for not doing anything. I fought in the war, you know, and I'm not famous. Do I want to be? No, not on your life!"

Kenneth Dreanman: "I like a lot of the serials like Dad's Army, and programmes about comedy and the heroes of yesterday. I like the Tony Hancocks and Eric Morecambes a lot more than I do the other stuff around. What's that lady called who's the vicar? Dawn French, that's it. I don't like her. The programmes I wouldn't watch are films or those bloody cookery programmes. They're bloody awful."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to customers at BHS in Birmingham.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Night of the hunters
fields.trailText: Manhunters
fields.body:
Lock up your sons, confine your husbands and electronically tag your fiancés. If Manhunters (Channel 4) is anything to go by, all across the country, there are marauding bands of randy, devious women intent on luring men to their doom. Indeed, if one were of a paranoid bent, one would worry for tramps sleeping on park benches: in a lighter fuel induced reverie one minute, the next mounted by some 21-year-old nymphomanical pick-pocket. It just doesn't bear thinking about.

These sirens who shop at Matalan are everywhere, from Troon to Southend, evangelically dedicated to pursuing, using, then dumping the unfairer sex, regardless of the hurt they cause.

Sandra was typical of these strumpety women, according to Tony anyway.

Sandra was a "woman from hell" who had ruined a perfectly good marriage, Tony said. It was his marriage and Sandra had ruined it by having an affair with him. Tony's explanation of the situation was barely more complex than "I happened to be giving my penis some fresh air one day and Sandra came along and fell onto it." Poor Tony! Bad Sandra! "I wanted him," Sandra explained, and said she was not going to let his marital status stop her. His facial hair status (nasty moustache) didn't stop her either. Nor did his bad taste in duvet covers. Or indeed, the collection of cuddly toys which littered his bed. Sandra, you might think, was a woman possessed. By the spirit of someone with really bad taste.

"That woman would use her looks, her sense of humour to get a man," Tony hissed like it was a bad thing. What did he want her to use, we wondered. A stun gun? Chloroform? One of those weighted nets Russell Crowe throws in Gladiator? Whatever, Sandra had got Tony (thanks to hypnosis perhaps) and then after much shenanigans, their affair became public knowledge. Tony and his poor wife decided to emigrate to get away from the threat to their 20-year marriage. Let's hope she takes up with a strapping Australian, eh.

In Eastbourne meanwhile, Margaret proudly sketched an outline of her ideal man (older, self-employed, rich, intelligent and, oh yeah, married) and regaled us with the view that "to expect fidelity in a marriage is unreasonable". This was simply the warm-up to the main event however: the seductive sight of Margaret having a bath. And it was a corner bath too.

Seemingly unaware that having a bath in front of a film crew is not normal behaviour, Margaret soaked and soaped and mused on the nature of her role as a mistress to two married men for some 15 years. She concluded that if it wasn't her providing illicit pleasure, "it would be someone else". Or it would be a handful of chopped liver and a Cindy Crawford exercise video.

In between Sandra and Margaret, there was Claire, who had stolen her mum's Freddie Mercury lookalike boyfriend (no, I have no idea why either) and Joyce, whose husband Tom had left her for Natalie, a woman he met on the internet. "Why pick my husband?" Joyce asked. God knows, the nation chorused in reply, slightly disappointed that "Natalie" hadn't turned out to be a transvestite steel erector from Birmingham.

Manhunters was engaging, entertaining and full of the richness of British life, a glimpse at the frighteningly colourful tapestry of ordinary life. It confirmed that weirdness and eccentricity are the norm, that regular human behaviour often beggars belief, and that some people have no shame. At all. Whatsoever. Nada.

But as a documentary, crafted and considered, Manhunters lacked both focus and direction. It had no point to make other than "Bloody Hell. Check this lot out", and as such, was like an extended dose of Trisha, on which the C&A clad hordes confess to stealing each other's husbands/benefit books/signet rings. You could pretend it contained some social comment regarding the changing role of women in society, the stupidity of men (and women's perennial surprise at their idiocy), or class as a defining factor in the definition of "loose women" as glamorous consorts or cheap slappers, but life is just too short for that. Really, Manhunters was nothing more than a voyeuristic gawk at the carnage that passes for some people's personal lives.

Just what you need on a cold winter's night, it was a steaming hot bowl of Schadenfreude. And proof that Brookside isn't that far-fetched after all.

Tony and his poor wife decided to emigrate to get away from the threat to their 20-year marriage. Let's hope she takes up with a strapping Australian, eh. In Eastbourne meanwhile, Margaret proudly sketched an outline of her ideal man (older, self-employed, rich, intelligent and, oh yeah, married) and regaled us with the view that "to expect fidelity in a marriage is unreasonable". This was simply the warm-up to the main event however: the seductive sight of Margaret having a bath. And it was a corner bath too. Seemingly unaware that having a bath in front of a film crew is not normal behaviour, Margaret soaked and soaped and mused on the nature of her role as a mistress to two married men for some 15 years. She concluded that if it wasn't her providing illicit pleasure, "it would be someone else". Or it would be a handful of chopped liver and a Cindy Crawford exercise video. In between Sandra and Margaret, there was Claire, who had stolen her mum's Freddie Mercury lookalike boyfriend (no, I have no idea why either) and Joyce, whose husband Tom had left her for Natalie, a woman he met on the internet. "Why pick my husband?" Joyce asked. God knows, the nation chorused in reply, slightly disappointed that "Natalie" hadn't turned out to be a transvestite steel erector from Birmingham. Manhunters was engaging, entertaining and full of the richness of British life, a glimpse at the frighteningly colourful tapestry of ordinary life. It confirmed that weirdness and eccentricity are the norm, that regular human behaviour often beggars belief, and that some people have no shame. At all. Whatsoever. Nada. But as a documentary, crafted and considered, Manhunters lacked both focus and direction. It had no point to make other than "Bloody Hell. Check this lot out", and as such, was like an extended dose of Trisha, on which the C&A clad hordes confess to stealing each other's husbands/benefit books/signet rings. You could pretend it contained some social comment regarding the changing role of women in society, the stupidity of men (and women's perennial surprise at their idiocy), or class as a defining factor in the definition of "loose women" as glamorous consorts or cheap slappers, but life is just too short for that. Really, Manhunters was nothing more than a voyeuristic gawk at the carnage that passes for some people's personal lives. Just what you need on a cold winter's night, it was a steaming hot bowl of Schadenfreude. And proof that Brookside isn't that far-fetched after all.

webTitle: EU bank to bail out tube with £1bn loan

fields.headline: EU bank to bail out tube with £1bn loan
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The European Union's in-house bank has agreed to bail out John Prescott's faltering effort to part-privatise the London Underground.
fields.body:
The European Union's in-house bank has agreed to bail out John Prescott's faltering effort to part-privatise the London Underground. It is to lend nearly £1bn to the companies bidding to take over half the tube's business.

A letter from the European Investment Bank to the London Transport chairman, Sir Malcolm Bates, passed to the Guardian, confirms that that the EIB board has approved loans of £300m each to whichever three consortiums win the 30-year contracts to run the tube's track and signalling.

The disclosure of the loans, which amount to more than a third of the £2.5bn the bidders are meant to raise for investment in the cash-starved underground, follows persistent rumours that the bidders were struggling to attract the finance in the private sector.

The leaked letter, signed by the EIB director Thomas Barrett and dated Monday of this week, said the board of the Luxembourg-based bank had "agreed to support this public-private partnership project in view of its strategic importance to the improvement of public transport services in London".

The government's plans for the tube, already more than a year behind schedule, have attracted strong opposition from the London Labour party, trade unions and the London mayor Ken Livingstone, who is due to take over responsibility for the scheme after the private handover has taken place next year. Last night Mr Livingstone said he was stunned by the loan commitment, which is backed by the EU member governments.

"I thought the whole point of the partial privatisation was that the PPP companies would finance investment in the tube, but this shows that the private bids are based on state-backed loans from the EU."

"This is the first I've heard about it," he said, adding that it underlined the need for his new transport commissioner for London, former New York subway boss Robert Kiley, to be given all documents and information on the plans.

An EIB spokesman said he could not comment, but at Mr Prescott's environment and transport department a spokesman said the EIB's interest "shows the strength of our proposals".

Following the government's second defeat in the Lords this week over his plans to sell off half the national air traffic control service, Mr Prescott was yesterday forced to defend his part-privatisation scheme for the tube from both sides in the Commons.

Goaded by the Conservatives' environment spokesman, Archie Norman - who said progress on the London Underground scheme was now "slower than a Doncaster to London express train" - the deputy prime minister insisted that the timetable given to MPs still held.

Although the potential political costs of pressing ahead have risen and public opinion in London hardened against the scheme since the Hatfield rail disaster last month, Mr Prescott shows no signs of backing off.

Last week, the four private consortiums bidding for the first two sections of the tube network to be contracted out submitted their "best and final offers".

The leaked letter from the EIB stated that the EU bank supported three out of the four submissions, while making clear that the basic terms of the loans would be available to whichever consortiums were successful.

The letter was copied to Mike Fuhr - the senior civil servant at the transport department most closely involved with the project - and Sir Steve Robson, second permanent secretary at the Treasury, who played a key role in privatisation programmes by previous Conservative governments and has since worked closely with the former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson, to develop this government's private finance schemes.

webTitle: Patten attacks Sinn Fein over police

fields.headline: Patten attacks Sinn Fein over police
fields.trailText: Chris Patten broke months of silence on his contentious report into policing in Northern Ireland yesterday when he threw his weight behind Peter Mandelson's call for nationalists to abandon their campaign against the Police Act and join the new force.
fields.body:
Chris Patten broke months of silence on his contentious report into policing in Northern Ireland yesterday when he threw his weight behind Peter Mandelson's call for nationalists to abandon their campaign against the Police Act and join the new force.

In a carefully timed intervention, which was welcomed last night by Mr Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, Mr Patten rounded on Sinn Fein for distorting his report: nationalists should "look beyond old political arguments" and "get back to the future".

Appealing to Sinn Fein and the SDLP to take up their seats on a new policing board, Mr Patten wrote in the Belfast Telegraph: "Everyone should put the politics of policing behind them and get on with building the new beginning for depoliticised policing."

His remarks were echoed by a Catholic member of his commission. "It is not leadership to retire into a cul-de-sac," Maurice Hayes said of the SDLP and Sinn Fein, which are threatening to boycott the new police board, to be set up formally next year.

The appeals from the two most prominent members of the policing commission provided a significant boost to the government which is facing a backlash from nationalists who believe that ministers have watered down key elements of the Patten report.

Sinn Fein and the SDLP believe that the police act, which was passed last week, severely weakens the powers of the new police board and the new police ombudsman. Nationalists also believe that Mr Mandelson has failed to live up to Mr Patten's recommendation for a new badge which is "free from association" with Britain or Ireland. The Northern Ireland secretary will rule on the badge if the police board cannot reach agreement.

In his article in last night's Belfast Telegraph, Mr Patten endorsed Mr Mandelson's stance on the badge and swept aside nationalist objections to the act.

"Political parties and other community leaders should now ... start to encourage youth from all parts of Northern Ireland to apply to join the police," he wrote. "The combination of [the ombudsman's office] and the policing board means that Northern Ireland will have, to the best of my knowledge, the most rigorous system of civilian oversight in the world."

Mr Patten hinted that he was not happy with every element of the act, but he reserved his strongest criticism for Sinn Fein. Republicans insist that they cannot accept changes to Mr Patten's recommendations because, they say, the report is a compromise which stretches them as far as they can go.

The European commissioner, who was careful not to name Sinn Fein, said that his report was not a political compromise: "We tested our proposals entirely against policing benchmarks, not political ones.

Mitchel McLaughlin, the Sinn Fein chairman, said: "He certainly is silent on the fact that the report has, in fact, been gutted by the British government."

Mr Mandelson welcomed the article and appealed to nationalists not to boycott the board. "The politics of boycott did not bring us the Good Friday agreement and it won't bring us the new police service that we want."

webTitle: Passnotes: Nancy Sinatra

fields.headline: Passnotes
fields.standfirst: No: 1771 Nancy Sinatra
fields.trailText: No: 1771 Nancy Sinatra
fields.body:
Age: A youthful 59.

Most significant achievement: Need you ask? "These boots were made for walking, dum dum dum de doo." That and many other triumphs.

Like? Like "Youuu only liive twiiiice..."

And? Well, let's see now... Oh yes, she's got a famous dad.

So does Natalie Cole. Who?

Exactly. Anything else? Yes, actually. She's also got a famous boyfriend.

Who's that? Nancy has recently been spotted out and about on the arm of none other than Phil Spector.

Rings a bell. What's his most significant achievement, then? Where do you want me to start? He produced the original versions of Twist and Shout and You've Lost that Loving Feeling, co-wrote Spanish Harlem for BB King, created the "wall of sound" technique of layered orchestration, produced the albums Let It Be and Imagine, invented the girl band, producing Then He Kissed Me and Da Doo Ron Ron for the Crystals and the Ronettes...

Sounds like a match made in back-catalogue heaven. She admires his, he admires her father's. Don't be rude. As it happens, they have a great deal in common.

Such as? Royalties, for a start. Both Nancy and Phil take a rather possessive view of songs that they didn't sing. In June, Phil was forced to pay his ex-wife Ronnie, former lead singer with the Ronettes, royalties of more than $2m, 37 years after signing her up and 13 years after she launched the lawsuit. The Ronettes understandably felt rather short-changed, having received only £9,564 in the duration of their career.

And Nancy? In a gesture worthy of King Lear's daughters, Nancy and her siblings once had their lawyer warn their father against re-recording some of his own songs - since he had given them the rights.

Don't say: Looks like they've lost that loving feeling.

Do say: Ah well, you only live once.

webTitle: Tories retreat on asylum detentions

fields.headline: Tories retreat on asylum detentions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is revising its hard line policy of locking up all asylum applicants in special detention centres after Home Office officials costed the programme at over £2bn in capital costs and £1bn in annual running costs.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is revising its hard line policy of locking up all asylum applicants in special detention centres after Home Office officials costed the programme at over £2bn in capital costs and £1bn in annual running costs.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday strongly disputed the costings, but said: "Nobody in their sane mind would think that if you elect a Conservative government on May 3, we will lock up 30,000 asylum seekers on May 4. It will take time, possibly the whole parliament."

She said a Conservative government would detain in the first instance only asylum seekers from approved "safe' countries. On the basis of the October asylum figures this means she would be trying to lock up in the first instance less than a third of Britain's applicants for asylum.

In April, at the height of the political furore over asylum policy, the Conservative leader William Hague promised: "The Conservative government will detain all new applicants for asylum, whether port applicants or in-country applicants, in reception centres until their cases have been determined." He conceded there "will be a cost in providing the centres", but claimed there would be an overall cut in the then estimated £600m cost of the asylum system. Miss Widdecombe said she had told the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, that her policy wouldroduce savings over a four- year parliament.

Home Office officials, however, have told the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, that the capital costs of a single detention centre with 500 places is £40m. To house 25,000 asylum seekers for six months would require 50 detention centres at a total capital cost of £2bn.

The Home Office have estimated that the running costs of such establishments would be £15m per centre, amounting to £750m in extra revenue costs. There would additional administrative and escort costs taking the total figure to £1bn. These estimates are based on the cost of the government's own Oakington detention centre. The government currently has 900 places in detention centres and wants to increase this to 2,500 places.

Mr Straw yesterday described the Conservative policy reiterated by Miss Widdecombe at the time of her ill fated conference policy speech as "simply inoperable". In her party conference speech, Miss Widdecombe, who also called for zero tolerance on drugs, said: "Our asylum system will be completely overhauled and we will automatically house all new applicants in secure reception centres... If the message goes out to those who simply seek to play our system that in future they will be detained, dealt with speedily and removed, they will cease to come and we will be able to process the genuine applicant more quickly."

Miss Widdecombe rejected figures prepared by the Commons library that the capital costs for just 8,000 asylum seekers might be as high as £1.8bn. She said yesterday such figures wrongly assumed all the detention centres would be newly built, rather than converted existing buildings. Ministers claim suitable buildings are simply not available, but she said her experience as prisons ministers proved to her that sites could be found..

She added the costings also did not take into account a far faster processing of applications. She also claimed her tough new policy would also have a swift deterrent effect. She asserted there was a 40% drop in applications after the Conservative government in 1996 hardened asylum policy by removing welfare benefit.

webTitle: The northern front

fields.headline: The northern front
fields.standfirst:
Labour returning to Blackpool for 2002 conference

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blackpool's fortune tellers on the Golden Mile should have seen it coming - the Labour party yesterday announced it is to return to its northern roots.
fields.body:
Blackpool's fortune tellers on the Golden Mile should have seen it coming - the Labour party yesterday announced it is to return to its northern roots.

The people's party is to hold its 2002 annual conference in the Lancashire resort after a three-year exile on the south coast. Trips up the tower, kiss-me-quick hats and sticks of rock will be back on the agenda after Leisure Parcs, new owners of the Winter Gardens, promised £1m of improvements to the crumbling complex.

Millbank denied the forthcoming election played any part in the decision but Labour, which in 1997 won the town's two seats from the Tories for the first time, had risked a backlash at the polls.

MPs Gordon Marsden and Joan Humble lobbied hard for the conference to "return home" as northern members complained of being forced to travel to Brighton or Bournemouth every year. The Winter Gardens has been cleaned, the roof repaired and disabled access improved after Labour blamed its poor condition for the original decision to stay away.

Labour started visiting Blackpool in 1927 and the Empress Ballroom in the Winter Gardens witnessed some epic party battles. Blackpool beat off competition from Birmingham, Cardiff and Glasgow as well as Brighton and Bournemouth to recapture a conference worth upwards of £10m. George Bancroft, Blackpool council leader, said: "We are committed to working together to deliver all the resources required for a modern political conference."

webTitle: Sketch: Macho man batters the language into submission

fields.headline: Macho man batters the language into submission
fields.trailText: It has happened two days in a row now: John Prescott has started making sense. I don't know why. Possibly his Mr Macho Man assault on the French environment minister cleared a blockage in his brain, in the way you can sometimes make a TV work by kicking it.
fields.body:
It has happened two days in a row now: John Prescott has started making sense. I don't know why. Possibly his Mr Macho Man assault on the French environment minister cleared a blockage in his brain, in the way you can sometimes make a TV work by kicking it.

Or perhaps he has had a Hansard computer chip in serted in his brain. This works like those primitive translation programmes, using binary technology to turn his thoughts into the words needed to express them. It is not perfect yet, but already it has led to a huge improvement. Take this, which is just part of an answer he gave when asked by a Labour MP why the government had no plans to renationalise the railways:

"Again, I can confirm of course about the length of journeys but I explained why it's necessary to have a thorough investigation of our Railtrack and the investment to ensure that we get safe railway lines. Hopefully by the beginning, by the end of this year, probably the beginning of next, we should have done that. You are well aware of the fact that this party agreed at the first stages not to renationalise rail, the argument being which I have used and deployed in this House that the £6bn compensation wasn't the right way of using public resources of this kind and even to consider the possibility now for another two years' negotiations in this house, the process of renationalisation bill is not the first priority that people want ..."

See what I mean? It's not the way anyone you know, or anyone you've ever met, would talk. But it does make sense. Renationalisation would cost too much and would take too much time.

By my calculations, the use of this computer chip, even in the experimental stage, will save enough money in the Hansard team, which until now has had to turn Mr Prescott's speech into English by hand, to re-lay 170 miles of track in time for Christmas.

We also enjoyed what the late Alan Clark would have called a "piccolo" triumph for a junior minister, Keith Hill. Mr Hill is an amiable fellow with an ever so faintly camp manner, and a magnificent set of gnashers. As in the works of the old masters, his teeth follow you round the room.

Ian Stewart, the Labour MP for Eccles, had asked him a nice easy question about highway maintenance and street lighting.

Mr Hill kicked into his So Graham Norton mode. "The last Conservative government left our local roads in the worst! state! of repair, since! records! first began! he emoted.

"To the people of Eccles and Salford, I say, the end of their potholes is in sight!" he squeaked, to loud and delighted cheers from his Labour colleagues. "And in due course they will be able to see! their well maintained! roads!"

In Essex, he said, the news was even better. He quoted a Tory councillor, Ron Williams, as calling the extra spending "a major boost for Essex. This is really good news. We must now look carefully to see how we can invest this large sum to achieve the greatest benefit.

"This is not the knee-jerk response of Tory central office," Mr Hill went on, "but the real honesty of councillor Ron Williams. God bless him!"

Jonathan Sayeed, a Bristol Tory, said grumpily that he was grateful to the minister "for repeating one of his Labour stooge's press releases."

"But he's a Tory, a Tory!" yelled the Labour benches.

"He may call himself a Tory," said Mr Sayeed, darkly, meaning we know not what. But it was too late. Mr Hill's teeth flashed their message of triumph all around the chamber.
