You are well aware of the fact that this party agreed at the first stages not to renationalise rail, the argument being which I have used and deployed in this House that the £6bn compensation wasn't the right way of using public resources of this kind and even to consider the possibility now for another two years' negotiations in this house, the process of renationalisation bill is not the first priority that people want ..." See what I mean? It's not the way anyone you know, or anyone you've ever met, would talk. But it does make sense. Renationalisation would cost too much and would take too much time. By my calculations, the use of this computer chip, even in the experimental stage, will save enough money in the Hansard team, which until now has had to turn Mr Prescott's speech into English by hand, to re-lay 170 miles of track in time for Christmas. We also enjoyed what the late Alan Clark would have called a "piccolo" triumph for a junior minister, Keith Hill. Mr Hill is an amiable fellow with an ever so faintly camp manner, and a magnificent set of gnashers. As in the works of the old masters, his teeth follow you round the room. Ian Stewart, the Labour MP for Eccles, had asked him a nice easy question about highway maintenance and street lighting. Mr Hill kicked into his So Graham Norton mode. "The last Conservative government left our local roads in the worst! state! of repair, since! records! first began! he emoted. "To the people of Eccles and Salford, I say, the end of their potholes is in sight!" he squeaked, to loud and delighted cheers from his Labour colleagues. "And in due course they will be able to see! their well maintained! roads!" In Essex, he said, the news was even better. He quoted a Tory councillor, Ron Williams, as calling the extra spending "a major boost for Essex. This is really good news. We must now look carefully to see how we can invest this large sum to achieve the greatest benefit. "This is not the knee-jerk response of Tory central office," Mr Hill went on, "but the real honesty of councillor Ron Williams. God bless him!" Jonathan Sayeed, a Bristol Tory, said grumpily that he was grateful to the minister "for repeating one of his Labour stooge's press releases." "But he's a Tory, a Tory!" yelled the Labour benches. "He may call himself a Tory," said Mr Sayeed, darkly, meaning we know not what. But it was too late. Mr Hill's teeth flashed their message of triumph all around the chamber.

webTitle: Comment: The right is wrong

fields.headline: The right is wrong
fields.standfirst:
Republicans and Tories share the same delusion: that they are the natural party of government

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Republicans and Tories share the same delusion: that they are the natural party of government
fields.body:
By now both Tony Blair and William Hague had hoped to welcome the president-elect as a friend and omen of good fortune. Mr Blair would love to have hosted an early Downing Street summit with President-elect Gore, where the two might have toasted yet another victory for the centre-left. Mr Hague would happily have trotted over to Austin to join the queue of foreign dignitaries introducing themselves to President-elect Bush - gently pointing Britain out on the map, just to prevent any confusion. Both would have hailed an American triumph as a good-luck charm for their own electoral contest next spring.

But they, along with the rest of the world, have been denied so clear a sign. They have not been able to draw the instant lessons from America, or to open up the transatlantic trade in ideas, that usually follows a US election. Instead Britain's politicians have, like the American electorate, been in a state of suspended animation for three weeks - all analysis on hold.

Yet there is much to look at and much to learn. For this 22-day post-election battle in America has been at least as revealing as the 18-month election contest which preceded it. The paralysis has laid bare an ugly fact about the American right - one eerily echoed by conservatism's lead forces here in Britain. It is a feature that the left, both here and in America, ignores at its peril.

Throughout, the Republicans have behaved not as if they and the Democrats were locked in a uniquely close race - but as if their opponents were bafflingly and selfishly refusing to recognise a clear defeat. The constant calls on Gore to concede, to bow out gracefully, would make sense if the Democrat had transparently won fewer votes than Bush. But he didn't: he won 323,000 more votes nationally and may well have won more in Florida, the kingmaker state under America's electoral college system.

Yet since the morning after the election night before, Bush and his surrogates - most notably the silkily scary former secretary of state, James Baker - have acted as if Gore was a sore loser and a constitutional wrecker, refusing to bow to the democratic will. As if that will has ever been clear.

So Republicans repeat that there has been a count, a recount and a re-recount - and that Bush has been the winner each time. They choose not to mention that even on the votes that have been counted (and that's not all of them) Bush's margin has been wildly different - and smaller - with each total, proving that the picture is not at all clear and needs sorting out.

There is an explanation for this tone, and for the constant claims that Gore is trying to "steal" the election, when all he asks for is a full and accurate count which he may well lose. It is that, fundamentally, Republicans don't believe that a Democrat like Gore belongs in power - no matter how many votes he gets.

That should be a shocking statement to make about a democracy, yet it is an accurate description of a wide vein in Republican thinking. The assumption, all too visible on the faces of Baker, Bush and would-be vice president and "transition" boss, Dick Cheney, is that they are Republicans and should therefore run the country - and who the hell is this man Gore to hold them up?

That is why the American right has resorted to the tactics of a virtual coup d'etat to install its candidate - and restore what it regards as the rightful order of things. It sent in a baying mob to surround the vote-counting room in Miami-Dade county last week - shouting and pounding away until the local officials were so intimidated they abandoned their recount only a fifth of the way through. It has welcomed an incomplete vote certified by a Florida official who just happens to be the co-chair of the Bush campaign in the state - the Cruella de Ville of Republican politics, Katherine Harris - and who deliberately excluded updated figures which boosted Gore. Nor does it mention that the result was formally sealed by Florida's governor, Bush's brother Jeb. If this was how Democrats won an election, Republicans would denounce it as a travesty - but because it restores the natural order of politics, by putting them back in the White House, they can't imagine how anyone could question it.

Those who dare are instantly condemned as illegitimate. When a Florida court found in Bush's favour, it was a triumph for the rule of law. But when the supreme court overturned that decision and ruled against Bush, the justices were trashed as a bunch of Democrat appointees who could not be trusted.

Here is the alarming echo for Britain. Last week saw a vicious attack on Britain's top soldier, Charles Guthrie, the chief of the defence staff, in the Daily Mail. The paper condemned him for failing to block Tony Blair's plan to commit 12,500 British troops to a future European rapid reaction force, using the most lurid language of partisan hostility - even accusing the general of harbouring a schoolboy's homoerotic crush on the PM.

For the Mail and its backers on the Tory right, Guthrie had become a legitimate political target because he serves under and had failed to thwart a Labour government. Blair rightly seized on the assault, making it the theme of last week's Cabinet meeting, because it revealed more than an objection to Labour's defence policy. It was proof, said the PM, that the rightwing simply do not accept the legitimacy of his administration or of anyone who serves it. "For them it is an affront and an outrage that there is a Labour government at all," says one Downing Street aide.

Accordingly, the right will not only condemn those, like Guthrie, who work for a Labour administration, but support any attempt to unseat it: hence Mr Hague's praise for September's fuel protesters as "fine, upstanding citizens". In this, Britain's Conservatives are entirely in step with their American cousins.

For the presumption on both the British and US right is that they represent not just the natural party but the natural order of government - and that any challenge to that dominance, no matter how democratic, is fundamen tally illegitimate. The occasional exception can be made, when the right screws up or disgraces itself: Watergate in America, sleaze here. An occasional charismatic figure of the left might slip through the net - a Kennedy or a Clinton, once a generation - but before too long the right chaps will be back in.

Bill Clinton suffered from this for eight years, besieged by a Republican right that flatly refused to accept him as president: a refusal which culminated in the impeachment effort of 1998-9. Gore is grappling with that same arrogance of presumed power right now - and so, in a quieter, less obvious way, is Mr Blair. The left needs to know this about its adversaries, on both sides of the Atlantic. But so does everyone else. For a refusal to accept the choice of the democratic majority is a refusal to accept democracy itself.

jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

webTitle: Dutch MPs vote to legalise mercy killings

fields.headline: Dutch MPs vote to legalise mercy killings
fields.trailText: The Netherlands, where the authorities have for decades turned a blind eye to euthanasia, yesterday became the first country to legalise it.
fields.body:
The Netherlands, where the authorities have for decades turned a blind eye to euthanasia, yesterday became the first country to legalise it.

In a historic vote, the lower house of parliament in the Hague approved by 104 to 40 a bill backed by most Dutch doctors that will, its supporters say, put the country at the forefront of patients' rights.

"Doctors should not be treated as criminals. This will create security for doctors and patients alike," said the health minister, Els Borst, who drafted the bill. "Something as serious as ending one's life deserves openness."

But religious and pro-life groups were hostile, saying the law was open to abuse. Some even drew parallels with Nazi Germany. "The same line of reasoning is being used as in Germany in 1935...Your life is no longer safe," said Bert Dorenbos of Scream for Life. "If doctors are not hesitating to kill people, they will not hesitate to withdraw treatment from people they do not like."

Rita Marker, the head of another anti-euthanasia group, said the law would "tell people that if it's legal, it's right - what is a crime now will be transformed into a medical treatment".

The Catholic church, too, was quick to criticise the move. "It is a sad record for the Netherlands to become the first to want to approve a law that goes against human dignity," said the Vatican's spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls. "We are faced with a law of the state which opposes the natural law of human conscience."

Following a series of court rulings and government directives since the 1970s, including a carefully worded "codification" of mercy killing adopted in 1993, Dutch doctors already had virtual immunity from prosecution in euthanasia cases, provided they followed strict guidelines.

But the criminal code had never been amended, theoretically allowing them to be charged with murder. Under the new bill, the public prosecutor's office will not review euthanasia cases unless misconduct is suspected.

"This vote simply takes euthanasia out of the criminal arena," said a justice ministry spokesman. "Providing the regulations have all been met, there can be no threat of criminal charges."

While euthanasia is tolerated on certain conditions in several countries including Switzerland, Colombia and Belgium, none has yet sought to legalise it.

The US state of Oregon legalised medically assisted suicide - in which the doctor gives the patient the lethal drugs, but does not administer them - in 1994, and the Northern Territory in Australia followed in 1996, only to repeal the law a year later.

The Dutch bill, backed by all three ruling coalition parties, is set to to become law in 2001. It sets much the same conditions as those laid down in 1993: patients must be in continuous, unbearable and incurable suffering, be aware of medical options and have sought a second professional opinion.

The request to die must be made voluntarily, independently, persistently and only after careful consideration by a patient judged to be of sound mind. The doctor is not supposed to suggest euthanasia, and the patient's life must be ended in a medically appropriate manner.

The law also allows a patient to make a prior written request for euthanasia, giving doctors the right to use their own discretion when patients become too ill physically or mentally to decide for themselves.

But a highly controversial clause that would have allowed children as young as 12 to demand a mercy killing even if their parents disagreed was dropped earlier this year. Children between the ages of 12 and 16 will be able to ask for help to die, but only with parental consent.

According to new data from the health and justice ministries, Dutch doctors helped 2,216 patients, mostly with cancer, to die in 1999 through active euthanasia or assisted suicide. The actual numbers, however, are thought to be higher, as some experts claim that 60% go unreported.

webTitle: Leader: The limits of complementary treatment

fields.headline: Hit and miss medicine
fields.standfirst: The limits of complementary treatment
fields.trailText: Somebody needed to say it. A distinguished group of medics on the Lords select committee on science and technology obliged yesterday. A one-year study of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) has produced a blunt conclusion.
fields.body:
Somebody needed to say it. A distinguished group of medics on the Lords select committee on science and technology obliged yesterday. A one-year study of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) has produced a blunt conclusion. Most CAM training courses involve unacceptable variations in content, depth and duration; the regulation of the multiplying number of different specialties is fragmented and inadequate; and research on their effectiveness is virtually non-existent. But before sceptics respond with the Mandy Rice Davies reply ("they would, wouldn't they"), yesterday's report is not a self-serving, protectionist defence of modern medicine. Far from wanting to suppress complementary and alternative therapies, the medics want to bring them under the National Health Service umbrella, but only where they can demonstrate their effectiveness. The committee rightly concludes that the public needs much better independent guidance on CAM thera pies, and recommends the NHS should be given this responsibility. It calls for more government funding for CAM research, noting the success of the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine in the US.

CAM therapists - now, at 50,000, outnumbering GPs by 10,000 - will rightly note that only 20% of modern medicine is evidence-based. But this proportion is growing exponentially. Modern medicines ensure that - 50% were unknown six years ago. A rational society should pursue evidence-based medicine, resisting populist calls for a retreat from science. The committee produces three useful categories: the "big five" (acupuncture, chiropractic, herbal medicine, homeopathy, and osteopathy), which could qualify now for NHS inclusion; a group of complementary rather than alternative therapies giving comfort, not cures; and a third category with no evidence of effectiveness. It is time for complementary medicine to respond.

webTitle: Ancram steps in as Eurosceptics try to unseat MP

fields.headline: Ancram steps in as Eurosceptics try to unseat MP
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservative leadership has weighed in to try and rescue a pro-European ex-minister who had won reselection to fight the coming election, only to face an emergency meeting to remove him for "heresy" organised by hardline Eurosceptics.
fields.body:
The Conservative leadership has weighed in to try and rescue a pro-European ex-minister who had won reselection to fight the coming election, only to face an emergency meeting to remove him for "heresy" organised by hardline Eurosceptics.

Ian Taylor, MP for Esher and Walton, who resigned from William Hague's frontbench team over its increasing hostility to Europe, was given a letter of support from his party chairman, Michael Ancram, ahead of Monday's meeting.

The MP, first elected in 1987, has already won the backing of rightwing colleagues, including prominent Eurosceptics. Sir Teddy Taylor, Richard Shepherd, Michael Howard and even Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, fear that they could be similarly ousted if policy fashions change.

The Esher and Walton Conservatives, activists in a prosperous area in suburban Surrey, are holding an extraordinary general meeting on Monday to decide whether to deselect Mr Taylor, who survived an earlier attempt to oust him last spring - as did Kenneth Clarke and David Curry, fellow Euro-refuseniks.

Activists on the right viewed his opinions as "tantamount to heresy" and organised the necessary 50 names to trigger Monday's meeting. If they vote against the MP there would be a full meeting of all 1,400 local supporters, or a postal ballot if the MP prefers.

In a firmly worded letter last night to the constituency chairman, John Burns, Mr Ancram said that challenging the position of a MP because of his opinions had "never been a part of our tradition". Senior party officials had originally advised Esher's executive to be "neutral" - only to realise that the advice was being interpreted as the green light to get rid of their unfashionably outspoken MP, contrary to William Hague's warning against ideological purges.

Last night Conservative central office said the Ancram letter was intended to send a clear signal to grassroots activists that the leadership would not tolerate "witch hunts" against pro-European MPs. In his letter, Mr Ancram said: "The Conservative party is a broad church encouraging, at any given time, many shades of opinion and we have always taken pride in that breadth of view and our ability to build upon it."

Mr Taylor said last night that a protracted battle over the Christmas and new year would "obviously be damaging for the party locally and nationally. I hope the meeting will serve to clear it up. My views on Europe have not changed, but William Hague and Michael Ancram have made clear that a party should gain strength from diversity rather than regard it, as one constituent said, as heresy."

A leaked copy of Conservative party notes on candidates last night underlined concerns at the top over pro-Europeans that constituencies are "screening out applicants for specific policy reasons". The list also disclosed concern that interest groups are exerting "unfair pressure" in selections.

Sean Woodward, the Tory turned Labour MP, said last night: "Michael Ancram's intervention to keep Ian Taylor in the Commons smacks of tokenism. It is only when Ian Taylor's selection battle received national coverage that the Tory high command weighed in."

My views on Europe have not changed, but William Hague and Michael Ancram have made clear that a party should gain strength from diversity rather than regard it, as one constituent said, as heresy." A leaked copy of Conservative party notes on candidates last night underlined concerns at the top over pro-Europeans that constituencies are "screening out applicants for specific policy reasons". The list also disclosed concern that interest groups are exerting "unfair pressure" in selections. Sean Woodward, the Tory turned Labour MP, said last night: "Michael Ancram's intervention to keep Ian Taylor in the Commons smacks of tokenism. It is only when Ian Taylor's selection battle received national coverage that the Tory high command weighed in."

webTitle: Watchdog admits ignorance of incinerator health risks

fields.headline: Watchdog admits ignorance of incinerator health risks
fields.trailText: The environment agency admitted yesterday to MPs that it had no idea how dangerous Britain's new generation of incinerators will be to public health.
fields.body:
The environment agency admitted yesterday to MPs that it had no idea how dangerous Britain's new generation of incinerators will be to public health.

Paul Leinster, director of environment protection at the agency, told the Commons environment sub-committee investigating waste strategy that the evaluation of dangers of air pollution to public health "were at an early stage".

The admission came after pressure from Hilary Benn, Labour MP for Leeds Central, and Crispin Blunt, Conservative MP for Reigate. It comes as the Treasury confirmed to MPs that at least eight new in cinerators will be built as part of new schemes approved under the government's private finance initiative.

The agency told MPs that a private consultancy, Entech, employed by them had made a major error on the number of the number of deaths and hospital admissions that would be caused by emissions from incinerators, and figures of 88 deaths and 168 hospital admissions every year were not accurate. No new figures are available at the moment.

Mr Leinster told Mr Blunt: "We are really at only an early stage at finding out how public health will be affected by the building of incinerators."

Earlier Lord Cranbrook, the chairman of Entrust, defended the private regulatory body which monitors £350mof environmental grants, which had been at the centre of an investigation by the Guardian earlier this year.

The body checks the probity of the cash which is donated by waste companies in lieu of paying 20% of the new landfill tax. Lord Cranbrook said the Guardian's allegations that Entrust was presiding over a flawed initiative dominated by the waste industry and to the benefit of some local councils were "unfounded".

He said that the paper's investigation had made the body "sharpen up its procedures - but it also proved that its system worked". He said that the Guardian had not uncovered anything that breached regulations.

webTitle: Yesterday

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Poll of the day
fields.body:
Poll of the day

Despite the acres of outraged newsprint deployed in the eurosceptic press against the European rapid reaction force, the great British public seems to have remained largely unmoved. A poll for the ITN Powerhouse programme yesterday found 68% of voters support military co-operation with Europe.

Gem of the day

Tory party chairman Michael Ancram's family certainly didn't shop at Ratners. Yesterday they offered up a family heirloom, a jewel encrusted 200-year-old necklace containing a gem from Catherine the Great, for auction but it failed to reach its reserve price. A snip at £600,000.

Quote of the day

Weighty issues occupying London's mayor Ken Livingstone down at his ad hoc headquarters in Romney House. Furniture is falling apart, rather like the Underground. "It is unbearable," he moaned after another arm fell off during a meeting. "These chairs are the worst I have ever had."

Today

Commons: PM's questions. Disqualifications bill, political parties, elections and referendums bill, timetable motion, Lords amendments. Lords: Debate on the Millennium Dome. Insolvency bill, Commons amendments.

webTitle: Comment: Scots Guards are Britain's favourite killers

fields.headline: The killers we like
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: I have been weighing up possible reasons for the hype around the European army, or European Knee-Jerk Reaction Force, call it what you will. For a while, I toyed with the fact that the world has of late been a relatively safe place to live. America has effectively been without a real president, so the prospects for world peace were looking quite rosy.
fields.body:
I have been weighing up possible reasons for the hype around the European army, or European Knee-Jerk Reaction Force, call it what you will. For a while, I toyed with the fact that the world has of late been a relatively safe place to live. America has effectively been without a real president, so the prospects for world peace were looking quite rosy.

With no chief, how was Europe to have a war? What if we just had to sit on our hands indefinitely? From whom would our orders come? Could it be that a trade association run by bankers would adopt a military strategy of its own?

Ken Clarke was wheeled out to champion the idea of the single currency having an armed wing. He posited that the Kosovo war hadn't been fought properly because the Pentagon favoured bombing from a great height and not running around in mud with fixed bayonets like good Tommies. He failed to explain how infantrymen would have taken out Serbia's infrastructure, or adequately terrorised its civilian population.

In the bad old days of Vietnam, General Wesley Clarke was sent to tour Britain justifying the My Lai massacre, in which GIs raped and murdered hundreds of women and children. The advantage of killing civilians by air is that it's nothing personal. No harm is meant. In fact, they are not even people really, just unavoidable casualties, collateral damage, propaganda tools of the regime and so on.

And if invading soldiers took wrecking balls to hospitals and schools, broke into chemical works and spread toxins all over the country, it would appear to be some brutal scorched earth policy. Moreover, lots of soldiers would die. No one who advocated bloody hand-to-hand humanitarianism last year gave us any indication of how many military or civilian personnel they would be thinking of expending in such an exercise.

I suppose some European countries might have been prepared to undertake this adventure if Washington had not been running the show. If it had gone pear-shaped, the US would have sent in the bombers to flatten Belgrade. Anything done by a Euro army will ultimately have to be sanctioned by the American president, with Europeans knowing that he will probably bail them out in the end. So I doubt whether the EU is going to try to start a war in the next few days.

No, the plan for more war is a long-term one, and the world will have a leader again before long. So perhaps there is a connection between last week's rush for another tier of militarism and the fact that the army board finally reached its decision not to sack the two murderers James Fisher and Mark Wright. Two men prepared to shoot an unarmed civilian in the back will be just the sort of chaps we'll need if we're going to be going over the top with less American air cover.

These two Scots Guards are Britain's favourite killers, even more so than the Krays. Reggie and Ronnie only did it to their own and their appeal is confined to actors and cockneys. Jim and Mark are loved by Martin Bell, Ludovic Kennedy and a swath of Scottish people of the Orange persuasion. The army board that has found them fit for duty includes armed forces minister John Spellar and General Sir Michael Jackson, hero of Kosovo and a man who was an adjutant on duty when the Paras committed mass murder in Derry in January 1972.

Unusually for British soldiers, Wright and Fisher were actually arrested and convicted of murder. If they had been charged with possession of cannabis, or even if they had killed a Celtic supporter outside a pub while on leave, they would in all likelihood have been kicked out of the army, but a uniform confers diplomatic immunity. After all, the atrocities committed against Irish people these past 30-odd years have been carried out in the name of peacekeeping - the very same role envisaged for the devolved European regiment.

But one should not imagine that the only uniformed keepers of the peace involved in controversy are the ones who kill the Irish. Last week, we also heard that no police officers would be prosecuted for their involvement in the "restraint" of Roger Sylvester, because prosecutors found insufficient evidence.

"Restraining" appears to be the way in which black people meet their deaths in police custody. Another such man, Christopher Alder, was finally laid to rest on Saturday. The officers who stood around him as he lay dying are charged with "wilful misconduct in public office", which is one way of putting it. Christopher had been a paratrooper at one time, but never killed any civilians. Perhaps if he had the state might have taken more care of him .

webTitle: Kouchner to quit UN post in Kosovo in three weeks

fields.headline: Kouchner to quit UN post in Kosovo in three weeks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The head of the UN mission in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, has told UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, that he plans to leave his job in less than three weeks, western diplomatic sources in New York say.
fields.body:
The head of the UN mission in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, has told UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, that he plans to leave his job in less than three weeks, western diplomatic sources in New York say.

Dr Kouchner passed the message to Mr Annan on Monday through the undersecretary general in charge of peace-keeping, Jean-Marie Guehenno, according to a report by a diplomatic mission to the UN.

It said his resignation was effective from December 15.

Dr Kouchner, who had told colleagues that he planned to leave by Christmas, previously said that he would stay until a replacement was found.

He told journalists earlier this month that he had already told Mr Annan of his wish to leave Kosovo. "I always said I will be free, but I don't want to resign or corner anyone."

The spokeswoman for the UN mission in Kosovo, Claire Trevena, maintained that Dr Kouchner did not yet know when he was going.

"He feels after the [recent municipal] elections was a good stage to talk about leaving. He has said he won't go until his successor is named."

Dr Kouchner's departure may come as a disappointment to the province's majority Albanian population.

In recent weeks he has argued strenuously in the face of international opposition that the municipal elections in October should be followed by elections for a provincial government next spring.

Speculation about a successor has been rife for months. The former Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown was seen as strong possibility, but UN aides say that, opposed by the US, he has out himself out of the running.

webTitle: TV: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Death In Venice | Stormy Monday | Best Laid Plans | Best Laid Plans | He Got Game
fields.body:
Death In Venice (Luchino Visconti, 1971) 9pm, TCM

One of the late Dirk Bogarde's finest hours: a meticulous and moving study of a dying (Gustav Mahler-like) German composer haunted by the angelic beauty of a young Polish boy. It is a glimpse of sunlight and life before a lonely death in Visconti's stately, sombre version of the Thomas Mann novel.

Stormy Monday (Mike Figgis, 1987) 10pm, FilmFour

Gritty Newcastle-set thriller with Sting (pictured) as a passable Geordie hardman-turned-clubowner trying to keep oily American mobster Tommy Lee Jones off his patch. Sean Bean and Melanie Griffith make a refreshing pair caught up in the inevitable rough stuff. Mean and moody, with a little northern charm and an atmospheric, bluesy soundtrack.

Best Laid Plans (Mike Barker, 1999) 10pm, Sky MovieMax

Reese Witherspoon is just slightly too cheerleader-wholesome for this feature, which can't decide whether it's a violent thriller, a sick slacker comedy or a love story. She stars alongside Alessandro Nivola, as Nick, one of the world's unluckiest men, whose life seems to be spiralling into freefall. Lots of artfully arranged flashbacks and mascara later, it's getting worse. The tricksy close-up camera angles and trendy-literate script try hard but ultimately the pieces of the puzzle are just too mismatched.

He Got Game (Spike Lee, 1998) 12.35am, Sky Premier

Lee's sporting drama has Denzel Washington as Jake, a convict given one week's parole in order to sign up his basketball-star son, Jesus (NBA player Ray Allen) for the state governor's favourite college team. Given that Jake is in jail for the killing of Jesus's mother, this is never going to be easy, but his freedom depends on it. The typically spiky father-son relationship is played out with conviction, and while it's no Hoop Dreams, Lee scores points in his depiction of the flashy sport's seamy side.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Tamar Valley
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
For weeks land has shed water and earth, with occasional dry spells of azure and sun, starry nights and rolls of early mist cut short by a succession of storms. Seasonal jobs like fencing are held back and winter cereals remain unplanted; already purchased seed corn is only viable if sown by February. Maize is windblown and withered and, although cobs hang on, forage harvesters would be mired in ruts and mud. Cattle are indoors and sheep pastures are soggy hoof prints filled with water, trodden pathways turn into rivulets under each downpour.

Downhill, below Boetheric, mossy oak and holly woods drip long after the rain ceases; underlying ivy, ferns and leaf mould soak up the wetness, reducing the rate of run-off. The adjoining steep market gardens overlooking the river are now dominated by eucalyptus bushes and groves of black-stemmed, variegated pittisporum, polythene tunnels protecting next year's strawberries and budding silvery-grey pinks.

In the afternoon gloom, high tide washes over saltings by South Ward under Braunder Wood, lapping over Dung Quay, ponding back Cotehele's mill stream and glinting in the fringe of ginger reeds. Low-lying meadows on Etheric Marsh are protected by an embankment but, after 150 years, there are plans to breach it, allowing salt and fresh water to flood back in. After discussions with the Environment Agency and English Nature and a study by Newcastle University, the National Trust proposes to recreate expansive mud flats and, eventually, reed beds on Hayemarsh, perhaps alleviating future floods.

webTitle: Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Connect | Half Minute Melodies
fields.body:
Radio 4 broadcasts a new four-part series on how science and technology affect our everyday lives. The first episode of Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) finds Quentin Cooper exploring the mysteries of perfume. The scent industry turns over some £8,500 million a year worldwide, so it's hardly surprising that everyone wants to get in on the act. Competition is fierce among major players and each year hundreds of dedicated scientists try to concoct up to 100 new perfumes.

The late Johnny Johnston was king of the Half Minute Melodies (11.30pm, Radio 4) which signal your favourite programmes. He wrote more than 4,000 such musical nudges, getting them to buzz insidiously through your head years after you'd forgotten what they signified. Chris Serle talks to some of his successors about the art of conveying a memorable message with a signature tune. Barrington Pheloung had it easy: Morse's name was already coded for him.

webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Well, in the week that Robert Downey Jr fell off the wagon in style with his Palm Beach arrest for possession of cocaine and metamphetamine, another devout recidivist bit the dust on Monday night as rapper Ol' Dirty Bastard found himself arrested six weeks after absconding from a court-ordered stint in rehab.

The original sentence of an indefinite stay in New York's Impact House came after ODB (real name Russel Jones) violated his 1999 probation for various drugs offences; while taking the 12 steps, he was also to be tried on charges of crack possession and, oddly, illegally wearing a bulletproof vest.

Ironically, his conclusive brush with the law came just days after the then-fugitive made a surprise appearance with his Wu-Tang Clan compadres at a concert at New York's Hammerstein Ballroom last Tuesday. Greeted with deafening applause and disguised in a bulky parka and snow hat, Jones defiantly told the crowd that "the cops is after me" but that "I'm here to tell you, they can't keep me down" - a sentiment rendered somewhat outdated by his subsequent arrest in a Philadephia fast-food restaurant six nights later.

Meanwhile, the ever-troubled Eminem has been offered a plea bargain in his impending Michigan trial for carrying a concealed firearm and assault with a deadly weapon, stemming from the affray which followed spouse Kim Mathers and one John Guerra allegedly being seen kissing in a nightclub car park.

Now, however, Macomb County prosecutor Carl Marlinga has announced that, should the hip-hop poster-boy plead guilty to one charge when he appears in court a week Friday, the remaining count will be dropped. Not, it must be said, that the carrot-on-a-stick is all that tempting; even if he does enter a guilty plea, there's still a potential 17 year sentence waiting at the end of proceedings...

webTitle: Arts: Lyn Gardner  meets  Stephen Jeffreys

fields.headline: Pact with the devil
fields.standfirst: Stephen Jeffreys tells  Lyn Gardner  why Robert Johnson, father of the blues and a man with a few dark secrets, was the perfect subject for his new play about life, death - and cotton-picking
fields.trailText: Stephen Jeffreys tells Lyn Gardner why Robert Johnson, father of the blues and a man with a few dark secrets, was the perfect subject for his new play about life, death - and cotton-picking.
fields.body:
Legend has it that the blues guitarist Robert Johnson couldn't play a lick until he met the devil at a crossroads one night and sold him his soul. It was not a good bargain. Johnson was dead at 37, poisoned in 1938 by the jealous husband of one of his lovers. But his reputation lives on - he is still regarded as one of the world's greatest ever blues musicians.

The story of Johnson is the basis of Stephen Jeffreys's latest play, I Just Stopped By To See the Man, which previews at the Royal Court, London, this week in a production by Richard Wilson. At 64, Wilson is very far from the grave, and consolidating his reputation as a major director of new plays.

In Jeffreys's play, set in a shotgun house (so called because you could shoot from the porch right through to the yard door in a straight line) in the Mississippi Delta in 1975, Johnson is transformed into the character of Jesse Davidson, and history, into fiction.

Jesse is a blues player who has gained mythical status after his disappearance some years previously. In fact he is alive and living with his daughter, a college-educated black activist who has her own reasons for being holed up in a dirt-poor shack. Tensions are already running high, but the the arrival of Carl, a white English rock star who has long been on Jesse's trail, leads to an explosive situation.

The amiable Jeffreys, 50, who with his shaggy halo of hair looks as if he has just stepped out of the 1970s himself, has long been intrigued by the blues. The fascination dates from a Juke Box Jury episode in the 1960s when a panel voted a record by Howlin' Wolf a complete miss. "I was suddenly aware that there was this huge tradition of guys who had seen a lot, and had something to sing about. I wanted to know more."

One of the questions raised in I Just Stopped By To See the Man is why kids from Surrey - such as Mick Jagger - became obsessed by the music that began in the cotton fields, while the US's young blacks rejected it in favour of soul and Motown. In the play Jesse's daughter sees the blues as victim music and is surprised that Carl should revere it.

Jeffreys argues that American blacks saw the blues as an embarrassment and a reminder that they were once poor, while soul music was perceived as a stepping stone into the middle class. Meanwhile white British kids were using the blues to make their own statements: "In 1950s and 1960s Britain pop music was anaemic. Liking the blues was like being a member of a secret society. It was outlaw music, a way out from the nine-to-five grind of your parent's generation."

Jeffreys appreciates the irony that the music that had its roots in the sweated labour of 14-hour days in the cotton fields was appropriated by people determined never to do a traditional day's work in their lives. "It was guys like Robert Johnson who set the agenda for pop music in the 20th century. But sometimes it's hard to hear their music afresh because we hear its echoes every day in modern rock music."

It is even harder to separate the music and the myths. I Just Stopped By To See the Man is set at a pivotal moment of political transition when the US pulled out of Vietnam, the black power movement became institutionalised and people lost faith in the liberal ideals that had emerged during the 1960s. But it is likely to take its resonance as much from the way it taps into our subconscious knowledge of age-old stories and myth as it does from our political hindsight. On the surface it may be a naturalistic three-hander, but Jeffreys's play is epic in intent and in the way it plays with ideas of life and death. The Orpheus story - in which the dead musician gets a chance to come back to life - is entwined with ideas of the Faustian bargain.

Jeffreys has his own theories about why the blues is so closely associated with this myth and was often known as "the devil's music". "These musicians were often guys with lots of sexual allure. But they travelled around on their own a lot and were vulnerable. Not least from jealous husbands. To put it about that you have a pact with the devil might give you a bit of protection. In the same way, singers of a later era associated themselves with the mafia to get the protection they needed."

Jeffreys himself is not immune from being mythologised. Besides having 25 plays produced at top theatres such as the Royal Court and Hampstead, and a winning a clutch of best-play awards, Jeffreys has written a fine, but as yet unproduced screenplay. The Libertine, based on his Royal Court play about the 17th-century pornographer and poet the Earl of Rochester, was about to go into production two years ago, with Johnny Depp and John Malkovich in leading roles, when it got bogged down in studio and personality politics. It has been gathering dust ever since.

Then there are those many playwrights who talk of Jeffreys in tones of hushed reverence because of his reputation as theatre's leading expert on structure. It is Jeffreys who, in his role as literary associate at the Royal Court, has been responsible for easing many a blocked or struggling writer from first draft to final production. As Stephen Daldry once said: "What he doesn't know about playwriting isn't worth knowing."

Jeffreys believes that the secret of a good play is all in its shape. He began writing I Just Stopped By To See the Man in the same week that his son Jack, now 14 months, was conceived. He finished writing nine months later, but it was only in the final month of the process that he produced any dialogue.

"I think writing a play is a bit like improvising in music. You get to a point in the process where you know the progression but you don't know how you are going to improvise and what note you are going to play. I always save the dialogue to the very end because, if everything else is in place, that's when you really begin to have fun and start singing the blues."

webTitle: Arts: Bruce LaBruce on pornography

fields.headline: Porn free
fields.standfirst: Bruce LaBruce became notorious as the director of such films as Skin Flick and No Skin Off My Ass. So why is he so worried about pornography moving into the mainstream?
fields.trailText: Bruce LaBruce became notorious as the director of such films as Skin Flick and No Skin Off My Ass. So why is he so worried about pornography moving into the mainstream?
fields.body:
Sauntering into a newsagent's recently, I glimpsed a row of about a dozen magazines with covers graced by scantily clad women in provocative positions that signify pornography. I took a few steps back and looked up at the store's sign to check I hadn't wandered into a dirty bookstore by mistake. But no, this was a regular retail outlet selling mainstream publications. When exactly, I wondered, did the world become so smutty? I felt my cheeks flush. Could I, Bruce La Bruce, pornographer, be blushing?

I am, however, according to the title of my memoirs, "The Reluctant Pornographer", which may explain my ambivalence toward the notion of pornography taking over the free world. I don't watch porn. I don't collect it, I don't keep tabs on the latest porn stars and their exploits, I don't even incorporate it into my sex life. One reason for this may be that, like many gay men, I tend to live my life as if I were a porn star anyway, so I have no need to watch it.

Another reason may be that I encounter enough "found pornography" in ordinary, everyday images, which can be utilised as jack-off material: young black men, their clothes scissored off, being operated on in the emergency room in an episode of American documentary Trauma: Life in the ER; or, at a pinch, good, old-fashioned men's gymnastics. I find these images, along with the amateur porn self-portraits that members of the public send me over the internet, much more stimulating than the average entertainment adult video.

As someone who has made a number of sexually explicit avant-garde films in which he has performed oral sex and sodomy, I've been stuck with the epithets "porn star" and "pornographer". So shouldn't I be immune to the moral issues that are raised by such porn staples as bestiality, rape fantasies and snuff?

I'm not supposed to blush or become embarrassed or, presumably, feel any normal human emotion, especially with regard to sex, since I entered that netherworld inhabited by those who have dared to commit their sexual practices to celluloid or videotape for public consumption. In fact, nothing could be further from the truth. Although I consider myself an artist who works in pornography, I've discovered it's not a world in which you can survive for long without a normal set of human responses, and yes, a strong moral compass.

With so much emphasis lately on the "mainstreaming" of pornography and on the blurring of the line between art and porn, little attention is being paid, particularly by those who are indulging in it, to the depth and darkness of the sexual imagination and the implications of toying with this dark side. The multi-billion-dollar porn industry, which nonetheless still operates as a kind of dirty little secret, is nothing less than an adjunct of the collective unconscious, and to bring it to the surface, to "mainstream" it, may be to unleash things we're not prepared to handle.

Gender studies and postmodern courses on desire introduced academics to sex-trade workers and pornographers in the 1980s and 90s. Some academics I knew even segued into various sex trades as part of their research, often with disastrous results. One learns quickly that there is nothing noble or glamorous about getting fucked for money, either through pornography or prostitution. As I stood on the set of my first "legitimate" porn movie and found myself obliged to walk over and wipe the ass of one of the performers who was experiencing a little anal leakage, I didn't feel particularly glamorous.

Once a participant in the sex trade, you must also be prepared for the wall of moral disapprobation that you will run up against - which may come from the most surprisingly liberal sources. Factor in the other occupational hazards (STDs, emotional instability, drug abuse) and you may find yourself longing for a life a little more humdrum.

Today we're supposed to be beyond all these mundane, practical considerations. The debate raging now is about aesthetics - about how pornographic images are mediated in the mainstream, and about the lexicon that has developed to accommodate this imagery. I'm quite willing to consider the aesthetic dimension of pornography because I think that's what ultimately civilises porn and makes sense of it. The fact that 95% of the pornography that is produced today is unwatchable pap can be directly attributed to the advent of video and the concomitant decline of aesthetics.

When pornography was being produced exclusively on film in the 60s and 70s, the emphasis on camera style and narrative and the formal mediation of content - the artistic considerations - were as important as capturing the sexual moment, which today has become the singular, all-consuming focus.

The digital revolution has ushered in an era of literalism, an unimaginative unity of style and substance that reduces meaning to a set of stylistic imperatives devoid of any complex interplay. The notion that formal aspects may engage content in such a way as to produce contradiction or paradox or synthesis has been subsumed by the slavish capitulation of meaning to technology and production - to pure form.

This is probably one of the reasons that the signifiers of the mainstream entertainment industry and of the adult film industry have started to become indistinguishable. Their fixation on the means of production, instead of on the production of meaning, has resulted in a dumbed-down, sexually extreme aesthetic that has been proven to be the most commercially viable. Mainstream stars and porn stars alike are forced to conform to the same hypersexualised image, regardless of the nature of the product they're promoting. It is a bland standardisation of sexuality that has little or nothing to do with liberal or progressive attitudes towards sex.

My initial motivations for getting into pornographic representation, back when I was a punk in the 80s making underground fanzines and experimental Super 8 movies, were not only aesthetic but also political and, yes, revolutionary. I was a sexual idealist.

My work since has been as much about the intersection of race and class with homosexual representation as about filming and photographing hot, sexy boys; as much about examining sexual stereotypes and iconography as about getting off. I can't deny that there was pleasure in the text, but the text itself was always as important. Audiences today are so inured to the blandification of extreme sexual imagery that it no longer has that same kind of subversive impact. It's just meat now.

• Bruce LaBruce is in conversation with Candida Royalle as part of a one-day event on erotica and pornography at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, London SW1 on Saturday. Details: 020-7930 3647.

webTitle: Arts: A quick one  by Arthur Smith

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: by Arthur Smith
fields.body:
Here is a new phenomenon. Wherever four or more people are gathered together you can be certain that within half an hour one will say: "Have you seen The Sopranos?" This apparently innocuous inquiry will be met with orgasmic whoops of delight and cries of, "It's fantastic, isn't it?" There follow lengthy exchanges proclaiming the programme's infinite merits. At least one person is obliged to sit quietly during this outpouring, allowed only two remarks: "I haven't seen it," and "I should watch it."

The Sopranos Bore is among us. I know this because I am one. I can evangelise for many hours about the script, the acting and the big themes. Following a marathon Sopranos bore-in with Tony the Sparks, I can even do a 20-minute routine about the lighting of the show. The conversation never ends without my proposal that at some point after the end of the present series we should stage a Sopranos weekend; obviously every episode will be shown, but there will also be a quiz, fancy dress, Italian food based on meals featured in the series and a competition to see who can say "Fuck you" in the most authentic New Jersey accent.

Despite my enthusiasm for Tony and his mates, I recognise that a columnist owes it to his readers to go against the grain and offer the opposite of the accepted view. So, however tricksily self-referential the series may be, the creators of The Sopranos cannot disguise the stunning lack of originality of its basic concept. A story about Italian-American mafiosi? Haven't there been a few films with the same subject? There is also something insidious about the way we are manipulated into feeling sympathy for a man whose job involves extortion and murder. The whole thing is so relentlessly masculine - all the female characters seem to be merely satellites of the repulsive men. And let's be honest, half the time you can't work out what the hell is going on. You keep thinking, "Hang on, who's that one?"

So I hope you agree with my conclusion that The Sopranos is fantastic television and the biggest load of garbage you have ever seen.

webTitle: Arts: Children in the circus

fields.headline: The smaller they come...
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon  sees how Cirque du Soleil catches them young
fields.trailText: Peter Lennon sees how Cirque du Soleil catches them young.
fields.body:
In a tent in Bilbao, northern Spain, a group of circus people are practising acrobatics. Ten-year-old Kristina Besstchetnyi perches daintily high above the ground, one foot in the palm of her father Konstantin's extended hand.

Another father and child join them: Sacha Pestov and his five-year-old son Vova. In a moment they have borrowed another child, and adults and children form a kind of Catherine wheel in the air.

Sacha and Konstantin are members of the Banquine troupe of gymnasts, part of the international Cirque du Soleil group. The troupe's act is one of the most dramatic elements in Cirque du Soleil's show Quidam. No room here for special effects or theatrical bombast. No elaborate costumes and no nets. In the climax of the routine one man stands on top of a three-man-high "human pyramid" facing a similar group. He is then flung somersaulting across the void and lands feet first on the shoulders of the highest man opposite. Sometimes it is a woman who is flung through the air. Sometimes he or she misses. Some day it might well be Kristina.

Someone who is not in the circus business might wonder why a parent would train their child for a career where injury is part of the deal. In the past two years alone Konstantin has had surgery on his shoulder, knee and wrist. "Doesn't it worry you that you are training your daughter to do something dangerous?" I ask Konstantin. "I don't think about it," he replies. "But I have had some experience and I only train her in the safest tricks."

The question is how genuinely Kristina wants to become a circus performer. How much is due to the absence of a peer group with other ambitions, and how much to her attachment to her father? Does she feel that this is a dangerous job to be going into?

"I dunno. Well, not really."

"What do you like about the act?"

"I dunno. I just like it. It's exciting being thrown in the air."

She started training about two years ago, she says. "I want to be in the act with my dad."

"So is really because you like working with your dad?"

"Partly."

"Would you like to train with someone else and not your dad?"

"Maybe."

Would her father be happy for someone else to train her?

"Oh yes," Konstantin says. "I would be more free. It's difficult to train your own child. If you go too hard, she is ready to cry."

Kristina's expression suggests there will be a showdown later.

Konstantin says he will not rush his daughter into the career. Her education must come first. "At this age she can build up her body, but I won't train her in the real circus tricks until she has finished college. By that time she will be at a high level [of gymnastics]. I will continue at this until she is much older and smarter and then she can say, 'OK, I want to stay an artiste.' Or she can say, 'No, it's not OK.' "

Konstantin is familiar with the problem in reverse: his father was an engineer and his parents did not want him to become a circus performer. They hoped he would be a doctor. "I had a little bit of a fight over this. But I said: 'No, I will make my own decision.' "

Vova Pestov has both parents in the profession. Sacha and Natalia are from a town in the Caspian Sea area and have known each other since they were 10; they even trained in the same gymnasium. Sacha began gymnastics at six and a half. Does five-year-old Vova ever express a wish to be something else - a train driver, a policeman?

Vova sits hugging his knees, watching keenly as his parents speak for him.

"No. He wants to be an artiste," says his mother.

Aren't they worried that their child is being trained for a dangerous job?

"We will pass those bridges when we come to them," Vova's father says. But his mother is almost defiant: "Everything is dangerous. Just driving a car, you can crash."

And what about the parents? What keeps them going?

Sacha actually tried to give up his profession. His wife says that for one year he worked in a factory. "My dad gave him a job, hoping that he would stop. But after a year he could not take it any more."

Is it the applause that he craves?

"I dunno," Sacha says. "For me it is like drugs or something. You cannot live without this activity."

Only time will tell if Kristina and Vova grow up to feel the same way.

 The Banquine acrobats are appearing in the Royal Variety Performance at the Dominion Theatre, London W1 (0870 607 7401) next Tuesday, and with Cirque du Soleil's Quidam show at Battersea Power Station, London SW8, from December 15 to February 4. Details: 020-7957 4090.

Sacha and Konstantin are members of the Banquine troupe of gymnasts, part of the international Cirque du Soleil group. The troupe's act is one of the most dramatic elements in Cirque du Soleil's show Quidam. No room here for special effects or theatrical bombast. No elaborate costumes and no nets. In the climax of the routine one man stands on top of a three-man-high "human pyramid" facing a similar group. He is then flung somersaulting across the void and lands feet first on the shoulders of the highest man opposite. Sometimes it is a woman who is flung through the air. Sometimes he or she misses. Some day it might well be Kristina. Someone who is not in the circus business might wonder why a parent would train their child for a career where injury is part of the deal. In the past two years alone Konstantin has had surgery on his shoulder, knee and wrist. "Doesn't it worry you that you are training your daughter to do something dangerous?" I ask Konstantin. "I don't think about it," he replies. "But I have had some experience and I only train her in the safest tricks." The question is how genuinely Kristina wants to become a circus performer. How much is due to the absence of a peer group with other ambitions, and how much to her attachment to her father? Does she feel that this is a dangerous job to be going into? "I dunno. Well, not really." "What do you like about the act?" "I dunno. I just like it. It's exciting being thrown in the air." She started training about two years ago, she says. "I want to be in the act with my dad." "So is really because you like working with your dad?" "Partly." "Would you like to train with someone else and not your dad?" "Maybe." Would her father be happy for someone else to train her? "Oh yes," Konstantin says. "I would be more free. It's difficult to train your own child. If you go too hard, she is ready to cry." Kristina's expression suggests there will be a showdown later. Konstantin says he will not rush his daughter into the career. Her education must come first. "At this age she can build up her body, but I won't train her in the real circus tricks until she has finished college. By that time she will be at a high level [of gymnastics]. I will continue at this until she is much older and smarter and then she can say, 'OK, I want to stay an artiste.' Or she can say, 'No, it's not OK.' " Konstantin is familiar with the problem in reverse: his father was an engineer and his parents did not want him to become a circus performer. They hoped he would be a doctor. "I had a little bit of a fight over this. But I said: 'No, I will make my own decision.' " Vova Pestov has both parents in the profession. Sacha and Natalia are from a town in the Caspian Sea area and have known each other since they were 10; they even trained in the same gymnasium. Sacha began gymnastics at six and a half. Does five-year-old Vova ever express a wish to be something else - a train driver, a policeman? Vova sits hugging his knees, watching keenly as his parents speak for him. "No. He wants to be an artiste," says his mother. Aren't they worried that their child is being trained for a dangerous job? "We will pass those bridges when we come to them," Vova's father says. But his mother is almost defiant: "Everything is dangerous. Just driving a car, you can crash." And what about the parents? What keeps them going? Sacha actually tried to give up his profession. His wife says that for one year he worked in a factory. "My dad gave him a job, hoping that he would stop. But after a year he could not take it any more." Is it the applause that he craves? "I dunno," Sacha says. "For me it is like drugs or something. You cannot live without this activity." Only time will tell if Kristina and Vova grow up to feel the same way.  The Banquine acrobats are appearing in the Royal Variety Performance at the Dominion Theatre, London W1 (0870 607 7401) next Tuesday, and with Cirque du Soleil's Quidam show at Battersea Power Station, London SW8, from December 15 to February 4. Details: 020-7957 4090.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Student victim of meningitis
fields.body:
Student victim of meningitis

A 19-year-old student at the University of Wales, Swansea, died in hospital yesterday from meningitis. The woman, from Gwent, was among six cases of meningitis to have been reported in south Wales in the past three weeks.

Harpers editor dies of cancer

The editor-in-chief of Harpers & Queen, Fiona Macpherson, died from cancer yesterday aged 60, just two weeks after she had finished working on the January issue of the society magazine.

Elton John puts clothes on sale

Elton John is selling 15,000 items from his well-stocked wardrobe to raise money for his Aids foundation. The sale opens to the public at noon today in New Bond Street, London.

Calls to ease stress at work

The government was urged yesterday to help tackle excessive workloads after studies by the TUC and the Industrial Society showed increasing worries about the stress levels of workers.

Christmas test for trading law

Sainsbury's and Asda plan to circumvent the Sunday Trading Act by opening at 9.30am on Christmas Eve for "browsing". The act forbids trading before 10am - the time the supermarkets will open their tills.

Night sky spectacular

Venus and the moon will put on a spectacular display tonight in the south-western sky. The evening star will shine close to a thin crescent moon, dominating the sky as twilight deepens, but the best views will be when most of the light has gone but the moon and Venus have not started setting.

Guardian's drug issues award

The Guardian was last night named as best national newspaper for reporting drug issues in the DrugScope media awards. The judges said the award was for the Guardian's wide range of stories stretching from possible problems with Prozac use to a detailed look at drug treatment.

Pollock painting row settled

A row over a Jackson Pollock painting worth millions of pounds was settled yesterday with the original owner agreeing she had lost her right to claim it. Mercedes Matter, 87, had been given the 1943 painting by the American artist as a wedding present, and said it was stolen in 1945 or 1946. Briton Robin Judah, who bought it in London in 1965, asked the high court to declare him rightful owner. The parties agreed terms.

Straw calls for 999 unity

Police, ambulance and fire service staff should work together at shared headquarters to improve communication, social life and save money, Jack Straw, the home secretary, told the first joint emergency services conference yesterday.

World Cup star to sell medal

Former soccer star Ray Wilson is selling his 1966 World Cup winner's medal. Wilson, 65, says he is not in need himself but wants to spend the money - which could be as much as £50,000 - on his children and grandchildren.

Deadline for cab licences

London minicab firms will have to be licensed from October 22 next year, the government said yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ebola death toll rises to 149
fields.body:
Ebola death toll rises to 149

The death toll from the Ebola virus in Uganda rose to 149 yesterday, with four deaths reported in Gulu, north of Kampala, where the outbreak started nearly three months ago.

The figures were announced a day after officials said that the disease had spread to the south-west. The total number who have contracted the virus, which has no known cure, is 361.
AP, Kampala

French plan for human embryos

France's prime minister, Lionel Jospin, said yesterday legislation was being drawn up to allow research on human embryos.

Mr Jospin said the bill would permit the lifting of stem cells from embryos between seven and 12 days old and their transfer to patients suffering from incurable illnesses.
Reuters, Paris

Three arrested for bomb plot

Kuwait has arrested three more Kuwaitis linked to an alleged Islamist ring that plotted to blow up targets in the Gulf region, a newspaper said yesterday.

"They [the suspects] were arrested based on confessions made by the alleged mastermind of the suspected terrorist group," an unidentified source told the Arab Times.
Reuters, Kuwait

Russia to fiddle with Soviet tune

President Vladimir Putin wants Russians to resume singing Stalin's old anthem, but with words about a flying Russian eagle to replace the lines about the "unbreakable" Soviet Union.

A Kremlin source said Mr Putin wanted to bring back the tune with new words by the same poet who composed the original nearly 60 years ago.
Reuters, Moscow

webTitle: Obituary: Conrad Voss Bark

fields.headline: Conrad Voss Bark
fields.standfirst: Incisive broadcaster of parliament's great debates
fields.trailText: Conrad Voss Bark, who has died at the age of 87, was a household name throughout the 1950s and 1960s - not just because of his memorable surname, but because he was a daily presence on Radio Newsreel, news bulletins and, later, television news, reporting parliament as the BBC's gallery correspondent.
fields.body:
Conrad Voss Bark, who has died at the age of 87, was a household name throughout the 1950s and 1960s - not just because of his memorable surname, but because he was a daily presence on Radio Newsreel, news bulletins and, later, television news, reporting parliament as the BBC's gallery correspondent. He joined the corporation from the Times in 1951, and was one of a team of only three men; initially, there was no lobby correspondent.

Voss Bark was born near Hull, and educated at Hymer's College, Hull, and Bristol grammar school. He was a Quaker and, during the blitz, was injured while serving in a mobile ambulance unit.

He was a sub-editor by training, and, having worked on the Hampstead News and the Western Daily Press in the era of newsprint rationing, had learned how to make words count. This gift for concision, for taking complex political issues and turning them into a terse and simple narrative, served him well. He often had to broadcast live, without a teleprompter, and at short notice, from his shorthand notes.

Once, while reporting a speech by the Labour leader, Hugh Gaitskell, after leaving the Commons chamber at the last moment, Voss Bark said on air: "I'm sorry, I can't read my shorthand . . ." He recovered, and made the rest up, but thought that he would get the sack - only to discover that millions of listeners had enjoyed the human drama. The phone lines to Broadcasting House were jammed with messages of sympathy and congratulations, largely from shorthand typists.

Voss Bark had a famous ability to edit his notes as he went along, only taking down essentials; he once won fame with his colleagues by taking down the whole of a Budget speech on one side of a sheet of foolscap. His secret was knowing which bits would not interest the listener.

He covered stirring times - the end of the Churchill government, the Suez crisis, the arrival of women life peers in 1958, the era of Harold Wilson's premiership and the Commons debate on the American bombing of Hanoi.

Voss Bark always gave an impression of tightlipped unflapability, reliable and authoritative. But he could get excited, and convey that excitement - as when he came out of the gallery, after hearing Bernadette Devlin's maiden speech, to proclaim that she was "just like Joan of Arc".

He was never told by editors what to say, but often came under political pressure, particularly during the Suez crisis, when rightwing Conservatives objected to the BBC reporting the deep divisions in parliamentary and public opinion. An internal BBC inquiry cleared him of bias.

He did once fall foul of his editors. He had listened to the Conservative home secretary, RA Butler, giving an involved and equivocating set of answers about a possible inquiry into the case of a man hanged for murder. Conrad summed up his report by saying that Butler had given a "non-committal reply" - and got a rocket from his editor. Irritated by the response, he showed his script to Butler, who agreed it was fair comment because he had intended to be non-committal.

Voss Bark would enjoy telling colleagues about the hair-raising early days of BBC televison news at Alexandra Palace, to which he was sent as a sub-editor from Egton House. Early broadcasts, dubbed "the magic lantern show" by the press, consisted of stills with an off-screen voice. Conrad would be given three hours' notice that he was to read the news that night. There was no training, little rehearsal and no teleprompt. He was told not to say good evening, or smile. He was not allowed to change the script. After a few months, he escaped to the Commons press gallery.

His private passion was fly-fishing. During recesses, his fellow correspondents remember him typing detective novels (the central character was a Downing Street security man named after a fellow correspondent, David Holmes) and tying flies.

Voss Bark left the press gallery in the early 1970s and, needing to work beyond the age of 60, joined a public relations company, Charles Barker City, for whom he lobbied MPs on behalf of trawlermen, among others. He rejoined the Times as fly-fishing correspondent, a post he held for 12 years, and brought out a string of books in his 70s and 80s on the art of catching trout and salmon.

He gave courses at the Arundell Arms, Lifton, Devon, a famous fishing hotel with several trout streams; it was owned by his fourth wife, Anne Fox-Edwards. He taught the art to many celebrities, and once broke off a phone call with the words: "I'm sorry, the poet laureate's here for his lesson."

He leaves his wife, and two sons and daughters from his second marriage.

 Conrad Lyddon Voss-Bark, journalist and fly-fishing enthusiast, born March 9 1913; died November 23 2000

webTitle: The guide:  Jo Whiley to take over the Radio 1 morning slot

fields.headline: Morning glory
fields.standfirst: Jo Whiley is to take over Simon Mayo's prestigious Radio 1 morning slot when he departs for Radio 5. Her musical credibility isn't in doubt - but does she have the common touch?  Mark Morris  reports
fields.trailText: Jo Whiley is to take over Simon Mayo's prestigious Radio 1 morning slot when he departs for Radio 5. Her musical credibility isn't in doubt - but does she have the common touch? Mark Morris reports.
fields.body:
Out with the almost old, in with the newer. February will see the final part of the changing of the guard at Radio 1 with the departure of Simon Mayo after 14 years. Now well into his 40s, he has decided to follow Nicky Campbell to Five Live. Sliding into his prestigious morning slot is Jo Whiley, gaining an extra hour over her current lunchtime show.

Whiley is the embodiment of modern Radio 1. She is female, knows her music, likes a drink - Jack Daniels, by preference - and doesn't appear to be using pop radio as a pathway to primetime ITV game shows. Better yet, she's a mother, and Radio 1 has been accused in the past of having an unstated policy that raising kids and DJing were incompatible pursuits for its women presenters. And she has paid her dues: she started off booking bands (Nirvana, most famously) for The Word, then co-presented Radio 1's evening show with Steve Lamacq before advancing to daytime.

She's no Big Breakfast bit of attitude-heavy fluff, then. But in case you didn't know that, her current show is carefully signposted for hipper fanboys. It's called the Lunchtime Social, a knowing nod to legendary 90s Sunday club bash the Heavenly Social, and the weekly "tip for the top" is referred to as the Pet Sound. This is daytime radio for the post-Nick Hornby generation.

Yet the news that Whiley is being promoted won't be greeted with unqualified joy across the land. She certainly has more than her share of admirers: teen girl magazines adore her, and the Elle and Guardian readers who voted her most stylish female presenter of 1999. But there are also the doubters. It was just the little things at first: the excessive matiness, announcing that she's "well chuffed" to meet David Bowie. The odd mannerisms, notably a tendency to find novel ways of pronouncing names: Nate Dogg was rendered "Nat-ay Dogg", which isn't a crime, but was curious because being a hip-hop type he kept bigging himself up on the record. Incidental at first, this kind of thing becomes mesmerising when repeated day after day after day.

But it was the Jo Whiley Show on Channel 4 that made her a public figure. The Observer described it as an "abysmal promotional tool where stars lounge on sofas and show how inarticulate, self-obsessed and crass they can be".

Which, in itself, is not Whiley's fault. Bringing assorted pop stars together for a discussion was a loser from the start for the simple reason that pop stars tend not to be too bright. They have other attributes.

Thus Melanie B meeting Shaznay from All Saints is never going to produce intellectual fireworks along the lines of Hazlitt vs Coleridge, or even Timothy Leary vs G Gordon Liddy. And at least that had the prospect of a scrap (didn't happen). Line-ups like Björk, Jay Kay and Karl Hyde from Underworld could offer the occasional moment of madness at most. But Jo Whiley doesn't help. If Simon Le Bon isn't Tom Paulin (it works both ways of course: Paulin never got to have cocaine orgies on yachts and marry a supermodel), then Jo isn't Mark Lawson. There is a special talent for stimulating and controlling a round-table discussion, and she doesn't quite have it.

Perhaps her early days working on The Word haunt her, because she seems to have inherited Terry Christian's mastery of the prepared non-sequitur. Just as a debate seems like it might be drifting into life, Whiley breaks in with the unrelated next question on her list, killing the conversation dead. More contentious were the feet. Bare feet have mixed success in the modern era: they worked for Sandie Shaw, but not for Zola Budd. You can't miss Whiley's either, because she sits with them up on her chair, presumably inviting her guests to feel like they are in her living room, and not in a badly designed TV set.

Still, there is no doubt that she cares about the music. The TV show has had live performances from bands unlikely to get coverage elsewhere, including a blistering outing from Ralph Nader-loving agit pop crew Company Flow. And on the radio show she plays stuff you wouldn't normally expect to hear on daytime Radio 1, even after the big shake-ups of the Matthew Bannister era. But, in fairness to them, a lot of the Smashy & Nicey types genuinely loved their music too. Mike Read would stick his neck out for bands such as The Icicle Works. Dave Lee Travis, for all his all-too apparent flaws, loved soul, and John Peel has conceded that in the early 70s, Tony Blackburn was getting it right more than he was.

And these days, Radio 1 has no need to be defensive about its roster. In fact, the station is bursting with figures who have had a profound impact on what this country listens to: the likes of Danny Rampling, Pete Tong, Tim Westwood and Trevor Nelson. The most recent additions to this list are the UK garage gurus the Dreem Teem. Like Jo Whiley, the Dreem Teem make Radio 1 executives feel good about themselves. But unlike Jo Whiley, the Dreem Teem are spontaneous, funny and great radio. Now, they should have got a promotion.
